data.description: This self-guided interpretive tour takes you on a driving tour of Dunes Drive, the scenic 8-mile park road that winds through the dunes. Along the way, stops will explore what makes White Sands National Park unique as a natural wonder and a place that has drawn humans for thousands of years.

images.altText: Soaptree yucca with white flowers sits on top of a white sand dune with mountains in the background
images.caption: Welcome to White Sands National Park
images.title: Dune with Yucca

stops.significance: This self-guided interpretive tour takes you on a driving tour of Dunes Drive, the scenic 8-mile park road that winds through the dunes. Along the way, stops will explore what makes White Sands National Park unique as a natural wonder and a place that has drawn humans for thousands of years.

Gypsum sand dunes are among the rarest geologic features on earth. The conditions to create the dunefield you see before you took millions of years of creative and destructive geologic forces in exactly the right sequence
Walk in the shoes of ice age humans and megafauna by exploring the largest collection of ice age fossilized footprints on earth
The White Sands ecosystem is a diverse mixture of specialized permanent dune residents and temporary visitors who live on the periphery of the dunes

The White Sands dunefield has existed for only 7,000 years and yet in that time the life within the dunes has gone through rapid evolutionary change to create species that are found nowhere else on earth

These sands witnessed one of the most significant events in human history on the morning of July 16, 1945 when the first atomic weapon was tested 60 miles to the north. Life for every person on earth would be forever changed by this moment
Wind is often perceived as a force that brings chaos and destruction, yet here at White Sands it has sculpted the world’s largest gypsum sand dunes
White Sands is the largest gypsum dunefield on earth, but gypsum just like this is also found on Mars and could possibly reveal what the climate on the Red Planet was once like
After sunset, the darkness brings the park alive with nocturnal animal activity and gives visitors the opportunity to experience a completely different side of the park under a clear night sky
Thank you for completing the Sunset Roll self-guided audio tour. We hope this breathtaking place has become even more special at the end of your tour and visit.
stops.assetName: Final Stop on our Auto Self Guided Tour

data.title: Automobile Tour of Dunes Drive

data.description: Follow a self-guided driving tour of the battlefield accompanied by audio and video. This 17.5-mile tour has nine stops. and takes about two hours. Start by getting a park map and self-guide from the Visitor Center. The tour route follows public roads. Valley Pike (U.S. Route 11) is a heavily traveled route, while others are narrow county roads with low clearances. Buses and RVs should not attempt this tour. Stop 1 is a gravel pull-off on Valley Pike just south of Belle Grove Road.

images.altText: An 1890 illustration shows blue uniformed soldiers in a cavalry charge.
images.caption: "Battle of Cedar Creek" illustration by Kurz & Allison, c. 1890
images.title: Battle of Cedar Creek

park.fullName: Cedar Creek & Belle Grove National Historical Park
park.name: Cedar Creek & Belle Grove

stops.significance: From the pull-off, you can look on Belle Grove Plantation and the heart of the Cedar Creek Battlefield. While the U.S. Army camped across the fields and around the manor house in October 1864, the Confederates looked for ways to score a much-needed victory.

After an all-night march along the base of Massanutten Mountain, the Confederates came out of a dense fog to attack the Federal positions. The first Confederate assault struck here at 5 o'clock in the morning. The attack surprised and routed the U.S. 8th Corps.

The monument honors the 128th New York. It marks the left end of the U.S. 19th Corps, which occupied a fortified trench line on a ridge above Cedar Creek. The Confederates struck the unprotected left flank, catching the Federals by surprise.

The trails cover one area where the Confederate attackers overran part of the Federal defenses. Only the 8th Vermont's desperate stand delayed the Confederate advance. The trails include a stop at the 8th Vermont Monument.
Heavy fighting swirled around the 1797 plantation manor. Federal commanders tried to evacuate their headquarters before the Confederates overran the area at around 7 o'clock in the morning.

Fighting among the cemetery headstones, a Federal division held this prominent hill for one and a half hours. They withdrew only after a half-hour of bombardment and a third Confederate assault on the hill.

The brick house marks the farthest advance of the Confederate army. Confederate Gen. Early formed his line along Miller Lane, modern Cougill Road. This "fatal halt" gave the Federals a chance to regroup.

U.S. Gen. Sheridan returned from Winchester at around 10:30 a.m. near this spot. The sight of their general rallied the Federal troops. During the pause in the Confederate advance, Sheridan prepared a counterattack.
At four o'clock in the afternoon, the Federal counterattack struck the Confederates here. After fierce resistance, the Confederate line collapsed, setting off a full scale retreat.

data.title: Battle of Cedar Creek

data.description: The San Juan Islands Scenic Byway was created in 2009. It provides a picturesque auto-touring route that takes visitors to some of the most beautiful places in our archipelago. One unique feature of this Scenic Byway is that it begins on the Washington State Ferry, a marine highway traversing the San Juan Islands in which your car is parked and you can observe the islands and marine life of the Salish Sea. It also links our American Camp and English Camp units and visits other scenic and historic sites.

images.altText: Logo of a madrona tree on an outcropping beside a ferry. Text reads "San Juan Islands Scenic Byway"
images.caption: The San Juan Islands Scenic Byway visits natural wonders and historic treasures
images.title: Drive the San Juan Islands Scenic Byway

park.fullName: San Juan Island National Historical Park
park.name: San Juan Island

stops.significance:
This Ferry Terminal is a central node on the Scenic Byway, which begins with a ferry trip to San Juan Island from Anacortes. When you disembark the ferry, you will be in the heart of Friday Harbor, the urban center of the San Juan Islands. Until the mid-twentieth century, when the tourism industry began to grow, this was a busy fishing port, with salmon canneries right beside what is now the ferry landing. 

Today, pleasurecraft far outnumber fishing boats, but the sea remains the heart of Friday Harbor. As you wander the streets surrounding you, prepare for the sleep uphill climb that takes you into town and away from the water. In town, you will find museums, art galleries, dining, tour operators, and many other services.

This Visitor Center, completed in 2022, is the first full scale visitor center for our park. Created in collaboration with park-affiliated tribes, it examines the ongoing history of Coast Salish people, The Pig War, its aftermath, and our ecology. The Visitor Center is open from Spring until Autumn and features illuminating exhibits whose hands-on components engage visitors of all ages.

The Visitor Center is located near one of our park's main trailheads. From its parking lot, visitors can travel a level .1 mile trail to the historic Parade Grounds at American Camp, .3 moderately steep miles (with a stairway at the end) to the sheltered tidepools of Grandma's Cove, and 1 mile to South Beach, the longest stretch of publicly accessible wild coastline in the San Juan Islands.

At this trailhead, visitors have numerous options to explore our natural and human history. Five miles of trails with numerous shorter and longer options are available. Directly downhill from the trailhead, you can walk down to Old Town Lagoon. This area was once the site of the first Euro-American village on San Juan Island, where more than a hundred people built a small town shortly after the American military occupied the island. 

Hikers can climb to the top of Mount Finlayson, the highest point on the south side of San Juan Island, where you can see the North Cascades, Mount Baker, the Olympic Mountains, and on a clear day all the way to Mount Rainier 150 miles away! 

This trail network also traverses the oldest surviving forest on the island, unique intertidal lagoons, and Pacific Northwest Coastal Prairies. Along the way, you may see Bald Eagles, Red Foxes, and maritime species, such as Orcas and river otters.

Navigational lights have been aiding seafarers from this spot since 1888, but the present-day lighthouse was not built until 1935. Cattle Point, which takes its name from a shipwrecked boat that marooned its cargo of cows here in the 1850s, has long been a tricky area to navigate due to the changing tides and currents, nearby rocky islands, and shoals which threaten boats which head through Cattle Pass. 

Today, the Cattle Point Lighthouse is managed by the Bureau of Land Management's San Juan Islands National Monument. Visitors to the Lighthouse can climb down to excellent tidepools below the lighthouse, walk across prairies filled with wildflowers and foxes, and watch eagles hunt in the nearby waters

At the center of this popular state park lies the Lime Kiln Point Lighthouse,which is regarded as the last major lighthouse in the state of Washington. The waters surrounding it are regarded as the best place for seeing whales in the San Juan Islands, especially the endangered Southern Resident Killer Whale.

The lime producing industry, which gave this state park its name was once the major island on this island. Lime miners cut down large amounts of old growth trees to power massive furnaces that chemically transformed mineral rich rocks into useful industrial chemicals. Lime from this island was transported as far away from Hawaii and employed hundreds of islanders until the 1950s.

San Juan County Park is a popular space for recreation and camping on the island. Its tranquil waters provide an excellent kayak launch spot, while the bluff where the campground is located provides a perfect vantage point to watch for marine mammals such as killer whales or just enjoy a scenic picnic.

The Royal Marines landed at English Camp in March of 1860, where they established a garrison that would last for twelve years. Since time immemorial, this has been a Coast Salish homeland, where large longhouses provided year-round homes for numerous native people. The vast marine resources of this area sustained the tribes who stewarded clam gardens and operated nearby reef net fishery sites.

The English were also attracted to the area for its still waters, freshwater resources, and relative flat lands. English Camp was a tranquil outpost of the British Empire with relatively stable personnel for the dozen years of its existence.

After San Juan Island became American territory in 1872, homesteaders moved into English Camp which they transformed into orchards, sheepfolds, and light industrial workshops. The Crook Family, which homesteaded here lobbied for the creation of our park and their preservation efforts can be seen on the landscape to this day.

The first lime producers on San Juan Island were the Royal Marines stationed at English Camp, who mined and processed lime at Roche Harbor during the Joint Occupation of San Juan Island (1860-1872). This lime was used to construct English camp itself, serving as a vital ingredient in the whitewash, mortar, and paint used to build English Camp. Commercial operators, including Lyman Cutlar, the settler whose violence towards a Hudson’s Bay Company pig sparked The Pig War, began limited commercial lime production in 1860. The San Juan Islands soon became the largest site of lime production in Washington State, a title it would retain into the 1920s.

In the 1950s, with the lime industry unprofitable, this former industrial center was converted into one of the island's largest resorts. Today, visitors can tour historic structures, hike an extensive trail network, and visit the nearby Sculpture Park.

data.description: The modern farmworker movement's roots are in Delano, a small town in central California near Bakersfield. Along this driving tour, visit sites that are significant to the movement, including the Forty Acres property, the residences of the movement's leaders, and the gravesites of Larry Itliong and Richard Chavez.

images.altText: A long line of people walk along a road past a sign for the city limits of Delano, California. Some
images.caption: National Farm Workers Association members and supporters march to support of the Delano Grape Strike
images.title: Delano Grape Strike march, 1966

stops.significance:
After the Delano Grape Strike began in 1965 the Filipino Community Hall was the de facto headquarters for the strike because the mostly Filipino Agricultural Workers Organizing Committee had started the strike and Cesar Chavez's National Farm Workers Association (NFWA) had hardly any infrastructure. The NWFA headquarters had only recently moved out of Cesar's house (see the "First UFW Headquarters" stop on the tour).

Forty Acres became the hub of union activity and organizing for the last half of the strike, and was the first opportunity for Cesar to bring his vision of a union to reality. Over the years, many of the farmworker movement’s most historic events took place here.

data.description: The Black Heritage Trail® showcases residences and community buildings associated with a Black community that thrived on, and near, the north slope of Beacon Hill before, during, and after the American Civil War. Throughout that time, this community struggled and organized for equal rights and access to equal education. Community members championed the movement to abolish slavery and even housed freedom seekers on their journey along the Underground Railroad.

images.altText: Alley with a 3-story red brick building on the left that has tall windows and homes on the right.
images.caption: Smith Court is home to three stops on the Black Heritage Trail®.
images.title: Black Heritage Trail® Self-Guided Tour

park.fullName: Boston African American National Historic Site
park.name: Boston African American

stops.significance: The Robert Gould Shaw and Massachusetts 54th Regiment Memorial commemorates one of the first African American regiments of the Civil War. Following his Emancipation Proclamation in 1863, President Lincoln called for the raising of Black regiments. Massachusetts Governor John Andrew soon created the Massachusetts 54th Volunteer Infantry and chose Robert Gould Shaw, the son of prominent abolitionists, to serve as its colonel. Through their heroic, yet tragic, assault on Fort Wagner, South Carolina on July 18, 1863, in which Shaw and many of his men died, the 54th helped erode Northern public opposition to the use of Black soldiers and inspired the enlistment of more than 180,000 Black men into the U.S. forces. To commemorate this brave Black regiment, Bostonians chose Augustus St. Gaudens to create this high relief bronze monument, which sits prominently on Beacon St. across from the Massachusetts State House. Unveiled in 1897, this monument depicts the 54th as they marched down Beacon St. off to war in 1863.
stops.assetName: Robert Gould Shaw and Massachusetts 54th Regiment Memorial

stops.significance:
George Middleton and Louis Glapion began constructing this two-family residence at 5 Pinckney Street in 1786. Finished a year later, this building is believed to be the oldest standing home on Beacon Hill. 
Louis Glapion worked as a hairdresser and may have been from the French West Indies. During the Revolution, George Middleton led a Black militia company called the Bucks of America. While little evidence of this group has survived, they likely guarded the property of Boston merchants during the Revolution. A horse breaker and livery man by profession, Middleton also served in several Black community organizations. He became the third Grand Master of the African Lodge, later known as the Prince Hall Masons. Middleton and others also organized the African Society, a charitable organization dedicated to community service, uplift, and education. As a community leader, George Middleton helped build some of the early institutions and organizations in the long history of Black activism on Beacon Hill.

Built in 1824, this building originally served as the Boston English High School. It became the Phillips Grammar School in 1844, named after Boston’s first mayor, John Phillips. Until 1855, the Phillips School, like most public schools in the city, only educated White students. Black students attended segregated schools nearby, including one in the basement of the African Meeting House and then later at the Abiel Smith School. Equal School Rights activists such as William Cooper Nell, Lewis Hayden, Benjamin Roberts, and others led protests and petition drives that ultimately compelled the state legislature outlaw segregated schools in Massachusetts in 1855. Following this landmark victory, the Phillips School become one of the first public schools in Boston with an interracial student body.

John J. Smith, a barber, community activist, and state legislator, lived in this home from 1878 to 1893. Born free in Richmond, Virginia, Smith moved to Boston in the 1840s. He became a leading community activist and ran a barbershop that became a center for abolitionist activity. Smith played a crucial role in helping Shadrach Minkins, a freedom seeker arrested in Boston under the provisions of the 1850 Fugitive Slave Law. In a daring rescue, Black Bostonians freed Minkins from the courthouse where the slave catchers held him and helped him make his way to freedom in Canada. Smith and his wife, Georgiana, also participated in the equal school rights movements of the 1850s. Their daughter, Elizabeth, became the first person of African descent to teach in an integrated public school in Boston. During the Civil War, Smith recruited for the Black Massachusetts regiments and the 5th Calvary. He later served in the Massachusetts House of Representatives for three terms, as well as on the Boston Common Council.

Built in 1807, this building originally housed the Third Baptist Church. In April 1836, member Timothy Gilbert tested the church’s racial segregation policy by inviting several African Americans to join him in his pew. The church immediately expelled Gilbert for this violation. He soon set out with several other members to form the First Free Baptist Church, which became officially recognized in 1839. In 1876, the First African Methodist Episcopal congregation purchased the Charles Street Meeting House. This prompted one historian to note while African Americans once sat in one section of the church, "now they own the building." The Meeting House also served as a forum and gathering place for activists. For example, in 1895 Josephine St. Pierre Ruffin and other Black clubwomen formed the National Federation of Afro-American women, a precursor to the National Association of Colored Women. The AME congregation held services in this location until 1939, becoming the last Black institution to leave Beacon Hill.

The Lewis and Harriet Hayden House served as the preeminent Underground Railroad safe house in Boston during the 1850s. In the 1840s, the Haydens escaped slavery in Kentucky and eventually settled here. They lived in this house by 1850, operated it as a boardinghouse, and turned it into one of the most documented safe houses in the area. The Haydens notably assisted in high-profile Fugitive Slave Law cases, helping William and Ellen Craft as well as Shadrach Minkins on their journeys to freedom. In addition to their Underground Railroad work, Lewis and Harriet played other prominent roles in the community. Lewis served as Grand Master of the Prince Hall Masons, presided over numerous community meetings, and participated in the Equal Schools movement. During the Civil War, he recruited Black soldiers for the Massachusetts regiments. Following the War, Lewis Hayden served as one of the first Black members of the state legislature and, along with Harriet, lent his support in the fight for women’s suffrage.

Clothes dealer and community activist John P. Coburn and his family lived at this home beginning in 1844. In addition to his clothing shop, limited evidence suggests that Coburn may have ran a gaming house for wealthy Bostonians in his house. Coburn served as the treasurer of the New England Freedom Association, an organization dedicated to assisting freedom seekers who escaped slavery and came to Boston on the Underground Railroad. In 1851, authorities arrested, though later acquitted, Coburn for his alleged role in aiding in the courthouse rescue of Shadrach Minkins. Along with other community leaders in the 1850s, Coburn founded the Massasoit Guards, an unsanctioned Black militia. Militia groups such the Massasoit Guards can be considered precursors to the Black Civil War regiments, including the famous 54th Massachusetts. Coburn died in 1873 and his home passed to his son Wendell, whose widow, Mary, lived in the house until the turn of the twentieth century.

As home to the African Meeting House and the Abiel Smith School, Smith Court served as a vital center of African American life and culture for much of the nineteenth and earlier twentieth century in Boston. The residences along Smith Court also provide a valuable window into the lives of the African Americans who called this neighborhood home. Residents of 3 Smith Court, James Scott and William Cooper Nell, both sheltered freedom seekers in the 1850s. In 1849, George Washington purchased 5 Smith Court. He served as deacon of the First Independent Baptist Church at the African Meeting House. Built in 1799, 7A Smith Court is the only surviving example of the early homes that lined Holmes Alley. African American chimneysweep and clothing dealer Joseph Scarlett owned 7 Smith Court, 7A Smith Court, and 2 Smith Court. Living in 2 Smith Court, Scarlett rented out the other properties. By the time of his death in 1898, Scarlett owned 15 different properties in Boston, Cambridge, and Charlestown.

The Abiel Smith School opened in 1835 and served as the segregated public school for Black children in Boston for twenty years. Prior to this, Black students attended school at the African School on the ground floor of the African Meeting House. Overcrowded and underfunded, the Smith School became the focal point in the Black community’s ongoing struggle for Equal School Rights in the 1840s and 1850s. William Cooper Nell led the charge against the segregated Smith School, facing opposition from Whites and well as from some in his own community. Over the course of more than 15 years, through a series of local petitions, protests, court cases, and ultimately a state-wide petition, Nell and others successfully convinced the legislature to outlaw public school segregation in 1855. Today, the Smith School houses the Museum Store and exhibition galleries of the Museum of African American History.

Built in 1806, the Meeting House stands as the oldest surviving Black church structure in the nation. It first served as the home for the First African Baptist Church. It also housed the African School for a number of years before the Smith School opened next door, and it hosted numerous community lectures, celebrations, and adult education classes. The Meeting House also served as a gathering space for social activism. Maria Stewart, William Cooper Nell, Lewis Hayden, John Smith, John Coburn, and others used its platform to fight for equal school rights, the end of slavery, and for civil rights. During the Civil War, the Meeting House became a recruitment center for the MA 54th Regiment. A Black church and community center until the end of the 1800s, it became a synagogue in 1904. In 1972, the Meeting House was purchased by the Museum of African American History, who continues to own and operate it today.

data.description: Follow a journey into Glacier Bay, with locations and descriptions hand-picked by Glacier Bay Park Rangers.

images.altText: A tour boat is dwarfed by steep rugged icy mountains, while a glacier pours into water, overcast day
images.caption: See magnificent views of a bay that was covered in ice less than 150 years ago.
images.title: Tour Boat in Johns Hopkins Inlet

stops.significance: Icy Strait is the body of water that runs east to west between the Gulf of Alaska and the Inside Passage. The entrance to Glacier Bay opens north from Icy Strait.
Bartlett Cove is the geographic headquarters for Glacier Bay National Park and Preserve.
The Huna Tribal House memorializes the clan houses that once lined the shores of present day Bartlett Cove, now the site of National Park Service headquarters in Glacier Bay.
The Beardslee Islands are a grouping of islands just to the north of Bartlett Cove and the Gustavus mainland.

Welcome to Glacier Bay! Sitakaday Narrows is the entrance to the Bay. With strong currents passing through here twice a day with the tides, this area is a productive place to find wildlife such as seabirds, sea otters, and humpback whales.
South Marble Island is a wildlife hotspot! Steller Sea Lions and many species of seabirds await you here. Even humpback whales come to the Marble Islands to feed near their shores.
Known as Glacier Bay's East Arm, Muir Inlet is a lesser-traveled arm of Glacier Bay. Named for the once tremendous Muir Glacier, that glacier now sits aground at the end of the long inlet.

As you motor up Glacier Bay, keep an eye on the shorelines for wildlife activity. One charismatic member of Alaska's wildlife family is the brown bear! Brown bears in Glacier Bay are often seen flipping rocks in the intertidal zone to search for food.

The sea otter. Most likely you've already seen several of this marine mammal floating in the waters of Glacier Bay. Sea otters are found in bays and protected inlets throughout the park, such as Hugh Miller Inlet.
Gloomy knob is a geologic masterpiece, and a great place to spot mountain goats!

Now that you are nearing the upper reaches of Glacier Bay, evidence of glaciers should start becoming more apparent. What makes a glacier? There are many ingredients to create these rivers of ice, click explore to learn more.
stops.assetName: Glacier Recipe: What Makes a Glacier in the Bay?

stops.significance: Russell Island sits in the intersection of several glacial fjords. From here, Lamplugh, Reid, Johns Hopkins, Margerie, and Grand Pacific Glaciers are a short distance away.
Tarr Inlet marks the entrance to the body of water which holds Margerie and Grand Pacific Glaciers. Keep an eye out for floating icebergs!
Glaciers are moving rivers of ice, so what happens when that ice meets the sea? Action!
stops.assetName: What is Calving? In Glacier Bay

stops.significance: A crown jewel of Glacier Bay, Margerie Glacier drops ice into the bay with regularity. Soak in the view, and keep your ears open too!

The final stop in the tour, Grand Pacific Glacier once filled the entirety of Glacier Bay no more than 200 years ago. Today, it is covered in rock and glacial till, and extends many miles into a vast icefield.

A colony of black-legged kittiwakes has occasionally chosen to nest just south of Margerie Glacier's face. When the glacier calves, fish and other aquatic life can be stunned from the shockwave, leaving easy pickings for the kittiwakes.
As you travel through Glacier Bay, know that thousands of years of glaciation formed the landscape around you.
stops.assetName: Glacial Landscape Features in Glacier Bay

stops.significance: Mount Cooper is a picturesque mountain rising high above Lamplugh Glacier, at the point between Lamplugh and Johns Hopkins Inlet. Even if you can't see its summit on a cloudy day, look for hanging alpine glaciers on its steep slopes.

Harbor seals have raise their pups in narrow Johns Hopkins Inlet each year in the early summer. Harbor seals are one of just a few animals on earth that rely heavily upon floating icebergs to rear their pups on.
The entryway to Johns Hopkins Inlet, Jaw Point offers a stunning view of Johns Hopkins Glacier as you round the point.
This rock-streaked tidewater glacier has undergone many changes over the years. Stunning mountains surround you in Johns Hopkins Inlet, many with remnant alpine glaciers high in the mountain peaks.
As you view floating ice and the mighty rivers of ice that reach down from Glacier Bay's mountainsides, a common question might be, why is the ice a vivid blue color? Read on to find out.
stops.assetName: Why is the Ice Blue? In Glacier Bay

stops.significance: Like its neighbor Reid, Lamplugh Glacier slopes down from the Brady Icefield before reaching Glacier Bay.
This inlet is home to Reid Glacier, a gently sloping glacier which descends from the massive Brady Icefield.

Plant succession is a critical element of Glacier Bay's scientific story. As glaciers recede and melt, what happens to this newly exposed land? And how fast will vegetation retake the new ground? Scientists and ecologists have looked to answer these questions since the park's de-glaciation.

Stumps as old as 9,000 years still reside in Glacier Bay. These stumps have survived multiple periods of glaciation, and are visible as you pass through Whidbey Passage. Unassuming on the shore, look for broken stumps sitting along the rocky beach.
The mighty humpback whale. Endangered humpback whales have been studied at Glacier Bay for decades, leading to one of the longest-running whale monitoring programs for this species.

data.title: Boat through Glacier Bay!

data.description: Come take a hike along the Boca Trail, a 2 mile loop at the base of Capulin Volcano! Most of the lava that erupted from Capulin Volcano erupted from vents in the boca on the western side of the cinder cone. Lava features including levees, lava lakes, and collapsed lava tubes can be seen along this trail.

The accessible Bodie Island Nature Trail provides some of the best views of the Bodie Island Lighthouse while allowing you to explore the unique ecosystem of the tidal marshes.
Nature trail that provides great views of the rich soundside ecosystem.
A place to access the beaches of Cape Hatteras National Seashore.  Lifeguards provided in the summer months.

data.description: Welcome to Georges Island! This self-guided audio tour will help acquaint you with the history and function of the Island and Fort Warren. This audio tour is presented by the Boston Harbor Islands National and State Park partnership, including the National Park Service, the Massachusetts Department of Conservation & Recreation, and Boston Harbor Now.

images.altText: Black sign that says "Welcome to Georges Island" logos for NPS, BHI, and BHN next to it.
images.caption: Georges Island is home to the Civil War era Fort Warren
images.title: Georges Island

park.fullName: Boston Harbor Islands National Recreation Area
park.name: Boston Harbor Islands

stops.significance:
Welcome to Georges Island, one of the 34 islands and peninsulas in Boston Harbor Islands National and State Park. Georges Island is owned and operated by the Massachusetts Department of Conservation and Recreation. Located seven miles from downtown Boston, this 39-acre island is home to Fort Warren, a National Historic Landmark. 

Georges Island offers a Visitors Center, restrooms, snack bar, and picnic tables. Check our website www.bostonharborislands.org or with staff on island for seasonal program offerings. You can also learn more on your own by following this 50-minute self-guided tour.

As you make your way around the fort, look for the Audio Tour logo on signs to indicate each stop.

Built around 1825, the first wharf on Georges Island supported workers in the construction of a seawall and leveling the island for the fort to be built. By the 1890s, the army replaced an expanded wooden pier with a rail system to move submarine mines and their accompanying materials on and off the dock. 

Built in 1906, the Visitor Center originally served as a storehouse for the submarine mines that played a critical role in the defense of Boston Harbor. Mines were placed in the harbor at predetermined points and depths, and connected to the fort via an electrical cable system. During both World Wars, vigilant operators inside the fort stood ready to detonate the mines in the event of an attack by German forces.

The guardhouse nearby operated as the security office for the fort and served as temporary confinement for soldiers in violation of their duty. Additionally, soldiers on guard duty covered fixed posts or patrolled a route from here.

The coverface served as an initial line of defense and shielded the granite walls of Fort Warren from direct fire by enemy cannon from either a broad sided ship or an invaded nearby island. The crescent-shaped stone structure within it is known as the Demi-Lune. The Demi-Lune offered defending soldiers a covered position to fire at attacking enemy foot soldiers approaching from the beach. The road to the left was constructed later.

The largest entrance and most heavily defended approach to Fort Warren was the main sallyport. The original design included a drawbridge and portcullis, and interior slope. The current bridge design dates from World War II. The narrow windows on either side allowed  defending soldiers to fire onto attackers. The protruding iron rods fastening the inner yellow oak doors deterred attempts at breaking through with an axe.

Bastion C remains structurally unchanged from its first use. The rooms inside have been used 
throughout the years for food storage, preparation, and dining. The fort’s first bakery is to the left and retains the original ovens and remained in operation from the 1860s until about 1900 when new mess halls, kitchens, and barracks were built. By World War II, the bakery became the Non-Commissioned Officer’s Club. 

Inside the right side of Bastion C is an L-shaped powder magazine. This space is sheathed in cedar wood to help regulate the moisture and temperature of the room, in order to protect against the possibility of a friction spark and accidental explosion of the gunpowder.

The casemates of Front II were designed for housing the lower ranked enlisted soldier. Sleeping accommodations ranged from triple-decked, double platformed bunks to single metal bedsteads. These casemate rooms housed enlisted soldiers and prisoners at various times, numbering anywhere from 9 to 80 individuals at one time.

The terreplein supported the main line of mostly Rodman cannon. These smooth bore cannons fired a 10-inch diameter iron ball. In the 1880s, grooved rifled sleeves were inserted in the bore, increasing its distance and accuracy. The terreplein can be accessed at the top of the stairway. 

In the once open courtyard of Bastion B sits Battery Jack Adams. Installed in 1899, Adams held one 10-inch disappearing rifle. This rifle was loaded while sheltered from enemy fire behind a concrete wall. A counterweight raised the gun to firing position, and after firing the recoil pushed the barrel of the gun backward and down ready for reloading.

The casemates in these areas were originally divided in half. The outer half overlooked the Nantasket Roads shipping channel with two cannon embrasures each. The parade ground facing squad rooms housed 6-30 enlisted men depending on rank.

As the leading defensive side of the fort, two major structural developments took place largely due to artillery needs. Bastion A’s courtyard was covered in the 1870s, allowing for a total of five 15-inch Rodman cannons on the terreplein with new large indoor spaces below. The second development was the completion of Battery Stevenson in 1902 on the terreplein of Front I. Stevenson’s two 12-inch disappearing rifles had a range of 9 miles.

For a view of Boston Light and the top of Battery Stevenson, head up the stairway.

As the center of Fort Warren, the roughly six-acre open field parade ground hosted various activities. Soldiers regularly formed for troop drill, assembly, and inspection. Beyond training and official functions, calisthenics and sports such as boxing, kickball, football, and baseball happened here.

Situated on the parade ground is the 1860s main black powder storage magazine. Its isolated location and stone courtyard wall favored safety over convenient access to guns. Most of the fort’s black powder was stored in 100 pound wooden kegs. Given the chance of sparks, swords, pistols, and muskets/rifles were stored in an ordnance storeroom.

Responsible for the fort and prison from 1861 to 1864, Colonel Justin Dimick resided in quarters here with his wife and two of his daughters. Union soldiers and Confederate prisoners regarded Dimick as a compassionate and considerate leader. As a testament to Dimick's character, some Confederate prisoners provided his son, a Union officer, a letter to carry with him asking for humane treatment in the event he was captured by Confederate forces. 
The rooms on the left served as the hospital from the time of the Civil War until 1906. Of the more than 2000 Confederate soldiers imprisoned at Fort Warren, 13 died after suffering from tuberculosis, measles, typhoid fever, and other illnesses. When a new hospital was built outside the fort, this area became a library. By the 1940s, the room functioned as a post exchange, selling a variety of items to soldiers stationed at Fort Warren.

data.title: Boston Harbor Islands National and State Park: Georges Island Tour

data.description: Follow this 4-mile long trail through Rock Creek Park to the iconic Boulder Bridge and back to the Rock Creek Nature Center

images.altText: A bridge covered in rocks spans a creek
images.caption: Boulder Bridge
images.title: Boulder Bridge

stops.significance: Begin your hike at the Rock Creek Park Nature Center where you can get a park map to take with you on your hike. You can also learn about the flora and fauna you might see while hiking.

The Rock Creek Horse center is a concession within Rock Creek Park. Please do not enter the stables or stand on the fences. Many of the horses are not owned by the Horse Center and cannot be pet or fed.
The White Horse Trail meanders through the park. This is a common access and trail head due to the proximity to the Horse Center.
Picnic Grove #22 is indicative of many of the smaller picnic areas in Rock Creek Park. There is a pull out for a few cars, and an historic stone chimney to grill at.
This trail junction is frequently used by hikers and equestrians. The Black Horse Trail parallels Beach Drive.
stops.assetName: Trailhead: Black Horse Trail at Beach Drive

stops.significance: Heading downstream, listen to the fast-flowing water—i.e., rapids. This is the fall zone, a geologic transition zone where the Piedmont Plateau (harder rock) meets the Atlantic Coastal Plain (softer, sedimentary rock).

Boulder Bridge is an example of "parkitecture." The birth of national parks in the late 19th centry brought with it a unique and new style known as National Park Service (NPS) Rustic or, as it's more affectionately known by NPS staff, 'Parkitecture.'

Infused with native materials, natural whole logs, and built by hand (or meant to look as if it was), 'Parkitecture' defines the National Park Service experience in the collective memories of visitors just as much as our natural landscapes. In part, this is because the buildings were designed with the purpose of blending into landscapes instead of imposing upon them.
Blagden Mill operated on Rock Creek for over 100-years in the 18th and 19th Centuries. The ruins of the mill were removed in the late 1890s to make way for Beach Drive.
The Western Ridge Trail will return you to the Nature Center. Follow the Green pain blazes.
stops.assetName: Trailhead: Western Ridge Trail at Broadbranch Road NW

stops.significance: Equitation field (between picnic groves 25 & 26) has been a part of the park landscape for over 100 years and is a turn out that can be used by equestrians in the park.

data.title: Boulder Bridge Loop Hike

data.description: Join us in an audio exploration of what over 100,000 people commemorated on June 17, 1843, the memory of some of the men who fought at Bunker Hill on June 17, 1775, and why the monument and men continue to have relevance today.

images.altText: A large crowd surround the Bunker Hill Monument while listening to an orator on a stage platform.
images.caption: This lithograph depicts the ceremonies of June 17, 1843, the dedication of the Bunker Hill Monument.
images.title: View of Bunker Hill Monument June 1843

stops.significance: On June 17, 1843, over 100,000 people crowded on this hill to witness the dedication of this immense granite monument. Nothing like it had ever been realized in the history of the young nation. It was a fitting tribute, the builders felt, to those who fought on this ground 68 years earlier on June 17, 1775.

Peter Brown first arrived here on Breed’s Hill in the middle of the night of June 16, 1775. With orders to dig a fortification in Charlestown, his unit quietly marched from the vicinity of Harvard College, in Cambridge, to this location. After hours of digging in the dark, the sun slowly rose to expose their position in the middle of an open field. British cannon soon opened fire on Brown and his comrades.
Awaiting the inevitable arrival of attacking British soldiers, Brown looked back toward Cambridge in hope of reinforcements.

When British cannon roared at dawn on June 17, 1775, the entire countryside awoke. New England militia units received confused information and conflicting orders. Col. John Nixon’s unit ultimately decided to assist their comrades here on this hill, entering the redoubt. Among them marched Peter Salem.
Enslaved at birth and a native of Framingham, Massachusetts, Peter Salem fought here alongside his neighbors and former enslavers. Yet here he lay, armed, in defense of this community as an unknown fate marched closer.

Lieutenant John Waller set sail with his unit in March 1775, to respond to the growing political crisis in Boston. On the morning of June 17, 1775, he roused his men. They assembled on the Boston waterfront, waiting for boats to ferry them to Charlestown.
When they arrived on shore, regular British Army units were already engaged with the New England militia in heavy fighting. Focused on climbing this hill, Waller struggled to keep his men together under heavy fire. Against all odds, they reached the redoubt’s walls and charged over the top.

When British forces breached the redoubt that stood on this hill, desperate and bloody carnage ensued. Peter Brown, no longer able to hold his ground, fled for his life. Peter Salem kept firing at British soldiers and officers alike in the retreat.
John Waller and his fellow British marines and soldiers pursued, but not without continued casualties. His commander, Maj. John Pitcairn, fell with four bullet wounds to his body. According to some accounts, Peter Salem landed one of those ultimately fatal shots before fleeing for his own life.
stops.assetName: The Retreat and the Pursuit Wayside

stops.significance:
Peter Brown, Peter Salem, and John Waller all survived the battle. Over a thousand others, however, died or suffered wounds. After intersecting in the midst of a battle on this hill, each man followed their own separate paths. None of these three ever saw fame or fortune for their fighting here.
Collectively, though, their actions on this hill became significant to others long after the battle. The acts of defending liberty, defying enslavement, and sustaining law and order have spoken to later generations in many lasting ways.

As the scars of war slowly disappeared into the landscape of Charlestown, a renewed interest in the battle arose by the 1820s. Many prominent men with deep ties to New England believed that they were the inheritors of a great national destiny—a destiny that began at the Battle of Bunker Hill. With this belief, the Bunker Hill Monument Association formed in 1823 with the goal to construct a “permanent monument, which shall carry down to remote ages a testimony, consecrated by the patriotism of the present generation, to the heroic virtue and courage of the men who began and achieved the independence of their country.”
Because of struggles to fund such an ambitious project, it took 20 years to finally realize the vision.
But those who dedicated the monument in 1843 echoed one remembrance of the past and its meaning into the future. There were many others, and there continue to be more.
What memory does the monument echo to you?
What does it hold for the future?

data.title: Bunker Hill Monument: Remembering Revolution

While on this trail visitors can view the remnants of the CCC settlement while experiencing the biodiversity of Mississippi forest habits.

data.description: The Calumet and Hecla copper mines merged in 1866 and grew into some of the most elaborate and extensive mines in the world. They sparked the creation of villages like Calumet and Laurium, housing locations like Hecla, Yellow Jacket, and dozens more. At their heart was the Calumet Conglomerate, a copper-bearing rock formation angled from southwest to northeast along Mine Street. Explore the remains of this industrial giant amid the communities it inspired on this walking tour along sidewalks and paths.

images.altText: Black and white image with men posing with tools in front of a stone two story building.
images.caption: C&H carpenters pose in front of the public library.
images.credit: MTU Archives Photo - Calumet & Hecla Carpenters (Image#: MTU Neg 00244)
images.title: C&H Carpenters

stops.significance: A long tradition of Indigenous mining coupled with settler discoveries of float copper led the United States to seek the 1842 Treaty of LaPointe. With this treaty, lands traditionally inhabited by American Indians including those from Keweenaw Bay Indian Community, Lac Vieux Desert, and others could be mined by newcomers. Keweenaw National Historical Park is located on these ceded lands.

Paul Wayland Bartlett, a student of Rodin, was commissioned by Alexander Agassiz’s son Rudolphe to create this statue before World War I. Due to metal shortages, his plans were scrapped until after the war. Agassiz is posed in a metallic rendition of a C&H boardroom chair. Please do not climb on the statue or its pediment.

With a “storied” past and a mosaic of architectural features including local stone, the library cemented C&H’s reputation as a force for education in the community. Building elaborately with stone was a way to demonstrate the company’s stability and permanence.
In another show of investment, C&H built this brick warehouse. When it proved short on space for the growing company, another warehouse was built across the street.

How’s your commute? As the mines became deeper, ladders became longer and more dangerous. One solution was to build a man-engine, which was a lot safer in practice; some thought because it was always moving and kept the underground workers on their toes!

When the snow got too deep for this plow, men would have to shovel the tracks, which riddled this area. A wye from where the Russell Snowplow is stationary once entered Warehouse No. 2 across the street.
Rather than relying on foundries in far-away cities, Calumet & Hecla established their own. Here, workers carefully designed and crafted patterns for original and replacement parts of iron and brass.

The gray stone of this structure contrasts with the red sandstone trim; both types of rock are from the Keweenaw area, and were used in many buildings. They gray (sometimes with a hint of red, blue, or green) is basalt, “poor” rock from the mines without much copper. The red sandstone is from the Jacobsville formation, a Global Heritage stone which was quarried nearby and shipped for use in buildings around the region and nation.

Sand would hold the shape of a casting pattern, allowing it to be filled with molten metal. Its storage was necessary for foundry operations, and proximity to the railroad tracks was convenient for transportation.

When the mines were just beginning their Hecla & Torch Lake Railroad, they needed a place to service the engines and trucks. They did this in a stone shop in a wooded area, now falling into ruin. Please respect private property.
Close to the surface of the mines they supervised, the mine captain on duty at a nearby shaft would keep an office in this small building.

Gandy dancers had no need for an office; their work was along the rails. Still, their tools needed storage when not in use. This early stone building is another example of a very permanent structure built by C&H when another mine may have built a wooden shed.
Calumet & Hecla built, supplied, and staffed fire stations at Hecla, Calumet, Hubbell, and others. This sole remaining example has a more recent one-story garage bay addition.
In spite of its size, the Machine Shop would seem ant-like beside the underground world which crouched at its feet.
The roundhouse served to store and service the engines of the Hecla & Torch Lake Railroad; once, a turntable filled a rounded gap between its bays; today, that gap has been filled in.

The company that bathes together, stays together? Whether the bathhouse was provided purely for welfare or to spare the expense of individually retrofitting company houses, it was a popular amenity used extensively by miners and their families. Here, like at the former C&H library, we see more refined use of now-familiar local materials.

Calumet provided more than copper munitions to the front lines of America’s conflicts; its soldiers participated in every war from the time the mines were founded, and C&H sponsored its own “Light Guard” which became a part of the Michigan National Guard.

data.title: Calumet & Hecla Industrial Core: "The Footprints of a Giant" Walking Tour #1

data.title: Carl Sandburg Home Home Tour

data.description: Carl Sandburg and his family moved to the property known as "Connemara" in 1945. This grounds tour will help you explore the landscape and structures as the Sandburg family and previous residents used them. As you explore the buildings and grounds you will get a sense of the history of this place, its productivity, and the creativity it has inspired.

images.altText: Illustrated map of grounds with building names
images.caption: Illustrated map of grounds with building names.
images.title: Tour Map

park.fullName: Carl Sandburg Home National Historic Site
park.name: Carl Sandburg Home

stops.significance: The Sandburg Home is the starting place for the tour.

From 1838 until 1945 this was the kitchen for residents of Connemara.  The Sandburg's modernized the main house with an interior kitchen and converted this building into a three-car garage.  Today the interior is used for special events and programs.

Constructed in the 1840's the first owner of this property, Christopher Memminger, housed enslaved persons in this building while he lived here in the summers.  Living near the main house they likely helped with domestic tasks of cooking and cleaning, however little is known about these early enslaved workers.

The second owner, Ellison Smyth installed large wash tubs in 1924 and called it the "wash house".

In modern times, Mrs. Sandburg used the left side of the building for chickens and the right side for young goats.

Sandburg's granddaughter, Paula Steichen discusses how the family used the building.

"It was used first for chickens, and then we used it primarily for baby kids that we raised after the kids were old enough to be moved from in the basement of our house, we would take them out there.  The kids of course were separated from the does as soon as they were born so they had to be kept in separate quarters."

From the 1830s until the 1980's this building provided water for the early residents and even park visitors to Connemara.  A reservoir located near the top of Glassy Mountain provided the water supply.  A pump in this building then sent water to the house, the pond in front of the house and down to the barn.

Cool water from a mountain reservoir flowed through the spring house providing a perfect place for Mrs. Sandburg and her daughter Helga to store and cure cheeses made from goat's milk.

Listen to the audio for a description of the cheeses cured here from Mrs. Sandburg's granddaughter Paula Steichen.

"Then we had a little cheese house on the…if you continue on the Memminger path, where my grandmother and mother did make the most wonderful cheeses of all different sorts and flavored them with anise seeds and with all number of herbs.  My mother actually wrote an article called “Making Goat Cheese” for the dairy goat journal I believe it was."

In addition to storing wood for the fireplaces, the Sandburg's stored older farm equipment here including a poultry feeder, a baby chick house, cream seperator, plows, mowers and unused building materials.

Built in 1873 this building served originally as a root cellar.  The Sandburg's used the greenhouse side to start plants for the flower gardens and occasionally stored bulbs in its cellar.

Adjacent to the greenhouse, the Sandburg's cleared up to an acre for a vegetable garden.  The garden provided much of their own food for the year through canning, drying and preservation.  Still used each year to pant a variety of vegetables, this garden retains a strong association with its past.

Mrs. Sandburg used these sheds when goats were ill and needed to be isolated from the main herd.  The shed on the right was also sometimes referred to as the "breeding shed" as goats would be brought here in the fall for breeding.  Today only one shed is in use and it houses the bucks (boy goats).  The bucks are separated from the does once they reach four to six months old to prevent unplanned breeding.

Constructed in 1923 this corn crib originally stored corn grown on the farm and fed to the livestock raised by second owner Ellison Smyth.  The Sandburg's stored various farm equipment here and today garden tools are stored inside.

The goat barn sheltered the does (girl goats) at Connemara.  Mrs. Sandburg operated a successfull dairy, selling milk from the farm to dairies in Asheville and Greenville.  Many of the farm's goats won top awards at state and local fairs. Jennifer II, a Toggenburg dairy goat, was internationally recognized as the top producing Toggenburg in the world in 1960. 

Mrs. Sandburg helped establish the American Dairy Goat Association, located in Spindale, NC, and was its Director for over ten years. She was honored with a lifetime directorship. A legend in the dairy goat industry, Mrs. Paula Sandburg was a champion of champions.

The Sandburg's built the milk house in 1948 to process and bottle milk for sale on the farm.  Pipes run from the milking parlor inside the barn into the milk house to be strained and separated before bottling.  Quart-size cardboard bottles were affixed with "Connemara Farms" caps and sold to local dairies and individuals.  

After mandatory pasteurization laws were passed in the early 1950's, Mrs. Sandburg no longer sold milk directly, but collected the milk in large containers to be sold to larger dairies for pasteurization and distribution.

The Sandburg's kept a family milk cow in this shed and sawdust for the goat barn in the storage shed behind it.

Today the cow shed is used to care for chickens of similar breeds to those Mrs. Sandburg raised. The Sandburg chickens were housed in a building up the road by the main house.  Saw dust for the goat barn is still stored in the shed behind it.

The grandchildren, Paula and John Carl each had a horse to ride through the pastures and along the many trails throughout the property.  This building housed their horses, saddles and tack.  Work horses for plowing were also kept here.

Mrs. Sandburg housed her young buck kids in this building and adjacent play yard until they were old enough to join the older bucks or be shipped off to other dairy goat farms. 

Today the park uses this building and play yard in the spring for does and their new kids.  Later in the summer, once the buck kids reach four to six months old they are separated from the herd and housed here until they are large enough to join older bucks across the road or are sold to another farm.

The Sandburg's stored farm equipment including the farm tractor and jeep in this building.  Occasionally the equipment was removed for evening square dances, including a group known as the Connemara Farm Dancers.

Listen to the audio to hear Sandburg's granddaughter Paula Steichen talk about the square dances held here.

"The garage at the barn was often used for square dances on Saturday nights.  When we had a caretaker Frank Mintz for quite a time who was part of a dancing group, a mountain dancing group, and we would have square dances, he would really hold the square dances there, and sometimes members of the family would go down.  I know that Frank Mintz’s group for a while wore the shirts that said Chickaming Goat Herd on them."

This residence was constructed around 1915 to serve as the home for Smyth's farm caretaker and his family.  The Sandburg's continued this use when they hired Frank Mintz in 1946 to tend Connemara Farms.  He helped by feeding, milking and breeding the goats, plowing the fields and making repairs to buildings.

In the 1960's Leroy Levi moved in with his family to serve as farm manager.  Today the house is used as a residence for temporaray employees and in the spring for the Carl Sandburg Writer-in-Residence.

This building housed the servants of the first two owners.  Carl Sandburg later named it the "Swedish House" because of the scalloped fascia and used it as an overflow library for magazines and books.

Built around 1910, this "little white house" was a residence for farm assisstants, chauffers and family guests of the Smyth family.  During Sandburg's time it was occasionally used as a residence for farm employees or as a studio for Helga Sandburg's painting.
The Sandburg's oldest daughter Margaret cared for this "wild, overgrown, and beautiful" fenced garden of roses, peonies and perennials.  She used the gazebo to store her garden tools.

This large, exposed rock was a favorite location for Carl Sandburg to bring a chair and orange crate for an outdoors study. He enjoyed the quiet and peacefulness of this location to edit his work. Exposed rocks like this are located throughout the area and have a long history of use going back to the first peoples to settle the area we know today as Flat Rock.

data.description: This self-guided tour takes visitors by a number of historic carriage road bridges. It starts from Jordan Pond House and goes along carriage roads to create a five mile loop. Duration will vary whether visitors are on foot or bicycle. John D. Rockefeller financed 16 of 17 stone-faced bridges, each unique in design, to span streams, waterfalls, roads, and cliffsides. The bridges are steel-reinforced concrete, but the use of native stone for the facing gives them a natural appearance.

images.altText: Stone bridge with a narrow opening in a forested area
images.caption: This carriage road bridge spans Jordan Stream, located between Intersections 14 and 21
images.credit: Photo by Nathaniel X. Boëchat, Friends of Acadia, NPS
images.title: West Branch Bridge

stops.significance: This is the first stop and "trailhead" for the self-guided carriage road bridges tour.

The Jordan Pond Dam Bridge (1920) was the third of 17 bridges constructed along 57 miles of carriage road on Mount Desert Island between 1917 and 1940. The bridge carries Asticou-Jordan Pond Road across Jordan Stream adjacent to a small dam at the southwest corner of Jordan Pond.

Cliffside Bridge (1932) is one of 17 bridges constructed along 57 miles of carriage road on Mount Desert Island between 1917 and 1940. It carries Amphitheater Road (Asticou-Jordan Pond Road) over a ravine on the flank of Jordan Mountain along a road between Amphitheater and West Branch bridges.

Amphitheatre Bridge (1931) is the largest of 17 bridges constructed along 57 miles of carriage road on Mount Desert Island between 1917 and 1940. It carries Amphitheatre Road (Asticou-Jordan Pond Road) -- which itself had been abandoned for ten years due to the objections of summer residents -- near the Little Harbor Brook waterfall.

The Little Harbor Brook Bridge (1919) was the second of 17 bridges constructed along 57 miles of carriage road on Mount Desert Island between 1917 and 1940. It is located on Little Harbor Brook Road for a section of carriage road connecting Jordan Pond with Brown Mountain Road over a shallow and rocky brook deep in the woods.

data.title: Carriage Road Bridges Tour

data.description: The Cemetery Ridge trail will take approximately 90 minutes to complete and is slightly over one mile in distance. It will take you from the Gettysburg National Military Park Museum and Visitor Center to Cemetery Ridge, where the center of the front line of the Union Army of the Potomac was located from the evening of July 1 through July 3, 1863. Heavy fighting occurred along the ridge on July 2, and on July 3, it was the scene of “Pickett’s Charge,” which determined the outcome of the battle.

images.altText: A row of monuments following a tour ridge on a ridgeline
images.caption: Hancock Avenue is surrounded by monuments of Union regiments there during Pickett's Charge
images.title: Hancock Avenue on Cemetery Ridge

stops.significance: This was the home of the 52-year-old widow Lydia Leister and her four children in 1863. They left the house on July 1 after being warned it was likely there would be fighting in the area. General George G. Meade, commanding the 90,000-man Union Army of the Potomac, established his headquarters here early on July 2 because it was central to all parts of his army’s front lines.

These guns represent the position of Lieutenant John G. Turnbull’s Battery F & K, 3rd U.S. Artillery late on the afternoon of July 3.

Before the Confederate infantry advanced during Pickett’s Charge on July 3, nearly 150 Confederate cannon bombarded Cemetery Ridge for almost two hours. Between 80 to 100 Union guns responded, and one of the greatest cannonades of the war ensued.
stops.assetName: Turnbull's Battery F & K, 3rd US Artillery

stops.significance: The equestrian statue of General Meade, mounted on his favorite horse, “Old Baldy,” depicts the “quiet, resourceful commander” of the Army of the Potomac. A West Point graduate and career soldier, Meade was placed in command of the army by President Lincoln only three days before the Battle of Gettysburg. An experienced soldier and highly respected in the army, he was also known for his sometimes explosive temper which earned him the nickname “old snapping turtle.”

This wayside exhibit marks the focal point of the Gettysburg Cyclorama Painting. In the spring of 1882, French artist Paul D. Philippoteaux visited the battlefield for the purpose of painting a cyclorama of the Battle of Gettysburg. The subject of the battle selected for the painting was Pickett’s Charge.

In the planning for Pickett’s Charge on July 3, the clump, later dubbed the Copse of Trees, was designated as a landmark to guide the attacking troops. In 1887, the iron fence was built to protect the trees from souvenir hunters. None of the trees inside the fence today date to 1863. The High Water Mark of the Rebellion Monument was erected in 1892 to honor the commands of both armies that participated in the July 3 “Longstreet’s Assault,” which today is more popularly known as Pickett’s Charge. The monument was designed by John B. Bachelder, the first historian of the battlefield.
stops.assetName: High Water Mark Monument and Copse of Trees

stops.significance:
This line of monuments marks the positions of Union infantry of General John Gibbon’s 2nd Division, 2nd Corps, and General Abner Doubleday’s 3rd Division, 1st Corps, on July 3. 

One of the more unique monuments along this line honors the 20th Massachusetts Infantry. The 20th had the nickname “The Harvard Regiment,” because a number of their officers were graduates of Harvard College.

The 69th had 26 officers and 258 enlisted men equipped for duty when they first went into action on July 2. By the end of the battle, the regiment had 40 killed or mortally wounded, 80 wounded, and 17 captured: nearly one-half its strength.

This monument to the 69th, which was dedicated in 1887, is unique in that it is the only regimental monument on the field to include markers for each of the ten companies in the regiment. The company markers are connected to each other by a chain to symbolize that the 69th’s line bent, but did not break, during Pickett’s Charge.

The 72nd Pennsylvania Monument was dedicated on July 4, 1891 and is one of the more evocative monuments on this part of the field. It is also one that was embroiled in controversy. During Pickett’s Charge, the 72nd was initially held in reserve behind Cemetery Ridge.

The stone wall in front of you is the remnant of a wall that was built by the local farmers before the battle and was originally two to three feet high. The soldiers used this wall for protection from enemy fire. This area, encompassed by the wall running south and the wall extending east, became known after the battle as “The Angle.” On July 3, Confederate troops advanced up to the wall in front of the 71st’s monument and drove back the men of the regiment positioned here.

This is the Abraham Brian barn and farmhouse. Brian’s property was on the edge of Ziegler’s Grove, an oak grove that covered about 2½ acres in 1863, and served as cover for Battery I, 5th U. S. Artillery, and for elements of Hays’ infantry during the battle.

Brian, his wife Elizabeth, and their five children were not living in the house at the time of the battle. As members of the local African-American community, the family left the Gettysburg area upon news of the Confederate invasion, perhaps joining the exodus to Lancaster County.

data.description: From April 30-May 6, 1863, the Battle of Chancellorsville raged in the area called the Wilderness. For Confederates, this victory provided a distraction from a crumbling home front and hope that Northern support for the war would falter. What were the consequences of the Battle of Chancellorsville? This tour follows the route indicted by the numbered stops on the circular battlefield tour signs on the park map and out in the landscape, including shared public roads that move at high speeds. Drive carefully.

images.altText: A trail heading into the woods in spring.
images.caption: Jackson Wounding Trail outside Chancellorsville Battlefield Visitor Center.
images.title: Trails Around Chancellorsville

stops.significance:
Welcome to the Chancellorsville Battlefield Driving Tour. The Chancellorsville Campaign included three engagements between the Army of the Potomac and Army of Northern Virginia: at the Chancellorsville intersection, at Fredericksburg, and at Salem Church. This 10-stop tour focuses on the Chancellorsville engagement. 

The Chancellorsville Battlefield Visitor Center is located at the spot where Confederate soldiers accidentally wounded General Thomas J. “Stonewall” Jackson. You can learn more about this event on the short interpretive trail encircling the visitor center. While the story of Jackson’s wounding is arguably the most famous incident that occurred during the battle, it is a story that has frequently overshadowed and obscured the historical consequences of the Chancellorsville Campaign. 

This tour looks at the context within which this battle took place, the people here and the decisions they made, the role of strategy and chance, and how the events here fit into the wider story of the Civil War.

Oscar and Catharine Bullock lived in a white house that once stood here with their two small children and Catharine’s brother, David Kyle. The Bullocks enslaved five people, whose names we do not know. They lived in a smaller house nearby.

Over the winter of 1862-1863, Confederate soldiers were a constant presence in this area. A battle became more imminent on the morning of April 30, 1863 when the approaching Eighth Pennsylvania Cavalry skirmished with the 12th Virginia Infantry here. The Confederates backed away towards Fredericksburg, opening up the road for US soldiers in to advance on Chancellorsville. The Battle of Chancellorsville unfolded over the next several days. This location would be a headquarters, a field hospital, and ultimately, this clearing would become the apex of Hooker’s last defensive line after retreating from Chancellorsville.

By the end of the battle the property was in ruins and the lives of the civilians here changed forever.

Forty years before the Civil War the Chancellor family erected a large house here, a tavern catering to travelers coming to and from Fredericksburg. Over time, the property expanded and included the Chancellorsville Inn and 300 acres of improved farmland. 

During the war, widow Frances Chancellor occupied the house with her children. Approximately 20 enslaved people plus an overseer and his family lived and worked on the property. After the passage of the Emancipation Proclamation all the enslaved residents crossed into Union lines in Stafford except for one young girl who remained behind.  

The Chancellors had strong Confederate sympathies and their home was a popular resting place for Confederates over the winter of 1863. When the US army arrived at the Chancellor House on April 30, neighbors and friends took refuge here, bringing the total number of civilians in the house to 16.

The Chancellor house became Hooker’s headquarters during the battle and was the central point around which the battle raged.

From here the Chancellorsville intersection is located just over a mile to the west. On May 1st, Hooker ordered his troops to march on Fredericksburg. After a brief engagement with Confederates a mile east of here Hooker ordered his advancing troops to retreat and consolidate around Chancellorsville.

Following the retreating Federals, Confederates under General Lafayette McLaws arrived here in the afternoon. The Army of Northern Virginia would occupy this location for the rest of the battle.
On May 2, McLaws launched a series of diversionary attacks across this ground, keeping US forces occupied while Jackson led a flank march around the Federals. On May 3, Lee renewed his efforts to repel US forces at Chancellorsville. From here, McLaws increased the pressure with bigger, more determined attacks against the Federals.

There is a 1-mile loop trail here that interprets the action between Lafayette McLaws’ Confederates and Nelson Miles’ US troops on May 3.

On the evening of May 1 Confederates held a battle line that stretched along this road, currently the park road, from the Orange Turnpike south along the Furnace Road to Catharine Furnace.

While US forces focused on improving their defenses, Robert E. Lee and Confederate commanders discussed what actions to take. For Lee, ordering a frontal assault against the entrenched Federals would be perilous. A flank attack, hitting the Federal line from the side, would maximize the Confederate’s impact. This is the course Lee decided to take in the night between May 1 and May 2. General Jackson, in charge of the Confederate 2nd Corps would lead the flank attack with nearly 30,000 troops beginning on the morning of May 2.

Today all that remains of Catharine Furnace is the stone furnace stack that sits at the intersection of the Furnace Road and Jackson Trail East. 

Catharine Furnace was part of the reason why the area around Chancellorsville was known as the Wilderness. When European colonists began settling here they depleted the soil after repeated tobacco planting and began calling the region “the Poison Fields.” While the ground was not ideal for agricultural production, it was ripe with minerals. 

In 1837, Catharine Furnace became one of numerous furnaces in the region. The primary owner, John Wellford, created a furnace complex with dozens of buildings, loading docks, dorms for enslaved and free laborers, and a road network across over 4,000 acres. Fuel for the furnace came in the form of coal, made from local trees. This deforestation left large swaths of land barren. By the time the armies arrived, many of these formerly deforested areas were filled with young, dense, second growth forests.

Between Catharine Furnace to the south and this location lies Lewis Run. Lewis Run carves out a swampy morass in the Wilderness; it is a difficult place for soldiers to maneuver or fight.

Slocum Drive is located on higher ground to that guards the region north of Lewis Run. General Henry W. Slocum’s US 12th Corps formed its battle line along this high ground. Today, faint traces of earthen fortifications erected by the US soldiers follow the curves of the park road. Slocum’s men built these trenches on May 1 and 2 and Hooker established his defensive line around Chancellorsville.
Slocum’s troops used logs principally for cover and dug enough dirt to hold the logs in place. As the war went on and soldiers gained more experience building defensive works, their trenches became deeper and more imposing. 

On May 3, as Confederates seized Hazel Grove they would force Slocum’s men to abandon this position and retreat back to Fairview.

General Oliver Otis Howard’s US 11th Corps anchored the edge of the Federal battle line, the right flank, on the high ground here. 

The 11th Corps was the smallest corps in the Army of the Potomac, and Howard had only been in command of the corps for a month. Of the 11th Corps’ 23 regiments present (one brigade had been sent to Catharine Furnace) 11 were German, composed primarily of first- and second-generation immigrants, and 8 had never before been into battle. Because of the high concentration of Germans both in the ranks and in leadership positions, the rest of the Army of the Potomac frequently associated the 11th Corps with German culture and the wider community of German immigrants in the United States.  

German troops hoped that proving themselves in battle would improve their standing and increase the trust between the German and English speaking regiments. Instead, the Battle of Chancellorsville would become a disaster for the 11th Corps.

Hazel Grove was a 300-acre plantation established by Melzi Chancellor, the eldest son of Ann and George Chancellor, located adjacent to the Chancellor family’s Fairview Plantation. Melzi Chancellor moved out in 1859, and the property was reportedly occupied by a family named Sullivan during the Civil War. By the end of the battle, the construction of earthworks, fighting, artillery fire that swirled around this site left the property in ruins.

On May 2, this knoll was occupied by the US 3rd Corps led by General Daniel Sickles. After Jackson’s flank attack rolled up the US 11th Corps, Sickles attempted to attack the Confederate position north of here that night. However, the dark woods created too much confusion and chaos for an effective assault. Sickles’ troops would instead wait until morning for the fighting to resume.

Taking this ground proved critical to Confederate forces on the morning of May 3, 1863, and from here, the most intense fighting of the Battle of Chancellorsville took place.

The US Army held their position at Fairview for 5 hours on May 3, 1863 before falling back to a secondary line near the Bullock House. This retreat marked the end of the fighting around the Chancellorsville, but was not the end of the battle. Ultimately, it was Hooker who decided to take his army back across the Rappahannock River and put an end to his ambitious campaign. 

Large numbers of causalities sobered Lee’s excitement about his victory here, and the battle did nothing to solve the many problems plaguing the Confederate government. In the Army of the Potomac, soldiers maintained their morale, even if they had lost faith in Joseph Hooker. The armies would fight again.

After the armies moved on, the region surrounding Chancellorsville was devastated and would barely have a chance to recover before these same armies fought here again, at the Battle of the Wilderness, one year later.
