park.fullName: Longfellow House Washington's Headquarters National Historic Site
park.name: Longfellow House Washington's Headquarters

stops.significance:
Prior to European colonization, this area was inhabited by the Massachusett people, who used the landscape for hunting and farming. European colonizers claimed the land that the Longfellow House stands on, establishing the town of Newtowne (later renamed
Cambridge) in 1630 as the administrative capital of Massachusetts Bay Colony.

Activity link to see what plants and wildlife are native and nonnative to our area: https://www.nps.gov/long/planyourvisit/grounds-tour.htm

The earliest European settlers in the Brattle Street area used the land for small farms. After the colony’s capital was moved to Boston in 1638, wealthy families began building grand country estates in this area. In 1759, John Vassall Jr., who owned Jamaican sugar plantations, used his wealth gained through the labor of enslaved people to build the house you see today. Look at our activity page to see what the house was like when it was first built: https://www.nps.gov/long/planyourvisit/grounds-tour.htm

When the house passed into the hands of the Craigie family, and eventually the Longfellows, the landscape had evolved from a laborious farm into a leisurely lawn. Before owning the home, Longfellow rented two rooms here under Elizabeth Craigie’s ownership. The Craigies made changes to the house that can be seen today, however, their famous gardens were removed when the Longfellows bought the home in 1843. The Longfellows added hedging around the property to shield the home from increasing urbanization. The landscape was a source of leisure and happy memories for the family. Find parlor games here: https://www.nps.gov/long/planyourvisit/grounds-tour.htm

How would you choose to share your home with the public? After the death of her father Henry, in 1882, Alice Longfellow lived in and preserved the Longfellow property. A local celebrity from both her father’s fame and her own achievements, Alice frequently hosted visitors. In 1905, Alice removed the billiard room her father created and replaced it with this small trellis garden. In 1910, she added a veranda to the second floor so she could overlook her gardens privately.

Gardens have been part of the house’s landscape from the time of the Vassall family; however, we now know that the purpose and appearance changed with each owner. During her ownership of the house, Alice Longfellow had the formal garden redone in a Colonial Revival style resembling her father’s garden. First designed by Martha Brookes Hutcheson in 1905 and replanted by Ellen Biddle Shipman in 1925, the garden’s appearance is meant to reflect aspects of the house’s history, from both the Washington and Longfellow era.

Here's the activity link for the photo scavenger hunt: https://www.nps.gov/long/planyourvisit/grounds-tour.htm

data.title: Changing Landscape Tour

data.description: At more than 200 years old, the Charlestown Navy Yard you see today is the product of constant change, both planned and unplanned. The central mission of the yard was always to support the US Navy—to build, repair, and modernize its warships. As the needs of the Navy changed and shifted, so did the landscape and the people at the Yard. The lasting legacy of those changes and shifts is what remains today. Join this tour to explore how the Navy Yard fulfilled its mission, and secured that legacy.

images.altText: black and white photo of a crane and a dry dock with a ship in it. Workers are seen throughout.
images.caption: Join us for a tour of the Charlestown Navy Yard!
images.title: Charlestown Navy Yard

stops.significance:
When the US Navy bought a piece of shoreline off Boston Harbor in 1800, they envisioned a station that would support the small fleet of warships built to protect a young nation. Only a handful of buildings existed during the first 12 years. During the War of 1812, the Navy expanded the Yard to keep up with defense and technological change. At that time, carpenters built the ships of wood, caulkers waterproofed the hulls with rope & tar, and riggers organized a complicated network of ropes and sails to propel the ships forward. Over the next 130 years the Navy Yard demolished what was obsolete. The Navy constructed replacement facilities and purchased new technology when practical. By 1943, the Yard employed some 50,000 workers. Every day, men and women welded metal, forged steel, fabricated machinery, fitted pipes, and ran electrical wire to build massive ships.

The Charlestown Navy Yard played a significant role in transforming the Navy from sail to steam. This legacy is embedded in the surviving landscape.

Gate 1, originally a simple wooden sentry box and a picket fence guarded by Marines, served as one of the earliest entries to the Yard. Facing the public, Gate 1 was often the first place a visitor to the Yard experienced. Iron bars replaced the simple wooden fence in 1847, and in 1901 Gate 1 was reconstructed as a granite and brick gatehouse in the Beaux-Arts style. This castle-like structure was used by Marines not only as a gatehouse but also as living quarters.
After World War II, gate usage shifted again. Increasing automobile traffic ultimately led to the demolition of the ornate gatehouse in the 1950s. This new Gate 1, which still greets visitors to the yard today, allowed for two-way traffic and featured 1950s architecture that incorporated a greater use of steel and glass. While somewhat mismatched to the older buildings and architectural styles, Gate 1 represents the Yard as a space in a constant state of change, one that is required to both uphold tradition and meet practical requirements.

If you visit the Charlestown Navy Yard today, you might notice railroad tracks crisscrossing the ground. While many sections are gone—either torn up or paved over—the surviving pieces echo what used to be a busy network of tracks throughout the Navy Yard. On that rail network, small trains once trundled from building to building and out to the dry docks and piers.
Compared to wagons pulled by horses and oxen, the introduction of the railroad in the 1860s allowed the Yard to transport heavy and bulky materials more effectively. Further, a rail connection to nearby railroads meant the Charlestown Navy Yard was not only interconnected, but it was also directly accessible to places far beyond its gates.
In the 1950s, however, the US Navy’s use of the rails sharply declined. Larger and more powerful trucks, capable of driving anywhere, replaced many roles of the railroad. Nevertheless, the surviving tracks remind us of the railroad’s 100 years of stalwart service to the Yard.

With the US Navy’s growing fleet in the early 1800s, the Charlestown Navy Yard began expanding its facilities. This included the construction of the first American dry docks. A dry dock is a large basin attached to a body of water. When full with water, the basin can be opened and a ship can be maneuvered inside. Shipyard workers then close the dry dock and drain the water, leaving the ship resting on keel blocks.
For the Yard, Civil Engineer Loammi Baldwin designed a revolutionary dry dock that used steam engines to power the pumps that drained the basin. The Boston dry dock opened on June 24, 1833 for repair work on the USS CONSTITUTION. To accommodate larger ships, Dry Dock 1 has been extended a couple times. After a final extension in 1947, Dry Dock 1 measured 404-feet in length, the same length it remains today.
When the Yard closed in 1974, Dry Dock 1 remained one of its few operational assets. It continues to play a critical role in maintaining both USS CONSTITUTION and USS CASSIN YOUNG.

Some of the structures at the Charlestown Navy Yard were carefully designed for highly specialized purposes. Building 10, on the other hand, represents a different type of structure at the Yard: one built to fill multiple, evolving roles as the needs of the US Navy changed.
Completed in 1853, Building 10 initially served the yard's caulkers, who used tarred rope fibers to make the hulls of wooden ships watertight. However, with the shift from wooden to iron-hulled ships in the 1890s, the Navy repurposed Building 10 to be a paint shop. In 1906, when the workload of the shop outgrew the building, its function changed again. 
Over the following years Building 10 served as a storeroom, office space, radio station, and a laundry. In 1948, it became a sonar facility and by the 1960s, Building 10 had become a battery charging station. From 1972 - 1973 and after serving multiple roles since its original construction, Building 10 became the USS Constitution Museum, before the Museum moved to its current location.

From underneath, it is easy to see why the two large cranes still found at the Charlestown Navy Yard—Crane 62 and Crane 65—are called "portal cranes." The open space, or portal, between the metal legs allowed workers and machines to move through the crane rather than having to go around. Conversely, operators could move the cranes along railroad tracks, driving them over blockages and repositioning them where needed.
The combination of its open portal, revolving top, and ability to move made the portal crane remarkably flexible and well-suited to its work at the Navy Yard. These cranes played a pivotal role in the building and repairing of ships at the Yard starting from their introduction in the 1940s until the Yard’s closure in 1974. When the Yard closed in 1974, many of the cranes were scrapped or moved. However, since the Charlestown Navy Yard remained the home of USS CONSTITUTION, these two portal cranes have remained alongside Dry Dock 1 to assist with maintaining the ship.

Set upon the highest point in the Charlestown Navy Yard, the Commandant's House stands apart from the cranes, shipways, railways, and industrial buildings that define the Yard's landscape. It sits at the center of a small community of US Navy and Marine personnel that worked and lived in the Navy Yard.
The Commandant served as the highest officer at the Charlestown Navy Yard. He directed the Yard as a military and industrial center while also welcoming important guests. As such, he needed a home that fit those needs. Completed in 1805, the Commandant's House reflected the Commandant's importance and expectation as a host. The house was divided into two worlds. Upstairs, the house was a private living space for the Commandant and his family. Downstairs, it was a public ceremonial space for dances, formal luncheons, dinners, and other gatherings. After more than two centuries, the Commandant's House still stands upon the slight rise of the Yard's landscape, overlooking the Yard and Boston Harbor

From 1802 to 1974, United States Marines guarded this Navy Yard and served on many of the ships that sailed from here, including USS CONSTITUTION. Completed in 1811, the Marine Barracks building here in Charlestown is the oldest surviving Marine Corps structure in the United States. It served as home for the “Leathernecks” for 163 years, expanding as necessary to fit the needs of the Marines stationed at the Yard. The Barracks included not only housing, but also a barbershop, post exchange, chaplain’s office, movie theater, brig, and pistol range. 
At the Yard, Marines controlled access to the Yard, guarded the naval prison, and deployed as required to conflicts around the world. The Marines even responded to civil emergencies throughout Boston, including prison riots, crowd control, and fire relief.
The Marines lowered the Yard’s American Flag for the last time on July 1, 1974, when the Yard closed. The Marine Barracks stands as a permanent reminder in the Navy Yard of their years of service here.

Opened in 1838, the Navy Yard Ropewalk followed what is now Chelsea Street for 1325 feet, allowing workers to produce rope up to a quarter mile in length. Initially steam-powered, the facility made use of a number of innovations designed by local inventor Daniel Treadwell. Its sturdy granite and brick construction was also notable as an early attempt at fireproofing. The Charlestown Navy Yard Ropewalk became the Navy’s biggest ropemaking facility. Even after the transition from sail to steam in the later half of the 1800s, ships still required miles of rope. A World War II battleship needed 34,000 feet of cordage and the Charlestown Navy Yard rapidly increased production after Pearl Harbor to its highest levels during World War II. While the US government considered closing the Ropewalk after the war, its role in rope testing and developing new types of rope likely kept it operation until 1970.

Completed in 1904, Building 105 was not the first metal working shop at the Charlestown Navy Yard. By the 1880s, the Yard had already established itself as the primary manufacturer of anchors and anchor chain for the US Navy. This new building was designed to keep pace with the radically increasing size and number of Navy ships during the 1900s. Despite its size, Building 105's output remained limited because the chain-making process of the era proved very slow. Anchor chain was made from wrought iron and involved welding each link by hand. During World War I, the rapid expansion of the Navy required the development of a new chain-making process. With the chain forge facing obsolescence in the 1920s, workers developed a new type of chain using the drop hammers and forging equipment already in Building 105. The resulting steel “die-lock” links were much stronger and faster to produce than wrought iron chain. The forge in Charlestown remains the only place in the world that has made a 4 ¾ inch die-lock chain.

data.title: Charlestown Navy Yard Tour

data.description: Enjoy the springtime tradition of hanami (花見) or flower-viewing and enjoy the sights of the Tidal Basin and beyond. This 4-mile walking tour starts at the Smithsonian metro station and includes popular views of the famous Yoshino cherry trees, as well as off-the-beaten path locations to see unique trees away from the crowds. Make sure to bring water, dress for the outdoors, and wear comfortable footwear. Help us protect the cherry trees by staying on paved surfaces and leaving flowers on the trees.

images.altText: Cherry blossoms frame a view of the Washington Monument in the distance.
images.caption: Cherry blossoms frame a view of the Washington Monument in the distance.
images.title: Cherry Blossoms and Washington Monument

stops.significance: If you start your tour at the Smithsonian / National Mall Metro Station, look for the information Kiosk near the top of the escalator. At the kiosk rangers and volunteers may be able to assist you with helpful maps and information.

The bookstore in the Washington Monument lodge has cherry blossom shopping opportunities as well as restrooms accessible from outside the shop. Tickets to the Washington Monument may be available at the window at the rear of the building (you may also reserve tickets online at recreation.gov). The Washington Monument Lodge is also a handy stop for national park passport stamp collectors!

This lantern, carved in Japan in 1651, is the symbolic epicenter of the cherry blossom festival. Adjacent to the lantern, some of the oldest, original cherry trees from the 1912 planting remain. The majority of cherry trees in the park and around the Tidal Basin are Yoshino (Prunus x yedoenis) cherry trees.

This memorial was designed to incorporate cherry trees to perpetuate the cherry grove in this location prior to the memorial's construction. The trees happen to bloom around the same time of year that Dr. King died, serving as a reminder of the beauty and fleeting nature of life.

The walking path along Ohio Drive that begins here is full of several varieties of cherry trees unlike those along the Tidal Basin. Look for Akebono and Shirofugen trees here, as well as the bold-colored First Lady tree which blooms earlier than the Yoshinos on the Tidal Basin.

The First Air Mail marker is a helpful waypoint to take you past cherry trees along the river. From here, you can choose to double back to the FDR Memorial or continue onto the Inlet Bridge. Looking at the open field from here, imagine the first Curtiss Jenny biplane climbing from this field in 1918 as onlookers cheered the first air mail flight in the United States.

The Franklin Delano Roosevelt Memorial was designed by landscape architect Lawrence Halprin, incorporating many interesting trees and plants including the iconic Yoshino cherry trees. Also look for blooming azalea bushes here in the spring.

A gift from Japan, the pagoda represents elemental forces of sky, wind, fire, water, and earth. The gift was given to recognize 100 years of trade between the U.S. and Japan since the 1854 Convention of Kanagawa in Yokohama, Japan, and the "peace and amity" of the accord.
The Inlet Bridge is where water enters the Tidal Basin from the Potomac River at high tide. From here, you have a sweeping view of the entire Tidal Basin and the Washington, DC, skyline.

Saucer magnolias and forsythia bushes ring this memorial, with other plantings in the center. The fountain here is the only remaining of four fountains that were built here in the early 1900s to make First Lady Helen Taft's vision of beautifying West Potomac Park. Taft had a major role in securing the original gift of cherry trees in 1912, and her love of eastern culture was foundational to the landscape we see in the park today.
Enjoy another sweeping view of the Tidal Basin from here, as well as a bookstore and restrooms inside the memorial's lower level.
If you still have energy left, maybe you'll enjoy a ride on one of the paddle boats on the Tidal Basin! Get interesting views of cherry trees and avoid the crowds while out on the water.

data.title: Cherry Blossom Walking Tour

data.description: Throughout this tour, you will see monuments and memorials honoring those who fought here. You may also notice tablets, blue for US and red for Confederate, that describe the soldiers' actions; they date from around 1890. You can reach the major points of interest on the seven-mile auto tour. Most stops follow the battle's final day, September 20, 1863.

images.altText: A park ranger leads a tour of Chickamauga Battlefield
images.caption: A park ranger leads a tour of Chickamauga Battlefield
images.title: Chickamauga Battlefield Tour

stops.significance: This is an introduction to Chickamauga and Chattanooga National Military Park, the nation's first national military park, established August 19, 1890.
On September 20, Confederates commanded by former US Vice President John C. Breckinridge assaulted and briefly penetrated the US line in this area before turning their attack southward.

The line of US monuments extending the length of Battleline Road mark where US troops constructed crude breastworks during the early morning hours of September 20. Secure in their positions, they successfully halted repeated assaults.
As officers called for troops to strengthen the left end of the US line, General Rosecrans ordered a division to shift out of its position. Unknowingly, his command created a fatal gap in the line.
stops.assetName: Tour Stop #3: Mix-up in Union Command

stops.significance: Before troops could fill the gap in the US line, the yells of thousands of Confederates pierced the air as they poured across LaFayette Road and through the gap. The breakthrough split the US army.

Step back one day to September 19. Thousands of soldiers, one division at a time, fought back and forth across this field trying to gain control of LaFayette Road. When sunset came, neither side held the road, yet thousands had paid the ultimate sacrifice. 

Tabler Viniard, the father of the family who owned and farmed the land surrounding this tour stop, enlisted in the 1st Georgia Infantry, US. Unfortunately, he passed away in 1864, while stationed in North Alabama. He is buried in the Chattanooga National Cemetery.

US Colonel John T. Wilder's brigade of mounted infantry, armed with Spencer repeating rifles, halted a portion of the attacking Confederates. The "Lightning Brigade" had the only US success on this part of the Battlefield.

Confederate soldiers swept out of the woods and into the fiels in what one commander called "a scene of unsurpassed grandeur." This attack collapsed the US right, forcing the defenders, including US General Rosecrans, to flee.
stops.assetName: Tour Stop #7: Rout of the Union Right

stops.significance: US soldiers held the ridge throughout the afternoon, repulsing repeated Confederate assaults. As darkness fell, one final assault revealed the remaining US troops had slipped away to Chattanooga. After three days of fighting, the Confederate Army of Tennessee was victorious.
stops.assetName: Tour Stop #8: Horseshoe Ridge and Snodgrass Hill

data.title: Chickamauga Battlefield Auto Tour

data.description: This 3.9 mile loop traverses the most difficult sections of trail in the park and allows hikers to experience the impressive views and geological formations at Chimney Rock and Wolf Rock.

images.altText: A large rocky outcrop looking over a mountain ridge at sunset with a phone over the image.
images.caption: Chimney Rock provides an excellent view of the ridge and Frederick Valley.
images.title: Chimney Rock at Twilight

stops.significance:
Chimney Rock is a popular spot for many people visiting Catoctin Mountain Park, but to reach this scenic formation hikers will have to be prepared. The Visitor Center is a great location to start the trail loop. Parking is available year-round, with two parking lots on either side of the Visitor Center. If parking is full by the Visitor Center, the Chimney Rock Loop can also be accessed from the parking lot by Park Headquarters, which will be a stop along the hike, as well as the Wolf Rock Parking Lot. 

At the Visitor Center, park staff will be able to provide you with information about the park such as trail maps, park brochures, as well as park conditions.

A short walk from the Visitor Center, you will arrive at the trailhead to the Chimney Rock Loop. This trail will be marked by an orange blaze and will also share sections with the white, pink, and yellow blazed trails. This self-guided hike will follow the trail counterclockwise from the right side of the trailhead.

The first section of the trail will run for 1 mile to the junction by Park Headquarters. The Gateway Trail, marked by a white blaze, will also share this section of the loop.

After hiking 1 mile from the trailhead, you will arrive at the intersection by Park Headquarters (Camp Peniel). Parking is also available here if the lots by the Visitor Center are full, as well as a map kiosk and bulletin board. From this point you will begin the hike up the most strenuous section of trail in the park, so be prepared.

Having hiked up the steep side of the mountain, you will arrive at Chimney Rock. Standing at 1,419 ft above sea level, this large rocky outcrop is a fun and exciting place to explore and the splendid views overlook eastern Frederick County and Sugarloaf Mountain to the South.

Please be advised that jumping across the rocks at these overlooks is extremely dangerous. People are seriously injured on a frequent basis. The size of the gaps between rocks is very deceptive, so please do not attempt to jump these hazard areas. Timber Rattlesnakes are also known to come out on to the rocks so be sure to maintain a respectful distance.

While it may not be an overlook like Chimney Rock, the Wolf Rock formation is still a scenic spot to explore. The length of a football field, Wolf Rock is a boulder field standing at 1,401 ft in elevation with a large boulder in the shape of a wolf standing at the northwestern end. 

Use caution when climbing and walking around Wolf Rock. There are large crevasses found across the formation and Timber Rattlesnakes may also come on to the boulders to sun themselves. Technical, roped rock climbing is allowed at Wolf Rock during daylight hours.

data.title: Chimney Rock & Wolf Rock Trail Loop

data.description: The landscape of Chinn Ridge saw severe fighting during both battles at Manassas. This roughly one-mile out and back trail will traverse the scene of the most sustained fighting at Second Manassas.

images.altText: Chinn House foundation
images.caption: Chinn House foundation
images.title: Chinn House foundation

stops.significance:
Begin your tour at the foundation of the Chinn House.

In 1860, Benjamin Chinn and his family lived here in a two-and-a-half story frame farmhouse. Known as "Hazel Plain," the modest plantation comprised several hundred acres. Like roughly one-third of their immediate neighbors, the Chinn family owned slaves.


On August 30 1862, war once again engulfed the Chinn property. Following the repulse of federal infantry at the Deep Cut, General Irvin McDowell ordered thousands of Pennsylvania infantry from this position to the north to cover a potential confederate counter attack.  This left the 1,500 men of General Nathaniel  McClean's brigade on this position.  

At 4PM, Confederate General James Longstreet's so far successful assault reached the low ground to your west, now obscured by dense trees, and began to climb the ridge.  McLean's men opened fire, which one Confederate noted staggered us "like an electric shock." The fight for Chinn Ridge had begun.

McLean's brigade held a very strong position along the ridge line, but lacked the manpower needed to hold against the strong numbers headed their way.  Though able to throw back the first Confederate assault against this position, additional Confederate solders soon began arriving beyond McLean's left flank. 

In order to meet this threat,the Ohioans redeployed, making use of a fence that rank across the field near where you currently stand. desperation McLean ordered two of his regiments to change front and reform at the fence line. By this point Confederate forces were sweeping onto the Chinn farm. As they surged past the Chinn house, McLean's brave remnant rose and fired. Their concentrated volley struck the Confederates like a shock wave. For ten minutes, deafening musketry continued until overwhelming numbers forced the Ohioans back along the ridge.

With McLean's line collapsing, General Irvin McDowell busied himself with finding new federal troops to send to Chinn Ridge.

Fighting swirled across the Chinn Ridge landscape, as additional Federal and Confederate soldiers were fed into the maelstrom. 

A battery of artillery from Maine deployed nearby to stem the Confederate tide, with one Virginian noting that the guns seemed to shake the very Earth.  The dull thud of balls as [they] tore through the bodies of the men- the hiss of the grape- and mingled screams of agony and rage.

One Massachusetts soldier noted of the engagement: "“Everything to our hasty glance seemed in confusion.  Wounded men were everywhere; some were being helped away, others were striving with all their strength to get away to a safe distance." 

Colonel Fletcher Webster, son of the Massachusetts Senator Daniel Webster, fell mortally wounded near this location, while at the front of his 12 MA Infantry. 

Federal troops had bought nearly two hours of time in their fighting on this ridge, allowing Generals Pope and McDowell the chance to build a last line of defense along the Sudley Road and Henry Hill.

data.title: Chinn Ridge Walking Tour

data.description: Walk around City Point to explore why this area was, and still is, a popular place for living along the rivers. The Eppes family established the Appomattox plantation and their home here as early as 1635, until 1976. In 1864, General Grant and the U.S. Army used City Point as its headquarters to supply the army during the Petersburg Campaign.

images.altText: white house with red roof, two smaller buildings background with green grass and blue sky
images.caption: The Eppes family home on the Appomattox Plantation.
images.title: Appomattox Plantation at City Point

data.description: Drive to four Civil War battlefields: Bolivar Heights, Schoolhouse Ridge North, Schoolhouse Ridge South, and Murphy-Chambers Farm. Explore the sites significant to the 1862 Battle of Harpers Ferry. Number of stops: 5 stops Estimated tour time Driving only: about 30 minutes Diving and hiking: about 2 hours

images.altText: Split-rail fencing runs along a dirt road through a grassy field
images.caption: Schoolhouse Ridge South battlefield.
images.title: Civil War Battlefields Driving Tour

stops.significance: The primary U.S. defensive line stretched across this ridge facing School House Ridge to the west. To the east and north looms Maryland Heights, site of the fighting on the first and second days of the battle. To the east and south sits Loudoun Heights, which was occupied by Confederate Gen. Walker. The Chambers Farm is to the south across Rt. 340. Cannons from both heights, School House Ridge, and eventually the Chambers Farm bombarded the U.S. troops here, forcing the garrison’s surrender, and mortally wounding U. S. Col. Miles. This site features easy to moderate hiking trails ranging from 0.3 of a mile to 3.2 miles roundtrip, panoramic views of the Blue Ridge mountains and surrounding areas, interpretive markers and signs, reproduction cannons, and Civil War earthworks.

U.S. pickets exchanged gunfire here with their Confederate counterparts between the lines.  A twig snapping in the night might provoke a volley of fire from the jumpy new recruits in the U.S. garrison.  Gen. Jackson also advanced soldiers to this area in a feint attack to cover for Gen. A. P. Hill’s flanking maneuver on the night of September 14th.  This area includes a moderate hiking trail of approximately 0.9 of a mile roundtrip, views of the surrounding ridgelines, interpretive markers and signs.

At this point you are about mid-way between the center and left flank of Jackson’s position. Confederate Gen. J. R. Jones’ division was located on the left flank, at the north end of the ridge, while Confederate General Alexander Lawton’s division sat astride the Charlestown Pike (modern Rt. 340) in the center. This site includes a moderately difficult hiking trail of approximately 1.75 miles roundtrip, views of the surrounding ridgelines, interpretive signs and markers, reproduction cannons, and restroom facilities.

This was the right flank of Jackson’s position. Confederate Gen. A. P. Hill’s 5,000-man division marched off the line here to execute their flanking maneuver on the night of September 14. This area features easy to moderately difficult hiking trails ranging from 1.2 to 3.7 miles roundtrip, views of the surrounding ridgelines, interpretive markers and signs, reproduction cannons, and restroom facilities.

Located on the far left flank of the U.S. defensive line, this farmstead was only lightly defended. Gen. A. P. Hill’s men easily scattered the few U.S. troops posted here as he completed his flanking maneuver. Artillery firing from here, and from the new position on Loudoun Heights on the morning of September 15 were much more damaging to the U.S. defenders then they had been on School House Ridge. This helped compel Col. Miles to surrender his remaining garrison to the Confederates. This site includes easy to moderately difficult hiking trails of up to 1.2 miles roundtrip, views of the surrounding ridgelines and the Shenandoah River, interpretive markers and signs, reproduction cannons, and Civil War earthworks.

data.description: Explore Civil War and Reconstruction stories throughout the village of Appomattox Court House. Please press "Start Guided Tour" to begin.

images.altText: View looking across the village. The Meeks Store is on the right and McLean House on the far left.
images.caption: View looking across the village from the Courthouse
images.title: Civil War and Reconstruction Tour

park.fullName: Appomattox Court House National Historical Park
park.name: Appomattox Court House

stops.significance:
Although the armies had not passed through the area prior to the spring of 1865, the war deeply impacted the lives of the people of Appomattox Court House long before any musketry and cannon fire shattered the stillness of the quiet village. 

In 1861, Appomattox County raised four companies of soldiers to swell the ranks of the Confederate army. 18-year-old Lafayette Meeks enlisted in May of 1861, just days after Virginia seceded from the Union. Less than 6 months later, Meeks contracted typhoid fever and passed away. His father Francis and mother Mariah buried him in this field near the family’s store, which also served as their home. The surrender of the Army of Northern Virginia left the Meeks family and the white residents of the village to grapple with an anguished sense of loss and uncertainty about the future. 

Free and enslaved African American residents of the village simultaneously understood that emancipation and Lee’s surrender offered a promise of hope for a better future.

After a grueling 90-mile retreat from Richmond and Petersburg, the Army of Northern Virginia marched into the village with Federal forces in close pursuit. On the afternoon of April 8, 1865, Confederate reserve artillery, totaling approximately 100 guns rolled through the village, stopping three miles to the west at a railroad depot at Appomattox Station. 

Four trains filled with rations and supplies awaited Lee’s army at Appomattox Station, but a Federal cavalry division under Maj. Gen. George Custer dashed into the station and captured three of the trains before the Confederates could secure them. The Battle of Appomattox Station took place in the dark, between 8:00-10:00 PM. After a series of charges, Custer’s cavalry prevailed, capturing around 1,000 prisoners and 25 artillery pieces. 

A patrol of Federal Cavalry probed along the Stage Road into the village but fell back up the road after a brief skirmish with the 5th Alabama Battalion. 

Click "Explore This Location" below to learn more.

On the night of April 8, Lee held a council of war at his headquarters approximately a mile to the northeast of this location. Lee and his generals determined to launch an attack the following morning to brush aside the Federal roadblock to allow the army to continue its march. Roughly 9,000 Confederate soldiers assembled along this farm lane. At dawn, Confederate cavalry surged forward.
Federal cavalry contested the advance in a fighting withdrawal, buying time for reinforcements to arrive. For a moment, the road appeared open, but by mid-morning, a line of about 13,000 Federal infantry, including about 5,000 United States Colored Troops, launched an attack.

With Federal forces closing in on three sides and the James River to the north, Lee recognized that his army was trapped. At approximately 10:00 A.M., Lee sent out flags of truce, requesting a ceasefire until he could meet with Grant. 

Click "Explore This Location" below to learn more.

As the smoke of battle cleared on the morning of April 9, 1865, Wilmer and Virginia McLean's home became the setting for a meeting between opposing commanders, General Ulysses S. Grant and General Robert E. Lee. Grant's Federal forces had surrounded Lee's Confederates, and after one last attempted breakthrough, Lee asked for terms of surrender. 

The commanders met in the parlor of the McLean home for about an hour and a half. Grant accepted Lee's surrender with generous terms designed to pacify the white southern population. Nearby, nine enslaved people realized that they were now free to live independently of the McLean family, with all of freedom's challenges and opportunities.

At least nine enslaved people lived in the small white buildings behind the McLean House at the time of the surrender. Bettie Love Stewart and her four children worked alongside Mary Ann and her three children as caretakers of the McLean home. In addition to cooking the family’s meals, they took care of the McLean children, maintained the house, and looked after the family’s animals. Emancipation brought a mixture of hope and uncertainty for formerly enslaved people in the wake of Lee’s surrender. Following the war, Bettie moved to Lynchburg with her husband, Henry. 

For the enslaved people of Appomattox County, April 9, 1865 was Freedom Day. Following Lee’s surrender, Federal soldiers enforced the Emancipation Proclamation in Southside Virginia. As other U.S. forces restored Federal authority throughout the South, their arrival signaled freedom for those still held in bondage. That December, the 13th Amendment was ratified, putting a formal end to slavery in the United States.

Because Lee’s surrender only included the Army of Northern Virginia, many of the men paroled at Appomattox Court House had to pass through active war zones to return to their homes. To ensure that Lee’s men were not mistaken for deserters or active combatants by other Confederate and Federal forces, Grant agreed to print parole passes that would allow each man to navigate safely through areas where the armies remained active. These passes allowed the paroled Confederates to secure free passage on board Federal trains and steamships, and they also permitted Lee’s men to draw rations from any Federal forces they encountered on the way home.

 On April 10, Federal soldiers set up printing presses in the Clover Hill Tavern and General George Sharpe oversaw the printing of approximately 30,000 passes in the span of about 30 hours. Once printed, the passes were distributed to Confederate officers who filled them out for the men they commanded.

George Peers, Appomattox County clerk for 40 years, lived in this frame house that was built in the early 1850s. The home is not open to the public.

As Federal infantry pressed Gordon’s Corps from the west and south of Appomattox Court House on April 9, the Confederates conducted a fighting withdrawal back through the village and east of the Appomattox River. Confederate artillery posted in front of the Peers House helped to cover the retreat of Gordon’s Corps and fired some of the last artillery shots of the war in Virginia. Tragically, some of these final shots found their mark, causing several casualties moments before Lee’s flags of truce stopped the fighting.

Grant and Lee held a short conference on horseback near this location on the morning of April 10. The terms of surrender agreed upon at the McLean House on April 9 only applied to Lee’s Army of Northern Virginia, but on April 10, Grant sought to hasten the war’s end by requesting that Lee use his influence as General in Chief of the Confederate armies to convince the other Southern forces to surrender. Lee refused this request, stating that the fates of the remaining Confederate armies would be up to Jefferson Davis and the other Confederate generals to decide. With armies remaining in the field, Lee asked if something could be provided to his men to ensure them safe passage home through Federal and Confederate lines, and Grant agreed to print parole passes for the Confederate troops.
stops.assetName: Lee and Grant Second Meeting Site

stops.significance:
The formal surrender of the Army of Northern Virginia spanned three days. On April 10, the Confederate cavalry that remained with the army surrendered their weapons along the Stage Road. The following day, Federal troops took possession of the Confederate artillery east of the Appomattox River. April 12 witnessed the stacking of arms of the Confederate infantry along the Stage Road. 

Given temporary command of the First Division of the Fifth Corps, Brig. General Joshua Chamberlain presided over the ceremony from this position. The 5,000 men under his command stretched through the village along both sides of the Stage Road as nearly 22,000 Confederate infantry marched up the road one division at a time and stacked their arms. Chamberlain recalled, “we received them with the honors due to troops, at the shoulder and in silence.” Maj. Gen John Gordon led the first Confederate troops into the village, and Chamberlain recorded that the soldiers on both sides demonstrated mutual respect during the ceremony.

The Civil War forever changed the two families that lived in this house both during and after the war. At the outbreak of the conflict, widow Elizabeth Kelley lived in this home. By the fall of 1862, all five of Kelley’s sons had enlisted in the Confederate Army. Two sons died of disease, but the others survived the war. One son remained with the Army of Northern Virginia in April of 1865 and was present at the surrender. For many White, Southern families like the Kelleys, Lee’s surrender marked a bitter conclusion to the war.

In 1871, John Robinson purchased the home. As a formally enslaved man, Robinson had been trained as a cobbler. He applied his skills by operating his own shoemaking business out of this house. Robinson’s trade skills likely provided him with greater opportunities than those available to formerly enslaved people without a trade skill. Emancipation signaled a landmark moment in the lives of freedmen, but equality remained an unrecognized hope.
Click "Explore This Location" to learn more.

While the other restored and reconstructed buildings at Appomattox Court House closely resemble their 1865 appearances, this structure looks quite different than the one visible to the soldiers present during the surrender. The original Appomattox County Jail was constructed on the opposite side of the Richmond-Lynchburg Stage Road, where its footprint is today marked by bricks. The old jail burned in 1864, and work on a new jail at the site of its present location may have begun before the surrender. Construction of the new jail was finally completed around 1867.

data.description: Imagine yourself in a semi-tropical environment like Florida or Mexico. Palms, swamps, and even crocodiles once covered the landscape, which are now fossils preserved in the Palisades and fallen rocks around you. Fossil leaf imprints of tropical-loving flora imprinted in the boulders tell a story about the ancient environment. Discovering these fossils shaped the way scientists and visitors alike understand and appreciate Oregon’s past. What are you hoping to discover during your visit to the Clarno Unit?

The trail’s gentle grade of 122 feet relative elevation is suitable for families with children or anyone looking for an easier hike in the Reserve. In spring and early summer enjoy the running creek and small cascading waterfall. Outstanding scenery, sculpted granite pinnacles, and a diversity of plants and animals await you.

data.description: Explore the human side of Brooks River. Katmai’s landscape has been home to people for thousands of years. The Brooks River area is both a National Historic Landmark and a National Register of Historic Places Archeological District. With over 900 house depressions near the river, this is one of the most densely concentrated archeological areas in North America. This walk follows an easy 1/4 mile trail to a reconstructed traditional Alutiiq/Sugpiaq home and explores the human history of Brooks.

images.caption: The Cultural Walk concludes at this partially reconstructed traditional Native Alaskan home.
images.title: traditional Native Alaskan home

data.title: Cultural Walk - Self-guided

data.description: This loop is a moderate hike with uphill and downhill sections of the trail that include moderate to steep inclines. This trail is the longest loop (without making any variations) and features Maryland’s largest cascading waterfall at 78 feet and two stunning vistas. The Hog Rock Vista is the highest elevation overlook on any of the trails/loops reaching 1610 ft. Expect hills, uneven surfaces, and rocky terrain along this loop trail. Wolf Rock, Chimney Rock, & Hog Rock formations are pet free areas.

images.altText: A rocky outcrop overlooking a valley with a phone overlain on the image.
images.caption: Hog Rock stands at 1610 ft, the highest view in the park.
images.title: Hog Rock

stops.significance:
If you're planning on completing the 5 mile yellow blazed trail loop, the Visitor Center will be the best place to start your hike. Parking is available year-round at the two parking lots on either side of the Visitor Center. If both of these areas are full, the yellow blazed trail can also be accessed from the Wolf Rock, Thurmont Vista, and Hog Rock Parking Lots.

At the Visitor Center, you will be able to pickup a trail guide and park brochure. Park Staff will also be available to answer any questions that you may have.

After stopping by the Visitor Center, you will arrive at the trailhead to the Cunningham Falls Nature Trail. This trailhead also serves as a starting point for the one-way 0.3 mile Blue Blazes Whiskey Still Trail. If you have some more time and would like to take a gentle 20 minute walk along a forest stream, the Blue Blazes makes a nice detour. 

The Cunningham Fall Nature Trail will be a moderate 1.2 mile hike. Be sure to bring water along for your hike and use caution when crossing rocky areas.

After walking along the Cunningham Falls Nature Trail and using caution to cross MD Rt. 77, you will arrive at the boardwalk to the falls. Walking to the end of the one-way boardwalk, you will be able to see Cunningham Falls. The largest cascading waterfall in Maryland, Cunningham Falls carves through 78 feet of impressive rock formations. 

Handicap parking is available at the start of the boardwalk alongside MD Rt. 77.

After hiking up the mountainside, you will arrive at Hog Rock. Standing at an elevation of 1610 ft, this vista overlooks the eastern ridge of the Weverton Formation and the Hunting Creek gap. 

Named after the pigs that enjoyed sunning themselves on the rocks when the area was farmland, Hog Rock is a Metabasalt (or Catoctin Greenstone) formation that dates back well over 500 million years. The metamorphic rock gets its greenish hue from minerals such as epidote and chlorite. As you continue to walk along this section of the ridge, you will notice multiple large greenstone outcrops throughout the forest.

After leaving the Hog Rock Parking Lot and winding through the forest, you will arrive at Blue Ridge Summit. This overlook stands at 1520 ft. Here you can peer through the forest canopy and look northward into Pennsylvania.

data.title: Cunningham Falls, Hog Rock, & Blue Ridge Summit Trail Loop

data.description: This out and back trail guide follows in the footsteps of the largest federal assault of Second Manassas on 30 August 1862. This trail will involve walking up a moderate incline over rough and rocky terrain. Please exercise caution and wear appropriate footwear.

images.altText: Assault at the Deep Cut
images.caption: Painting showing the federal assault at the Deep Cut
images.title: Assault at the Deep Cut

stops.significance:
Convinced that he was facing a retreated foe, General John Pope ordered federal troops to launch a pursuit of "Stonewall" Jackson here at the Deep Cut.  At 3PM on 30 August 1862, nearly 6,000 soldiers under General Fitz John Porter moved through the woods behind you into the pasture fields of Lucinda Dogan's Farm. 

As they entered into the open field, a New York soldier remembered: "Now the bullets began to fly about our ears, and men to put forward or backwards, out of line, to the earth.  Artillery from unseen locations opened upon us and the shouts and yells from both sides were indescribably savage."

As you move along this trail, you will largely be moving with the middle of this large federal assault.  The attacking column stretched to your left and right for almost a half mile.  This attack column consisted of men from New York, Pennsylvania, Michigan, Maine and Massachusetts. 

This force would soon find out that the Confederates were far from retreating...

You are now standing along the Federal skirmish line that was established prior to the assault. 

Nearly a half hour prior to the advance, Colonel Hiram Berdan's 1st US Sharpshooters moved through the Dogan fields to clear it of any Confederate resistance.  One of Berdan’s men later recalled, “As soon as we got out of the woods, we got a perfect shower of bullets, as thick as hailstones. to protect themselves, Berdan's men clambered into the safety of the dry-bed of School House Branch, which is visible to your front. Another one of Berdan's men remembered, "At first the rebels thought they had us tight, and then showed themselves pretty plain, but after a few shots from us they concluded there was something there beside smoothbore muskets."

The monument near you was placed after the war by George Albee, a veteran of the sharpshooters, to mark his position during the engagement.  The original sign can be found on exhibit in the Henry Hill Visitor Center. 

Soon, thousands of federals began the push forward.
stops.assetName: 1st US Sharpshooters at the Deep Cut

stops.significance:
You are now standing at the Deep Cut along the unfinished railroad grade occupied by "Stonewall" Jackson's wing of the Confederate army.  Soldiers from Louisiana and Virginia occupied this stretch of it.

As federals neared the railroad embankment, the fighting grew in intensity. One man of the 15th AL said, “What a slaughter!  What a slaughter that was!” Many troops simply held their muskets horizontally above their heads and fired blindly.  To your left, federal troops momentarily broke through but, a confederate counterattack, soon threw them back. 

To your right, Louisianians resorted to throwing rocks as they ran out of ammunition, described by one New Yorker as an "unlooked for change in the proceedings." 

With renewed attacks from front and flank, and with a lack of reinforcements, the federal assault retreated, leaving thousands in their wake. The largest Federal assault of Second Manassas had failed. The fight soon moved south of the Warrenton Turnpike.

data.title: Deep Cut Trail Guide

data.description: The Deerfield Nature Trail takes you through a rich cultural history from American Indians gathering resources for stone tools to early European settlers homesteading in the area to start a new life. This 1.3 mile loop trail will reflect on the resources that were used to help people survive and thrive.

images.altText: A mobile device with a map superimposed on a forested trailhead.
images.caption: Deerfield Nature Trail is a great hike for families.
images.title: Deerfield Nature Trail

stops.significance:
The Deerfield Nature Trail takes you through a rich cultural history from American Indians gathering resources for stone tools to early European settlers homesteading in the area to start a new life. This 1.3 mile loop trail will reflect on the resources that were used to help people survive and thrive.

The Deerfield Nature Trail will be marked by a yellow triangle blaze. Access to this trail starts from the Owens Creek Campground. Parking is available nearby at the start of the boardwalk to the Owens Creek Sawmill and the Owens Creek Picnic Area. The Deerfield Nature Trail also links up with the orange-blazed horse trail.

Rhyolite rocks, which can be found on the west side of the park in parts of Owens Creek, Round Meadow, Greentop, Hog Rock, and Blue Ridge Summit Vista, were a useful resource for many people throughout the years. American Indians quarried the rhyolite because it could be easily knapped to make lithic tools, such as arrowheads and spear points. Early European settlers would also collect large quantities of rhyolite and other stones to build stone walls for their homesteads.
stops.assetName: Deerfield Nature Trail Stop 1: Rhyolite Outcrop

stops.significance: This plant can be found year round at different phases, from cream colored to brownish and scaly. It grows in dense clusters around oak and beech trees. Bear Corn gets its nutrients from the roots of the host tree. It produces yellow seed pods that are eaten by deer, bears, and turkeys.
stops.assetName: Deerfield Nature Trail Stop 2: Bear Corn

stops.significance: Take a good look at the trees around you. Do you see some with more than one trunk? These trees indicate that early logging took place in this area. In the late 1700s-mid 1800s just about every standing tree on this mountain was cut for the production of charcoal to fuel the Catoctin Iron Furnace. Trees were allowed to grow in 25-30 year cycles before they were cut again. A few trees were left standing to re-seed the forest, cut trees would sometimes produce new stems that grew out of the stump of the tree. This causes the tree to have multiple trunks.
stops.assetName: Deerfield Nature Trail Stop 3: Coppiced Trees

stops.significance: What do you think caused the knot on this beech tree? Burls, like this one, can be formed when the tree's wood grains are disturbed by environmental or insect damage. The tree will form a growth over the damaged area and create a burl. A tree that has developed burl wood is still generally healthy. In fact, many trees with burl wood will go on to live for many years.
stops.assetName: Deerfield Nature Trail Stop 4: Beech Tree Burl

stops.significance: Take a moment to absorb the sounds of Owens Creek flowing just below you. Water plays a very important role in the forest ecosystem. Various species of animals, American Indians, and early European settlers all benefited from Owens Creek. Not only was the creek a source of fresh water, but it assisted the early settlers with the sawmill industry. Check out the sawmill exhibit located at the entrance to the campground.
stops.assetName: Deerfield Nature Trail Stop 5: Owens Creek

stops.significance: The downed trees that litter the forest floor play a huge role for new plant life. As a tree decomposes over 50-70 years, fungi, bugs, and other decomposers help break down the tree into soil that provides rich nutrients for other plants to grow.

This deciduous perennial shrub is a host plant to spicebush swallowtail butterflies that inhabit the park in large numbers. The leaves release a spicy, citrusy smell. The shrub also produces red berries that animals such as white-tailed deer, eastern cottontail rabbits, and opossums like to eat.
stops.assetName: Deerfield Nature Trail Stop 7: Northern Spicebush

stops.significance: Stone walls, like this one, can be found throughout the western side of Catoctin Mountain Park. As far back as the 1700s, early European settlers inhabited the area, cleared large areas of trees and built their homesteads. The abundance of greenstone and rhyolite gave settlers plenty of rocks to construct stone walls for livestock fencing and building foundations. Other examples of stone walls can be found on the Brown's Farm Trail, around Owen Creek Campground, and on parts of the Horse Trail.
stops.assetName: Deerfield Nature Trail Stop 8: The Stone Wall

stops.significance: Maple trees, like this one, provided American Indians and European settlers with sap that could be collected and boiled into maple syrup. During autumn, this tree's leaves change to vibrant reds, yellows, and oranges.
stops.assetName: Deerfield Nature Trail Stop 9: Sugar Maple

stops.significance: As you cross Owens Creek, look for animals that inhabit the stream. This is a prime area for salamanders, frogs, toads, and even small minnows. Listen closely as you look up stream. You can hear the sound of water flowing under rocks. This is called a "losing stream" because it loses water as it flows downstream. The water filters into the ground, recharging the local groundwater, because the water table is below the bottom of the stream channel.

Invasive plants such as Japanese barberry are spreading throughout the forest. This thorny decorative shrub turns maroon red in the fall, and produces bright red berries that are toxic to humans. It is also a prime habitat for ticks. You can help stop the spread of these invasive plants by brushing off your shoes before hiking the trails in any new area and not planting invasive plants at home.
stops.assetName: Deerfield Nature Trail Stop 11: Japanese Barberry

stops.significance: This tree gets its name from its shaggy bark. The shaggy bark provides an excellent habitat for bats to roost under. Hickory nuts that fall to the ground provide a great food source for bears, chipmunks, squirrels, and even foxes because of their sweet, non-bitter taste.
stops.assetName: Deerfield Nature Trail Stop 12: Shagbark Hickory

stops.significance: This evergreen fern is popular among florists and gardeners. This area of the park is prime habitat for these ferns because of the damp soil along the banks of this shaded stream.
stops.assetName: Deerfield Nature Trail Stop 13: Christmas Fern

stops.significance: Like the Christmas fern, this blue-green fern is one of the few evergreen ferns in this forest. It grows in rocky, moist woods, along ravines.
stops.assetName: Deerfield Nature Trail Stop 14: Marginal Wood Fern

stops.significance: The tulip poplar is one of the fastest growing and largest trees in the forest, growing up to 100 feet. Because of this, it was one of the first trees the Civilian Conservation Corps re-planted in the park in the late 1930s. It is a flowering tree that produces yellow and orange flowers in the spring that emit a sweet scent. American Indians and early European settlers favored the trees for construction. What do you think caused the burl at the base of this tree?
stops.assetName: Deerfield Nature Trail Stop 15: Tulip Poplar Tree

data.title: Deerfield Nature Trail: A Story of Natural Resources

data.description: This self-guided tour combines driving and walking, and calls out the main sights to see within the first 15 miles of the Denali Park Road. The best time of year to do this tour is summer (roughly May 20 to mid-September), although many of the sights are worthwhile before or after those dates. In winter, however, most of the park's sole road is closed, so the sled dog kennels are the farthest point you can easily reach.

images.altText: a narrow paved road winding through sparse forest in front of a mountainous backdrop
images.caption: The Denali Park Road is paved for the first 15 miles, which the public may drive in the summer.
images.title: Denali Highlights

stops.significance:
Denali does not have an entrance station, so visitors who desire information and maps should plan to stop at the visitor center upon arriving in the park. 

Denali has just one road—called the Denali Park Road—and locations on that road are listed by how far they can be found from the entrance. For example, the visitor center is at Mile 1.5 (meaning it is 1.5 miles from the entrance). 

The Denali Visitor Center is generally open from mid-May to mid-September. Visitors coming in fall, winter, or spring should stop by the Murie Science & Learning Center, located near the Denali Visitor Center.

A number of trails can be found from the visitor center. If you wish to hike, pick up a trail map and speak with a ranger about what sort of hike you'd enjoy and get a recommendation or two.
Denali Park Headquarters is a cultural landscape and historic district. It's also a short walk from the HQ parking lot down to the sled dog kennels!

Denali is the only national park in America to be home to a kennel of sled dogs! 

Rangers and dogs work together to protect the wild nature of Denali. Much of the park is closed to motorized vehicles, so in winter, sled dogs provide a means for rangers to travel, and to establish recreational trails for hardy winter visitors who wish to ski or run their own sled dog teams in the park. 

In summer, the dogs stay busy, welcoming hundreds of thousands of visitors to the kennels. Visitors can attend a regularly-scheduled ranger program, or just stop by to pet a few dogs and take a few photos.

Mountain Vista offers views of North America's tallest mountain, as well as two trail choices. 

The Mountain Vista Loop trail is a very easy, short loop through spruce trees just downhill from the parking lot. 

The Savage Alpine Trail is much more strenuous, traveling uphill from the parking area to a low peak on Healy Ridge, before descending steeply to Savage River. From Savage River, in summer, visitors can use a free bus to travel back to Mountain Vista. If hiking the trail outside of the main summer season, visitors must be prepared to walk a few miles back along the Denali Park Road from Savage River to Mountain Vista.

Savage River, Mile 15, is the furthest point into the park that a visitor may drive during a normal summer season (roughly May 20 to mid-September). 

The area itself is a great example of how geologic forces shape the landscape. 

Look down-river, and you'll see a very narrow canyon, or v-shaped valley, as the river carves its way through the outer range. This indicates that the force of the river alone has carved the valley downstream.

Look up-river, and the landscape is a broad, rolling plain, leading up to steep mountains. Long ago, a glacier flowing out from the Alaska Range created this u-shaped valley, with the massive weight and size of the ice smooshing the landscape into its current form.

Not far from this picnic spot, the park's first superintendent—Harry Karstens—established the original park headquarters in the 1920s. 

Not long thereafter, Harry realized this area along Riley Creek is a cold hole. In the winter, it's not unusual for Riley Creek to be twenty or more degrees colder than the hillsides. To everyone's benefit, past and present, Harry moved the park headquarters up to its current location, on "Government Hill." 

Riley Creek remains scenic, however, and is a great spot to stretch your legs or enjoy a picnic, if you brought food with you.

The road ends at the Kennicott River footbridge, where you can walk, bike or take a shuttle 5 miles further to the Kennecott Mines National Historic Landmark.

data.description: The unpaved Nabesna Road stretches for 42 scenic miles, and it is much the same today as it was when it was built back in 1934 to transport gold from the mines. Generally, the Nabesna Road is passable by any two-wheel drive vehicle. But especially after it has rained, stream crossings may become impassable. At times, the road is rough and you may need a four wheel drive vehicle. Please be cautious and take care, as there may be uneven surfaces, potholes, and washouts present.

stops.significance:
This visitor center is perfectly located for those coming from / to Grants Pass, Oregon. Outside is a mural, picnic tables, plenty of parking, and a short interpretive trail about trees and plants.
Inside are exhibits about Tolowa people, park history, ecology as well as the 10-minute park orientation film. A sales store is located inside. Park information, visitor guide newspapers, back country permits, and junior ranger booklets are provided by park rangers.

To see the heart of the redwood forests you have to drive this. Stunning old-growth trees and many trails are found along this famous 9-mile long road. The parkway is named after a man who during his conservation career was responsible for 125,000 acres of redwoods being protected - that is almost half of the old-growth redwoods that remain today.

A five-minute walk on a fully accessible path leads to trees more than 300-foot tall. The "Big Tree" has interpretive exhibits about the Yurok culture, forest ecology, and it leads to other walking trails.

Just a few minutes off HWY 101, this short hike leads to some small waterfalls surrounded by old-growth redwood trees, maples, and hemlocks.  This is consider by many staff as the best little hike we offer.

data.description: This driving tour will take you through ten stops related to the Battle of Brices Cross Roads. Federal Army Major General William T. Sherman ordered Brig. Gen. Samuel D. Sturgis and a force of 8,100 to move out of Memphis and threaten north Mississippi in hopes of drawing Confederate General Nathan B. Forrest away from Sherman’s much needed railroad in Tennessee. The soldiers of Sturgis and Forrest met at Brices Cross Roads June 10, 1864.

data.description: The Castolon Historic District represents the largest and most complete example of human history in Big Bend, from Paleo-Indians to pioneers, to the establishment of the national park. Castolon’s history includes famed tales of bandits, soldiers, farmers, and ranchers, in a place where the cultures of Mexico and the United States meet. This tour will help you explore Castolon’s past through an eight-mile (one-way) driving tour from Castolon to Santa Elena Canyon.

data.description: The 16-mile Katahdin Loop Road in Katahdin Woods and Waters National Monument offers spectacular views of Mount Katahdin in neighboring Baxter State Park while exploring the cultural, biological, and geological features of significance in the monument.

images.altText: Mount Katahdin framed by vivid red, orange and yellow fall foliage.
images.caption: View of Mount Katahdin from Katahdin Loop Road
images.title: Loop Road View of Mount Katahdin

park.fullName: Katahdin Woods and Waters National Monument
park.name: Katahdin Woods and Waters

stops.significance: The entrance gate is situated between a section of glacial esker and a mixed shrub marsh. Combined with the spruce forest you just passed through, this area is particularly rich in biological diversity. To explore this area further continue 0.3 miles past the gate to the first road on your right where you will find an abandoned gravel pit and a rustic unimproved parking area.
Just past mile marker 1 a small pullout on the left provides a first view of almost mile-high Katahdin at 5,267 feet above sea level in nearby Baxter State Park.

The path to Lynx Pond is on the opposite side of the road just before the parking area. This small pond, surrounded by a nutrient-poor Leatherleaf Boggy Fen, is home to a resident belted kingfisher that rattles as he flies about defending his territory. Carnivorous pitcher plans grow in the bog mat along the edge of the pond. When insects investigate the pitcher-shaped structure that holds water, they meet a watery demise. The plant dissolves the insect and uses it for food. Moose often feed on the opposite shore. Canada geese, and ring-necked and common goldeneye ducks are known nesters. Boreal bird species of note including black-backed woodpecker, rusty blackbird, Canada warbler, and Wilson's warbler have been recorded here.

Walk a short distance along the roadside to where a Spruce-Fir-Cinnamon Fern Forest containing wild azalea (Rhodora) and swamp maple as well as a variety of other ferns and bog plants can be viewed from either side of the road. Listen and watch for alder flycatcher, magnolia, palm and Canada warblers, hermit thrush, swamp and white-throated sparrows.
stops.assetName: Mile 3.2 Katahdin Loop Road-Black Spruce Bog

stops.significance: Turn left to reach the scenic overlook with its expansive views. It is a great place for a picnic lunch. Millinocket Lake (meaning "many islands") is the large body of water to your left. Mud Brook Flowage and the Sandy Stream valley flow out from surrounding mountains. The forests before you are a transitional deciduous northern hardwood and boreal spruce-fir mix-a type that does not exist anywhere else in the National Park System. Mountain tops are dominated by spruce-fir with lowland valleys full of colorful northern hardwoods. Historically, in addition to lumber-wood carvings, chips, mulch, charcoal, syrups, oils, gums, and extracts have been produced from these forests.

Just before mile marker 12 is parking for the International Appalachian Trail (IAT) and Barnard Mountain Trail. Park away from the gate ensuring access for logging equipment. 

The IAT continues the Appalachian Trail that runs from Georgia to Maine. The IAT follows the ancient Appalachian Mountains, created far back in geologic time and now separated by the North Atlantic Ocean. The ancient mountain chain was built when continental plates drifted together to form a single continent, Pangaea, or "all land." Parts of those plates began to drift apart more than 200 million years ago, and now form North America, Europe, and Africa. The IAT links traces of these mountains around the arc of the North Atlantic. The section of the trail that runs through Maine starts here and continues through the monument for 30 miles, to continue another 100 miles to Fort Fairfield, Maine, and then on into Canada, Greenland, and Europe, ending in Morocco.
stops.assetName: International Appalachian Trail / Barnard Mountain Trailhead

stops.significance: The hike to Barnard Mountain beings on a brief section of the International Appalachian Trail, for about 1.5 miles up the gravel logging road frequented by moose, bear, mountain bikes, hikers, and occasionally logging trucks carrying wood harvested from adjacent lands. Within the first few minutes of the hike you will cross Katahdin Brook and pass the first IAT campsite. Continue up the long hill and the trailhead sign will be on your right. This first portion of the trail can be biked as well as hiked. From here you leave the logging road and hike through a section of thick young hardwoods before ascending through a mature softwood forest over switchbacks and stone steps built in 2014 by the Maine Conservation Corps. Bring your lunch and enjoy the views from the top. Watch for moose signs near the summit where they hang out in the cool breezes of summer.
At the Orin Falls Gate, located at approximately mile 15.5 on the Katahdin Loop Road, you have the option to turn onto the road leading to the Wassataquoik Gate and start of the hike to Orin Falls.

Wassataquoik Gate is the starting point for hikes to Orin Falls, Barnard Mountain and Deasey Mountain. This is also an access point and parking area for Esker and Wassataquoik campsites and Wassataquoik Lean-to.

Orin Falls is a 6-mile round-trip hike (or bike) for families and fishing enthusiasts looking to access Wassataquoik Stream, which is translated as "place where they spear fish." Most of the trail is a former logging road that is wide and avoids steep slopes. A portion of the International Appalachian Trail (IAT) also follows the same path for a short distance. The trail begins by following a glacial esker above Wassataquoik Stream before dropping to cross a bridge over Katahdin Brook (the outflow from Katahdin Lake inside Baxter State Park). Just beyond the bridge there is a large campsite as well as a lean-to shelter. The trail passes through a section of Hardwood River Terrace Forest where the lush carpet of herbs below changes from spring ephemerals such as trillium and trout lily to dense fern cover in summer. Continue going straight at the next junction where the IAT heads left towards Barnard Mountain.

images.altText: A group of living history specialist in Union army uniforms demonstrate firing rifles.
images.caption: Monocacy National Battlefield commemorates the July 9, 1864, battle "that saved Washington."
images.title: Living History at Monocacy

stops.significance: Around 7:30 a.m. on July 9, 1864, Confederate troops marched from Frederick down the Georgetown Pike (Urbana Pike or Route 355) towards Washington, DC. The expected to find a small unit of untrained 100-day men guarding the bridge over the Monocacy River. The confrontation turned into an all day fight that cost the Union 1,300 men and the Confederates time and the element of surprise.

Confederates outnumbered and out gunned their Union adversaries almost three to one. After the initial small arms skirmishes between the advance Confederates, Confederate guns were set up across the Best Farms to try to tame Union forces.

As Early's troops advanced south toward Washington on the morning of July 9, 1864, along the Georgetown Pike (now MD 355) they met stiff resistance from Union skirmishers waiting at Monocacy Junction. The Confederates set up artillery at the Best Farm and opened fire on the junction. Union artillery across the river responded.

Confederate cavalry crossed the Monocacy mid morning at the Worthington Ford. They dismounted and formed for attack on the fields behind the Worthington House. As they marched toward the Thomas Farm, they ran into a well-concealed Union line positioned behind a fence. The Federals opened fire, driving the Confederates back. The Confederates launched a second attack and took the Thomas House. The outflanked Federals fell back, attacked and drove the Confederates back to the Worthington Farm.

Caught between the two armies, the Thomas House became the focal point of the battle, as Confederates on the Worthington Farm and Federals on the Thomas Farm faced off in the most furious fighting of the day. Confederate artillery pummeled the house with shells to drive off the Union sharpshooters. Throughout the afternoon, the house was captured and recaptured as the battle line moved back and forth across the Thomas Farm.

Araby Church Road follows the path of the original route of the Georgetown Pike. It was here that Federal forces rallied and pushed back to retake the Thomas House. It was from here that they were forced to retreat after a fierce day of fighting.

Built in 1830, Gambrill Mill was run by an interior undershot water wheel. The mill could produce 60 barrels of flour a day and kept two coopers busy producing barrels for its products. During the battle Union troops used the mill as a field hospital. Wallace later noted, "The place appeared well selected for the purpose, its one inconvenience being that it was under fire."

data.description: Ross Maxwell Scenic Drive highlights the geologic splendor of Big Bend by offering 30 miles of overlooks, informative exhibits, and trailheads. Highlights include Sotol Vista, Mule Ears Overlook, and Santa Elena Canyon. In addition, exhibits and trails at locations such as Sam Nail Ranch, Homer Wilson Ranch, and Castolon provide insight into the lives of Big Bend's early pioneers. This drive begins at the turnoff located 13 miles east of Maverick Entrance Station, or 13 miles west of Panther Junction.

data.description: Take a short 2 stop driving tour and learn about the Battle of Tupelo that took place in and around Tupelo, Mississippi July 14th and 15th, 1864.

images.altText: Granite monument commemorating the Battle of Tupelo with civil war cannons flanking each side
images.caption: Tupelo National Battlefield Monument
images.title: Tupelo National Battlefield Monument

stops.significance: On the morning of July 14, the Battle of Tupelo began at 7:30 a.m. when the Confederates began a series of uncoordinated charges against the Federal position. These attacks were beaten back with heavy losses to the Confederates. Failing to break the Federal center, the Confederates attacked the Federal right again without success. After dark, the Confederates made another attack from the south without significant effect. Although his troops had repulsed several Confederate attacks, Federal General Andrew Jackson Smith ordered his men back towards Memphis. His army would engage the Confederate forces several miles outside of town on July 15, 1864 at what is called the Battle of Old Town Creek.

At 2 p.m. on July 15, 1864, after skirmishing with Confederates on the western and southern fronts, the Federals began marching north in the direction of Memphis. They marched four miles and crossed to the north side of Old Town Creek and camped in the late afternoon. At 5 p.m., from a commanding ridge south of Old Town Creek, Confederate forces surprised Smith’s troops with artillery and infantry fire. The Federals scrambled and formed a line that pushed the Confederates off the ridge and forced them to retreat to Harrisburg. The fight at Old Town Creek ended the Battle of Tupelo. Among the casualties was Forrest himself, who was kept out of action for three weeks.
stops.assetName: Battle of Old Town Creek July 15, 1864

data.description: The 8 stop driving tour will take you from one end of the park to the other. Each stop will discuss important events and individuals related to the battle that was fought on these grounds.

stops.significance: This introduction will explain how the American War of Independence could start in New England in 1775, but shift so that two major armies end up in the backcountry of North Carolina in 1781.
stops.assetName: Visitor Center and Beginning of Guilford Courthouse Auto Tour

stops.significance: The Hoskins Farm is where the British Army deployed for battle in the late morning of March 15, 1781. From here, the visitor will follow in the footsteps of the British army through the battlefield.
stops.assetName: Hoskins Farm Entrance and British Deployment Area

stops.significance: The Crown Forces Monument commemorates all the individuals who served with the British at this battle. It also helps mark where the British army had advanced to when the North Carolina militia fired at them and started the battle in earnest.
At the south end of the American Second line, Edward Stevens' brigade held on the longest while the ends of the line crumbled under the British attack.
stops.assetName: South End of the American 2nd Line

stops.significance: The "seperate fight" that erupts at Guilford Courthouse sees 1/4 of the British army engaged in a confused fight in the woods, and drawn away from their main effort to break the American third line which is positioned a 1/2 mile away at the court house site.
This spot will help people see how interpretation of the battle has evolved over time. Monuments are left in their original, erroneous, placements to help illustrate the park's evolution.
stops.assetName: Cavalry Monument and old third line

stops.significance: This is both the former site of the Guilford court house and the site of where the battle reached its zenith. The 2nd Battalion of Guards nearly roll up the American third line before being devastated by a counterattack of American infantry and cavalry.
stops.assetName: Auto Tour Stop 6 at the American Third Line

stops.significance: This site is a perfect place to explore some of the monuments associated with the fighting at the third line. The monuments remain in their original locations when the third line was though to be at tour stop 7.
This is the location of the Nathanael Greene Monument and the Signers Monument. It is also the north end of the American Second Line.
