data.description: The Encampment Tour route consists of 9 major tour stops along a 10-mile driving route. This self-guided tour takes you to many historic monuments and sites and past some of the most scenic views of the park.

images.altText: an illustration of a vehicle driving past the national memorial arch
images.caption: Drive in your own vehicle to see monuments, buildings, and historic locations at Valley Forge.
images.title: Driving Tour: Valley Forge Encampment

stops.significance:
Stop 1 on the Encampment Tour route, the Visitor Center at Valley Forge is home to The Encampment Store and the Valley Forge Tourism & Convention Board travel information desk.

This is a great place to talk to a ranger and prepare for a day at the park!

Muhlenberg's Brigade is the site of the encampment of the Virginia troops led by Brigadier General Peter Muhlenberg during the encampment of the Continental Army in 1777-78. Today, the site features nine reconstructed log huts and is the home of the park's living history programming.

The United States National Memorial Arch was erected in the early part of the 20th century to commemorate the arrival and the sacrifices of General George Washington and the Continental Army at Valley Forge during the American Revolution.

The Anthony Wayne Monument is located in a grassy area surrounded by trees and facing Wayne’s home in Chester County. The bronze statue, supported by a large rectangular base of pink granite, features General Wayne on horseback, emphasizing his role in the military. The north side of the pedestal lists the many roles that Wayne filled during his lifetime.

Washington's Headquarters, also known as the Isaac Potts House, is the structure used by General George Washington and his household during the 1777-1778 encampment of the Continental Army at Valley Forge.

At the time of the encampment, the house was being rented by a relative of Isaac Potts, Deborah Hewes. Mrs. Hewes, in turn, rented the entire house along with some furnishings to the General and his military family.

Redoubt 3 is the site of a partially reconstructed earthworks fortification originally constructed by Continental troops during the encampment and designed to help defend the camp from potential attack from the south.

During the Valley Forge encampment, Artillery Park was the central location used to keep cannons at the ready in case of a British attack. If there was a threat, the artillery crew could hear the alarm call made with fife and drum from anywhere within the encampment and mobilize the weapons.

The bronze statue of Friedrich Wilhelm August Heinrich Ferdinand de Steuben, known as Baron von Steuben, overlooks the Grand Parade at Valley Forge. It was erected in 1915 by the National German American Alliance during a time of rampant anti-German sentiment in the United States.

The Patriots of African Descent monument, one of the newest Revolutionary War monuments in a National Park, was erected in 1993 through the efforts of the Valley Forge Alumnae Chapter of Delta Sigma Theta Sorority, Inc. It is also the only site in the Northeast that honors African Americans’ contributions to the founding of our nation.

data.title: Driving Tour: The Valley Forge Encampment

stops.significance: Start your day with a stop at the Blue Ridge Parkway Visitor Center in Asheville. Get Parkway maps and information, check out the exhibits, watch the park movie, and get advice and current conditions from staff.
The Folk Art Center highlights the crafts of the Southern Appalachians. It's a great place to see exhibits and galleries, craft demonstrations, and shop at an amazing craft shop.
Tanbark Ridge Overlook is the first overlook north of Asheville that really gives you the feeling of being in the mountains and away from civilization.
Tunnels are iconic features of the Blue Ridge Parkway. Enjoy the drive through this one or make a quick stop to safety take a picture.

Lane Pinnacle is one of those overlooks that blows you away on a clear day. You feel like you are on top of the world and can see for miles. You have gained significant elevation since the start of your journey, so the air feels cooler and crisper.

The Craggy Gardens Picnic Area is great spot for a lunch break. And even if you aren't eating, it's worth a drive through this scenic spot to look for wildlife and colorful blooms along the road and throughout the picnic grounds.

The visitor center is the epicenter of Craggy Gardens. Information, exhibits, souvenirs, and restrooms can be found in the building. Great views are waiting for you on both sides of the Parkway. Access to the Craggy Gardens Trail is at the southern end of the parking lot.
A stop at the Glassmine Falls Overlook gives you the chance to see this seasonal waterfall from a distance.

Mount Mitchell is the highest point east of the Mississippi River at 6,684 feet. Operated as a state park accessible via the Parkway, you can drive almost to the top and then walk on a paved path to the summit.

data.title: Driving the Parkway North from Asheville

data.description: When you explore the Parkway south from Asheville, you will experience an abundance of high elevation scenic overlooks, vistas, and tunnels as well as have the opportunity to hike, picnic, and camp.

images.altText: Mountains with sunlight illuminating bare rock face
images.caption: View of Looking Glass Rock
images.title: Looking Glass Rock

stops.significance: Start your day with a stop at the Blue Ridge Parkway Visitor Center in Asheville. Get Parkway maps and information, check out the exhibits, watch the park movie, and get advice and current conditions from staff.
After driving through the Asheville Valley, stop for a moment to appreciate the ancient and historic French Broad River before you begin your climb to higher elevations.
Mills River is one of the rare overlooks with expansive views on both sides of the Parkway. It's a great spot to take a break from driving or to catch a sunset.
Buck Spring Gap Overlook is the gateway to another world. It's a glimpse into the extravagant and elegant world of the Vanderbilts of Biltmore Estate fame.
Although the Buck Spring Lodge is no longer standing, you can still appreciate its amenities and innovations that were ahead of their time.
Lunch time!  Enjoy this peaceful picnic area for your meal. If you need supplies, the Pisgah Inn has a restaurant and country store just 1 mile south.
If you are a camper, it's hard to beat the Mount Pisgah Campground. Its high elevation keeps things cool and the peaceful wooded campsites are perfect for relaxing and unwinding.

Look to your right from this overlook. You will be getting one of the first views of the iconic Looking Glass Rock, a granite monolith that rises out of the forest. This landmark will be visible from varying vantage points as you continue south.

Devils Courthouse is a great place to take a short (but steep!) hike to a rock outcrop for 360 degree views. Keep your eyes open for peregrine falcons that frequent the area and appreciate the unique and rare habitat that surrounds you.

data.title: Driving the Parkway South from Asheville

data.description: Are you only passing through the Badlands? This tour takes you off the freeway and through the main highway of the park. You'll begin by stopping by one of our stunning overlooks and then taking a short 1.5 mile hike along Notch Trail. From there, you'll head to the visitor center and then drive the famous loop road with several overlooks marked along the way.

images.altText: A brightly lit green field with badlands formations in horizon under blue sky.
images.caption: The Badlands is nearly 250,000 acres of natural and cultural significance.
images.title: Welcome to the Badlands

stops.significance: This is one of the main entrance stations to the park. You can pay your entrance fee, purchase passes, or inquire about military and access passes at these stations. They also provide logistical information, such as maps and guides.
Big Badlands Overlook provides the opportunity to view the eastern portion of the Badlands wall.

This is the most popular trail in the Badlands. It is 1.5 miles, round trip, with a moderate difficulty rating. If you would like to do something less strenuous, there are two other trail options available at this stop.

The Visitor Center is named after Ben Reifel, the first American Indian to serve in Congress. Ben Reifel was an enrolled member of the Rosebud Sioux Tribe.

The visitor center provides interpretive information, fully accessible restrooms, picnic tables, and a gift shop operated by Badlands Natural History Association.

Aside from being an impressive geologic vista, Big Foot Pass is also a historic area which marks the route of Chief Spotted Elk on his way to Wounded Knee.

There are several picnic tables and restrooms available at this site.
Yellow Mounds Overlook is a great place to get a look at older Badlands geology in the form of brightly colored rock layers.

Pinnacles Overlook is the highest elevation in the North Unit, making it a popular stop on the Loop Road. It offers one of the best views of the park. The Black Hills are visible on the horizon.

Bighorn sheep are often spotted near this location.

This is one of the main entrance stations to the park. You can pay your entrance fee, purchase passes, or inquire about military and access passes at these stations. They also provide logistical information, such as maps and guides.

data.description: An audio tour through the Dungeness Historic District has nine stops and describes the island's rich human history spanning thousands of years.

images.altText: The brick and stonr ruins of a mansion are lit up by the evening sun with patchy clouds behind.
images.caption: The Dungeness Ruins stand guard over the south end of the island.
images.title: Dungeness Ruins

stops.significance: This stop describes the Native people that lived on the island and used it's resources.
This stop describes the many uses of the live oak tree and how the island's forests have changed over time.
This stop describes life for the many enslaved individuals during the plantation era.
There have been several Dungeness mansions built at this location. Learn who built them and what happened to these grand buildings.
The tabby house is the oldest standing structure on the island. Learn how it has been used over the past 200 years.
The ruins of the recreation house speak to the many activities the Carnegie family participated in while visiting the island.
It took many people to run the Dungeness estate. Learn about the business manager and how he managed the estate.
The village is where all the employees lived while working on the island.
The Greene-Miller Cemetery contains the resting places of the Greene/Miller family as well as a memorial marker to Henry "Light-horse Harry" Lee.

data.description: On July 3rd, 1863, Union Cavalry were sent east of town to prevent Confederate Cavalry from attacking the Union right flank. This tour will cover the action between J.E.B Stuart's Cavalry and Union Cavalry under the command of Brigadier General George Custer and Brigadier General David Gregg.

images.altText: A stone monument in an open field
images.caption: the 1st Maine Cavalry Monument in East Cavalry Battlefield
images.title: 1st Maine Cavalry Monument

stops.significance:
On July 3, 1863, in an effort to protect the Confederate left flank, Confederate Maj. Gen. J.E.B. Stuart led his Cavalry troops from near Hunterstown to a position near the York Road. The area today known as East Cavalry Field.

On the morning of July 3, this ground was occupied by a brigade of four Michigan regiments and a battery of horse artillery under the command of newly promoted Brig. Gen. George A. Custer. After a battle at Hunterstown the previous evening, Custer had been ordered to this position to protect the right flank of the Union army at Gettysburg and secure the important intersection of the Low Dutch and Hanover Roads just off to your right. Custer’s four regiments were soon reinforced by the arrival of Brig. Gen. David M. Gregg’s Second Cavalry Division, which took position on Custer’s left along the Hanover Road.

Discovering no sign of Stuart, the 1st NJ Cavalry moved forward around 2 pm from the Lott House to this position to investigate Rummel’s Woods. This wooded area is beyond the stone farmhouse to your right front. Within moments, dismounted Confederates from Brig. Gen. Albert Jenkins’ Virginia Brigade appeared from behind
the Rummel house and barn, formed a line and opened fire.

Federal reinforcements from McIntosh’s Brigade joined the NJ men and extended the line of battle to the left (across the road) and right of the monument. Soon the Union troops exhausted their ammunition and began to withdraw. They were replaced by the 5th MI Cavalry from Custer’s Brigade armed with new 7-shot repeating rifles. Custer, disregarding his previous orders, obeyed Gregg’s order to stay when the fighting began.

From this commanding position on Cress Ridge, General Stuart prepared his cavalry and artillery to attack Gregg’s and Custer’s position. Stuart arranged his 19 regiments, numbering 5,000 in a line behind and to the northeast of Rummel’s Woods to keep them hidden from enemy scouts.

On this stretch of open ground halfway between the opposing lines, the last charge by Lee’s and Hampton’s 3,600 horsemen was defeated. As the compact lines of horsemen crossed these fields heading for the Union positions along the Hanover Road (Stop 2), they were attacked on 3 sides by McIntosh’s and Custer’s 3,200 men.

data.title: East Cavalry Battlefield Auto Tour at Gettysburg

data.description: This four-mile driving tour of the Eastern Front has eight stops and some short, interpretive walking trails. The initial assaults that failed to capture the city and the encounters that followed shaped the siege’s history on the Eastern Front. Soldiers along this front suffered in trenches under constant artillery and rifle fire in lines only yards and sometimes feet apart. Nowhere else along the siege lines were the opposing armies this close.

images.altText: A paved road cuts through a green grass field, with a few trees with yellow leaves, the rest green.
images.caption: The Eastern Front Tour Road offers views throughout the year, in each season.

data.description: In 1950—after 34 years of marriage and dozens of moves—the Eisenhowers finally found a place they could call home. Gettysburg, Pennsylvania had loomed large in the life of Dwight David Eisenhower for decades. We invite you to explore the only property that they ever owned in their long and eventful lives together.  This 20-stop walking tour will guide you through the Eisenhower farm and some of Eisenhower's favorite locations on the property.

images.altText: A black and white aerial view of the Eisenhower farm.
images.caption: The house is on the right, the guesthouse in center, and the bank barn on the left
images.title: The Eisenhowers in Gettysburg

stops.significance:
In 1950—after 34 years of marriage and dozens of moves—the Eisenhowers finally found a place they could call home. Dwight D. Eisenhower first came to Gettysburg with his West Point class. Later, the 27-year-old Eisenhower was assigned the command of Camp Colt, the U.S. Army tank training camp in the middle of the Gettysburg battlefield. 

Decades after Camp Colt, Eisenhower was returning to Gettysburg a much different person. He was the victorious 5-star general who oversaw the Allied victory in Europe during World War II. Ike and his wife Mamie purchased the property for $44,000, dreaming of a peaceful and tranquil retirement.  

Soon after buying the farm, Eisenhower became the Supreme Commander of NATO forces. The following year, he left that role to run for the presidency. Over his two terms, this home would be a central part of the Eisenhowers' lives.

Finally, in 1961, 11 years after buying their farm, the Eisenhowers left the White House and, at long last, had their retirement home of their dreams.
A beautiful and scenic pathway, the tree lined allee was the main entrance to the property, providing privacy and serenity for the Eisenhowers and their guests.
This former milk house was used as an office space by agents of the United States Secret Service during Eisenhower’s presidency and retirement.
This building was originally used as a storage and garage area. Since 1980 it has welcomed visitors as the Eisenhower National Historic Site Reception Center.
General Eisenhower enjoyed skeet and trap shooting here. The range was used primarily during his presidential years.
This 19th century barn is the oldest standing structure on the Eisenhower farm. Used initially for dairy cows, General Eisenhower used it for stables and storing farm equipment.

Originally a small garage, the Eisenhowers converted this building into a guesthouse in 1955. The home features a bedroom, a small bathroom, and a sitting room, with a porch offering tremendous views of the surrounding area.
Formerly a chicken coop, this area was used as a garage during the Eisenhower’s time here. Today, exhibits show several vehicles used by the Eisenhowers during the 1950s and 1960s.

President Eisenhower was the first president to use a helicopter during his time in office. This mowed area served as a landing pad for the President and his guests when they landed at the Gettysburg farm.
General Eisenhower was widely known for his love for the game of golf. He practiced his putting and chipping here at his personal putting green.
The fields around the flagpole east of the Eisenhower home saw many uses, including gathering spaces for political events and luncheons at the farm during Eisenhower’s presidency and retirement.
Roses were a favorite flower of both General and Mrs. Eisenhower. Historic documentation shows that roses were always intended to decorate the landscape around the Eisenhower home.
The Eisenhowers thoroughly enjoyed entertaining guests at this serene setting. Pictured here is a White House picnic on July 1, 1959.

The Eisenhowers used the gardens and greenhouses during both the presidential and retirement years as a source of fresh produce and enjoyment. This photograph, taken in May 1969, provides a view of the Eisenhower gardens, greenhouses, and a playhouse for the grandchildren.
This was the home of the head herdsman of the Eisenhower cattle herd. Today, it is the headquarters for the staff of the Eisenhower National Historic Site.
The Show Barn housed the president’s prize-winning cattle. President Eisenhower brought many world leaders here to show his cattle herd and conduct informal diplomacy.

data.description: This self-guided audio tour of Val-Kill is part of the Hyde Park Explorer Series. Walk the grounds and hear the stories of this place. Wife, mother, grandmother; Hyde Park neighbor, activist, and diplomat—get to know Eleanor Roosevelt as you hike the paths she walked daily for recreation and contemplation. See the historic buildings that hosted family gatherings as well as powerful dialog among national leaders. Explore the woodland trails that inspired many of Eleanor’s famous My Day columns.

images.altText: Eleanor Roosevelt walks her dog along a path.
images.caption: Eleanor Roosevelt walking her dog, Fala, at Val-Kill.
images.credit: Photo by Dr. A. David Gurewitsch
images.title: Eleanor's Walk

stops.significance: Val-Kill established itself as the gathering and recreation place for the Roosevelt family. The Roosevelts enjoyed outdoor activities, and Val Kill offered plenty of opportunities—tennis, horseback riding, swimming, and hiking on wooded trails.
Stopping here for a moment gives you an opportunity to view the historic core of her former property, buildings with great stories to tell!

data.description: Welcome to Ellwood! Explore the history of these grounds from the land's inhabitation by the Manahoac people to its transformation into a slave plantation. Discover how Ellwood went from being a place over which Civil War soldiers fought and died to a site that preserves the memory of past conflicts. What does this landscape teach us today? What stories are hidden from view?

images.altText: A brown sign directing to a path leading to a red house.
images.caption: Explore the history of Ellwood on this audio walking tour.
images.title: Ellwood Walking Tour

stops.significance:
Welcome to the Ellwood Audio Walking Tour. If you are onsite during the hours the house is open, you can begin this tour in the parking lot. If you are onsite when the house is closed, you can park outside the gate (please do not block the gate) and walk 0.4 miles up the driveway to the parking area.

First constructed in the 1700s, Ellwood is best known for its association with the Battles of Chancellorsville and the Wilderness during the Civil War. This tour explores the history of Ellwood from its initial development through its preservation by the National Park Service. 

Here in the parking lot, learn about the people who first inhabited this land and the ways that colonial settlement altered the physical landscape.

During the late 1700s, the Jones family funded the construction of Ellwood Plantation here in the Wilderness. This tour stop will explore what life was like at Ellwood during the Antebellum period. How did the lives of enslaved people differ from the lives of the Jones and Lacy families? What physical reminders of slavery remain on the landscape today?

Located in the Wilderness region, Ellwood Plantation became the site of a Confederate hospital and a U.S. headquarters during the Civil War. How were civilians impacted by the battles that took place in the Wilderness? What did the landscape around Ellwood look like at the war’s end?

After the Civil War, life at Ellwood changed drastically. The Lacy family returned home and worked to memorialize the Confederacy. Through the work of former Confederates like the Lacys, Ellwood’s family cemetery became a tourist attraction. Today, the burial site of Thomas “Stonewall” Jackson’s arm is one of the most recognizable features of Ellwood. What does the family cemetery and the burial of Jackson’s arm tell us about how our nation remembers the Civil War?

In 1907, the Lacy family sold Ellwood, which ushered in a period of great change. The final owners of Ellwood transformed the former plantation into a modern farm. How did the surrounding region change during the 20th century? What steps did the National Park Service take to preserve Ellwood when the surrounding area was developing rapidly? How should we manage Ellwood today?

data.title: Ellwood Walking Tour

data.description: Find the useful plants of Glacier Bay and Bartlett Cove! The Tlingit have called Glacier Bay home since time immemorial. Learn the Tlingit words for the many edible and useful plants found in Glacier Bay. Tour starts at the Whale 68 (Snow) exhibit, but can be started at the far end of the Tlingit trail and completed in reverse. CAUTION: Glacier Bay is home to several inedible or dangerous plants. Do not consume wild plants unless you are certain it is safe to eat.

images.altText: Hands holding a bowl of wild strawberries. Strawberry plants are visible on the ground beneath.
images.caption: Glacier Bay is home to many edible and usable plants
images.title: Strawberry collection

stops.significance:
Welcome to the Bartlett Cove Ethnobotany tour! Along the gravel path known as the Tlingit Trail, (parallels the beach in Bartlett Cove) you will find signage explaining what native plants grow nearby, as well as the Tlingit word used to describe them. The Huna Tlingit have called Glacier Bay homeland since time immemorial, and continue to return here to harvest plants to this day. 

Press 'explore...' to read the text of each given sign online.
stops.assetName: Keishísh - Sitka Alder - Glacier Bay Ethnobotany

stops.significance: Sitka spruce are tied into the fabric of Huna Tlingit culture, and are valued for their many uses.
stops.assetName: Shéiyi - Sitka Spruce - Glacier Bay Ethnobotany

stops.significance: Its stalks are similar to celery, cow parsnip is one of several plants in Southeast Alaska to be wary of. Close contact combined with sun exposure can lead to painful skin irritation.
stops.assetName: Yaana.eit - Cow Parsnip - Glacier Bay Ethnobotany

stops.significance: With its infamous name, devil's club sounds like a plant to avoid. And while its prickly thorns should emphasize that point, the plant itself has countless uses to knowledgeable harvesters.
stops.assetName: S’áxt’ - Devil's Club - Glacier Bay Ethnobotany

stops.significance: One of the first flowering plants in Glacier Bay every year, the early blueberry plant produces tender bright-colored flowers each spring, attracting early insect arrivals and rufous hummingbirds.
stops.assetName: Kanat’á - Early Blueberry - Glacier Bay Ethnobotany

stops.significance: Glacier Bay's neighboring town of Gustavus was originally known as "Strawberry Point" due to the numerous wild strawberries growing on its beaches. Wild strawberries are still found in this region, becoming ripe each July/August.
stops.assetName: Shákw - Beach Strawberry - Glacier Bay Ethnobotany

stops.significance: These raspberry-like fruits are prized berries in Southeast Alaska. Visit in mid-late July to pick them at their ripest!
The fiddlehead fern is a key ingredient in the Southeast Alaskan rainforest. Did you know they are edible at a stage in their growth? Press 'explore...' to read the text of the fiddlehead fern sign.
stops.assetName: K’wálx - Fiddlehead Ferns - Glacier Bay Ethnobotany

stops.significance: One of several varieties of currants found in Glacier Bay gray currants offer a different flavor to pair with the many berry varieties found in this region.
stops.assetName: Shaax - Gray Currants - Glacier Bay Ethnobotany

stops.significance: Perhaps as meaningful as the Sitka Spruce, the Western Hemlock is another tree with a significant presence in Tlingit culture and history. Press 'explore...' to see the sign's text online.
stops.assetName: Yán - Western Hemlock - Glacier Bay Ethnobotany

stops.significance: Try giving the Chocolate Lily's flower a sniff and you might wonder where it got its name! And while the plant does not produce berries, its bulb can be harvested and eaten.
stops.assetName: Kóox - Chocolate Lily - Glacier Bay Ethnobotany

stops.significance: The thimbleberry is another delicious fruit found in many places throughout Glacier Bay. Paired with strawberries, nagoonberries, huckleberries, blueberries, and more, the thimbleberry adds a touch of sweetness to the mix. Press 'explore' to see this sign's text online.

data.title: Ethnobotany Walk in Bartlett Cove

data.description: The Brown's Farm Trail is a mostly flat, half-mile loop trail that passes through several different forest ecosystems and the remains of an early 1900s farmstead.

images.altText: A small wooden bridge crossing a stream through a green forest with a phone overlain on the image.
images.caption: The Brown's Farm Trail provides a peaceful walk through the mountains diverse forest ecosystems.
images.title: Brown's Farm Trail

stops.significance:
If you have parked at the Owens Creek Picnic Area, you will be able to access the Brown's Farm Nature Trail Loop. This mostly flat, half-mile loop trail will be marked by a white, triangle blaze passing through several different forest ecosystems and the remains of an early 1900s farmstead. 

Parking at the Owens Creek Picnic Area is open seasonally from early spring through late fall. Year-round parking is available at Camp Round Meadow, with the Brown's Farm Trail's southern trailhead linking to the nature loop after a half-mile hike.

The trailhead of the Brown's Farm Trail also is your first stop to learn about the mountain's ecosystems. You are in a deciduous eastern hardwood forest among trees that will lose their leaves in the winter. Along the trail you will see oak, hickory, tulip poplar, beech, and maple trees. This forest is home to white-tailed deer, chipmunks, raccoons, bluebirds, woodpeckers, owls, and other animals.

This area is a wetland, sometimes under a shallow layer of water. Wetlands filter groundwater and provide habitat for a variety of plants and animals. Ferns live year-round in these shady, damp places. Skunk cabbage blooms appear in February, providing an early glimpse of spring.
Do you see the quartz, Catoctin greenstone and other types of rocks in the streambed? The stream, the trees overhead, and the quiet of the woods make this an ideal spot for birdwatching.
stops.assetName: Brown's Farm Trail Stop 3: The Streambed

stops.significance: Walking slightly uphill from the boardwalk, notice the subtle changes in the forest. The marshy earth becomes firm under foot, ferns give way to greenbrier and spicebush, and wetlands give way to a hardwood forest. Invasive plants like barberry, multiflora rose, and Japanese stiltgrass are gaining hold in the understory, the layer of forest beneath the tree canopy.
stops.assetName: Brown's Farm Trail Stop 4: Invasive Plants

stops.significance: Living trees produce oxygen, stabilize the soil, provide homes for wildlife, and offer a cool place to rest on a hot summer day. Dead trees are also valuable in the forest cycle of life. A dead tree provides shelter for wildlife. The insects, bacteria, and fungi that live in and on a dead tree provide food for wildlife while slowly decomposing the tree into rich, replenishing soil for the next generation of plants.
stops.assetName: Brown's Farm Trail Stop 5: Cycle of Life

stops.significance: Take a deep breath. Can you smell the fresh scent of pine? Why is a pine grove in the middle of a hardwood forest? In 1957, children from Frederick County schools joined the reclamation project on Catoctin Mountain and planted this pine grove. The pines help control erosion and provide shelter for wildlife. Schools and scouting groups continue the tradition of helping the park today.
stops.assetName: Brown's Farm Trail Stop 6: The Pine Grove

stops.significance: The Brown Family's farmhouse was built of chestnut logs that once stood on this stone foundation. The Browns, a family with four daughters, "lived by oil," using oil lamps for light. The water well was nearby, convenient at a time when water had to be hauled for washing and cooking. Today, asters grow at the well, brightening the scene with late fall blooms. The buckeye tree is an 'alien' species because it is not native to this area. Could it be a memento from their former home in Ohio?
stops.assetName: Brown's Farm Trail Stop 7: The Farmhouse

stops.significance: In addition to the raspberries, potatoes, green beans, and wheat the Browns grew, animals supplemented their diet and livelihood. They owned hogs, chickens, and sheep, and Victor Brown sheared his neighbors' sheep for extra money. On the left is a concrete watering trough for the farm animals. To the right is part of the foundation of a 'bank barn,' which used a hill as one of the first-floor walls.
stops.assetName: Brown's Farm Trail Stop 8: The Bank Barn

stops.significance: This area has many trees with multiple trunks, meaning they were cut down and the stumps re-sprouted. What did it look like when these trees were only stumps? Did the other plants seize the newfound sunshine when the shade was removed? In addition to the forest changing with human influence, there is a natural forest succession. When the pines reach their full height, small shrubs appear. Then, pioneer trees such as poplars and locust gain a foothold. These, in turn, provide shade necessary for the seedlings of the hardwood forest to sprout. As the oaks, maples, beeches, and hickories grow tall and strong, the forest reaches maturity.
stops.assetName: Brown's Farm Trail Stop 9: Forest Succession

stops.significance: The stone wall is a reminder that these were once field or farm boundaries. Today, the stones provide cover for insects, chipmunks, woodchucks, and snakes. Take care not to disturb the residents.
stops.assetName: Brown's Farm Trail Stop 10: The Stone Wall

stops.significance: Flying squirrels call this pine grove home: the trees provide food and shelter, and the small squirrels can even glide while holding a pine cone or other forage! As plant species change, either from human impact or natural succession, the wildlife in the area also changes. Warblers who prefer open fields move on as trees grow, while deer and turkeys move in. As trees age and decay forming hollows or downed logs, raccoons, chipmunks, and other creatures enjoy these ready-made shelters.
stops.assetName: Brown's Farm Trail Stop 11: Food and Shelter

stops.significance: Bubbling out of the ground, this spring offers a drink for wildlife and moisture needed by plants and fungi to grow here. The soil acts as a filter, taking with it contaminants picked up on its travels from beneath the ground and into streams. Catoctin Mountain Park is in the Chesapeake Bay watershed. As difficult as it may be to imagine, the water that springs out here makes its way to the Chesapeake Bay and ultimately to the Atlantic Ocean.
stops.assetName: Brown's Farm Trail Stop 12: The Spring

data.title: Ever-Changing Ecosystems: Brown's Farm Trail Loop

data.description: The village of Boston may look like it has not seen progress or change in years, yet the area has transformed repeatedly. Explore the pros and cons of progress. This walk is intended to be around 35 minutes in length, covering about a mile over roads and trails of flat terrain. Be aware that this walk uses current paths, trails and roadways, all adjacent to Boston Mills Road and an active railroad line. At times, noise may be an issue. Watch for cyclists along the Towpath Trail.

images.altText: Black-and-white photo of a train approaching a station; a sign on the station reads "Boston Mill".
images.caption: The Boston Mill station viewed from the north, looking toward today’s overhead bridges, ca. 1900.
images.title: Historic Boston Mill Station

stops.significance: Do you know the history of your hometown? Has your town seen progress? Join us on a walk through Boston, exploring progress. Start your journey at Boston Mill Visitor Center, exploring the inside and outside exhibits. Boston started as an early settlement on the edge of the frontier. But eventually progress found the village. The wealth of water, pulp, and transportation made the industry of paper making here possible. Look for the history of the papermill as you explore. What industry started your hometown? How did it change your town for the better or the less better?

Imagine what your town may have looked like a century ago. With the arrival of the canal, the village of Boston shifted from a river focus to a canal focus. The building you are standing outside of, the Boston Land and Manufacturing Company Store, was built during the canal’s heyday in 1837. Step inside to explore the architecture of the time. Why do you think this building was built in this shape?

What industries were brought to your town? As you can see, the canal put Boston on the map. What do you think the sights, smells, and sounds of Boston may have been like? It was not the quiet little village you see today. The air would have smelled of steam, wood, sweat, and animals. The sounds would have been of men talking, hammering, and sawing, with animals in the chorus braying, mooing, and more.
Locks served as hydraulic elevators for boats, managing changes in elevation over the canal’s course. What do you think it would have been like to bump through a lock?

James Stanford was one of the first three permanent Western Reserve settlers in Boston. They built a crude cabin. But in time, James’s son, George Stanford would build the house before you, signaling the transition from a frontier settlement to an established town. Using wealth acquired by the canal, and supplies brought in by boat, he built, and later descendants added onto, this farmhouse. What was it like to build this house as the son of one of the first settlers? What progress did he see in his lifetime? What were the benefits or detriments of the progress the canal brought?

After exploring the exhibits outside Stanford House, return to Boston Mill Visitor Center by re-tracing your path. As you walk, think about what progress has brought to your town. Are there pros and cons to that progress?

data.title: Ever-changing Boston Walking Tour

data.description: The original structure that would eventually become bunkhouse row was built by Johnny Grant in the 1860’s. Over the years, the bunkhouse row was remodeled and lengthened with additional rooms and a living space for cowboys and ranch hands. Take a short walking tour of bunkhouse row, explore the different rooms and discover what it took to manage a large-scale cattle ranch and keep the ranch's hardworking cowboys happy and content.

images.altText: A dirt path and white picket fence run the entire length of the Grant-Kohrs Ranch bunkhouse row.
images.caption: There are many different rooms and stories to explore inside of the Grant-Kohrs Ranch bunkhouse row.
images.title: Bunkhouse Row

stops.significance: From approximately 1935 to 1947, this office was used by Conrad Warren, the grandson of Conrad Kohrs, to manage the daily operations of the ranch.
The sitting room was at the core of the bunkhouse row and it was a place where the ranch’s cowboys could relax, unwind, and spend some social time together.
This sleeping area was set up in the middle of bunkhouse row so hard-working cowboys could relax, read a book, or get a good night’s sleep.
This room was where hungry cowboys would gather around the table and eat their meals together.
A variety of cooks prepared hardy and filling meals for the ranch’s cowboys in this kitchen.
Before this shower room was added the ranch's cowboys had to go into town to bathe.

data.title: Explore Bunkhouse Row

data.description: Walk along Bathhouse Row and then take a scenic drive to take in the sights and learn more about Hot Springs National Park.

images.altText: A sweeping panoramic view of rolling hills with a city rising in the valley.
images.caption: Hot Springs as seen from the Mountain Tower
images.title: Aerial View of Hot Springs

stops.significance:
The Grand Promenade is brick-paved, half-mile long National Recreational Trailway which separates the forested Hot Springs Mountain from the landscaped setting of Bathhouse Row. A walk along the Grand Promenade reveals the natural, cultural, and geologic history of Hot Springs National Park.  

First built in the 1930s, the Grand Promenade is one of several CCC projects that took place in Hot Springs National Park. The CCC, or Civilian Conservation Corps, was a public work relief program that operated from 1933 until 1942, during the Great Depression. The Grand Promenade was completed in the late 1950s, connecting Reserve Street to Fountain Street.

Where the Administration Building now stands was once the Government Pump House. All the thermal water flowed through the pump house before being distributed to the fountains and bathhouses throughout the park. Today, several popular thermal water fountains can be found in front of or near the Administration Building.  

When the Administration Building opened in 1936, architects imagined it as the visual link between the Army-Navy Hospital and Bathhouse Row. The building’s Spanish Colonial Revival architecture also reflects the style of many of the bathhouses along Bathhouse Row.   

Before you leave this location, we invite you to join the centuries old practice of drinking the Hot Springs thermal water from the jug fountain along the sidewalk. The thermal spring water is the Park’s primary resource and is available to drink from designated fountains. Thousands of park visitors will bring their cups, bottles, and jugs to fill up on the very hot, ancient thermal water.

In 1915, the Fordyce Bathhouse opened as the “most complete, practical & luxurious bathhouse” in Hot Springs. Located at the heart of Bathhouse Row, next to the Formal Entrance to Hot Springs National Park, the Fordyce provided the world-famous thermal baths until it closed in 1962.  Today, after restoration by the National Park Service, the Fordyce serves as the Hot Springs National Park Visitor Center and Museum.  
The restored Fordyce is a grand old bathhouse. Samuel Fordyce, the namesake and first owner, traveled across Europe and the United States to study bathing facility architecture and equipment. Much of the Spanish Renaissance Revival structure, marble interior, stunning stained glass pieces and medical machinery is historically accurate for the early 1900’s.  

Visitors may guide themselves through 23 restored rooms furnished as they appeared during the heyday of the spa. There are three floors and a basement which are accessible by a modern elevator or two sets of marble stairs.
stops.assetName: Fordyce Bathhouse Visitor Center and Museum

stops.significance:
Bathhouse Row is the largest grouping of historic bathhouses in the United States and shows the popularity of the medical bathing and spa movement in the 19th and 20th centuries. The Row is also visually stunning as an excellent collection of early 20th century architecture. Today, the preserved Bathhouse Row is a model of historic rehabilitation of older buildings. 

On April 20, 1832 Congress established Hot Springs Reservation to protect the dozens of thermal springs that emerge from the base of Hot Springs Mountain for medical care and drinking. Bathers and business owners developed bathhouses to cool the water to a usable temperature and to provide therapeutic bathing to treat rheumatism, polio, muscle pain, venereal disease and other ailments.

There are more than 40 thermal springs located at the base of Hot Springs Mountain, just behind the Bathhouses. By the early 1900s, all but one of the springs were covered to protect the quality of the water. With so many people depending on the thermal springs for bathing, drinking and healing – they were covered by the “green boxes” that you can see throughout the park. 

These two display springs before you were opened for public view in 1931. Park staff wanted visitors to be able to see open hot springs , and not just be limited to hot water in the fountains or bathhouses. The water that flows out of these display springs does not go to the fountains or the bathhouses, but rather, it flows into Hot Springs Creek, as all of the springs once did.   

Visitors often ask whether they can soak in these springs directly. However, the thermal spring water comes out of the ground at a piping 143F or 62C. Even though the water may not be boiling, it is 40 degrees hotter than most hot tubs and showers.

The Maurice Spring Historic Area was an early attempt to protect drinking fountains and springs during the development of Bathhouse Row. Located between the Hale and Maurice Bathhouses, the Dripping Spring and Tunnel Springs are surrounded by natural tufa rock and stonework.  

The Maurice Spring was the first display spring in Hot Springs National Park. All of the stonework around the Maurice Historic Spring area was completed in 1903.  

The Dripping Spring served as a convenient drinking fountain for many visitors. From the time that Hot Springs Reservation (later named Hot Springs National Park) was established in 1832, the thermal springs were considered to be a guaranteed source of safe drinking water – resulting in many people drinking from any spring that they encountered. Dedicated drinking fountains became important as increased visitation and the development of the bathhouses limited drinking springs.

The water that emerges at the Hot Water cascade has undergone a long journey. Rain falls in the recharge zone--an area larger than the park--and travels into the earth following cracks in the rock. Measurements show that the water you can drink today fell as rain more than 4,000 years ago – the same time some of the pyramids were being built in Egypt.  

These thermal springs are not heated by volcanic activity. Instead, they are heated by the geothermal gradient as water flows deep into the earth. Fractures in the rock allow the water to flow 6,000 to 8,000 feet deep (or 1800 – 2500 meters) into the Earth. At depth, the water is approximately 160F (71C). 

After its over 4,000-year journey, the heated water meets a fault line at the base of Hot Springs Mountain. The water rises relatively quickly along the fault, allowing the water to keep much of its heat and arrive at the surface at an average of 143F (or 62C).

The North Mountain Overlook allows visitors to see the ridges and valleys of the Ouachita Mountain Range, including a portion of the thermal springs’ recharge zone, which is the source of the spring water.  

Hot Springs National Park is located in the south-eastern edge of the Ouachita Mountain Range. The Ouachita Mountains extend from central Arkansas about 223 miles west into eastern Oklahoma. These mountains are unusual in North America in that the ridges are generally aligned east to west, unlike the Rocky Mountains or Appalachian Mountains, where the ridges usually run north to south. 

While today most of the mountains are between 1,000 and 2,000 feet above sea level, the ancient Ouachita Mountains were likely thousands of feet higher. The valleys between the ridges are filled with the eroded rock from those ancient mountains. The mountaintops visible today are the erosion-resistant remnants of folded layers of novaculite and sandstone.

Gulpha Gorge Campground is the only campground in Hot Springs National Park and offers a picturesque and convenient location for campers with a tent or an RV. All sites at the campground can be reserved 6 months in advance on Recreation.gov or by calling 1-877-444-6777.  

The Day Use Area and Picnic tables at Gulpha Gorge are free and cannot be reserved. There are two additional picnic areas in the park – at the top of Hot Springs Mountain, near the Mountain Tower; and at the 2nd West Mountain Overlook parking area.  

Following the paved walkway east of the Amphitheater leads to Gulpha Creek. Swimming and wading in Gulpha Creek is allowed, and is done at your own risk; there are no lifeguards on duty. Please keep all pets on a leash and clean up after them properly. 

Just across the creek, hikers can connect to Gulpha Gorge Trail, which connects to the Goat Rock Trail and Overlook or to the Sunset Trail, which leads to Rick’s Pond and the Stonebridge area.
The West Mountain Overlook offers a bird’s eye view to the East, including the downtown corridor, the city of Hot Springs, and Hot Springs Mountain.

In the parking area there is an outstanding outcropping of Arkansas Novaculite. Novaculite is famous for being a “sharpening stone,” and is commonly known as “Arkansas whetstone.” Novaculite is a microcrystalline type of chert which fractures easily – this allows rainwater to percolate down into the recharge area of the thermal springs. The fracture patterns also make it relatively easy to quarry. Novaculite was a popular resource used for trading and sharp edged tools by early American Indians in this area.  

The broad valley to the south is the pathway for the Ouachita River. Hydroelectric dams on the Ouachita River create several man-made lakes, including Lake Catherine and Lake Hamilton, which are partially visible from the summit.

data.title: Explore Hot Springs National Park

data.description: Dive into Canyonlands history with visits to historic mining camps, archeological sites and museum exhibits. This tour includes stops in the Needles and Island in the Sky districts, with a bonus stop at Horseshoe Canyon in the Maze District. You can visit a few stops in one afternoon, or complete the full tour in several days. Remember, archeological sites are fragile, irreplaceable resources. Never touch rock markings, leave all artifacts where you find them, and watch your step to avoid damage to sites.

images.altText: Red, brown and white figures on rock in the Grand Gallery panel, in Canyonlands.
images.caption: Rock markings in the Grand Gallery
images.title: Rock markings in the Grand Gallery

stops.significance:
Begin at the Needles Visitor Center for an overview of the park's human history inside the museum. The visitor center is located at the end of UT 211, approximately 35 miles west of US 191, south of Moab, UT. 

NOTE: The park museum is currently closed. Rangers are available outside on visitor center patios for assistance.
Roadside ruin is one of the best preserved and easily accessed ancient structure in the park, build over 1,000 years ago.

Springs are rare in the desert. In the alcove beyond the cowboy camp, you'll notice soot-blackened ceilings, handprints, painted figures, and grinding depressions. These tell us that this precious resource also attracted earlier people. Ancestors of today's American Indians occupied these canyons six millennia before the cattlemen arrived, about 6,000 to 700 years ago.

Newly installed human history exhibits in the Island in the Sky Visitor Center provide a unique look into the past. Island in the Sky Visitor Center is located off UT 313, approximately 22 miles southwest of US 191, north of Moab, UT. 

NOTE: The visitor center and exhibits are currently closed. Rangers are available outside on visitor center patios for assistance.
stops.assetName: Island in the Sky Visitor Center

stops.significance: Looking down at the twists and turns of the Shafer Trail is a journey through the past. Used by native peoples for thousands of years, the trail was expanded by John Sog Shafer in 1917 as a “one cow wide” cattle trail. Shafer Trail traffic started to boom as the hunt for uranium ensued in the 1950’s. Today, the trail is used by adventurous motorists, cyclists and even some hikers.

Horseshoe Canyon contains some of the most significant rock art in North America. The Great Gallery, the best known panel in Horseshoe Canyon, includes well-preserved, life-sized figures with intricate designs. Other impressive sights include spring wildflowers, sheer sandstone walls and mature cottonwood groves along the intermittent stream in the canyon bottom. 

NOTE: This location is difficult to get to, involving navigating along unpaved rocky and sandy roads. Two-wheel-drive vehicles can usually travel the 30-mile graded dirt road from UT 24 (near Goblin Valley State Park), or the 47-mile dirt road traveling south from Green River. Driving time is roughly 2.5 hours from Moab. A four-wheel-drive road leads to the east rim of Horseshoe Canyon from the Hans Flat Ranger Station. Hiking to the Great Gallery panel is a strenuous, 7 mi (11.2 km) journey, requiring five hours or more, and intended for only the most prepared individuals.

data.title: Explore Human History

data.description: Take a full tour of the historic site and learn about the community that made Herbert Hoover the man we know today.

images.altText: An 1870s classroom with an elevated teacher's desk and chalkboards as seen from a pupil's desk.
images.caption: Pupils' desks face the teacher's in the schoolhouse.
images.title: Schoolhouse

stops.significance: On August 12, 1965, an act of Congress established this park as a national historic site. Since then, the National Park Service has preserved and interpreted the historic structures and landscape of this 187-acre park. In the late 1930's, President Hoover and his wife, Lou Henry Hoover, chose this place to celebrate the values they believed helped shape his life.

West Branch boomed between 1869 and 1873. New buildings constructed in the neighborhood near the Hoovers' small cottage on Downey Street included the Laban Miles House, the Garvin House, and the Methodist Church, which is no longer standing.
Like any couple just starting out, 21-year old Hulda Minthorn and 23-year old Jesse Hoover were eager to have a place to call their own.

With no electricity or indoor plumbing, rooms in the compact cottage needed to be multi-purpose. The main room served as a combined living room, dining room, and kitchen, while the bedroom had sufficient furnishings for the parents and their three small children. Furniture like a trundle bed in the bedroom and a drop-leaf table in the main room helped save space.

The Hoover family's single bedroom had sufficient furnishings for the parents and their three small children. Furniture like a trundle bed in the bedroom and a drop-leaf table in the main room helped save space.
The partially enclosed and covered porch at the rear of the cottage may have served several purposes over time, including a woodshed, storeroom, summer kitchen, and spare bedroom.

Built in 1957, this building represents the kind of blacksmith and wagon shops that were common in the 1870s. It is based on the sketches of Herbert's older brother Theodore, from his recollections of what their father's shop looked like. The re-built blacksmith shop sits west of the original shop's location just a stone's throw from the Birthplace Cottage.
stops.assetName: Blacksmith Shop (Herbert Hoover National Historic Site)

stops.significance: The Blacksmith Shop at Herbert Hoover National Historic Site is a working smithy in the style of traditional blacksmithing. The techniques, tools, and fuel sources are what blacksmiths used in the 1800s.

Herbert Hoover recalled, "Iowa in those years was filled with days of school, and who does not remember with a glow, some gentle woman, who with infinite patience and kindness, drilled into us those foundations of all we know today."
Each day, the children's teacher filled her blackboard with lessons of arithmetic and spelling. Students shared reading books, and practiced penmanship on slate chalkboards.

West Branch was barely a settlement in 1852 when Baltimore native Aaron Baker came here to claim the free land he'd received from the United States government for his service in the Mexican War. He promptly sold all 160 acres of it for about a dollar apiece.

The South Downey Street Bridge extends across a tributary of the West Branch of the Wapsinonoc Creek. When Herbert Hoover was a boy, the creek was just a small stream of water trickling through marshy wetlands. Young Herbert and the neighborhood kids took their willow fishing poles about a quarter mile east to catch sunfish and catfish in the main creek.

Herbert Hoover grew up in a religious community that valued peace, simplicity, integrity, and service to others. The plainly furnished Friends Meetinghouse, built by the Society of Friends, or Quakers, in 1857, is the physical expression of those values. Now two blocks from its original location, the Herbert Hoover Birthplace Foundation relocated and restored this meetinghouse in 1964.

Mothers brought restless or hungry infants to the cry room, or nursery, to avoid disturbing the silent Quaker meetings. This cry room is not original to the meetinghouse. It came from another meetinghouse, added as part of the restoration.

A lone maple tree grows on the land where the Hoover family's second home once stood. The one-acre parcel, on the corner of Downey and Cedar streets, had a two-story frame house with two chimneys. Maple trees lined the front yard and a wild crabapple tree grew in back of the spacious four-room home.

In 1951 Herbert Hoover became the first recipient of the prestigious Iowa Award, which is bestowed to "recognize the outstanding service of Iowans in the fields of science, medicine, law, religion, social welfare education, agriculture, industry, government and other public service." Only 12 other Iowans have received this award.

The bronze, seven and a half foot tall statue "Isis, Goddess of Life" is the work of Belgian sculptor Auguste Puttemans. It was a gift from the people of Belgium in gratitude for Hoover's famine relief efforts on their behalf during the First World War.

Part of the National Archives, this presidential library allows people to explore the legacy of Herbert Hoover's presidency. It opened to the public on August 10, 1962— Herbert Hoover's 88th birthday. President Hoover himself attended the dedication, along with fellow former President Harry S. Truman.

The tallgrass prairie reconstructed here offer a glimpse of an Iowa landscape that had almost vanished by the time Herbert Hoover's grandparents moved here in 1854. Tall native grasses, sprinkled with brilliantly colored wildflowers once covered these rolling hills for as far as the eye could see.

When he died on October 20, 1964 at the age of 90, the 31st President was laid to rest five days later in this quiet, grassy hillside. More than 100,000 people lined the funeral procession route from Cedar Rapids to West Branch on that warm fall day.

data.description: Explore the San Antonio Missions! San Antonio is home to five Spanish colonial missions. The first mission established in San Antonio was Mission San Antonio de Valero, or as we know it today the Alamo, in 1718. The San Antonio Missions National Historical Park includes four of the five missions, Mission Concepcion, Mission San Jose, Mission San Juan, and Mission Espada. All five of the Missions in San Antonio are a World Heritage Site, visit https://www.sanantonio.gov/WorldHeritage

data.description: Historically, the area of Georgetown South of P Street (between 29th Street NW and Rock Creek) was known as Herring Hill. The area was an historically African American neighborhood for almost 200 years until it was gentrified during the New Deal. Follow this tour to explore this historic neighborhood and contemplate the meaning of the word "community" and what it's loss can signify.

images.altText: Street lined with trees
images.caption: 27th Street was part of the Herring Hill Community in Georgetown
images.title: 27th Street NW Georgetown

stops.significance:
Lee Feed and Grain was listed as the oldest African American-owned business in the country. It was an anchor and focal point for the Herring Hill community in Georgetown.

Is there a business in your neighborhood or community that has the same longevity as Lee Feed and Grain had? What does it mean to your community?

The Phillips School was originally a segregated school and was built to help alleviate the overcrowding experienced at Chamberlain School (the first school built for children of color in Georgetown after the Civil War). It served the African American population of Herring Hill and Georgetown's east end from 1890-1950. It has recently been converted into condo units.

How would you feel if your old school was transformed into something else? How would that change your sense of community?

Georgetown's First Baptist Church was built by church members. The men would work on the foundation at night after they'd gotten off work while the women cooked meals for them.

Church members spoke of how the children in the choir would race between this church and Trinity Catholic just a block away. Both houses of worship would participate in each other's street fairs. 

How does this illustrate community to you?

The Rose Park Tennis Courts are where two famous tennis-playing, African American sisters learned to play. Do you know who they are?

If you guessed the Williams sisters, you're wrong! Before there was Venus and Serena, there was Margaret and Roumania Peters. The Peters sisters often played on these courts where they honed their skills and made names for themselves playing doubles. Both were offered full scholarships to Tuskegee Institute and both attended starting in 1937 and graduating with degrees in Physical Education in 1941.

After college, they both played amateur tennis in the American Tennis Association. They won 14 doubles titles between 1938 and 1953. Though they were notorious enough to play in front of royalty and practice with celebrities like Gene Kelly, segregation prevented them from proving themselves against white players.

Poplar Alley represents the narrow alley communities that once dotted Georgetown. Many of the alleys were cleared of original residents by legal means with the intent of reducing illness and improving quality of life. These efforts did not benefit the original owners and in many cases forced them to sell their homes to developers and leave their communities. The Alley Dwelling Act gentrified Georgetown under the influx of white workers coming to take advantage of New Deal jobs in a segregated government.

Documentary evidence suggests that some of the residents of Poplar Alley had formerly been enslaved on the Peirce and Shoemaker estates in Rock Creek Park.

What do you think happened in communities like this one?

These two African-American cemeteries were almost lost to development in the 1970s. Efforts by community organizers have saved them. These groups endeavor to tell the stories of the early African-American residents of Georgetown buried here. The vault just down the hill is reported to have been used as a stop on the Underground Railroad.

The cemetery represents one of the outcomes of the loss of community in Herring Hill. 

What's something in your neighborhood that might become lost or forgotten if citizens who lived nearby were forced to leave?
stops.assetName: Mount Zion and Female Union Band Cemeteries

stops.significance:
The blue brick house was built by Alfred Pope. Alfred was a freedom seeker who lived in Georgetown. He was part of one of the most famous freedom-seeking attempts in American history. After he was emancipated, he stayed in Georgetown where he started several businesses and eventually owned property throughout Herring Hill. In the 1870s he was one of the men selected to represent Georgetown when it was being decided whether Georgetown would be absorbed by the City of Washington or if it would remain "Georgetown, DC."

How do you impact your community?

data.title: Explore the historic Herring Hill neighborhood of Georgetown

data.description: The Miners area on the west side contains some of the park's most scenic and diverse sites: cliffs, beach, shoreline, forest, waterfall, river, panoramic views of Lake Superior, and the famous Miners Castle. The three main locations are a quick drive to each other, so you can enjoy the entire Miners area in just a couple of hours.

images.altText: River flowing across sand beach into Lake Superior with forest cliff slope in the background
images.caption: Miners River and Miners Beach
images.title: Miners River flowing into Lake Superior

stops.significance: Begin at Miners Falls, which is a 15-minute drive from Munising via Alger County Road H-58 and Miners Castle Road (H-11). From the parking lot, walk an easy 0.6 mile forest trail to Miners Falls, the park's most powerful waterfall.
Miners Castle is a famous rock structure and landmark along the Pictured Rocks cliffs. It is also the only place in the park where visitors can drive onto the cliffs for easy access to overlooks.
At nearly a mile, Miners Beach is the longest beach on the park's western end. Miners River flows out on the west side of the beach, below the Miners Castle cliff.

data.title: Exploring the Miners Area

data.description: Roosevelt Farm Lane is part of the historic road network that connected the Roosevelt Home, Val-Kill, Top Cottage, the Home Farm, and FDR’s tree plantations. The interior of the land was heavily planted with trees by FDR—Norway spruce, tulip-poplar, white pine and red pine to name a few. FDR planted over 21 acres of trees between 1912 and 1944.

images.caption: Workers planting trees on FDR's land.
images.title: Workers planting trees on FDR's land.

data.title: Farm Lane Trail

data.description: The Hampton plantation was a fully operational site, and one of the largest in all of Maryland. Learn the stories of those forced to labor for the benefit of the rich upper class Ridgely family that owned the estate.

images.altText: A living historian shucking corn.
images.caption: A park living historian demonstrates farming techniques.
images.title: Farm Side Tour

stops.significance: The lower house represents the rise and fall of the Ridgely family's power. This is the oldest structure on the property.
This wooden structure provides an accurate representation as to what most of the enslaved quarters would have looked like.
The ash house is one of many functional structures that allowed a farm to operate.

Enslaved people did the bulk of the work on the Hampton plantation from the 1700's to 1864. These structures are an ever present reminder of the horrific institution that helped the Ridgelys rise to wealth and power.

These slave quarters today represent the use after slavery as tenant farmers quarters. The continued agricultural work on the Hampton estate would only help keep the Ridgely wealth afloat for so long after the days of slavery.
The dairy produced Hampton's highly sought after dairy products that added to the Ridgely's fortune thanks to the labor of enslaved people and later paid dairymen.
The long house granary provided an important structure for storing grains produced on the farm, as well as the livestock of the plantation.
Hampton's agricultural prestige continued to add to the Ridgely's wealth but at the cost of continuing the horrors of slavery.
The corncrib was a storage location where the fruits of the labor of enslaved people and paid laborers were stored to dry out in order to make corn based products.
The mule barn housed mules which were some of the most important livestock to the Hampton's farm work.

data.title: Farm Tour

data.description: This tour will direct visitors to the historic farmsteads on the battlefield. It will be combination of driving to each site and depending upon your level of interest, you will have to walk about five minutes in some cases to see the farm. Only the Pry and Newcomer Houses are open to the public, limited hours during the summer.

images.altText: numerous buildings, including a house and barn set off in a field
images.caption: The Mumma Farmstead
images.title: farm buildings

stops.significance: Over 8700 United States soldiers spent the night before the battle around the J.Poffenberger Farm.
The Cornfield, scene of the horrific combat during the first few hours of the battle, was owned by the Miller Family.
The Mumma Farm was destroyed early on the day of the battle when Confederates set fire to the house to prevent Union forces from possibly using it later in the day.
Union troops passed over this farmstead on their way to the Sunken Road.
Located south of the Sunken Road, the Confederates moved through this farmstead as they tried to reinforce the middle part of their line.
After carrying the Burnside Bridge men from the IX Corps commanded by US General Ambrose Burnside formed up and advanced across the Sherrick fields.
Parts of the Union IX Corps attacked across the Otto fields on the late afternoon of the battle, only to be turned back by the arrival of Confederates on the far south end of their property.
The Newcomer Farm is located near the Middle Bridge crossing of the Antietam Creek.
The Pry House was the forward command post for Union General George McClellan during the battle.

data.title: Farmsteads Tour

data.description: The Faulkner Trail is a popular hike featuring gentle switchbacks that build up to an incredible panoramic view of Woodstock from the South Peak of Mount Tom. Most of the hike gradually gains elevation, leading to a scenic overlook with a bench. The last 100 yards to the summit is strenuous. At this section of the trail, a handrail assists walkers with the uneven footing up the steep terrain to the peak. Ensure firmness of handrails before use. Please remain on the trail, and don't cut the switchbacks.

images.altText: overlook with two wooden benches during peak fall foliage
images.caption: Faulkner Trail overlook
images.title: Faulkner Trail Overlook

park.fullName: Marsh - Billings - Rockefeller National Historical Park
park.name: Marsh - Billings - Rockefeller

stops.significance:
The Faulkner trail was carefully constructed in 1937 by Marianne Faulkner in memory of her husband Edward Daniels Faulkner. She designed it to mirror gentle "cardiac health" trails in the spa town of Baden Baden, Germany. It connects the town of Woodstock with the trails of Marsh-Billings-Rockefeller National Park.

The Faulkner Trail has been continually maintained and repaired by groups including: the National Park Service Rivers Trails and Conservation Assistance Program; the Billings Park Commission; Vermont Youth Conservation Corps and the Student Conservation Association.

The trail begins in Faulkner Park, a park managed by the Faulkner Trust, located two blocks away from the Woodstock Village Green.
Stop by the Carriage Barn Visitor Center to view exhibits about the history of conservation stewardship in Vermont and beyond!

data.title: Faulkner Trail (Starting at Faulkner Park)

data.description: The Fayette Station Scenic Drive is a windy, narrow road that brings visitors to the bottom of the gorge. Once at river level, your vehicle will cross the one way bridge, which is a replica of the original bridge that once brought people across the New River without getting wet about 100 years ago.  The audio tour starts at the Canyon Rim Visitor Center parking lot and the guides you along the route, with directions and history as you weave down the gorge to the river.

images.altText: Map of the scenic driving
images.caption: Fayette Station Road Driving Tour map
images.title: Fayette Station Road Driving Tour map

park.fullName: New River Gorge National Park & Preserve
park.name: New River Gorge

stops.significance: The Fayette Station Scenic Drive takes you down into the gorge from the Canyon Rim Visitor Center and back up the other side of the gorge back onto Route 19. This route is how people crossed the gorge before the New River Gorge Bridge was built in 1977 and gives you a sense of how difficult travel could in the past. There are places to stop along the way to get out and view the bridge and even get to the river side. Please be mindful of the narrow roads and only park in marked parking lots, especially at the river level.

data.title: Fayette Station Scenic Road Tour
