data.description: Fire has touched every part of the park. Explore the effects the of fire historically and today.

images.altText: Ranger talks to visitors looking at smoke rising from the base of the Teton Range
images.caption: A ranger talks with park visitors about the Waterfalls Canyon Fire (1974).
images.title: Watching Waterfalls Canyon Fire

stops.significance: Stop 1 (Colter Bay Visitor Center): Learn about the role fire plays in our forests and its importance to this ecosystem.
Stop 2 (north of Colter Bay Visitor Center): Learn about how Europeans managed fire when they arrived in this area, and how the government shaped fire management in the early 1900s.

Stop 3 (Colter Bay Swim Beach): The 1974 Waterfalls Canyon Fire was one of the first fires in the National Park Service that was allowed to burn naturally. Listen to find out how it came to pass and what its legacy has been.

Stop 4 (Jackson Lake Overlook): What effects do repeated fires have on a landscape, and why is that important for forests and wildlife? Explore our Fire History page to see a map of fires in the park over the last several decades, including the ones Diane and Ron discuss.
Stop 5 (Huck Fire Turnout): You've probably heard of the 1988 fires in Yellowstone. Listen to hear about their legacy for fire management in the West and what scientists have learned from them.

Stop 6 (Headwaters Lodge parking lot, Flagg Ranch): The Berry Fire, in 2016, was the largest fire in park history. Learn about how it spread across the landscape, and how years of preparation helped protect the buildings at Flagg Ranch.
Stop 7 (Grassy Lake Road): How is climate change affecting fire behavior, and how will that change forests in Greater Yellowstone? Hear what scientists have to say.

Stop 8 (Flagg Canyon Picnic Area): "Fire isn't good or bad—it just is." Fire managers from Grand Teton National Park and Bridger-Teton National Forest reflect on the progress of the last 50 years, and what we need to think about for the future.

data.title: Fire in the Tetons

data.description: Discover the history of the first Fort Smith and the challenges the soldiers faced. The first fort is located roughly 300 yards west of the visitor center overlooking the Arkansas and Poteau Rivers. Each stop will have a question to encourage conversations while on the tour.

images.altText: Aerial view - park grounds trees with open areas on left and buildings and parade ground on right.
images.caption: Aerial view September 2018
images.title: Aerial View Park Grounds

stops.significance: Fort Smith was named after the commander of the U.S. Army Rifle Regiment, General Thomas Smith. The fort was active for just over six years. After it was abandoned, the buildings were used periodically, but it fell into disrepair. This site was eventually forgotten and lost to time until archeologists uncovered the foundations in the late 1950s.

Stephen H. Long was the first military officer to bring with him leading scientific experts of the day from the fields of botany, geology, zoology, and cartography. Long’s expeditions covered over 25,000 miles with the resulting knowledge helped in the expansion of the upper American West.
What is the longest journey you have ever taken? How did you feel when you arrived?
stops.assetName: Major Long Surveys the Western Frontier

stops.significance:
Major Bradford and his men traveled in two keelboats along with provisions supplies also including two six-pound cannons with carriages, two sets of harnesses for horses to pull the cannon, and over half a ton of pig iron for casting bullets. They started the long journey in mid-September and arrived at the mouth of the Arkansas River on Oct 15. The remaining 320 miles would take 71 days. Once they arrived the soldiers began building what would be Fort Smith along with their other duties. 
The Regiment of Riflemen would not complete the construction of the fort. In February of 1822, the Regiment of Riflemen was deactivated, and the men absorbed into the 7th Infantry Regiment. The 7th Infantry remained at Fort Smith for two more years. 
Have you ever left something behind that would confuse the people who find it in the future?

Major’s Longs plans included two blockhouses each were twenty-eight square feet, extending ten feet beyond the garrison walls and topped with an eight square foot cupola. Within the garrison plans called for officers’ quarters, junior officers’ quarters, soldiers’ barracks, quarters for guards and musicians, provisions house, shops for carpenters and tailors, sutler’s room, kitchen, hospital, and powder magazine. During the rest of the tour look for other visible parts of the foundation. Some sections remain underground to help preserve them.
What is something that you think will be still around 100 years from now and should be protected?

The Regiment of Rifleman was the elite of the infantry. Specializing in scouting and patrols. They were also top marksmen training on targets set at fifty to one hundred twenty yards using flintlock rifles. Life for a soldier at Fort Smith tedious and arduous. Waking to reveille at daybreak, followed by assembly, roll call, morning duties, and sick call all before breakfast at 8. Every day was filled with duties, drills, inspections, training, five roll calls with the only breaks being a noon meal and dinner. There was a parade every day twenty minutes before sunset followed by more duties before lights out around 9 pm in summer and 8 pm in the winter.
The rations tended to be monotonous. Hard bread, salt pork or bacon, beans, a gill (4 oz) of whisky, and on occasion coffee or tea. The post garden did provide some variety in summer. Crops included melons, onions, potatoes, and other fresh vegetables. 
Could you move to a new location and not have contact with your family or friends for over a year?

The greatest issue facing the leadership at Fort Smith was the ongoing vendetta between the Osage and the Cherokee. Each faction would agitate the other with raids and ambushes. Attempts to convene a council of tribal leaders was met with delays and last-minute refusals to attend. After months of the relative quiet, Fort Smith received word that the Osage was planning an attack. On April 9, 1821, Osage Chief Mad Buffalo and 400 warriors landed on the shore opposite the fort. They wanted gun powder to go “hunting”. Even though he was outnumbered 40 to1 Acting Fort Commander 1st Lt. Martin Scott stood up to the Osage Chief denying his request. After a tense stand-off, the Osage left the area.
What does it take to stand- up to someone against overwhelming odds?

Significance: December 25, 1817, to April 9, 1824 (6 years, 3 months, 16 days) the soldiers in the Regiment of Riflemen and later the 7th Infantry accomplished a great deal. On the edge of the frontier, they build the fort by hand, grew their food, and survived especially in the early years with little contact with little in the way of supplies and pay. The men mapped and surveyed the area, built roads, developed supply routes, and did what they could to maintain a fragile peace in the area. They also laid the foundation for the United States to continue westward expansion and what would become the community of Fort Smith.
What is one of your greatest accomplishments?

data.title: First Fort Smith

data.description: This five-stop, self-guided driving tour will take you to key locations related to the 21 July 1861 Battle of First Manassas.

images.altText: Artillery on Henry Hill
images.caption: Artillery on Henry Hill
images.title: Artillery on Henry Hill

stops.significance:
The Fauquier and Alexandria Turnpike bridge over Bull Run, known simply as "the Stone Bridge," was originally built in 1825. Its ability to carry traffic across the steep sided stream even at times of high water gave the Stone Bridge a key role during the Civil War.

The first shots of the First Battle of Manassas, fired by Union artillery on the ridge to the east, flew over the bridge but there was little more than heavy skirmishing in its vicinity on July 21, 1861.   A Union division commanded by General Daniel Tyler was tasked with launching a diversionary attack against the bridge while the main flanking column moved north towards Sudley.  

Nathan Evans' Confederate brigade held the high ground covering the bridge.  Leaving a covering force, Evans moved the balance of his brigade to cut off the Union attack at Matthews Hill.

A 1.3 mile loop trail takes you along the Bull Run to the site of Farm Ford (used by Federal troops to cross Bull Run on 21 July) and up onto the bluffs above the Creek.

The head of Irvin McDowell's flanking column reached Matthews Hill shortly after 10 a.m. 

The Union vanguard collided with Confederate skirmishers atop Matthews Hill . Both sides exchanged brief volleys of musket fire. Soldiers of the 2nd Rhode Island Infantry deployed and started across the field toward the crest of the hill. For General McDowell, his chance at surprise was gone. Battle had just begun.

Colonel Ambrose Burnside's brigade, leading the Union flanking column, soon collided with Confederates. Six James Rifles of the 2nd Rhode Island Battery established an advantageous position on the crest while Union infantry pressed forward.  
Confederate troops made headlong charges in a bold show of force that disguised their true weakness in numbers. It took ninety minutes to dislodge the stubborn Confederates. Despite the unexpected delays, the Union commander emerged confident of success.

A loop trail around Matthews Hill traverses the scene of the opening clash of First Manassas.

This structure served as a field hospital during both First and Second Manassas.  Built in 1848, its early years were spent as the home of farmer Henry P. Matthew and his family, who harvested the peaceful Virginia countryside surrounding the property.

Throughout the day of 21 July 1861, the House was caught in the crossfire as Union and Confederate soldiers fought through the yard following the collapse of the position on Matthews Hill.  Soldiers from various New York regiments moved around the House as they surged toward the Robinson Farm.  At the end of the Battle, Union soldiers who had sought refuge and medical aid in the house were taken prisoner. 

The House, open seasonally, includes exhibits of the history of the house and its use before, during, and after the Civil War. On the second floor are two carvings from soldiers from the 5th New York who were wounded on 30 August 1862.
stops.assetName: Auto Tour Stop #3: The Stone House

stops.significance:
The climactic struggle of the battle of First Manassas took place on Henry Hill.  A 1.1 mile loop trail explores the fighting that took place here.  

For more information on the trail, check out the self-guided Henry Hill Loop Trail guide available on this app.

Colonel Oliver O. Howard's brigade brought up the rear of the Federal flanking column. After crossing Bull Run, the New Englanders hastened towards the sounds of battle. In the mid-afternoon heat, dozens of men straggled on the march or collapsed by the roadside. By the time they reached the front, Union hopes for victory were fading.

Intending to outflank the enemy, Howard's regiments ascended to the top of this rise. Suddenly the air exploded with shell fragments. Confederate artillery opened a flanking fire from the Chinn House yard. Masses of Rebel infantry charged out of the woods. Howard's men managed a few ragged volleys before the parade-style battle lines began to break. The retreat gathered momentum and soon the Union army was in full flight.

A paved trail begins at the parking lot that will lead you to a marker near the site of Howard's brief stand.  Along the way, markers and cannon discuss the heavy fighting that took place here 13 months later at the end of the Battle of Second Manassas.

data.description: The Florida National Scenic Trail stretches about 1,400 miles from Gulf Islands National Seashore to Big Cypress National Preserve. The northernmost section of the trail, located within this park, begins at Fort Pickens and runs parallel to the coastline for 7 miles before exiting the park, then reentering in the Santa Rosa area for another 7 miles. The first few miles of trail provide opportunities to view wildlife, camp, and dip your toes in the ocean.

data.description: As a Third System fort, Fort Barrancas belonged to one of the most advanced systems of seacoast defenses in the world. Built between 1839–1844, the fort helped defend Pensacola Bay and the Pensacola Navy Yard from foreign attack. While seen as a symbol of peace, the fort was born from a great injustice. Today Fort Barrancas stands as a monument to human ingenuity and a memorial to the victims and survivors of enslavement. Begin your visit at the Fort Barrancas Visitor Center before your tour.

data.description: Explore Fort Frederica at your own pace with the self-guided tour. Stops include excavated settlers' plots and remnants of the British barracks and fort. Tune into the audio provided for more context at each stop.

images.altText: Remains of the King's Magazine, a tabby concrete fortification; grass area beside, salt marsh behind
images.caption: Explore Fort Frederica and its history by following the self-guided audio tour.
images.title: Fort Frederica Self-Guided Tour

stops.significance: Frederica was the name of both a fort and its associated town.  James Oglethorpe founded Frederica in 1736 to defend the three-year-old colony of Georgia. This model shows Frederica as she might have looked when her defenses were complete.

The figure is of James Edward Oglethorpe.  A respected scholar and member of the British Parliament, Oglethorpe served on Georgia’s board of Trustees, an elite council created by King George the Second.  The only Trustee ever to set foot in Georgia, he personally directed and defended the colony for ten years.

This walkway was once Military Road, the first colonial highway on St. Simons Island. Military Road extended from Fort St. Simons on the south tip of the island to the gates of Frederica. The moat was a part of the defenses of the town wall.
Earth works now covered with trees once supported a double wall of cedar posts eight-to-ten feet high. Inside ten streets divided the towns 84 lots.
Stop 5: BROAD STREET

This sign labeled “Indian Interpreter” marks the site of the home of Mary Musgrove Matthews. Half-Creek Indian and half-Scottish, Matthews was a frontier trader and Oglethorpe’s interpreter and liaison to the Indians. Her diplomacy bridged the gap between the two cultures and aided Oglethorpe’s desire for humane and peaceful relations with the Indians.

This house was the home of John Levally, Jr., a shoemaker from Charing Cross. Georgia welcomed men like Levally, the laborers and craftsmen Oglethorpe called England’s “worthy poor.” Like the Mary Matthews house, Levally’s house was made of tabby, a building material like concrete made from sand, lime, oyster shells and water, all materials available along the Georgia coast.

Frederica’s first houses were simple huts thatched with palmetto fronds. John Humble, the first occupant of this lot, stayed in his palmetto bower for years. The tabby foundations you see here may be from a later resident, Dr. Holzendorf.

This house, a duplex, features two brick hearths back-to-back along the center wall.  William Allen, one of the residents on this lot, was the village baker. Brick houses were rare at Frederica as early on brick had to be imported. By the end of 1737, however, brickmakers were consistently making bricks of a much better composition than formerly. Brick remained a building material for the middling and upper classes.
The intersection at Broad Street and Cross was the center of town.  Consider the noises, sights, and smells that once filled this crossroads.
Stop 11:  HOUSTON HOUSE

The Hawkins-Davison plot featured two houses sharing a middle wall. Samuel Davison ran the most respected drinking establishment in town, where officers and gentlemen came to relax. The Davisons' neighbors on the right, Dr. and Mrs. Hawkins, were notorious in town for being the root of much drama. Dr. Hawkins was the regiment’s doctor, Frederica’s bailiff, and a successful farmer.

The fort at Frederica became the center of military operations along the southern frontier of the British colonies. There were higher, more comfortable sites for a fortress, but few better suited to a tactical defense. Fort Frederica stood at a sharp bend in the river on the inland side of the island, making it "...impossible for any boat or ship to come up or down the river without being torn to pieces.”

Like the town palisade walls, the fort itself was built of earth and timber. Soldiers stood guard at the Kings Magazine. The fort included two storehouses- where food, ammunition, and other supplies could be kept. They were also the town’s first public buildings; upper floors were used for public business and church services. A well dug provided fresh drinking water for the fort.

The home of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Perkins stood on the excavated foundations here. These original settlers were coachmakers by trade in England but were apparently prohibited to carry on their business at Frederica. They would leave Frederica in frustration after five years.

The Calwell home, three stories high, was perhaps the finest in town. John Calwell was a chandler, rendering fat to make soap and candles. Unlike Samuel Perkins, Calwell prospered in Frederica, shipping his goods as far north as Philadelphia.

The barracks tower, a reminder of the military presence at Frederica. Oglethorpe was commissioned Captain of the 42nd Regiment of Foot, also called Oglethorpe’s Regiment, who was stationed here. The barracks housed about one hundred soldiers and included a gateway tower, central parading ground, and military jail.
Daniel Cannon was a carpenter who built many of the houses at Frederica. The odd zigzagging shape of the foundation found here may result from additions to the original structure.

Tavern keeping was one of the few business occupations available to a single or widowed woman. Anne Bennett’s tavern hosted soldiers and farmers, where they could consoled themselves with drinks and games. You can imagine the heated discussions in Frederica’s three taverns. Imagine the commotion here when the Spanish fleet was sighted as it sailed into Jekyll Sound.

Oglethorpe evacuated Fort St. Simons as the Spanish landed at Gascoigne’s Bluff on July 7, 1742. Two battles that day- both British victories- at Gully Hole Creek and Bloody Marsh would solidify British Georgia's fate and vindicate Oglethorpe. Frederica had fulfilled its purpose.

James Oglethorpe would leave for England in 1743 never to return to Georgia. The war continued until 1748, but mostly in other theaters. After the war, Oglethorpe’s regiment was disbanded. Without the regiment, the military town could not support itself. In 1758, fire finished what the devastated economy had begun. Oglethorpe lived to see Georgia and its sister colonies declare their independence only forty years after he build Frederica.

data.description: Hike through millions of years of geologic time on the Fossil Discovery Trail. Each rocker layer shows evidence of former ecosystems and extinct plant and animals that lived in landscapes quite different from what we see today. Long ago, dynamic forces pushed and tilted these layers upward. Then erosion exposed the layers as colorful mounds and ridges, full of signs of ancient life.

images.altText: A sandy trail lined by stones winding through desert shrubs among rugged hills.
images.caption: The Fossil Discovery Trail travels through rocks millions of years old.
images.title: Fossil Discovery Trail

stops.significance:
This tour describes the Fossil Discovery Trail as hiked downhill from the Quarry Exhibit Hall to the Visitor Center. From the Exhibit Hall parking lot, follow the guard rail downhill (north) to find the trailhead. (You may also hike uphill from the trailhead located behind the visitor center.) Restrooms and water are available during business hours near both trailheads.

Prepare for this rocky, sun-exposed trail by wearing good hiking shoes and dressing for the weather. In summer, bring plenty of water, sunscreen, and a sun hat. The trail is very muddy and slippery when wet. From start to finish the trail is 1.25 mi (2 km) one-way with an elevation change of 150 ft (46 m). Please stay on the established trail and leave all plants, rocks, and fossils where you find them.
stops.assetName: Fossil Discovery Trail - Quarry Hall Trailhead

stops.significance: As you begin your hike, take a moment to notice the dramatic tilt of the rock layers around you. These were once horizontal layers of sediment that eventually turned into flat-lying sedimentary rock, with older layers at the bottom and younger on top. Between 50-70 million years ago, the rocks here were uplifted and folded into an arch, or anticline. Since then, much of the top of the anticline has eroded away, and what you'll hike through today are the younger layers flanking the anticline's south side.

At the end of this trail spur you will have traveled to 161-156 million years ago when this area was part of a large inland sea. The Stump Formation reveals evidence of an ocean environment with a large variety of life. Fossils in these rocks include belemnites (squid-like sea creatures), snails, ammonites, and bones of ichthyosaurs (a giant marine reptile that resembled a modern dolphin). Find and feel many small indentations and bumps on the large rocks on the ground. These are impressions of saltwater clams.

Each step leads you through rock layers with different colors, textures, and fossils. Sometimes these differences are subtle, sometimes striking. Most of the Morrison Formation is mudstone and clay, but watch for the trail spur that follows a sandstone cliff. This part of the Morrison Formation is made up of river-deposited sand and gravel. Based on radiometric dating from volcanic ash, in older and younger layers on either side of the sandstone wall, this layer is estimated to be about 151 million years old. Fossil fragments of dinosaurs are embedded in the cliff along with impressions of freshwater clams. The Morrison Formation trail spur follows the same sandstone layer that is exposed in the Quarry Exhibit Hall. However, this cliff has not been worked on by paleontologists to make the bones easier to see. The first fossils along the spur are fragments that are shiny and dark orange in color. Some have a spongey-looking interior which contained bone marrow.

The Mowry Shale is easy to overlook today, despite its fascinating history. Look for the silvery gray mounds of shale rock between the prominent ridges of the Muddy and Frontier sandstones. The older Muddy Sandstone contains 100 million year old beach sand stained bright orange and yellow by iron-rich minerals. The younger Frontier Sandstone, formed from 90 million year old beach sediments. Along the coast of an ancient sea, volcanoes (near the present California/Nevada border) spewed ash which fell into salty waters. By studying minerals decaying in the shale, geologists determined that the ash was deposited between 99 and 97 million years ago. The ash likely killed most of the fish swimming here. Currents at the bottom of the sea then scattered their scales. Look for tiny, shiny gray-to-golden fish scales fossilized in these rocks. Taking the time to discover even the tiniest of fossils can bring ancient ecosystems to life in our imaginations.

The smooth surfaces of the 90 million year old Frontier Sandstone, a shoreline of an ancient interior seaway, provided an ideal canvas for these petroglyphs left by the ancestral indigenous people of the region over a thousand years ago. These designs include both petroglyphs (patterns chipped or carved into the rock) and pictographs (patterns painted on the rock). Pictographs are relatively rare here, perhaps because they are more easily weathered. Some petroglyphs show traces of pigment, possibly indicating that many designs originally included both carved and painted areas. These designs are very fragile. Touching the petroglyphs and pictographs can damage the designs by leaving oils behind that abrade the rock. Tracing and rubbings can damage the soft sandstone designs. For these reasons, please do not touch the designs. The style and content of these ancestral native designs vary throughout the region. The “Classic Vernal Style” predominates in Dinosaur National Monument.

data.title: Fossil Discovery Trail: A Journey Through Time

stops.significance: Fossil-lovers and families alike have a great time hiking Fossil Exhibit Trail, one of the easiest hikes in the park.
The fossil record shows that ammonites were unable to survive a changing climate.
Fossils such as the Titanothere share a story about the limited options life has in the face of a change climate.
Alligators show one of the successful options to survive a changing climate: relocate!
Mesohippus is one of the ancestors of the modern-day horse. They are an example of creatures who adapted to a changing climate.
Differences in the composition of each layer reveal what the climate was like when the sediments were deposited.
Today's wolf and modern domestic dogs are descendants of early canids
Fossils can reveal how animals lived and died, and what their environment was like.
Oreodonts are one of the most common fossils found in the Badlands.

data.description: Visit key historical sites to discover the challenges our Founding Fathers faced in creating a new, republican, government.

images.altText: An 18th century etching showing caricatures of two men fighting each other on the floor of congress.
images.caption: In 1798, a fight occurred between congressmen Matthew Lyon and Roger Griswold inside Congress Hall.
images.title: Congressional Pugilists

stops.significance: From the moment that the Declaration of Independence was signed in Independence Hall in the summer of 1776, it was well understood that this new nation was going to need a framework for government; it was going to need a constitution.  Each of the thirteen states feared losing some of its authority to a strong centralized government, and so our first constitution, the Articles of Confederation, left it to the States to check the power of the federal government. This government, consisting of Congress only, could do very little without the approval and support of the states. In effect, the Congress was powerless…powerless to tax, powerless to pay its bills and powerless to defend the nation. Something needed to be done.   In the summer of 1787 fifty-five men, from twelve States met here in Pennsylvania’s State capitol building and drafted a new Constitution, a framework of balanced power, with a strong executive, a Supreme Court, and “We the People” having their voice in Congress.

Creating a framework for government is not an easy task. In the Great Essentials exhibit is a marked-up, working copy of our first framework for government, the Articles of Confederation. What do the scratch-outs and scribbles in the margin suggest? George Washington’s almost pristine copy of the Constitution, located to the right of the Articles, disguises the struggles the framers had while drafting this document.  Issues of States’ rights, representation, and slavery were hotly discussed and debated. At times it was compromise that brought them to agreement. When compromise was not possible, they left those issues for future generations to tackle.  To assist those future generations, they gave us an amendable Constitution, one that was flexible enough to absorb change.

Originally built to be a Courthouse, Congress Hall served as a temporary capitol building in the 1790s while the permanent one was being constructed in Washington DC. The House of Representatives, met on the first floor of Congress Hall, while the Senate met upstairs. Raucous arguments between “the People’s” representatives over taxation, foreign policy, finance, slavery, as well as disagreements over interpreting the Constitution helped to bring about the creation of two political parties. On the one hand was the Federalist Party led by Alexander Hamilton, and on the other, the Democratic Republicans led by Thomas Jefferson. On one occasion, an argument between two political enemies led to violence on the floor of the House of Representatives, when Roger Griswold of Connecticut began to whip Matthew Lyon of Vermont with his walking stick, forcing Lyon to defend himself with fireplace tongs. This political atmosphere in Congress Hall made some question the wisdom of allowing "the People" a role in government.

Next to the Franklin Court Printing Office stood the newspaper office of Benjamin Franklin Bache’s Philadelphia Aurora, a newspaper published in Philadelphia in the 1790s. Newspapers played an active role in the political life of the early Republic. Bache, grandson to Benjamin Franklin and a Democratic Republican, believed that the voice of the people was being ignored by the government. Angry editorials in the Aurora claimed that the Federalist Party would, “overthrow the constitution…or establish a monarchy if they could…” Federalist newspapers claimed that men like Bache threatened the “peace and safety of this country.” Criticisms of the John Adams administration brought retribution to Bache. At times Bache was physically assaulted by political opponents, and in 1798 he faced imprisonment for sedition for publishing articles critical of the government. Though Bache would die of yellow fever while awaiting trial, his arrest sparked a debate over what freedom of the press and government of the people meant.

Robert Morris’ residence was rented by Presidents George Washington and John Adams. Washington and Adams both lived and worked out of their home. They held cabinet meetings, met with foreign dignitaries, and hosted state dinners.  The Constitution’s framers believed that “the People” alone could not be trusted to govern. As part of the balance of power, the Constitution included a powerful executive. The president would be selected by an Electoral College, be given the power to veto laws made by the people’s representatives, and uphold laws deemed unpopular by “the People,” even by force if necessary. This was made evident when Washington called out state militias and led them into western Pennsylvania to put down the Whiskey Rebellion in 1794. John Adams was criticized for his role in supporting the Sedition Act which made it a crime to “write, print, utter, or publish,” anything against the U.S. government. Was it any wonder that President’s Washington and Adams would be labeled by some as monarchists?

In the late 1820s a story began to be told. It was the story of how the “Old State House Bell,” hanging in the steeple of Independence Hall, had fulfilled the words inscribed on its crown, “Proclaim Liberty Throughout All the Land Unto All the Inhabitants Thereof,” when it rang in the Declaration of Independence in 1776. This document stated that, “All men are created equal,” and that these “men” had the “unalienable” right of having a say in their government. Soon after, abolitionists recognizing that these rights did not apply to all, adopted this Bell as a symbol in their struggle to make enslaved men a part of “We the People,” and renamed it the Liberty Bell. Later, women seeking the right to vote would also adopt it as symbol for their struggle.  Since then countless groups have used this Bell as their symbol including Civil rights activists and white supremacists; cold warriors and anti-war protestors; gun rights and gun control advocates… Who do you see adopting this Bell as a symbol of freedom today?

data.title: Founding of a Republic, 1776 - 1800

data.description: Along this self-guided tour you will see various hydrothermal features that are expressions of Yellowstone's still active volcano. Within this geologic system, each type of thermal feature is represented. They can be grouped into two general categories—those with a great deal of water (hot springs and geysers) and those with limited water (mudpots and fumaroles). Despite their structural similarities, no two features are exactly alike.

data.description: In "Frederick Douglass's Journey," you will hear many of the significant moments in Mr. Douglass's life, often as remembered by him. The historical writings of others who knew him will fill in the narrative as you travel across some of the highlights of this human rights champion's 77 years of life. Explore a deeper look beneath the surface level at what motivated Frederick Douglass, and find plenty of places to continue your own journey further. What motivates you?

images.altText: Douglass later years
images.caption: Frederick Douglass pictured in 1894, a year before his death.
images.title: Frederick Douglass as an elder

stops.significance: Frederick Douglass spent his life fighting for justice and equality. Born into slavery in 1818, he escaped as a young man and became a leading voice in the abolitionist movement. People everywhere still find inspiration today in his tireless struggle, brilliant words, and inclusive vision of humanity. Learn about Douglass's legacy and how it is preserved here at Cedar Hill, where he lived his last 17 years, while walking and touring the Grounds.

data.description: In December of 1862, the US Army of the Potomac crossed the Rappahannock and faced the Confederate Army of Northern Virginia. With a defensive line encircling Fredericksburg, the Confederates pushed the Federals back across the river in a devastating defeat for the US Army. This tour follows the route indicted by the numbered stops on the circular battlefield tour signs on the park map and out in the landscape. The battlefield includes shared public roads that may move at high speeds. Drive carefully.

images.altText: A cannon pointing atop a hill in late fall.
images.caption: Cannons atop Prospect Hill
images.title: Prospect Hill

stops.significance:
On December 13, 1862, United States forces under General Ambrose Burnside attacked the stone wall along the Sunken Road. Wave after wave of US soldiers marched towards the Confederate line; none made it closer than 50 yards. Confederate troops behind the stone wall and atop Marye's Heights held the high ground with their well-defended line. The Federal soldiers' assaults across Fredericksburg's open fairgrounds proved futile and left the soldiers exhausted and demoralized. They would not forget the loss they experienced at the Sunken Road. 

Casualties on this side of the battlefield were dramatically lopsided. By the end of December 13, 1862, there were around 1,500 Confederate casualties and 8,000 Federal casualties.

After the battle, a question haunted these soldiers: how did this happen? In this tour we will learn about the events of December 1862, the circumstances that led to battle here, and how the country was forever changed after of the Battle of Fredericksburg.

Both physically and chronologically, the Battle of Fredericksburg started at Chatham. Originally established as a slave plantation, Chatham embodies the main cause of the Civil War: the desire of white Southerners to maintain and protect the institution of slavery and the resulting material wealth that slavery produced for them.

On December 11, 1862, the Army of the Potomac commanded by Major General Ambrose Burnside, crossed the Rappahannock River below Chatham Manor. The engineers had only managed to build the bridge halfway across the river when shots rang out and the Battle of Fredericksburg began.

On the western side of Fredericksburg, atop a hill once known as Telegraph Hill, Confederate General Robert E. Lee made his headquarters in anticipation of battle. Initially, Lee and the Confederate Army of Northern Virginia were situated further south. As reports came in that the United States Army was amassing at Fredericksburg, Lee moved his army into position surrounding the town.

When Burnside and the Army of the Potomac arrived at Chatham, Lee was unsure of the Federals' plan. Where would Burnside cross the Rappahannock: right there at town, further upstream, further downstream? Lee was not prepared to face the larger US Army of 120,000 men because he had divided his forces,  with Jackson in the Shenandoah Valley and Longstreet in Culpeper.

From this hill, Lee was able to see both ends of his line: the north end above the stone wall and the south end on Prospect Hill. His vantage point gave him the opportunity to know what was happening and adapt if necessary.

Howison Hill, named for the Howison family that lived nearby, was an artillery position during the battle of Fredericksburg. In this area, Jane Howison Beale and her family watched the battle of Fredericksburg and she recorded her observations, thoughts, and feelings about the scene.

Lee utilized the high hills west of Fredericksburg for his defenses, giving his artillery clear views of the oncoming Federal troops. Citizens also used the heights to observe the battle, hoping that their homes would not be destroyed in the chaos. They watched and waited to see if they would have homes or a town to return to.

Around 1:00pm on December 13, 1862, Union General George Gordon Meade's 4,500-man division crossed an open field under intense artillery fire. Meade aimed for a swampy tract of woods that Confederate General A.P. Hill left undefended, thinking it was impassible. When Meade's troops broke through the Confederate line they surprised unprepared South Carolinians. Soon the Confederates rallied, and without reinforcements nearby, Meade's men could not hold their position against Confederate General Stonewall Jackson's 38,000-man corps.

When the Army of the Potomac arrived across the Rappahannock, the Army of Northern Virginia had few forces defending Fredericksburg. Robert E. Lee sent word to "Stonewall" Jackson, leading the 2nd Corps, to transition his troops from the Shenandoah Valley and join the rest of the Army of Northern Virginia at Fredericksburg. Jackson's troops were sometimes referred to as a "foot cavalry" because of their ability to move quickly. On November 24, Jackson's troops began the march. They traveled 13 to 17 miles a day and covered almost 175 miles. The 2nd Corps arrived in Fredericksburg on December 3. These Confederate forces formed a defensive line on the southern portion of the battlefield here at Prospect Hill.

Fighting at here was not as lopsided at it was at the Sunken Road, though the casualties were still steep; about 4,000 Confederates and about 5,000 Federals would become casualties at Prospect Hill.

data.title: Fredericksburg: Driving Tour

data.description: Why did this place matter in 1862?...and why does it matter today? Explore the Sunken Road through this guided walking tour that follows along the Sunken Road, where US soldiers made futile assaults against Confederate soldiers behind a stone wall, up Marye's Heights, where Confederate artillery ensured the Army of Northern Virginia's success, and through the Fredericksburg National Cemetery, the final resting place for over 15,000 US soldiers. *Pets are not allowed in the National Cemetery*

images.altText: A view from atop a hill, through autumnal trees, to a gravel road with a small white house.
images.caption: From Marye's Heights, look down upon the Sunken Road and out towards Fredericksburg.
images.title: The Sunken Road from Marye's Heights

stops.significance: During the Battle of Fredericksburg the US Army of the Potomac embarked on a winter campaign and sent waves of soldiers to attack a seemingly impregnable position. Why did this happen? This tour explores the events and contexts for the Battle of Fredericksburg. Learn of the commanders, the private soldiers, and the civilians who were thrust onto the center stage of the Civil War. Wind your way up the hill and into the National Cemetery, where nearly 15,000 U.S. soldiers rest—a reminder of the cost of war and of the nation put together from the pieces left over.

The people of Fredericksburg had lived along this road for almost 130 years before the Civil War even began. How did the Sunken Road and the now infamous stone wall come to be? When war came in December 1862, the civilians of this town found themselves in the middle of the two armies almost immediately. Some refugees fled Fredericksburg; others persistently stayed. The quiet unassuming homes along the Sunken Road soon earned famous spots in American history as the settings for some of the battle of Fredericksburg’s bloodiest fighting.

The Sunken Road and the stone wall were convenient features that became critical to the Confederate defenses during the battle. How did General Robert E. Lee take advantage of his position? What would be going through the minds of the soldiers behind this wall during the battle?

The repeated Federal attacks against the base of Marye’s Heights have become the most famous event of the Battle of Fredericksburg. Futilely charging again and again without success, each US attack in turn was repulsed. Why did the Union soldiers keep attacking? Explore the decisions made by US commanders during the battle and discover how the attacks at Marye’s Heights fit into the grander battle plans at Fredericksburg.

The Confederate cannon posted on the high ground overlooking the fields in front of Marye’s Heights proved a deciding factor in the battle. Fire from these cannons made reaching the Heights an impossible goal for the United States soldiers tasked with the repeated assaults on December 13, 1862. In the midst of the political fallout from the devastating loss at Fredericksburg, President Abraham Lincoln signed the Emancipation Proclamation on January 1, 1863. How would Lincoln’s proclamation change the course of the war?

The Civil War brought death on a scale unknown to the United States. Over the four-year conflict, 2% of the country’s population was killed. In the immediate aftermath of battles like Fredericksburg, the dead were buried in hastily created pits that could hardly be called graves. Once the war was finally over, the question of what to do with the remains of those killed was unanswered. The National Cemetery system emerged from that pivotal question and provided a final resting place for United States soldiers who died. Because of the unreliable ways to identify the dead, most graves in the Fredericksburg National Cemetery are unknown. The majority of graves here are from the Civil War, though there are some from later wars as well—the cemetery was closed to further burials in the 1940s.

The end of the Civil War brought unification and the end of slavery, but it did not solve every problem that faced the United States. How would the war be remembered by survivors of both sides? What type of nation would Americans build out of the ashes of this awful conflict? These same questions that Americans faced in the postwar period still challenge us 160 years later.

data.title: Fredericksburg: Sunken Road Walking Tour

We invite you to travel back in time, commune with nature, and discover the industrial legacy still imprinted on the Dale of Hope.

data.description: With a full day at the North District in Fort Smith, Montana, take the time to truly explore the park. Bring your camper or tent and plan to stay at one of our two campgrounds. Bring your binoculars and sense of adventure. Schedule your full day boat rental with Ok-A-Beh Marina. Spend the day looking for wildlife along the shoreline and enjoying the water. Before you get the campfire roaring in the evening, check out a ranger-led campground program or enjoy the variety of birds on the Afterbay Lake.

data.description: With a full day in the Lovell, WY district of Bighorn Canyon we recommend having reservations with Hidden Treasure Charters for their scenic boat tour which allows you the opportunity to experience the expansive canyon walls from within the canyon!. Tours are approximately 2 hours and are offered at 10am and and 2pm daily. This is an excellent way to learn about the area and see the canyon from within. Outside of the boat tour, spend the rest of the day exploring the park.

images.altText: Bighorn Canyon from Sullivan's Knob Trail
images.caption: Bighorn Canyon from Sullivan's Knob Trail
images.title: Bighorn Canyon

stops.significance: When starting your tour, make sure to stop at the Cal S. Taggart Visitor Center in Lovell, Wyoming. Here you can pick up a map of the park and learn more about how the Bighorn Canyon was carved by the Bighorn River along with many exciting facts about the wildlife found within the park.
stops.assetName: Cal S. Taggart Bighorn Canyon Visitor Center (Lovell, WY District)

stops.significance:
A full day allows you to not only see the amazing canyon views from Devil Canyon Overlook, but it also allows you the opportunity to experience the expansive canyon walls from within the canyon!
We recommend having reservations with Hidden Treasure Charters for their scenic boat tour. Tours are approximately 2 hours and are offered at 10am and 2pm daily.  This is an excellent way to learn about the area and see the canyon from within. For more info visit www.hiddentreasurecharters.com. Also, feel free to grab lunch or have a picnic at one of the pavilions located near the marina. There is also a short hike and swimming area nearby.

Devil Canyon Overlook is one of the best views of the canyon in the entire park. Sheer cliff walls 1,000 feet tall allow visitors to see the diverse rock formations that make up the area along with stunning views of the water below.

Sullivan's Knob Trail is about 1 mile roundtrip and has only a small hill to descend and climb. The hike will take you to the very edge of the canyon and affords gorgeous views of the river (there is no railing here so please be careful near the edge!). This site is also a frequent spot to see bighorn sheep, so keep your eyes peeled!

Keep your eyes peeled for the Pryor Mountain Wild Mustangs as you head farther north into the park to Two Eagles interpretive trail. This 1/10th mile gravel trail takes you around several teepee rings as well as a buffalo jump while telling the story of those who lived here long ago.

Visit Ewing Snell Historic Ranch to see the amazing work our historic preservation team does to keep the ranch looking like it was in history!  At this historic ranch you can open the doors, step inside, and take a step back in time.

data.title: Full Day at Bighorn Canyon, Lovell, WY District

data.title: Geology

data.description: The geology driving tour is a great way to see the park while learning about the rich geologic history of the Black Hills. On this 20 mile long tour, you will travel back in time and view Wind Cave's rock record to get a glimpse into its past.

images.altText: Self-Guided Tour
images.caption: Two of the longest caves in the world formed in this layer of limestone, Wind Cave and Jewel Cave.
images.title: Pahasapa Limestone

stops.significance: Two of the longest caves in the world formed in this layer of limestone, Wind Cave and Jewel Cave.

Geologic age: Permian

From the visitor center, drive 3.6 miles to this stop. Exit the south end of the visitor center parking lots, turn right onto route 385 South. Near the park's south boundary, you will see outcrops from road cuts. This is the Minnekahta Limestone.

The Minnekahta Limestone is a thinly bedded gray to purplish-gray slabby limestone. Caves rarely form in this limestone because it is so thinly bedded that the ceilings would collapse.

Look for prominent layers and folds. Note the differences between the Minnekahta and the Pahasapa Limestones.

Geologic age: Pennsylvanian & Permian

Drive 3.9 miles north on route 385. Park at the Wind Cave Canyon trailhead. A short hike on the trail (1 mile round trip) is required. Outcrops of this formation are on the left side of the canyon.

The Minnelusa Formation consists of interbedded limestones, sandstones and shales. It is yellow to red, with the shales being a grayish cream. Interbedded means that the limestones, sandstones, and shales alternate with distinct horizontal layers.

Can you see distinct layers? How are the layers different from those seen in the Minnekahta Limestone?

Geologic age: Cambrian

The distance is 2.2 miles to the Deadwood Sandstone. Continue north for 1.7 miles on route 385 to the junction of route 87. Turn right and drive 0.5 miles. Look for a large basin on the left side of the road. Much of the Deadwood Sandstone is on the north end and at the bottom of the basin.

Sandstone is sedimentary rock composed mostly of grains of quartz that vary in size. The Deadwood Sandstone is brown to light gray in color.

In what types of environments does sand accumulate?
Black Hills pegmatites are some of the oldest exposed rock in the world.
Black Hills schists are some of the oldest exposed rock in the world.
Native oral traditions speak of how a great race was held among the living creatures which created the Red Racetrack around the Black Hills, also known as the Spearfish Formation or Red Valley.
stops.assetName: Stop #7: Spearfish Formation / Inyan Kara Group

data.title: Geology Driving Tour - Self-Guided

data.description: Learn about the geologic forces that shaped Joshua Tree National Park. This tour is on a rough dirt and gravel road so 4-wheel drive is recommended and high clearance in needed beyond Paac Kü̱vü̱hü̱’k, where the road splits into a one-way loop. Additional road and safety information is in stop one. There is no cell coverage in the park so you will need to save Joshua Tree National Park for offline use within the app prior to your arrival.

images.altText: A dirt road surrounded by desert vegetation and rocks.
images.title: Geology Tour Road

stops.significance: Down this dirt road, the story of Joshua Tree National Park's unique geologic history is written in the stones. A series of five roadside stops will help reveal the story these rocks have to tell. Follow this tour to travel the road and learn about the forces that have shaped Joshua Tree in the past and continue to do so today. Directions to each stop along the tour will include the mileage between stops; consider resetting your trip odometer to help you find the next stop.

Revealing Queen Valley: Look around—this open valley was formed because the valley floor you are driving across is eroding faster than the surrounding mountains. The valley floor is softer than the metamorphic rock that makes up the surrounding mountains, so it weathers and erodes faster.  

Making Gneiss: Around 20 miles (32 km) below the surface extremely high temperatures and intense pressure caused the minerals in sediments that were once on the ocean floor to rearrange and form a new, durable metamorphic rock called gneiss (pronounced “nice”).

Intrusive Granites: Oceanic crust began sliding beneath the crust of the continent, in a process called subduction. Intense heat and pressure, along with water and gases from the oceanic crust, melted rock beneath the continental crust. This melted rock was more buoyant than the crust around it, and it began to rise—though it never quite made it to the surface.
stops.assetName: California Riding and Hiking Trail at Geology Tour Road

stops.significance:
An Island Getaway 
The large boulder piles of light-colored rocks that pop up from the flat plains are inselbergs, meaning “island hill” in German; they speckle the landscape like islands speckle an ocean. Inselbergs are the core of ancient hills, and they are revealed when the soil above them weathers and erodes away. The inselbergs remain while the other substances erode away around them because they are stronger and more durable.
stops.assetName: The Towers of Uncertainty Viewpoint and Rock Climbing Access Trailhead

stops.significance:
The unique, sculpted granitic boulder piles seen throughout the park are the result of jointing, weathering, and erosion. 

1.Magma cooled and solidified miles beneath the surface to form various types of granitic rocks including the monzogranite that is common in the park.
2.Cracks or fractures— called joints— formed while these rocks were still underground due to stress from geologic forces.
3.Groundwater entered the joints and began rounding out the edges and corner, and weathering the rock into smaller pieces.
4.Erosion carried away small particles of broken-down rock, exposing rounded boulders. 

Notches mark the height and give us insight into past soil levels. The notches form because water in the soils is slightly acidic, slowly dissolving the rock away. Tafoni are concave pits of varying size that form on the rock’s surface from wind erosion or from soil contact (similar to how notches form).
stops.assetName: Star Wars Rock Viewpoint and Climbing Access Trailhead

stops.significance:
Unlike the incremental changes caused by weathering and erosion, some geologic process have changed Joshua Tree’s landscape in short, violent events.  

Malapai Hill 
Volcanic Origins: Standing tall above Queen Valley to the west, the hard, black basalt of Malapai Hill weathers and erodes slowly. This volcano is much younger than the surrounding monzogranite and likely formed within the past 15 million years. 

Blue Cut Fault 
Ancient Earnt Valley: Located to the south southwest, there has not been an earthquake on this fault in the last 8,000 years, but it is still active and could generate a moderate earthquake. One of many fault lines in the park, the Blue Cut Fault extends for over 50 miles (80 km) through the heart of the park. Earthquakes on this fault have resulted in over four miles of offset over the last few million years, with the north side of the fault moving west and the south side moving to the east and the uplift of the Hexie Mountains along the northern edge of Pleasant Valley.

This area wasn’t always a desert. As recent at 12,000 years ago, lush green vegetation covered the valleys and mountain slopes around you. Streams once fed a seasonal lake that is now the dry playa you just drove across. 

Look for the following features to see evidence of an ever-changing landscape.

Bajada: Find bajadas where alluvial fans merge to form a vast sediment slope at the mouth of canyons.

Pediment: These sloping bedrock surfaces covered by gravel can be seen along the edges of mountains.

Dry Wash: Washes transport sediment downhill. The smallest, lightest particles are carried farthest. Desert washes fill with rushing water after rain and monsoons. The washes in Joshua Tree spend most of the year dry.

Playa: Streams carried sediment into a now dry lake. Clay and silt deposits are hundreds of feet deep here.

data.description: ¡Bienvenidos a Georges Island! Este recorrido autoguiado de audio le ayudará a familiarizarse con la historia y las funciones de la isla y de Fort Warren. Esta audioguía es presentada por la asociación de Boston Harbor Islands Parque Nacional y Estatal, incluyendo el Servicio de Parques Nacionales,el Departamento de Conservación y Recreación de Massachusetts y Boston Harbor Now.

images.altText: Black sign that says "Welcome to Georges Island" logos for NPS, BHI, and BHN next to it.
images.caption: Georges Island is home to the Civil War era Fort Warren
images.title: Georges Island

park.fullName: Boston Harbor Islands National Recreation Area
park.name: Boston Harbor Islands

stops.significance:
Georges Island (Isla de Georges):
Bienvenidos a Georges Island (la isla de Georges), una de las treinta y cuatro islas y penínsulas del Parque Nacional y Estatal conocido como “Boston Harbor Islands”. Georges Island está administrada y es propiedad del Departamento de Conservación y Recreación de Massachusetts. Ubicada a siete millas del centro de Boston, esta isla de treinta y nueve acres de extensión es donde se encuentra ubicado el Fuerte Warren, que es a su vez un Monumento Histórico Nacional.

Durante su recorrido por el fuerte, busque los letreros con el logotipo de “Audio Tour”, los cuales le indicarán cada una de las paradas.

Georges Island cuenta con un Centro de visitantes, baños públicos, una venta de meriendas y varias mesas de picnic. Visite nuestro sitio web o consulte con el personal de la isla para conocer los servicios disponibles según la temporada. También puede obtener más información por su propia cuenta siguiendo esta visita autoguiada, la cual dura 50 minutos.

Centro de visitantes y Muelle:
Construido alrededor de 1825, el primer muelle en Georges Island ayudó a los trabajadores a construir un malecón y a nivelar la isla para la construcción del fuerte. En la década de 1890, el ejército reemplazó un muelle de madera ampliado con un sistema de rieles, a fin de desplazar dentro y fuera del muelle las minas submarinas y sus materiales respectivos.

Construido en 1906, el Centro de visitantes sirvió originalmente como almacén para las minas submarinas, las cuales desempeñaron un papel fundamental en la defensa del puerto de Boston. Las minas se colocaron en puntos y profundidades predeterminados del puerto, y estaban conectadas al fuerte a través de un sistema de cableado eléctrico. Durante las dos guerras mundiales, los operadores vigilantes dentro del fuerte estaban listos para detonar las minas en caso de un ataque por parte de las fuerzas alemanas.

Demi-Lune (Media Luna) y Defensas externas
La cubierta sirvió como una línea de defensa inicial y protegió las murallas de granito de Fort Warren del fuego directo de los cañones enemigos, bien fuera desde un barco de costados anchos o desde una isla cercana invadida. La estructura de piedra en forma de media luna dentro de ella se conoce como Demi-Lune. La Demi-Lune ofreció a los soldados defensores una posición cubierta para disparar contra los soldados de infantería enemigos que se acercaban desde la playa. El camino de la izquierda se construyó más tarde.

Sallyport (Puerto de salida)
La entrada más grande de Fort Warren y el acceso más fuertemente defendido era Sallyport, el puerto de salida principal. El diseño original incluía un puente levadizo y un rastrillo, así como un talud interior. El diseño actual del puente data de la Segunda Guerra Mundial. Las estrechas ventanas situadas a ambos lados permitían a los soldados defensores disparar contra los atacantes. Las varillas de hierro que sobresalían y sujetaban las puertas interiores de roble amarillo servían para disuadir los intentos de irrumpir utilizando hachas.

Bastión C
El Bastión C permanece estructuralmente sin ningún cambio desde su uso inicial. Las habitaciones interiores se han utilizado a lo largo de los años para almacenar, preparar y consumir los alimentos. La primera panadería del fuerte está situada a mano izquierda. En ella se conservan los hornos originales, y la misma estuvo en funcionamiento desde la década de 1860 hasta aproximadamente 1900, cuando se construyeron los nuevos comedores, cocinas y barracas. Al llegar la Segunda Guerra Mundial, la panadería se convirtió en el Club de Suboficiales.

Dentro del lado derecho del Bastión C hay un polvorín en forma de “L”. Este espacio está revestido en madera de cedro para ayudar a regular la humedad y la temperatura de la habitación, a fin de proteger contra la posibilidad de una chispa de fricción y una explosión accidental de la pólvora.

Frente II y Bastión B
Las casamatas del Frente II fueron diseñadas para albergar a los soldados que eran de rangos más bajos. Los alojamientos para dormir iban desde literas de tres niveles y plataformas dobles hasta somieres de metal para una sola cama. En estos salones de casamatas se albergaron en diversas ocasiones los soldados enlistados o los prisioneros, en cantidades de entre 9 y 80 personas a la vez.
El terraplén apoyaba la línea principal de los cañones, que eran principalmente cañones Rodman. Estos cañones de ánima lisa disparaban una bola de hierro de 10 pulgadas de diámetro. En la década de 1880, se insertaron mangas estriadas en los cañones, lo cual aumentó su alcance y su precisión. Se puede acceder al terraplén a un lado de la parada de la escalera.

Frente I y Bastión A
Las casamatas de estas áreas estaban originalmente divididas por la mitad. La mitad exterior daba al canal de transporte de Nantasket Roads, con dos troneras de cañón cada una. El patio de armas frente a las salas de escuadrones albergaba de 6 a 30 hombres enlistados, de acuerdo con sus respectivos rangos.

Por el lado defensivo principal del fuerte, se produjeron dos avances estructurales importantes, en gran parte debido a las necesidades de artillería. El patio del Bastión A se cubrió en la década de 1870, permitiendo un total de cinco cañones Rodman de 15 pulgadas en el terraplén, con nuevos y más grandes espacios interiores en la parte de abajo. El segundo avance fue la finalización de la Batería Stevenson en 1902, en el terraplén del Frente I. Los dos rifles desapareciendos de 12 pulgadas de Stevenson tenían un alcance de 9 millas.

Para ver Boston Light y la parte superior de la Batería Stevenson, suba las escaleras.

El Campo de desfiles y el Polvorín
En el centro de Fort Warren, el campo de desfiles a campo abierto, con un área de aproximadamente seis acres, sirvió para llevar a cabo varias actividades. Los soldados se formaban regularmente allí para hacer ejercicios, reunirse en formación, y para la inspección de las tropas. Más allá del entrenamiento y las funciones oficiales, también se hacían aquí ejercicios de calistenia y se practicaban deportes como boxeo, kickball (futbéis), fútbol y béisbol.

Situado en el patio de armas se encuentra el polvorín de la década de 1860, donde se encontraba el almacén principal de pólvora negra. Su ubicación aislada y el muro de piedra del patio favorecían la seguridad por encima del acceso conveniente a las armas. La mayor parte de la pólvora negra del fuerte se almacenaba en barriles de madera de 100 libras. Para evitar la posibilidad de que se crearan chispas, las espadas, pistolas y mosquetes o rifles se almacenaban en un almacén de artillería.

Bastión D
Como responsable del fuerte y de la prisión desde 1861 hasta 1864, el coronel Justin Dimick residió aquí, en el cuartel, con su esposa y dos de sus hijas. Los soldados de la Unión y los prisioneros Confederados consideraban a Dimick un líder compasivo y considerado. Como testimonio del carácter de Dimick, algunos prisioneros Confederados le proporcionaron a su hijo, quien era oficial de la Unión, una carta para que la llevara consigo, pidiendo que se le tratara de manera humanitaria en caso de que llegase a ser capturado por las fuerzas Confederadas.

data.title: Georges Island (Isla de Georges) Visita autoguiada

data.description: The complete 24-mile auto tour starts at the visitor center and ends at the National Cemetery. The route follows the major events in the 3-day battle and gives an overview of the actions that took place here, in what would become one of the most significant battles of the Civil War. Allow a minimum of 3 hours to complete the tour. Little Round Top (stop #8) is currently closed to all visitation for a rehabilitation project. Warfield Ridge (stop #7) is closed to vehicle traffic, but open to pedestrians.

images.altText: A green cannon with a stone wall and farm field in the background
images.caption: Confederate Artillery on Seminary Ridge
images.title: Confederate Artillery on Seminary Ridge

stops.significance:
The Battle of Gettysburg began about 8 a.m. to the west beyond the McPherson barn as Union cavalry confronted Confederate infantry advancing east along Chambersburg Pike. Heavy fighting spread north and south along this ridgeline as additional forces from both sides arrived.

Only AUDIO is available on this page. For the full VIDEO experience, click EXPLORE THIS LOCATION below.

At 1 p.m. Maj. Gen. Robert E. Rodes’s Confederates attacked from this hill, threatening Union forces on McPherson and Oak ridges. Seventy-five years later, over 1,800 Civil War veterans helped dedicate this memorial to “Peace Eternal in a Nation United.”

Only AUDIO is available on this page. For the full VIDEO experience, click EXPLORE THIS LOCATION below.

Union soldiers here held stubbornly against Rodes’s advance. By 3:30 p.m., however, the entire Union line from here to McPherson Ridge had begun to crumble, finally falling back to Cemetery Hill. When the first day ended, the Confederates held the upper hand. Lee decided to continue the offensive, pitting his 70,000-man army against Meade’s Union army of 93,000.

Only AUDIO is available on this page. For the full VIDEO experience, click EXPLORE THIS LOCATION below.

Early in the day, the Confederate army positioned itself on high ground here along Seminary Ridge, through town, and north of Cemetery and Culp’s hills. Union forces occupied Culp’s and Cemetery hills, and along Cemetery Ridge south to the Round Tops. The lines of both armies formed two parallel “fishhooks.”

Only AUDIO is available on this page. For the full VIDEO experience, click EXPLORE THIS LOCATION below.

The large open field to the east is where the last Confederate assault of the battle, known as “Pickett’s Charge,” occurred July 3.

Only AUDIO is available on this page. For the full VIDEO experience, click EXPLORE THIS LOCATION below.

In the afternoon of July 2, Lt. Gen. James Longstreet placed his Confederate troops along Warfield Ridge, anchoring the left of his line in these woods.

Only AUDIO is available on this page. For the full VIDEO experience, click EXPLORE THIS LOCATION below.

WARFIELD RIDGE IS CURRENTLY CLOSED TO VEHICLE TRAFFIC, BUT IS ACCESSIBLE TO PEDESTRIANS VIA SOUTH CONFEDERATE AVENUE.

Longstreet’s assaults began here at 4 p.m. They were directed against Union troops occupying Devil’s Den, the Wheatfield, and Peach Orchard, and against Meade’s undefended left flank at the Round Tops.

Only AUDIO is available on this page. For the full VIDEO experience, click EXPLORE THIS LOCATION below.

LITTLE ROUND TOP IS CLOSED TO ALL VISITATION.

Quick action by Brig. Gen. Gouverneur K. Warren, Meade’s chief engineer, alerted Union officers to the Confederate threat and brought Federal reinforcements to defend this position.

Only AUDIO is available on this page. For the full VIDEO experience, click EXPLORE THIS LOCATION below.

Charge and countercharge left this field and the nearby woods strewn with over 4,000 dead and wounded.

Only AUDIO is available on this page. For the full VIDEO experience, click EXPLORE THIS LOCATION below.

The Union line extended from Devil’s Den to here, then angled northward on Emmitsburg Road. Federal cannon bombarded Southern forces crossing the Rose Farm toward the Wheatfield until about 6:30 p.m., when Confederate attacks overran this position.

Only AUDIO is available on this page. For the full VIDEO experience, click EXPLORE THIS LOCATION below.

While fighting raged to the south at the Wheat- field and Little Round Top, retreating Union soldiers crossed this ground on their way from the Peach Orchard to Cemetery Ridge.

Only AUDIO is available on this page. For the full VIDEO experience, click EXPLORE THIS LOCATION below.

Union artillery held the line alone here on Cemetery Ridge late in the day as Meade called for infantry from Culp’s Hill and other areas to strengthen and hold the center of the Union position.

Only AUDIO is available on this page. For the full VIDEO experience, click EXPLORE THIS LOCATION below.

About 7 p.m., Confederates attacked the right flank of the Union army and occupied the lower slopes of Culp’s Hill. The next morning the Confederates were driven off after seven hours of fighting.
Only AUDIO is available on this page. For the full VIDEO experience, click EXPLORE THIS LOCATION below.

At dusk, Union forces repelled a Confederate assault that reached the crest of this hill. By day’s end, both flanks of the Union army had been attacked and both had held, despite losing ground. In a council of war, Meade, anticipating an assault on the center of his line, determined that his army would stay and fight.

Only AUDIO is available on this page. For the full VIDEO experience, click EXPLORE THIS LOCATION below.

Late in the afternoon, after a two-hour cannonade, some 7,000 Union soldiers posted around the Copse of Trees, The Angle, and the Brian Barn, repulsed the bulk of the 12,000-man “Pickett’s Charge” against the Federal center. This was the climactic moment of the battle. On July 4, Lee’s army began retreating. Total casualties (killed, wounded, captured, and missing) for the three days of fighting were 23,000 for the Union army and as many as 28,000 for the Confederate army.

Only AUDIO is available on this page. For the full VIDEO experience, click EXPLORE THIS LOCATION below.

This was the setting for Lincoln’s Gettysburg Address, delivered at the cemetery’s dedication on November 19, 1863.

Only AUDIO is available on this page. For the full VIDEO experience, click EXPLORE THIS LOCATION below.

data.title: Gettysburg Auto Tour

data.description: This tour of the Gettysburg National Cemetery starts at the Taneytown Road entrance. You may follow the path from the Visitor Center to this point or park at the Cemetery parking area adjacent to the Taneytown Road. From the parking lot follow the short walking path up the hill and carefully cross the Taneytown Road to enter the Cemetery. Please be wary of vehicular traffic. The principal tour consists of five main stops (although you are encouraged to explore other elements of the cemetery at your leisure)

images.altText: A black and white metal sign that reads "Silence and Respect"
images.caption: A silence and respect sign for the Gettysburg National Cemetery
images.title: Gettysburg National Cemetery Sign

stops.significance: The Gettysburg National Cemetery is famous throughout the world today as the site of Abraham Lincoln’s Gettysburg Address, delivered at the cemetery’s dedication ceremony four and a half months after the battle. The monument to your right, the Lincoln Speech Memorial, honors that moment and the 16th president’s words.

This artillery, along with the other cannons and monuments located throughout the cemetery, not only mark the specific locations of Union artillery and infantry during the fighting, but also reflect the importance of Cemetery Hill during all three days of the battle.

The recovery efforts began almost immediately following the battle. David Wills led the charge to create a common burial ground for the Union Dead, leading to the creation of the National Cemetery.

The Lincoln Speech Memorial is unique: it commemorates the speech Lincoln gave here and not the man himself. Thus, it is one of the few memorials in the world dedicated to honor a speech.

The graves are arranged in a wide semi-circle that radiate out from the Soldiers’ National Monument, to your right, which marks the center of the cemetery. The burials were organized around state sections, divided into an inner ring (for smaller states) and outer ring (for larger states). This design was created by William Saunders, a famed “landscape gardener” (and later one of the founders of the National Grange), thus “the position of each lot, and indeed of each interment, is relatively of equal importance.”

The Soldiers’ National Monument, long misidentified as the spot from which Lincoln spoke, honors the fallen soldiers. The figures of War (the soldier), Clio, the Muse of History (represented by the woman writing upon the tablet), Plenty (woman holding a sheaf of wheat) and Peace (the mechanic) surmount the base, while the figure of Liberty mourning her dead appears on the pedestal. It was actually on the crown of this hill, a short distance on the other side of the iron fence and inside the Evergreen Cemetery, where President Lincoln delivered the Gettysburg Address to a crowd of some 15,000 people.

data.title: Gettysburg National Cemetery Walking Tour

data.description: Mount Rainier is the most glaciated peak in the contiguous United States with 28 named glaciers, plus numerous unnamed snowfields. Learn more about the major glaciers in this virtual tour, starting in clockwise order around the mountain with Carbon Glacier in the north.

images.altText: Rocky glaciated mountain
images.caption: South Tahoma & Tahoma Glaciers as seen from the trail to Indian Henry's Hunting Ground
images.title: South Tahoma & Tahoma Glaciers

stops.significance: Located on the north side of Mount Rainier, the Carbon Glacier has the lowest terminus of any glacier in the contiguous United States.
Located on the northeast side of Mount Rainier, the Winthrop Glacier is the second largest glacier on the mountain.
The Emmons Glacier has the largest area of any glacier in the contiguous United States.
Cowlitz and Ingraham are two glaciers that share a common terminus on the southeast slope of Mount Rainier.
Nearly a century ago, the ice caves of the Paradise-Stevens Glacier were one of the main attractions of the park. Today, the glacier has rapidly retreated, leaving a barren rocky valley.
Due to its proximity to Paradise, the Nisqually Glacier is the most visited and best surveyed glacier on Mount Rainier.
Located on the southwest side of Mount Rainier, the Kautz Glacier is a significant player in the recent geologic and climbing history of the mountain.
Located on the southwest side of Mount Rainier, South Tahoma and Tahoma Glaciers are separate glaciers that were connected in the recent historical past.
Puyallup Glacier begins high on the mountain in Sunset Amphitheater and ends in a hanging valley.
This large glacier on the northeast side of Mount Rainier is one of the most visible glaciers from the Seattle-Tacoma area.
The Columbia Crest Glacier occupies the summit crater on Mount Rainier.

data.title: Glaciers of Mount Rainier

data.description: "Have you ever wondered about the wooden sculptures throughout the Presidio? Andy Goldsworthy is a site-specific artist who created these sculptures using materials found in the Presidio. The idea is to invite viewers to experience the familiar in a new way. These sculptures are designed to change and ultimately “return to the earth.” Goldsworthy says the pieces are meant to serve not just as objects, but as layers, adding on to the long history of the site.
