data.description: The 1.3 mile (2.1 km) section of paved rim trail between Yavapai Geology Museum and Verkamp's Visitor Center features rock samples, fossils, interpretive waysides, and viewing aids to help you discover the geologic processes and the vast amounts of time involved in forming the Grand Canyon that we know and love today. While the trail can be walked in either direction this tour runs East to West, or from the most recent events to the most ancient. Adjust this tour to fit your needs.

images.altText: A paved path lined by exhibits and people next to Grand Canyon
images.caption: With plenty of canyon views this trail is both scenic and informative
images.title: Trail of Time

stops.significance:
Built in 1928 to help inform visitors to Grand Canyon about its vast geologic resources and stories the Yavapai Geology Museum is a must see for anyone interested in knowing more about how Grand Canyon formed. 

Filled with interpretive exhibits, waysides, and maps the Geology Museum provides an excellent overview of current thinking around the geologic process that shaped the canyon. 

Start here for a big picture idea of canyon formation and then head out to the Trail of Time for more details and a better sense of time between each of the processes involved.

Welcome to eastern end of the Trail of Time! 

This outdoor geologic display was designed to help those interested in understanding Grand Canyon's geology learn not only about the processes involved in the creation of Grand Canyon, but the vast amount of time needed as well. 

Set-up as a timeline along the rim of Grand Canyon you will find interpretive displays, samples of actual Grand Canyon rocks, time markers, and visual aids to help with coming to terms with over one billion years of history. 

The rocks around this entry portal come from Grand Canyon's youngest sources and include harden lava and cave spring deposits. As you walk this section of the trail you will travel back one million years in Grand Canyon history.
stops.assetName: Trail of Time: The Million Year Walk Portal

stops.significance:
From here on each "big" step you take will represent 1 million years in Earth's past along our geologic timeline. The bronze markers you see in the path will help to keep you oriented with your place in time.

Look at the rocks and paving stones surrounding this Trail of Time portal to see rocks and fossils from the upper layers of Grand Canyon.
stops.assetName: Trail of Time: The Main Trail of Time Portal

stops.significance:
The story of life and the fossils they left behind at Grand Canyon isn't about large dinosaurs, or even smaller mammal like reptiles, or the first birds with feathers, it's about the beginning. It's about firsts. 

When the oldest rocks of Grand Canyon were forming life as we know didn't exist and it wouldn't be until much later that the canyon's paleoenvironments would record sheets of single celled bacteria, the first complex eyes, and the first amphibians to walk across the ground.
stops.assetName: Animal Life Appeared About 630 Million Years Ago

stops.significance:
Up to this point we've been looking at the younger sedimentary rocks that dominate so much of the view here at Grand Canyon. These rocks make up the colorful layers, cliffs, peaks, and slopes of the canyon walls, but are only part of the story told in the canyon's layers. 

As you head further west from this point the rocks transition into the harder metaphoric and ingenious rocks that serve as the base for the canyon region. Their story is of a planet still young and represent some of the oldest rock still visible on the surface of the Earth.
stops.assetName: Trail of Time: Headquarters Portal (Parking Lot A)

stops.significance:
The nearby Elves Chasm Gneiss is the oldest known rock found at Grand Canyon and marks the beginning of the long, long process that would eventually end in the creation of the canyon that we see here today. 

Even though most of the canyon's unique size, shape, and color comes from the younger sedimentary rocks layered on top, without these harder layers forming the base of the region the uplift experienced millions of years later would have created a drastically different landscape. One that would have eroded to form something completely different than what see here today. 

Each rock here at the canyon has its own story to tell and their own part to play in the landscape we see before us. 

The story of Grand Canyon is a long and complicated one. A story geologists are still exploring and discovering themselves, but in that exploration we continue to learn more about not only the canyon, but the way in which our world works.
stops.assetName: Grand Canyon's Rocks Are Incredibly Old

stops.significance:
Marking the western end of the Trail of Time this portal features some of the oldest rocks found at Grand Canyon and concludes this portion of the trail, but not the story of Earth whose beginning lies even further in the past.  

For the adventurous and insatiable there are more Trail of Time waysides and markers further west of the Village along the Rim Trail. There you'll find markers for the Earth's formation and even the beginning of the universe. 

Coming to terms with the vast amounts of time involved with a geologic story like Grand Canyon's is one of the hardest parts of telling this story. Hopefully by seeing not only when the steps of canyon formation happened, but the long gaps in between helps to impart some sense of everything that goes into making a Grand Canyon.
stops.assetName: Trail of Time: Verkamp's Visitor Center Portal

data.title: Grand Canyon Geology - The Trail of Time

data.description: Start at the Monument parking lot,170 Mile Creek Road in Grand Portage. See the Heritage Center and work your way through the historic site structures. Add a hike to the top of Mount Rose for a stunning view of the bay, which will take you back to the parking area.

stops.significance: The Heritage Center is the first stop. Speak with staff, watch the park film, and view exhibits about the fur trade and Anishinaabe culture past and present. Pick up your Junior Ranger booklet and stamp your passport here.
Here you find yourself with traditional birchbark lodges. Learn about Anishinaabe lifeways, try out lacrosse, sit on animal skins, and hear the language spoken. Check out the Three Sisters Garden.
Inside the Warehouse are examples of era trades. See a treadle lathe in action, watch coopering (barrel making) and learn about canoe construction. Overhead are replicas of North West Company canoes.

This is an example of a state-of-the-art kitchen of the time. Watch staff demonstrate hearth cooking and see the tools that make it possible. Make sure to visit the bread oven and garden out back.
Continue your journey with the Mount Rose Trail from the Historic Depot Tour.

data.description: Learn about Acadia's natural and historical resources on the scenic Great Head Trail! From the park's 400-million-year old volcanic origins to a dramatic shipwreck on Sand Beach, the Great Head Trail contains many stories. This moderate hike is roughly two miles long and includes rolling terrain with some short, steep climbs. Wear sturdy shoes and bring a hat, sunscreen, bug spray, and water with you. Due to limited service, save Acadia for offline use on the NPS app to access these tour stops on trail.

images.altText: a spit of land covered in trees protects a sandy beach from the atlantic ocean.
images.caption: The Great Headlands contain many fascinating stories.
images.title: Great Head

stops.significance: Satterlee Field is named for the Satterlee family, who donated much of their coastal estate to Acadia National Park after the Fire of 1947.
The Schooner Tay once crashed on Sand Beach, leaving behind a skeleton-like shipwreck that would later get covered by the dunes.

Acadia National Park now exists where an ancient volcano once stood. Over 400 million years ago, that volcano formed rocks which now lie on Sand Beach. These rocks tell us about Acadia's geologic past.
Hints of the Satterlee property are along the Great Head Trail. This millstone gives hikers a glimpse into the landform's history as a family estate.

The Beehive, a mountain easily seen from the Great Head Trail, was shaped by glaciers. At this stop, learn more about how glaciers gave the Beehive its unique shape and created the famously steep path up to its summit.

Old Soaker, a low-lying rock ledge seen from the Great Head Trail, helps to protect Sand Beach from rough waves. Sandy beaches in Maine are unique, but Acadia boasts one of the best -- all thanks to the protection from Old Soaker!

In its heyday, the Satterlee Estate contained a teahouse for hosting guests. Although it was a sturdy structure, most of it was lost to the Fire of 1947. Today, remnants of the teahouse can be seen along Great Head Trail.
Cobble beaches are much more common than sand beaches in Acadia National Park. This one resembles a classic cobble beach, a well-known beach type along the Maine coastline.

The Fire of 1947 blazed through much of Acadia National Park, including the Great Headlands. The fire changed the forest type in many park areas and it also resulted in the Satterlee family donating the remainder of their estate on Great Head to the park.

The Satterlee Estate has been a part of Acadia for many years, but echoes of its past are all along the Great Head Trail. Here, there is a glimpse at this property's past: a driveway turnaround on trail.
Estuaries serve as important ecosystems where saltwater and freshwater communities meet. The estuary behind Sand Beach provides habitat for much of the park's marine and avian wildlife.

data.title: Great Head Guided Hike

data.description: Join this guided walk written by a Glacier Bay Park Ranger. The Forest Loop Trail is a great short hike in Bartlett Cove, able to completed in an average of about 45 minutes.

images.altText: A reflective pond with dense, marshy forest edge.
images.caption: Blackwater Pond is a unique feature of this guided walk.
images.title: Blackwater Pond

stops.significance:
Welcome to Bartlett Cove here in Glacier Bay National Park and Preserve. You are one of the small percentage of visitors who will explore this landscape on foot. Before heading off on the trail, let's take a moment to talk about safety. This self-guiding walk will take approximately 45 minutes at a comfortable walking pace.

Safety -
- Footwear: Comfortable sturdy shoes are recommended. The path is uneven with rocks and roots.
- Dress for the weather, which can change quickly. It's always good to have raingear handy.
- The route of this walk crosses roads and a parking lot. Please exercise caution when in these areas.
- Moose: Should you encounter a moose, increase the distance between you and the moose as quickly as possible.
- Bear: Should you encounter a bear, do not run. Stand your ground. Raise your arms above your head to make yourself big. Talk to the bear in firm, calm voice. If there are several of you, group together. For more info about bear safety, see Page 33 of the Fairweather Visitor Guide.
stops.assetName: Glacier Bay National Park Visitor Center

stops.significance: Glacier Bay is the traditional homeland of the Hoonah Tlingit, who have inhabited this region from time immemorial. They lived on a vast glacial plain which once extended across what is now the lower portion of the bay.  Imagine that, where today you see water, there once was land. That land was sandwiched between the sea and a large glacier. During the Little Ice Ages, temperatures cooled and that glacier moved forward. The land on which the Tlingit lived was overrun and the people were forced to flee. They left in canoes very similar to the one you see in front of you. This canoe provides us a clue about the age of these forests. It was carved from the trunk of a Sitka spruce tree, the same species you can see growing on the hillside behind it.

The Bartlett Cove around us today is very different from the way this area looked 250 years ago. Back then there was no bay! A giant ice sheet blanketed the region.  Since that time, the ice has receded. Seawater flooded the areas below sea level, creating the bay as we know it. Life has and continues to return to this landscape. By examining the land we can learn much about change and recovery. During this walk, we will explore the processes reshaping the landscape in the wake of the ice's retreat.

It has been said: "Buy land, they're not making anymore." But here in Glacier Bay, we are. The glacier that overran the Tlingit Homeland eventually receded. As it did so, a great weight was removed from the Earth's crust and as a result the land began rising in much the same way the surface of a cushion rises after you’ve been sitting on it. This is called isostatic rebound or post-glacial rebound. Today, the land in Glacier Bay is rising at a rate of about 1.5 inches per year -- faster than anywhere else on the planet. Notice the U.S.G.S. benchmark on top of this rock. It was placed here in 1966. Today it sits about five feet higher than it did then. Also, if you look across the cove, you’ll notice a point which juts out into the bay. From this angle, it’s evident that the trees are shorter closer to the shoreline. That’s because they’re younger, growing on land that only recently emerged from the sea.

Take a close look at the beach rocks and you'll notice they have lichen growing on them. In the classic story of plant succession, lichen spores carried on the wind are among the first life forms to return to the barren landscape after the glacier ice melts away. Landing on rocks, the lichen spores anchored themselves to the rock, and began to break down the rock surface making it possible for mosses to find purchase. Moss further breaks down the rock into soil making it possible for flowering plants and trees to move in. Alder helps put nitrogen into the soil making it possible for bigger trees to grow, like quick growing willows and cottonwoods. Later, spruce seeds germinate in the alder-leaf litter and, once they emerge into sunlight, they also grow rapidly. The spruce trees grow to great heights and will eventually crowd out the other trees. This process of each organism preparing the land for the one that follows is called succession. However, it is not always as systematic as that.

Smaller, weaker trees with shallow root systems are especially susceptible to wind gusts. But they may help other trees survive by becoming "nurse logs”, which play an important role in forest ecology. On the forest floor, the dense cover of ferns can impede the growth of new trees. Downed trees can provide an excellent perch for seedlings to take root. Also, by falling the dead tree opens up space in the forest canopy allowing light to reach the forest floor. As the logs decay, their accumulated nutrients become available to young trees and moss that also grows on the log helps retain water. Eventually nurse logs will rot away altogether, but by then the younger trees growing out of them may have extended their roots into the soil so they can survive on their own. In some places you will find rows of trees growing around seemingly hollow spaces where nurse logs once existed.

By now you may have noticed that Sitka spruce (Picea sitchensis) have singular dark green needles that are square and sharp to the touch. They have scaly bark that flakes off in small circular plates. Also present are western hemlock (Tsuga heterophylla) with blunt-tipped, soft, shiny, flat needles and stringy bark that becomes thick and furrowed with age. The relationship between these two trees and their presence in this forest is like that old story of the tortoise and the hare. Spruce grow quickly and need considerable sunshine. Hemlock grow slowly, but are shade tolerant. Though it seems like there are more spruce present right now, hemlocks might be slowly catching up and may eventually dominate. Time will tell.
stops.assetName: Hemlock vs Spruce in Glacier Bay

stops.significance: You have just climbed up a pile of debris -- a "moraine" -- left by the glacier that carved out the bay. A glacier is like a giant bulldozer, moving a lot of rock and rubble before it and along its sides as it flows out of the mountains. The moraine at the very end of the glacier is the "terminal moraine" while those along the sides are called "lateral moraines." You are standing on a lateral moraine. Notice the trees get bigger as the walk continues. These trees are older than those on the beach, which are growing on land that has emerged relatively recently due to post-glacial rebound.
stops.assetName: Top of the Hill - Forest Loop Trail

stops.significance: This huge rock looks out of place in this forest. That's because it is! The rock came from up the bay and rode piggyback on the glacier to this point. When the ice receded it abandoned the rock, which is why it is called a "glacial erratic." Notice the lichen and moss growing on the rock, starting the process of breaking down the rock into soil.

As with the small pond you passed by earlier, this pond likely began as a depression in the glacial moraine that eventually became lined with debris and sediment, which formed a "hard pan" that impeded drainage allowing it to fill with water. You'll notice many trees have fallen into the pond, the shores of which are lined with sphagnum moss and buckbean. It is possible that this pond is in the process of changing into "muskeg," which is a spongy, wet bog. As muskeg is highly acidic, it is difficult for things to grow. This might be the climax development for this part of the forest. However, if this pond were to drain, vegetation and trees might eventually take over. Time -- a long time -- will tell.

Examine the roots of this massive tree that toppled over some time ago. Notice the rocks embedded in the roots -- rocks carried by glaciers to this area from somewhere up the bay. If there is anything represented here it is the concept of change. Over the course of this walk we have explored various forces at work that influence what we see around us. From the land rising up due to isostatic rebound, to the challenges for small plants trying to colonize this new landscape, to the difficulties of trees trying to take root in the wake of receding ice, to great trees that grow and eventually fall -- this place is anything but static. These forces and likely others will remain at play long after we are gone.
stops.assetName: Root Ball - Forest Loop Trail Conclusion

data.title: Guided Walk - Forest Loop Trail

stops.significance: The gasholder housed a well for the natural gas reservoir found on the Garfield property in the 1880s.

The Windmill on the Garfield property was built under the eye of Mrs. Garfield in 1894. Inside the structure was a 1,000 water tank which fed water through  underground pipes to a 300 gallon tank on the third floor of the Garfield home. From there, modern amenities like sinks and toilets were installed.
This small building served as James A. Garfield's library but in 1880, during the presidential campaign was converted into the campaign office.
stops.assetName: Campaign Office of James A. Garfield

stops.significance: This chicken coop was constructed by Mrs. Garfield in 1893 when she was changing the look of the family farm.
The granary is an original building from James A. Garfield's era.  Not much is known about this building other than it housed grains used for the farm as well as the farm animals.
This Horse Barn is one of the original buildings from James A. Garfield's lifetime. It was originally to the left, looking north,of the Garfield Home but moved to its current location in 1893.

data.description: This tour is in the south of the Parks. Almost two-thirds of the land now in Redwood National and State Parks was logged before becoming part of the Parks. This means over 70,000 acres of forests and rivers need restoration, and a hundred of miles of logging roads still need to be removed. Since the late 1970s, we have been working behind the scenes on habitat restoration efforts. See how today's ambitious "Redwoods Rising" habitat restoration project will improve the Parks for future generations.

data.title: Half Day at Bighorn Canyon, Fort Smith, MT District

data.description: With half a day to spend in Bighorn Canyon, there is so much you can see! Start at the Lovell visitor center to get a map and then head out into the park! You will experience breath taking views at Devil Canyon Overlook, learn about Native American culture at the Two Eagles Interpretive Trail, go for a hike, visit a historic ranch to learn about past of the area, and, if you are really lucky, see some wildlife like our famous wild horses or bighorn sheep!

images.altText: Pryor Mountain Horse
images.caption: Pryor Mountain Horse
images.title: Pryor Mountain Horse

stops.significance: When starting your tour, make sure to stop at the Cal S. Taggart Visitor Center in Lovell, Wyoming. Here you can pick up a map of the park and learn more about how the Bighorn Canyon was carved by the Bighorn River along with many exciting facts about the wildlife found within the park.
stops.assetName: Cal S. Taggart Bighorn Canyon Visitor Center (Lovell, WY District)

stops.significance: Devil Canyon Overlook is one of the best views of the canyon in the entire park. Sheer cliff walls 1,000 feet tall allow visitors to see the diverse rock formations that make up the area along with stunning views of the water below.

Sullivan's Knob Trail is about 1 mile roundtrip and has only a small hill to descend and climb. The hike will take you to the very edge of the canyon and affords gorgeous views of the river (there is no railing here so please be careful near the edge!). This site is also a frequent spot to see bighorn sheep, so keep your eyes peeled!

Keep your eyes peeled for the Pryor Mountain Wild Mustangs as you head farther north into the park to Two Eagles interpretive trail. This 1/10th mile gravel trail takes you around several teepee rings as well as a buffalo jump while telling the story of those who lived here long ago.

Visit Ewing Snell Historic Ranch to see the amazing work our historic preservation team does to keep the ranch looking like it was in history!  At this historic ranch you can open the doors, step inside, and take a step back in time.
At Horseshoe Bend Marina you can enjoy beautiful vistas, rent a kayak, or during the summer months you can enjoy a snack, beverage, or full meal on their patio.

data.title: Half Day at Bighorn Canyon, Lovell, WY District

data.description: Explore the original and current locations of Hamilton Grange National Memorial, as well as the landscaping of the Grange as it appears today.

images.altText: A yellow house with hot pink rose bushes out front.
images.caption: Explore the area of Hamilton Grange.
images.title: Hamilton Grange Outdoor Tour

stops.significance: Once located at 143rd and Convent, it was moved to this spot in 1889 to be used as a chapel for St. Luke's Church. The surrounding structures would have loomed over the Grange for over 100 years, until it was moved to its present location in St. Nicholas Park. Facing the empty lot, turn to your left. Looking north at Convent Ave, the Grange in its original location would be visible from here, at 143rd and Convent Ave.
The gardens to accompany the Grange were described in great detail by Alexander Hamilton. They have been designed today to replicate, to the greatest detail possible, what Hamilton envisioned.

data.title: Hamilton Grange Outdoor Grounds Tour

data.description: This driving tour focuses on the local Black life during the Manhattan Project and the civil rights struggle that followed in the Tri-Cities.

images.altText: A group of 18 men in work clothes and protective hats pose for a picture. Six men kneel in the front
images.caption: Black workers played a major role in constructing the Hanford Site.
images.title: Black construction workers at Hanford

stops.significance:
The REACH Museum

This tour begins on Columbia Park Trail. During the Manhattan Project, workers, who lived in Kennewick, Pasco, and Richland traveled this road to and from the Hanford Site. African American workers who lived in segregated East Pasco also traveled many long hours and miles on this road to get to work every day.  

On May 31, 1948, the Columbia River experienced its worst flood in recorded history, inundating a section of Kennewick 2 miles (3.2 km) long by ½ mile (0.8 km) wide. The waters did not recede for two weeks and destroyed many homes along this road.

First Avenue was Kennewick's "main drag" during the Manhattan Project era and beyond. In 1963, Jack Tanner, head of the Pacific Northwest NAACP declared Kennewick "The Birmingham of Washington" because no Black people were allowed to live in Kennewick and less than 10 Black people worked there, all in unskilled positions. Many civil rights protests took place on this strip. Kennewick was reputedly so segregated that according to Marion Barton, who grew up in East Pasco, "they wouldn't even put you in [their] jail if you were Black." Instead, at First Avenue and Washington Street the police at one point handcuffed or tied a Black man they arrested to a lamppost "and called Pasco and said 'Come get him’" because Pasco was the only community in the Tri-Cities at that time with Black residents and the Kennewick jail was considered unfit for Black prisoners.

Built in 1922, the Pasco-Kennewick Bridge (the “Green Bridge”) in southeastern Washington began as a symbol of unity and progress. No one could have known then that the bridge would eventually gain a new and menacing significance, one of exclusion. During the Manhattan Project, the Green Bridge would become a dividing line between Kennewick, a community that sought to exclude Blacks, and Pasco, a community that sought to confine Blacks. Outside of the Hanford Site, Blacks could only live in East Pasco. Blacks were not allowed to live in Kennewick. There was even a sign on the Green Bridge that declared Kennewick as a sundown town, a place where Blacks aren’t allowed after sunset. Through the work of civil rights organizations, such as the NAACP and the Urban League, these communities are now integrated and are home to diverse communities. The Green Bridge was demolished in 1990 at age 68. This plaque and section of railing is all that is left of the Green Bridge.

In 1922, the Union Bridge Company of Seattle built the Pasco-Kennewick Bridge across the Columbia River between the rural towns of Kennewick and Pasco. This bridge replaced a dated ferry system that could only transport six cars at a time across the river. Like two other bridges that span the Columbia River, the Longview Bridge (now the Lewis and Clark Bridge) and the Bridge of the Gods, the Pasco-Kennewick Bridge was a steel cantilever truss bridge. The Green Bridge became dividing line between Kennewick, a community that sought to exclude Blacks, and Pasco, a community that sought to confine Blacks.

The dark and unwelcoming Lewis Street Underpass was the only way for Black residents of East Pasco to reach the businesses and services of downtown Pasco. During the Manhattan Project, East Pasco was where most African American project workers had to live. City managers intentionally neglected this area with substandard houses and no garbage service, streetlights, sidewalks, or sewer lines for its residents. 

 

As you drive down Lewis Street, you will travel through the main commercial center of Pasco. Pasco was rigidly segregated. Business opportunities and residential housing in this area were denied to Black families.

As you turn on Wehe Street, you will pass Virgie Robinson Elementary School. Virgie and her husband Richard owned the Queen Street Diner and the Dew Drop Inn, which were prominent businesses in segregated East Pasco. Virgie attended Columbia Basin College and became one of the first Black employees of the Pasco School District.  

Just past the school, you will find Kurtzman Park, a community park constructed by African American youth who wanted a place for play and sports their community. Feel free to stop here and take a stroll in the park or have a picnic.

This street also contains intact residences from the days of segregation that give a sense of what this community once looked like. 

 

 At the intersection of Butte Street and Douglas Avenue, you will find Morningstar Baptist Church. During the Manhattan Project era, Black residents did not have their own church.  Morningstar, founded in 1946, was the first Black church in Pasco. It served as a community gathering space in the 1950s and 1960s where civil rights organizers could meet and build resistance to segregation. Morningstar is still known for its deep community involvement and wide array of activities for parishioners of all ages. 

 

After you drive past Hugo Street, you will also pass by New Hope Missionary Baptist Church, another important community institution founded shortly after Morningstar Baptist Church.

data.title: Hanford: Black History Driving Tour

data.description: The Manhattan Project transformed Richland from a farming village of about 250 people to a planned garden suburb of 15,000 Hanford workers and their families. Follow in their footsteps and see what life was like in Richland during World War II

images.altText: Black and white photograph of a group of children engaged in activities in a shallow wading pool
images.caption: Young people frolicking in the Howard Amon Park wading pool.
images.title: Playing at Howard Amon Park

stops.significance:
The secret city of Richland rapidly expanded during the Manhattan Project. Under the master plan of architect G.A. Pherson, the small 250 person farming town of Richland was redeveloped into a garden suburb with new services, such as the Richland Laundry, which tried to meet the needs of the new residents.  

As you walk from this stop to your next stop at the Richland Players Theater, to your right you will see numerous alphabet homes. The Manhattan Project rapidly constructed these buildings as residences for the workers who operated the plutonium production facilities at the Hanford Site. You are now walking in the footsteps residents of the secret city took to get from their homes to the shopping, services, and entertainment areas in wartime Richland.

The Richland Players Theater was originally constructed as the movie theater for residents of the secret city. Hanford workers and their families flocked to the movie theaters to watch films of all types throughout the week. Most Richland residents were wartime migrants often living far from home and watching their favorite Hollywood stars connected them to the rest of America and allowed them to escape the unique stresses of wartime.
The Richland Players, who now occupy this building were originally created as a community theater group during the Manhattan Project. They continue to produce plays for the surrounding Tri-Cities community to this day and may have a production that you can see in this historic structure during your visit.

During World War II, this was the only department store in Richland. For workers arriving in the secret city, Anderson’s was a place to furnish their home, shop for necessary goods and small luxuries. The Parkway, which you ware now on was the heart of the wartime secret city. During the Manhattan Project, this bustling place was filled with Hanford workers and their families doing chores, out for a stroll, or socializing with their neighbors. The streetscape of the Parkway remains relatively unchanged from the Manhattan Project era and provides you with a sense of what life in this community was like.

This building was originally constructed to serve the farming community of Richland prior to the Manhattan Project as the community’s butcher shop, which closed in 1943.  Since the Manhattan Project, this building has had a range of uses, such as a newspaper office, tavern, chocolate store, and library. Today, it is a bakery/bistro, providing food to people in the Tri-Cities as it did when it was constructed in 1915.

Built in 1908, 3 years after Richland’s founding, the Dyer Building became the Richland Public Library during the Manhattan Project. Today it houses Allied Arts, a community arts organization originally created by Manhattan Project workers and their families to provide arts education and provide a sense of community during World War II.

Howard Amon, one of Richland’s founders, donated this land to the small farming village for use as a city park. Since 1911, Richland residents have come to Howard Amon park for community events, relaxation, picnics, swimming, and all other manner of activities.  

During World War II, Hanford workers and their families enjoyed walks similar to the one you just took through their new community. As they entered Howard Amon Park, the greenery and nearby Columbia River was a tranquil escape from the sand, wind, and ceaseless activity of the wartime secret city. Now that you’ve reached the end of your tour, you can enjoy Howard Amon Park like many generations of Richland residents and visitors.

data.title: Hanford: Secret City Walking Tour

data.description: Hike to the top of Candy Mountain to see the Hanford Site and the Tri-Cities. Along the way learn about the Ice Age Floods that shaped the landscape.

images.altText: Black and white photograph of a cityscape spreading out below as viewed from a mountain's summit.
images.caption: From the top of Candy Mountain, you can see the Tri-Cities and Hanford Site from above.
images.title: Candy Mountain

stops.significance: At the entrance to the Candy Mountain trail, you will encounter five informational tablets paying tribute to local history. They focus on the role of the Manhattan Project in transforming the Tri-Cities and convey a sense of the scale of the work Hanford has performed.

This wayside provides information about some of the lava flows that shaped the local landscape, especially the Columbia River. These prehistoric events laid the groundwork for the Manhattan Project, because the Columbia River’s abundant cold water and hydroelectricity, and the flat local landscape were important reasons for Hanford’s selection as a plutonium production site.

This wayside explains the impact of the Ice Age floods, which occurred during the end of the last Ice Age. The ice containing a massive glacial lake, known as Lake Missoula periodically melted during this period, releasing huge quantities of water that flooded Eastern WA, shaping the Tri-Cities landscape.

This marker gives information about the various locations on the Hanford Site and their role in the plutonium production process. It demonstrates how this vast industrial area was divided and how it was envisioned as an integrated whole.

This marks the site of Lake Lewis. During one of the Ice Age floods, water backed up into the area that is now the Tri-Cities, forming a massive temporary lake that rose to about 1200 feet above sea level for a period of weeks. This lake helped shape the modern landscape and only the part of Candy Mountain above this elevation remained above water.

From this vantage point on a clear day, you can see the Tri-Cities and the Hanford Site. You gain a sense of how the communities below you fit together, the immensity of the Hanford Site and how the local geography contributed to the Manhattan Project’s selection of the Hanford Site. Nearby inscriptions on rocks give a better sense of the Hanford Site’s geography and its history and future.

This wayside is located near a boulder deposited by the movement of icebergs during the glacial floods which shaped this area’s landscape during the end of the last Ice Age. This wayside provides further context on this important aspect of the Tri-Cities natural history.

Erratics dot the landscape of this mountain, reflecting the lasting local legacy of the Ice Age floods. This wayside provides more information on the nature of Candy Mountain’s erratics and the events and processes that led to their deposition.

data.title: Hanford: Summit Candy Mountain

data.description: Despite the name, there is more to the monument than dinosaurs. The Harpers Corner Road will introduce you to an area that features rolling sagebrush covered slopes and the canyon country of the Green and Yampa rivers.

images.altText: A paced two-lane road winding through a rugged plateau area.
images.caption: Harpers Croner Road winds through the scenic Colorado portion of the monument.
images.title: Harpers Corner Road

stops.significance: Located near Dinosaur, Colorado, at the base of the Harpers Corner Road, the Canyon Visitor Center is the gateway to the monument's mountains and river canyons. This building is open daily in summer and is closed during the winter. Exhibits and a park film orient visitors to resources, and staff are available to answer questions. A bookstore sells items that can further enhance your experience. Restrooms and water are available seasonally. There are no dinosaur fossil sites on this side of the park.

The Harpers Corner Scenic Drive is a 31-mile (50 km) one-way auto tour route from the Canyon Visitor Center to Harpers Corner. Dinosaur fossils are not located in this section of the park.

As the road gains in elevation, the scenery reflects the changing ecosystems. The last 12 miles (19 km) include several striking viewpoints and overlooks, some as high as 2500 feet (762 m) above the Green and Yampa rivers. All overlooks along the route are wheelchair accessible. The Harpers Corner Road is also the jumping-off point for several paved paths and hiking trails.

About 4 miles north of the Canyon Visitor Center, stop at the unnemed pullout on the right. Here, you can view a layer of deep red mudstone sandwiched between two lightercolored sandstones. This feature reminded an early traveler of a derby hat and inspired the name Plug Hat Butte, with a “crown” of Entrada Sandstone and a “band” of red Carmel Formation. As you drive around the butte, look for sweeping cross-beds of fine sand grains in the “brim” of Nugget Sandstone, indicating that this rock layer began as windblown desert sand dunes.
At the Plug Hat Butte picnic area, several viewpoints and short walks introduce you to the Colorado Plateau. Sedimentary rock layers across Colorado, Utah, New Mexico, and Arizona were uplifted to form a table-like region, or plateau, drained by the Colorado River and its tributaries. The scene before you is typical of the plateau’s colorful strata, flat topped mesas, buttes, and sheer walled canyons. Lack of soil and plant cover contributes to the visibility of these landforms

The broad valley before you, ringed by mountains, is called the Uinta Basin. Here, animals and plants from the Great Basin, Colorado Plateau, and Rocky Mountains come together to form a unique mix of ecosystems. The diversity of life within Dinosaur is enhanced by drastic elevation changes, ranging from 4750 to 9000 feet (1448 to 2743 m). 

Some plants, like manzanita (a green, round-leafed shrub), have very specific habitat needs. The only place within the monument with the right combination of soil type, sun exposure, and moisture level to support manzanita is here at Escalante Overlook. Some species, like arrowleaf balsamroot (a yellow-flowering plant with wavy arrow-shaped leaves), are less picky and more widespread.

Off to the right of the overlook, you can see Round Top Mountain, which is home to a fire lookout tower staffed during the summer. Summer thunderstorms keep the lookout busy reporting “smokes” produced by lightning strikes. Fire plays a natural role in the ecosystem and helps maintain a healthy diversity of plant and animal life. The goal of fire management at Dinosaur is to mimic the frequency, timing, and size of fires as they would have occurred prior to the late 1800s.

The vegetation here is markedly different from that of the surrounding sagebrush steppe. This north facing slope experiences less direct sunlight and therefore retains more moisture. These conditions encourage the growth of large trees, like aspens and Douglas-firs. This montane forest is only found over 7000 feet elevation and covers less than 5% of Dinosaur’s
211,000 acres. Douglas-fir trees live an incredibly long time; some are hundreds of years old. Over the years, they have survived many harsh winters and provided animals with food and shelter. Each cone contains 20 to 30 winged seeds, dispersed by wind. These seeds provide critical nourishment to a variety of birds and small mammals like mice, voles, shrews, and chipmunks.

There is a good chance that you will see cattle along the road, and may even encounter local ranchers driving their herds to better pasture. Over the last century, grazing has been a primary use of the land in and around Dinosaur National Monument. Today, grazing is still allowed at certain locations within the monument’s boundary. Many of the families permitted to pasture their animals here originally homesteaded in the area in the late 19th and early 20th centuries, prior to the establishment of the monument. In those days, cattle rustling was a common trade in this part of the country. Trail Draw, the small canyon before you, was part of what is now known as the Outlaw Trail. This famous backcountry route snaked through desolate, rugged terrain from Montana to New Mexico, linking well-known hideouts such as Hole in the Wall and Robber’s Roost. The most notorious outlaws that used this route were known as the Wild Bunch, led by Butch Cassidy and the Sundance Kid.

Island Park is below you, just out of sight. There, between Whirlpool Canyon and Split Mountain Canyon, the Green River flows placidly in island dotted channels. This grassy area near the river features abundant forage, attracting many early settlers, including the Ruple family. In April 1883, Henry and May Ruple homesteaded in Island Park and established a cattle ranch. They built a multi-story cabin with a stone fireplace—a fine house for anyone in such a remote area. After they finished construction, they were 18 miles from the nearest neighbors. The family ran cattle from Island Park to Wild Mountain, 10 miles away. In 1915, the Ruple’s son Hod took over the property and switched from cattle to sheep ranching. Sheep were better suited to the harsh, high desert climate and were an important part of the region’s early economy. The Ruples sold the majority of the property in 1945, but the family still retains a portion of the original homestead outside of the monument boundary.

At an elevation of 7600 feet, the rock under your feet is the same layer of rock that is exposed at river level about 2600 feet below. How is that possible? Two large blocks of land have slipped downward along the Yampa Fault and the Red Rock Fault, forming giant steps, or benches. Although the underlying rock of each bench is the same Weber Sandstone, differences in elevation and moisture dramatically affect the vegetation. Sagebrush and grasses dominate the lower benches, while pinyon pines and juniper trees forest this area. The pinyon-juniper landscape at this stop is a hallmark of many arid areas in the West. At Dinosaur, these forests support diverse native vegetation and can be very old. Intense fires, capable of altering entire stands of trees, are fairly rare here; some pinyons are over 700 years old. Today, pinyons and junipers are almost always associated with each other and are expected to be seen together, but this has not always been the case.

From here you can see directly down into Echo Park. Beyond Steamboat Rock, just out of sight, is the confluence of the Green and Yampa rivers. Both are part of the Upper Colorado River system, and each has its own unique story. From almost the beginning of American settlement in the West, demand for water has exceeded availability. In 1950, the United States Bureau of Reclamation presented the Colorado River Storage Project, a proposal to construct several dams throughout the Colorado River system. The initial project included a dam downstream of Echo Park that would have flooded both the Green and Yampa rivers, destroying many of the natural and cultural features that had been protected as part of Dinosaur National Monument since a boundary expansion in 1938.

Broad sage-covered plateaus eventually give way to an increasingly narrow ridge. This promontory of land was named Harpers Corner after a local rancher who used it as a natural corral. A short length of fence across one end was enough to confine his livestock, as the other three sides fall away in sheer cliffs to the canyons below.

A parking lot marks the end of the Harpers Corner Road, however your explorations of Dinosaur’s Canyon Country don’t need to end here. You’ll also find the trailhead for a moderate 2 mile (3.2 km) roundtrip trail that features unsurpassed views of the Mitten Park Fault and Whirlpool Canyon, often complimented by the sound of the river echoing up the cliffs.

data.title: Harpers Corner Driving Tour

data.description: Welcome to the Canyon Country of Dinosaur National Monument. This guide is numbered to the points of interest along the Harpers Corner Trail, which leads to sweeping views of the canyons.

images.altText: A large reddish sandstone canyon with pine trees dotted throughout.
images.caption: Whirlpool Canyon seen from Harpers Corner.
images.title: Whirlpool Canyon

stops.significance:
Welcome to the canyon country of Dinosaur National Monument.
In 1938 President Franklin D. Roosevelt expanded the original monument by adding over 200,000 acres of land encompassing the Green and Yampa River Canyons, including the Harpers Corner area. This guide is numbered to points of interest along the Harpers Corner Trail, which leads to sweeping views of the canyons.

While the deep canyons are the work of flowing water, high above the rivers, the land is dry. Only water-conserving plants and animals can survive up here. What do you notice about the plants? Most have small leaves, often dull colored with fuzzy or waxy surfaces. These features reduce exposure to drying winds, reflect sunlight, and hold in moisture. The open, even spacing of the trees lessens competition for groundwater. Though the piñon pine and juniper may live for hundreds of years, they rarely grow very large.

If you are here in spring or early summer, you may see wildflowers such as bluebells, gilia, and paintbrush. Please don’t pick the flowers or disturb any natural or historic features.

Piñon trees can live a long time, and even after death, an old piñon like this still contributes to the forest. Its wood provides a home for burrowing insects, which in turn are hunted by woodpeckers, nuthatches, and other birds. Falcons or hawks may survey their territory from the high bare branches. When the tree eventually falls, its slow decay will return nutrients to the soil.

What killed the big tree at the last stop? There are several possibilities: insects, disease, old age, a lightning strike, or maybe even a porcupine. Look for the yellow or gray scars on many of the tree trunks along the trail, signs of porcupine gnawings. In winter, when other food is scarce, porcupines relish the tender inner bark of piñons. Stripping only a little bark, porcupines usually do not harm the tree. If the animal chews all the way around the trunk (known as girdling), the tree’s food and water transport systems will be cut off and it will soon die.

If you were going to homestead, would you settle here on this high ridge or down by the river? Near the rivers, or any place with a reliable water supply, would be a better choice. See if you can spot the buildings of the Chew Ranch far below on a small tributary of the Green River called Pool Creek. The Chew family settled this pioneer cattle and sheep ranch around 1900. Today, it is maintained as an historic site.

Echo Park, at the junction of the Green and Yampa Rivers, is not only the geographic heart of Dinosaur National Monument, but a key location in the area’s history. The ruggedness of the land limited exploration by routes other than by water. William H. Ashley, a trapper looking for beaver pelts, conducted the first recorded expedition down the Green River in 1825. In the weeks that it took his party to pass through these canyons, the rapids nearly wiped out his small, hide covered bullboats. Having survived the ordeal, Ashley and his men went on to explore other areas of the American West.

“All this volume of water, confined as it is, in a narrow channel and rushing with great velocity, is set eddying and spinning in whirlpools by projecting rocks and short curves, and the waters waltz their way through the canyon, making their own rippling, rushing, roaring music.” Thus wrote Powell of Whirlpool Canyon below you. Listen… on a calm day you can still hear the distant music of the river.

Have you noticed the contrast between the rocks of Whirlpool Canyon to the west with the rocks of the Yampa Canyon to the east? Whirlpool’s walls are dark and sheer and are made up mostly of limestones and shales left by ancient seas. As the seas retreated, windswept sand dunes piled up to become the light colored Weber sandstone of the Yampa Canyon’s cliffs and domes. When geologic forces uplifted this area to its present elevation, faulting occurred. The rock layers were bent and broken as some blocks of land were pushed higher than others. You are standing on the edge of one of the high blocks from which the younger sandstone has been eroded away. In the low block to the east erosion has not progressed as far. The older limestone and shale are still buried beneath the sandstone, Faults contribute to the vastly different appearance of each canyon.

Can you pick out the course of the Yampa River? Its junction with the Green River is hidden by the ridge of Steamboat Rock, and above that, the river is lost in a maze of sandstone. Such a winding course is more typical of a slow, sluggish stream flowing across flat land than of a swift canyon cutting river. Some geologists have suggested that the Yampa River had already established courses on fairly level land before the region was uplifted. The rivers held course and sliced down through the rocks even as the land rose, forming deep, winding canyons.

The reddish rocks alongside the trail are made of a hard sandstone called quartzite, which also appears at the very bottom of Whirlpool Canyon. Did they roll up here from down there? Not likely, but their rounded shape does suggest that they rolled a long way from somewhere. The same quartzite forms much of the Uinta Mountains west of here, so these rocks may have been washed down from the mountains long before the Green River had carved Whirlpool Canyon. Now, stranded far from their source; they add another element of mystery to a landscape which has puzzled geologists since Powell’s time.

Take a closer look at the rocks along the trail; many of them bear a colorful crust of lichens. Small as they are, lichens are important pioneers, for they can grow on bare rock where most other things cannot. Their secret is that they are actually two organisms in one; a fungus whose sticky filaments anchor it to the rock, and an alga which uses the energy of sunlight to produce food through photosynthesis. The fungus provides a foothold and the alga feeds them both. Lichens prepare the way for other plants by slowly breaking down the rock through chemical and physical weathering and creating soil.

By now you may have spotted some of the local wildlife. The higher elevations of Harpers Corner are home to a variety of birds, some of which can be found fairly easily and others that are a bit more inconspicuous. Look for dark black ravens that are at home in the canyon country you see before you. Typically traveling in pairs, they are generalist species and are able to survive in almost all the environments found in the monument, from high forests to low dry deserts. Other birds you may encounter along the trail include the melodious Mountain Chickadee, the vibrant blue Scrub Jay, the mischievous Black-billed Magpie, and the boisterous Dark Eyed Junco.

Don’t build a house where you see trees like this one. Soil on this steep slope tends to slip downward and the movement would eventually topple a wall, telephone pole, or other nonliving object. A tree however, if the sliding is slow enough, keeps trying to straighten up as it grows resulting in a curved trunk. If you look around, you may notice many of the trees in this area have bent trunks near their base. While trees may slow erosion, they cannot stop it on a slope like this.

Trees respond to many environmental influences – some so subtle that we may hardly notice them. You might see some trees that are taller than the piñons and junipers you have been walking through. They also have spruce like needles and dangling, thin-scaled cones. These are Douglas fir, important timber trees in the Pacific Northwest, and common in the high Uinta Mountains, but almost out of their range here. They require a bit more moisture and cooler temperatures than other trees in the area. North-facing slopes, like these around Harpers Corner, receive slightly less sunlight, and more moisture which apparently makes just enough difference for Douglas firs to live here.

Back at stop number seven, it was noted that the rocks in Whirlpool Canyon were formed in ancient seas. How do we know this? First, the rocks are made up of fine grained sediments like the muds usually found on sea bottoms; and second, they sometimes are embedded with fossils of seas creatures. Look closely at the rocks beneath your feet, you may be able to spot the clam-like shells of brachiopods, and pieces of the stems of crinoids or “sea lilies,” animals actually related to starfish. Though they lived hundreds of millions of years ago, even before the dinosaurs, their remains help us piece together the jigsaw puzzle of the past.

Seashells far above the sea, great blocks of rock bent and broken, deep and tortuous canyons - was this land the site of some great cataclysm? To us, accustomed as we are to thinking in terms of minutes, hours, and days, the scene may look like the result of some chaotic upheaval but it wasn’t. All around us the forces that shaped it are still in action. Rivers deepen their channels grain by grain; minor earth tremors occur daily in one place or another; and lands have risen or fallen, slowly but measurably, within historic times. We measure our history in years, but the Earth measures time in millions of years, enough time for each tiny change to be multiplied over and over into a major change. The upturned layers of the Mitten Park Fault below you dramatize such a change. This is the same fault noted at stop number seven, but here the Green River has sliced through it to reveal the broken rocks in cross section.

People can also alter the land. While our changes are usually not on the same scale as natural forces, they often occur much more rapidly. In the 1950s, controversy arose over a proposal to build a dam for water storage and power generation in Dinosaur National Monument directly below this point at the head of Whirlpool Canyon. Many people protested that the Green and Yampa Canyons deserved to remain in their natural state. Ultimately, the protests were heeded and a dam was instead built at Flaming Gorge, 70 miles (113 Kilometers) upstream on the Green River from here.

data.title: Harpers Corner Trail: Tour of the Canyons
