data.description: The Henry Hill Trail is an easy walking trail that encompasses the area of the most intense fighting during the First Battle of Manassas (Bull Run). The trail begins and ends at the visitor center. Starting from the backside of the visitor center, the 1.1-mile trail takes you past significant landmarks and monuments including the positions of Federal artillery, Stonewall Jackson’s Line, the Robinson Farm site, and more.

images.altText: Henry Hill
images.caption: Fog hangs over the Henry Hill Plateau
images.title: Henry Hill

stops.significance:
You are standing along the position taken up by Union artillery commanded by Captain James Ricketts.   Despite protestations and lack of support, Union General Irvin McDowell ordered Ricketts' six cannon to this position around 2:00pm.  Upon arriving, they were met by severe short-range musket and artillery fire from Confederates, positioned a mere 300 yards to your front.   

Men clambered to the ground, horses screamed in fright, but Ricketts ordered his artillerymen to stand their ground and return fire.  Ricketts commented after the battle, “It was the hottest place I [saw] in my life; and I had seen some fighting before.” Many of the Union artillerymen and their horses were killed or wounded all around you, including Ricketts, who suffered a severe wound to the thigh.   

Three times this vulnerable artillery position changed hands.  Despite the Union Army having a manpower advantage, it was the Confederate infantry that maintained control of the battery, and the hill, at the end of the fight.

The fields around you lay fallow and overgrown in the summer of 1861, with a small vegetable garden and orchard surrounding the one-and-a-half story frame house. 85 year-old Judith Carter Henry remained bedridden and too old to leave the home she shared with her daughter Ellen Phoebe. The two women remained in the house during the time of the battle along with 14-year-old Lucy Griffith, an enslaved girl who was hired out to Mrs Henry. 
  
To drive off Confederates positioned in and around the house, Captain Ricketts’ artillery fired on the dwelling, completely riddling it and mortally wounding Mrs. Henry. She became one of the first civilians killed during the Civil War. Her grave is in the small family plot in front of the house, where she was joined after the War by her daughter Ellen Pheobe and son Hugh.

Following the war, the Henry family constructed a new home near the site of the original war-time structure. This pyramidal memorial behind the house was dedicated by Federal soldiers on June 11, 1865.

You are located on the northwestern corner of Henry Hill. To your north you can see the historic Stone House which stands at the important intersection of Sudley Road (modern day Rt. 234) and the Warrenton Turnpike (modern day Rt. 29). This position offers a sweeping vista over the area of the morning fighting at First Manassas. 
 
Positioned near where you currently stand were the four smoothbore cannons of Confederate Captain John Imboden’s Staunton Artillery.
 
Imboden’s battery suffered heavily from the Federal artillery fire on the hills to the north and northwest. With the retreat of the Confederate infantry from Matthews Hill, renewed pressure from Federal infantry and artillery, and running low on ammunition, Imboden determined the time had come to leave this exposed position. Making use of the ravine to your right, three guns of the Staunton artillery retreated towards the woods to the east where they were met by Confederate reinforcements under Brigadier General Thomas J. Jackson.

You are standing on the site of the James Robinson house. Robinson was a free African American born near Manassas in 1799, to a black mother and white father.   By 1850, Robinson was one of the wealthiest free African Americans in Prince William County. 

As the Confederate position on Matthews Hill collapsed, Colonel Wade Hampton’s Legion occupied the Warrenton Turnpike near where you stand. Having arrived at Manassas Junction earlier that morning after a 30-hour train ride from Richmond, VA, the 600 exhausted South Carolinians stood as the only organized Confederate resistance at that time. Realizing his men could not hold the turnpike, Hampton pulled his troops back into the Robinson farm lane. Hampton’s Legion stood in opposition to attacks by five Union regiments from New York, Maine, and Connecticut. The last of these attacks forced Hampton’s men to fall back but without a coordinated follow-up, the Union advance fell back.

The bronze cannons to your right and left mark the position of the Confederate line that rallied on Henry Hill in the early afternoon of 21 July 1861.  

As the Confederates retreated from Matthews Hill, Confederate Generals Johnston and Beauregard began piecing together a new line atop Henry Hill.  This position would quickly be crowned with 13 cannons and nearly 3,000 infantrymen commanded by General Thomas J. Jackson.    

Confederate General Barnard Bee, in speaking to men of the 4th Alabama Infantry would provide Jackson and his men with one of the most famous monikers in military history: “There stands Jackson like a stone wall, let us go to his assistance!”  

The action on Henry Hill would be characterized by confusion over similar uniforms and flags being carried by participants.  Union General Irvin McDowell would send nearly 15 different regiments to attack Henry Hill in a series of uncoordinated and unsupported attacks, with each being bloodily repulsed and forced back into the Sudley Road.

You are now located on the left flank of Jackson’s position, which marked by a fence.  The 33rd Virginia, clad in blue uniforms and commanded by Colonel Arthur Cummings, held this position.  These Virginians fired some of the first organized musket volleys on Henry Hill.   

The position held by Jackson’s brigade was a strong one. Their position on the reverse slope of the hill and within the confines of a pine thicket provided the Virginians with near invisibility from the distant Union batteries positioned on Matthews Hill and Dogan Ridge.  

Jackson had informed Cummings of the need to watch for Union artillery that may threaten his regiment, and indeed the newly established Confederate line’s, left flank.  This admonition would soon ring true, as two Federal cannons were spotted moving closer to the 33rd's position.  Cummings needed to act, and act quickly.  Cummings ordered his men to charge toward this new threat in their front.

Union Artillerist Charles Griffin repositioned two 12-pound howitzers to a position near where you now stand. Shortly after arriving here, Griffin noticed infantrymen clad in blue uniforms and civilian clothing in the woods to his right. 

 Confident that these were Confederates, Griffin ordered his guns to open fire.  Within minutes, Major William Barry, US Artillery chief, ordered Griffin to stand down, remarking that this body was his infantry support.  Griffin questioned this order, replying “They are Confederates; as certain as the world they are Confederates,” but in keeping with the chain of command, the Union guns held their fire.  All the while, the infantry rapidly approached.  When within 30 paces, the blue-clad soldiers of Cummings' 33rd Virginia Regiment leveled their muskets and fired.  Griffin relayed the outcome as, “That was the last of us.”  This marked a turning point in the fight on Henry Hill.

data.title: Henry Hill Walking Tour

data.description: The High View Nature Trail is a 1.3 mile loop. Total elevation gain on this trail is 400 feet (122 meters). There are several steep sections with steps. Hiking this trail in a counterclockwise direction means the steepest sections will be on the descent.

images.altText: Desert vegetation in the foreground with mountains in the background
images.caption: Hi-View Nature Trail Viewpoint
images.title: View from the Hi-View Nature Trail

stops.significance:
The Hi-View Trailhead provides access to several trails in the northwest corner of the park. The trailhead is located down a dirt road northwest of Black Rock Campground. Some of the more popular hikes include the Hi-View Trail, an easy 1.3 mile loop, and West Side Loop, a moderate 4.1 mile loop that can be combined with additional trails for longer hikes. The trails in this area are a mix of dirt, rock, and sandy washes.

The parking area for this trailhead is a small dirt parking lot so anything larger than a small RV (20 feet) may have difficulty turning around.

Black Rock Canyon gets its name from the main color in this metamorphic rock. It is called Pinto Gneiss (pronounced “nice) and is estimated to be more than 1.8 billion years old. Look closely to observe intricate banding and mineral crystals in the rock. Exposed rock is excellent habitat for lichens, several species of which can be observed on this outcropping. Look for bright splotches of green, orange, and yellow growing on the rocks. Different species can be identified by color and shape.

From this vantage point, on all but the foggiest days, the peak of Mount San Gorgonio is visible, rising from the San Bernardino Mountains and topping out at 11,503 feet above sea level. These mountains are the reason why this area is a desert. Moist air from the Pacific Ocean is pushed east by wind towards Joshua Tree National Park, but the mountains are too large an obstacle for wet, heavy clouds, so most of the moisture is discharged before the clouds can make their way over to Joshua Tree. Precipitation on the west (ocean) side of the mountains can be more than double the precipitation on the eastern side.

Joshua trees may be the namesake of this park, but their close relative, the Mojave yucca (Yucca schidiger) is even more widespread. The plants are both in the yucca family; Joshua trees grow taller and branch while Mojave yuccas stay fairly short and grow in clumps. Indigenous people used the fibrous leaves for many applications including rope and textiles. Members of these tribes still hike these trails and steward of the rich legacy of living in harmony with the desert.

While common in the Black Rock Canyon area, mature stands of pine and oak trees like these are relatively rare in Joshua Tree National Park. These species prefer a slightly cooler climate and are therefore confined to the higher elevations of the Little San Bernardino Mountains. Pinyon pine trees (Pinus pinaceae) are of particular concern to scientists as changing climate threatens the existence of this species in its current range.

Parry’s nolina (Nolina parryi) is a hardy desert plant with long, thin, flexible leaves that make it easy to tell apart from Joshua trees or yuccas. In the spring, nolinas can grow a very tall flower stalk-- up to 12 feet tall! The flowers are cream colored and appear like a cone of popcorn on top of the stalk. Nolinas are slow growing plants that can live to be hundreds- possibly even over 1,000 years old.

The trail seems steep for short reptilian legs, but desert tortoises (Gopherus agassizii) are impressively stalwart creatures that travel through the desert scrub to cross passes like this one in search of wildflowers to eat. In the spring, visitors sometimes spot tortoises while hiking on the High View Nature Trail, so keep an eye out! Tortoises are a federally threatened species; if you are lucky enough to see one be sure to give it plenty of space. Report any tortoise observations at the Black Rock Nature Center as scientists are eager for information on these elusive animals.

The peak of the High View Nature Trail is 4,445 feet above sea level. To the northeast lies the community of Yucca Valley, and on clear days it is easy to see the distant expanse of the Marine Corps Air Ground Combat Center, over 40 miles away. The peak of Mount San Gorgonio, to the west, is over 50 miles away. These stunning views are thanks partially to the high vantage point and lack of obstacles, and also because low humidity in desert air makes for easier long-range sightseeing.

The High View Nature Trail is in the northern foothills of the Little San Bernardino Mountains, which stand between the Morongo Basin to the north and the Coachella Valley to the south. The Little San Bernardino Mountains are part of the Transverse Ranges, a group of mountains that formed along the San Andreas Fault as the North American and Pacific tectonic plates grind past one another. The higher elevations, as well as the proximity to the San Bernardino Mountains, means that this area generally has the highest quantity of precipitation and experience the coolest temperatures of anywhere in Joshua Tree National Park.

Joshua trees (Yucca brevifolia) dominate much of the Black Rock area with their bright green leaves and spindly forms. These plants absorb as much water as possible after summer rains or winter snows through shallow roots that extend in a wide subterranean circle from their trunks. This leads to the fairly regular spacing of individual plants. Two Joshua trees growing near one another are likely the same individual, connected underground through networks of thin roots. Joshua trees store water in their trunks and branches, making them quite heavy during wet years and prone to tipping over or dropping branches. Take care not to climb on or attach ropes or hammocks to Joshua trees, despite their solid appearances they can be easily toppled.
The end of the Hi-View Nature Trail.

data.title: Hi-View Nature Trail Walking Tour

data.description: Dozens of springs cover the lower slopes of Hot Springs Mountain. However, most are hidden after two centuries of development and efforts to keep the water clean for consumption. This 1-mile loop along Bathhouse Row, to Happy Hollow Spring, and back along the Grand Promenade reveals the stories and images of some of the hottest, most famed springs from the 19th century. Along the way, you’ll learn about the hydrology and the cultural significance of the springs that help explain the park you see today.

images.altText: Sunlight shines on the steam of a small waterfall of hot water.
images.caption: Steam perpetually floats over the hot water springs as the water emerges at an average of 143 deg.
images.title: Hot Water Cascade

stops.significance:
The Display Springs are one of the few open-air springs accessible in the Park. Visitors here are witnessing the conclusion of a long, subterranean journey. 

Rain that falls in the nearby mountains travels through fractures in the rocks to an aquifer roughly a mile underneath Hot Springs Mountain. The water temperature increases to 160 deg. as it moves downward, heated by the natural heat of the earth. 

(Click EXPLORE THIS LOCATION for larger image and more information)

After thousands of years of percolating beneath Hot Springs Mountain, the water encounters an impermeable fault line. Hydrostatic water pressure then forces the super-heated water to travel up the fault line and return to the surface. 

When the water emerges as a hot spring, its human story is just beginning. As you continue your Hidden Hot Springs tour, you’ll see how 19th century visitors gave the springs different cultural significance and transformed the landscape into what we see today.

(Swipe left for directions to the next stop)

You are standing on top of Hot Springs Creek, but you cannot see it.  The creek flows through a tunnel hidden beneath Bathhouse Row.

Hot Springs Creek still collects the runoff of the Hot Springs waters, and its temperature increases significantly from the influence of the thermal waters.

(Click EXPLORE THIS LOCATION for enlarged image and more information)

Bridges across the creek connected Central Avenue to the bathhouses, which were mostly built on the east side of the creek.

As the town grew in the valley, the creek effectively became an open sewer, carrying away the used water from bathhouses, hotels, businesses, and even roaming cattle.

In the 1880s, the Department of the Interior oversaw construction of the Creek Arch that covers the creek to this day. The Creek Arch was part of the first major federal infrastructure development in the Park.

The Creek Arch helped to address sanitation issues around the creek. It also increased the available area in the valley to build bigger bathhouses.

You're looking at the Quapaw Bathhouse. But 140 years ago, Magnesia Spring flowed here from the east bank of Hot Springs Creek, at the base of a 15-foot-high tufa cliff. (click “Explore This Location” for a larger historical image). 

Magnesia Spring was one of several to emerge along Hot Springs Creek. Hot Springs Creek still flows beneath the walkway you are standing on. The creek cut into the side of the mountain, allowing several springs to emerge at the space between tufa deposits and bed rock.

Magnesia Spring's tufa backdrop made it popular for visitors posing for photographs.

Magnesia Spring was heavily influenced by the construction of Bathhouse Row. Developers first piped its water to the Rammelsburg Bathhouse (site of the current Buckstaff Bathhouse). In the early 1880s, the spring access was blocked by a tunnel built over the creek and blasting nearby decreased the spring flow.

In the late 1880s, a bathhouse, called Magnesia, was built over the site. The Quapaw Bathhouse replaced it in 1922.

The Big Iron Spring is one of the largest thermal features in Hot Springs. An observer in the 1870s described the mouth of the spring as “a vein nearly as large as the body of a man.” 

Historical photos show the spring as a tall mound of tufa rising next to the stream bed. The spring was named for the brownish, rust-colored deposits that the thermal waters created on the tufa outcrop.

The spring was big in several ways. The 147-degree water was the hottest measured in a 1901 survey. The spring produced 250,000 gallons a day, approximately one-third of the total daily water flow.  

The waters of the Big Iron were among the most popular for drinking water. In the 1870s, a bathhouse named Big Iron Bath House was built immediately north of the spring, accessible by a footbridge.

Blasting of nearby tufa rock in the 1880s altered the flow of the thermal water, causing the spring to temporarily dry up. Due to development, it was covered in 5 feet of soil.

By 1901, Big Iron Spring was no longer visible.

Arsenic Spring was one of the most popular drinking-water springs in the late 19th century, particularly for women. A national publication in the 1870s wrote that Arsenic Spring was “in great repute among the fair sex, who fancy that it improves their complexion.” 

Historical photos show that the spring emerged at the base of a cliff of tufa. By the late 1800s, a Victorian-style wooden gazebo was built over the spring. The naming is unclear as there is (fortunately) no arsenic in the water.

Physicians and health seekers believed that the hydrating waters helped flush out toxins and that drinking the hot water was an important step in the Hot Springs treatment. 

The water of Arsenic Spring temporarily dried up in the 1880s, when blasting along the base of Hot Springs Mountain interrupted the flow of thermal water. 

By 1901, Arsenic Spring was inaccessible underneath the Arlington Hotel. Following the destruction of Arlington Hotel due to fire in the 1920s, the Arsenic Spring was covered by the lawn.

Happy Hollow Springs is one of two cold water drinking fountains in Hot Springs NP. The water cycle for Happy Hollow is separate from the hot water springs nearby. 

Unlike the 4,400-year process for the thermal springs, the water emerging at Happy Hollow is roughly two decades old. Happy Hollow Springs contains less silica than the hot water but is otherwise similar in chemical composition.

The water emerges at approximately 62 degrees. Fluctuations in water flow suggest that the springs are strongly connected to seasonal rainfall amounts. 

African American families settled in the Happy Hollow area while working for the hotels and bathhouses. By the 1880s, the springs became more popular for White visitors, who promoted the waters as a treatment for kidney, bladder, liver, and stomach issues. Entrepreneurs developed an amusement park in the 1890s with a small zoo, shooting gallery, and photo studio.

The National Park Service maintains Happy Hollow Spring according to health and safety requirements.

In the 19th century, Egg Spring impressed visitors with the power of the hot water.

Egg Spring was historically one of the hottest springs in the park. One observer even reported a water temperature over 150 degrees. Its 1901 temperature was 143 degrees.

 Egg Spring earned its name because it could supposedly boil an egg the quickest, in about 15 minutes. (Other springs were also used to brew tea, wash clothes, and scald hogs.)

Water from Egg Spring was transported via pipes to a bathhouse half a mile to the north. The water was still so hot that it had to be mixed with cooler water before it could be used. 

In the 1880s, the location of Egg Spring was used as a reservoir from which to gravity-feed thermal water to the various bathhouses via pipes. 

By 1901, Egg Spring was covered by soil and grass, and no water was flowing at the surface.

Ral Spring was perhaps the most famous thermal water in Hot Springs in the 19th century. Visitors said the health stories, “seem like miracles.” 

Bathers built a crude bathhouse over the spring. Poorer health seekers established a nearby encampment known as Ral City.  

The name “ral” reflected its fame in treating “neuralgia,” a symptom of venereal disease.

Ral Spring became the source of controversy in the 1870s as bathhouse owners claimed that the freely accessible spring was contaminating other springs like the Big Iron Spring--located directly downhill-- leading to a loss of clientele. Ral City supporters said the owners were only interested in profit. The reservation’s first superintendent ordered the Ral Spring building torn down, the Ral City inhabitants removed, and eventually had the springs covered with trees and dirt.

When the pool was covered over in 1878, the waters were piped into the Big Iron Bathhouse.

By 1901, Ral Spring’s outflow was severely diminished by the drilling of nearby wells.

Corn Hole Springs attracted a broad range of bathers in the nineteenth century for foot treatment. A visitor described “a truly democratic gathering. A judge, a tramp, a Senator, a backwoodsman, may here be sandwhiched.”

The Corn Hole was named for its reported power to remove corns, calluses, and bunions on bathers’ feet. Bathers typically sat on wooden benches and placed their feet in the muddy, 120-degree water for up to half an hour. After a week of daily foot-bathing, bathers could then visit a “corn doctor” practicing near the spring who examined the corns and removed them for 25 cents per callus.

Observers frequently reported that Corn Hole was the most sociable location in Hot Springs, as strangers chatted about topics like the destruction of Ral Hole and their experiences during the Civil War, while healing their feet. 

Attempts to expand the size of the spring through dynamite blasting caused the spring waters to flow elsewhere. The spring never re-appeared, and its location is an approximation.

The Mud Hole, located approximately where the present seep emerges, helped to make Hot Springs famous as a government operated health and leisure resort.

Between 1878 and 1921, the Mud Hole was the site of the Government Free Bathhouse. The Government Free Bathhouse provided free, basic hydrotherapy treatment to health seekers unable to afford the businesses on the more luxurious Bathhouse Row. 

The seep is fed by a spring located on the Army Navy Hospital grounds further uphill. The water was piped to the Mud Hole to supplement the Government Free Bathhouse.

Despite limited facilities, the Government Free Bathhouse was often the most used bathhouse in Hot Springs. In some years nearly one-fourth of all health seekers used the Government Free Bathhouse.

Frequently overwhelmed by the needs of bathers, the building over the Mud Hole underwent several expansions. The Government Free Bathhouse moved to the location of the present day Libbey Memorial Physical Medicine Center in 1921.

The Balustrade Shell Fountain is one of the early attempts to make hot drinking water easily accessible to visitors. The fountain was part of a series of fountains between Reserve Street and Arlington Hotel.

By the 1890s, the hot springs that made the park famous were largely covered by the buildings and pathways that made the park accessible. As a result, six hot water fountains, several of which are still visible today, were put in place for visitors to easily consume the water for free.

The Stevens Balustrade Shell Fountain, in operation by 1897, was designed for public use, providing a hot water fountain in the heart of the formal entrance to the park.

The contrast in covering springs with infrastructure while providing drinking fountains shows the balancing act between medicinal use of the water and the visual scenery often associated with the National Park Service. 

Hope you enjoyed the journey into the creation of America's Spa.

data.title: Hidden Hot Springs: A Walking Tour of the Park as Told Through the Springs

data.description: Tour the missions by bicycle or on foot.  The Mission Reach Hike & Bike Trail along the San Antonio River connects all five missions: The Alamo, Mission Concepcion, Mission San Jose, Mission San Juan, and Mission Espada. Each mission is about 2.5 miles from the next. This is a safe and fun way to visit the missions. Take a look at the river map (https://www.sariverauthority.org/resources/san-antonio-river-walk-map) before you start your adventure. The hike and bike path is a great way to see the missions,

data.description: The Grand Portage Trail (Gichi Onigaming) is an eight-and-a-half mile long trail between Lake Superior and the Pigeon River used to transport goods during the Fur Trade Era and for thousands of years as part of a larger trading network. It is natural pathway formed by glacial runoff and a popular destination for through-canoers coming from lakes along the border country. Hikers begin at the Historic Depot or midway at old Highway 61 (County Rd 89). Reservations required to camp at Fort Charlotte.

images.altText: A wooden sign with interpretive text about the history of the Grand Portage Trail
images.caption: Connect yourself to the story of the continent.
images.title: Grand Portage Footpath

stops.significance: The Grand Portage Trail begins at the Historic Depot at the junction of Mile Creek and Store Roads. It is part of a larger trading route used for 1000's of years and a crucial path during the Fur Trade.
stops.assetName: Trailhead for Gichi Onigamiing, The Grand Portage

stops.significance: The Midway Parking area is accessible by vehicle when the road is snow free and is a convenient access point for hikers who desire a shorter hike. It is also a good place to meet portagers coming from Fort Charlotte with their canoes.
stops.assetName: Midway Parking for the Grand Portage

stops.significance: Old-growth white cedar trees persist despite fire, drought, and logging along this section of trail. Known simply as Giizhikag (The Cedars), the oldest of this group of trees were saplings when North West Company men and others trudged the portage in 1797.
The meadow provides hikers with an open vista. The wetlands sometimes host beavers. In the early summer, listen for swamp sparrows, common yellowthroats and other wetland birds.
The highest point on the trail, an ascent of approximately 700' from Lake Superior.

Site of Fort Charlotte, the final stop on this footpath (or the beginning for portagers). 1240 ft. (378 meters/m); 8.5 miles (13.68 kilometers/km) from Lake Superior. When Voyageurs reached Fort Charlotte, they left the supplies they carried, and picked up furs to take back to Grand Portage’s warehouses for processing and eventual shipment to England and Europe. Today it is the only campsite within Grand Portage National Monument.

data.title: Hike the Grand Portage Trail

data.description: Over time, Quincy Mining Company evolved from a failing mine to an industrial giant. As mining ceased in 1945, many buildings and equipment have since been lost to time. Explore how Quincy's landscape has survived, giving us a glimpse into the copper mining boom of the late 1800s. Do not enter ruins. Closed toed shoes, water and sunscreen are recommended. Be aware of loose footing and tripping hazards. Artifact collection is prohibited. The #2 shafthouse will be used as a landmark for this hike.

images.altText: A rusty steel rectangular skip leads to a winter sunrise of red, orange and grey skies.
images.caption: A Quincy Mine winter sunrise.
images.title: Quincy Mine Sunrise

stops.significance: A centralized location to distribute varying supplies was essential to a smooth-flowing mining company.
Buildings with flammables were kept away from high traffic areas.

The second hoist house used for the #2 shaft was later converted to a small warehouse to store items such as steel cable used for hoisting. Note the size of the building comparing it to hoist houses we'll see later.
Hundreds of company homes once dotted the landscape.
Built of reinforced concrete, a new idea at the time, the building housed the famous Nordberg Steam Engine.
Previous to the world's largest steam hoist next door, any hoisting in the #2 shaft was done by a smaller hoist in this building.
For a company that relied on steam, boiler houses were plentiful. Signs of a smokestack usually represent a nearby boiler house. We'll see more of these later.
A convenient location for Quincy's locomotives to "refuel."
stops.assetName: Quincy & Torch Lake RR Water Tower

stops.significance: As a maintenance garage for Quincy's locomotives, a turntable (since removed) lied in front of the building. As Quincy closed in 1945, locomotives were parked inside, waiting to be returned to service someday.

The hoist inside moved men and material in the #4 shaft, which we'll talk more about later. Note the window tops and contrasting colors, giving evidence to a building expansion, possibly to accommodate a larger hoist for the shaft's increasing depth.
A smokestack in ruin tells us we see another boiler house. The boilers inside fueled steam equipment on the southern end of the property.

Now just a small building foundation, most wouldn't realize this was once a profitable shaft that bottomed out at 6,000 feet. As Quincy grew and technology increased, the need for numerous shafts decreased. The #4 stopped producing in 1909. The shafthouse was likely dismantled, but leaving the shaft itself open increased airflow underground.

Do you see yet another smokestack in ruins? What does that tell us? That's right. Another boiler house. Elevated locomotive trestles allowed for overhead dumping of coal to the boilers, producing power to this steam-thirsty mining company.

The technology of a man-engine provided an immense upgrade from a grueling ladder climb for a miner's commute. Today, the shaft is capped  to restrict access, but with openings large enough for bats to navigate freely to their winter hibernating areas.

The #2 Shaft Rockhouse has undergone its own evolution, similar to the Quincy landscape. The previous structure, built in 1894, was a wooden, many-gabled structure. Unfortunately, damp mine air rising from the mine prematurely rotted the wooden framework. The solution? Build new out of steel and concrete. Since Quincy was not familiar with this building style, an outside company was contracted. The modern shafthouse served its purpose well until the #2 shaft shut for good in 1931. After over 50 years of decay, the shafthouse was resided in the mid 80s and has undergone recent structural stabilization, preserving its status as one of the most recognizable icons of Quincy Mine and the Copper Country.

data.title: Hike the Quincy Mine Ruins

data.description: This hike is one mile round trip with 350 feet of elevation change. Along the way, you will experience scenic views of the Tonto Basin and Roosevelt Lake. Waysides are placed along the path to give you more information on the people who lived here and the natural world. The hike will culminate at the Lower Cliff Dwelling where you can explore a number of rooms before you return upon the same path.

images.altText: Lower Cliff Dwelling set in a hillside covered by Saguaro cactus and other green desert vegetation.
images.caption: Lower Cliff Dwelling
images.title: Lower Cliff Dwelling

data.description: "The Top of Texas" - The hike to the summit of Guadalupe Peak is a very strenuous, 8.4-mile round trip hike with a 3,000-foot elevation gain. It will take most hikers from six to eight hours to complete. The peak provides fantastic views from the highest point in the state of Texas (8,751 feet / 2,667 meters). It also introduces hikers to several of the park’s ecosystems including the high desert and the high elevation forests. On a clear day you will be rewarded with a tremendous and windy view.

images.altText: A hiker stands on the trail to Guadalupe Peak to the right the summit of El Capitan can be seen
images.caption: Between El Capitan and the summit of Guadalupe Peak
images.title: Near the summit of Guadalupe Peak

stops.significance:
The Guadalupe Peak Trail begins at the Pine Springs Trailhead, adjacent the RV camping area. The nearby comfort station is your last chance to fill water bottles or use a restroom until you finish your hike. 

Before beginning the hike, there are a few things to keep in mind in order to have a safe and enjoyable experience:

1) Hikers should wear comfortable hiking boots. Trekking poles are strongly recommended.
2) Hikers should carefully monitor the weather. Afternoon thunderstorms are common through the summer months. Watch the sky. If storms develop, seek a lower elevation.
3) Winds can be high on the peak, especially in winter months.  Winds in excess of 80 miles per hour are not uncommon.  
4) Bring plenty of water, at least one gallon per person, per day.  Come prepared with sunscreen, a hat, and protective clothing.
5) Start the hike early in the morning to ensure you return in the daylight. 
6) All solid human waste must be carried out in a landfill-safe commercial toilet bag.
The Tejas Trail junction is a very short distance up the trail from the Pine Springs Trailhead. The Tejas Trail leads to the bulk of the park's trail system in the Guadalupe Mountains Wilderness.
At this junction, turning right takes you toward the strenuous hike into Devil's Hall; a left takes you along the El Capitan Trail towards the Salt Basin overlook and loop trail.

The Stock trail junction is where the first mile of trail (the so-called hiker section) meets the original trail. While using the stock trail adds a mile to the hike each direction, it is significantly less steep than the main trail, and may be useful if backpacking.

When the trail goes "Around The Bend", hikers switch from generally east facing slopes to a sheltered, north facing slope. In wintery conditions above this point trail surfaces can be slick and dangerous.
The Guadalupe Peak Wilderness Campground, with five tent pads, is a short distance down this trail. Wilderness Use Permits are required to camp here.
The bridge is well known landmark on the trail up Guadalupe Peak. It marks the beginning of the final mile up to the summit.
The Hitching Posts mark the end of the portion of the trail that horses and other stock are allowed on. Riders should dismount here and secure their stock before continuing onto the summit.

You've made it to the highest point in the state of Texas! Well done. Take a break, have a snack and some water, take some pictures, and enjoy your accomplishment.

Getting to the top of the peak means that you are really only halfway done with the hike. Because of the steep nature of the trail, for many the hike down can take longer and is more difficult. 

Remember: while up was optional, down is mandatory.

data.title: Hiking Guadalupe Peak

data.description: McKittrick Canyon is the centerpiece of the park. From the trailhead to the Grotto is a gentle hike in the canyon bottom. It's a moderate 4.8 miles roundtrip to the Pratt Cabin; 7.0 miles roundtrip to the Grotto. The canyon is a day use area only. Enjoy a surprising variety of plants, animals and dramatic views along this canyon trail. Please stay on the trail and out of the fragile stream.

images.altText: A gravel trail leads into fall foliage of green, red, and yellow.
images.caption: Fall along the McKittrick Canyon Trail
images.title: Fall in McKittrick Canyon

stops.significance: The McKittrick Canyon Visitor Center is the starting point for all exploration in the canyon. This is a day use area and visitors are required to exit the area before the closing time daily. Make sure to pay your fee at the drop box in front of the visitor center or display your entrance or park pass. The only restrooms in this area are located inside the visitor center breezeway. Potable water is available at a spigot at the rear of the visitor center.

Just past the visitor center is the McKittrick Canyon trailhead. A left turn here leads to the McKittrick Canyon Nature Trail. A right proceeds to the Permian Reef Trail. Proceed straight from the trailhead to begin the McKittrick Canyon Trail.

A short distance from the main trail is the Pratt Cabin. Built in 1930-31 as a retirement home for petroleum Geologist Wallace Pratt, the cabin sits at the junction between South and North McKittrick Canyon. The cabin is an excellent place to sit on the porch and consider Wallace Pratt's legacy in the Guadalupe Mountains.
One mile into South McKittrick Canyon is "The Grotto." An exposed cave formation, nearby are stone benches and picnic tables making this location ideal for a picnic lunch in the canyon.

The Hunter Line Shack was used by J.C. Hunter and his son, J.C. Hunter, Jr. as a base for conservation work and recreational use during the time they owned the bulk of what is today Guadalupe Mountains National Park.
The Notch is where the McKittrick Canyon trail breaks through the ridge and crosses into the deep interior of South McKittrick Canyon.

data.title: Hiking McKittrick Canyon

data.description: The Castolon Historic District represents the largest and most complete example of human history in Big Bend, from Paleo-Indians to pioneers, to the establishment of the national park. Castolon’s history includes famed tales of bandits, soldiers, farmers, and ranchers, in a place where the cultures of Mexico and the United States meet. This short walking tour will help you explore Castolon’s past.

data.description: The West Branch Commercial Historic District illustrates the prosperous decades (1870-1916) when West Branch grew from a country town of wooden storefronts into a bustling center of rural commerce and decorative brick business blocks.

images.altText: A restored wooden storefronts has cream trim and a red orange awning.
images.caption: The Gruwell-Crew Building on Main Street
images.title: West Branch Heritage Museum

stops.significance: When Herbert Hoover was born in 1874, West Branch was beginning a long period of growth and general prosperity that lasted through the early part of the 20th century. Fifteen of the sixteen buildings from that time remain and are listed on the National Register of Historic Places. That designation was the result of a proud community’s recognition of West Branch’s place in history and a tireless effort to preserve their past.

Heritage Square is the name of the small plaza anchored by a gazebo near the intersection of Downey and Main Streets. The gazebo is modeled after an earlier bandstand that sheltered the town pump near that location between 1895 and 1912. The pump itself had been in existence since the early 1870's, and the bandstand became a popular site for concerts.

data.description: Prior to 1920, there were very few shelters for backcountry rangers and hikers. In 1919-20, Superintendent Roger W. Toll reported the need for backcountry shelters to be placed ten to fifteen miles apart along the Wonderland Trail. Toll's system evolved into the construction of both patrol cabins and trail shelters under Superintendent O.A. Tomlinson's administration (1923-41).

This patrol cabin is located north of Sunrise near the park’s northern boundary.
This cabin has served as a base for backcountry patrols in the north side of the park along the Wonderland Trail.
This backcountry patrol cabin is located in the northern part of the park along the Northern Loop Trail.

St. Andrews Patrol Cabin, is located on the Westside Road on St. Andrews Creek, two miles from the Wonderland Trail.

data.description: Fort Larned is one of the most complete Indian Wars Era forts along the Santa Fe Trail. The nine original (and one restored) sandstone block buildings represent a perfect opportunity to see what Army life was like in the mid-1800's.

images.altText: Large, square, grassy area with flagpole in the middle, sandstone block buildings surrounding it.
images.caption: The sandstone buildings at Fort Larned date back to the 1860's.
images.title: Fort Larned's Sandstone Buildings

stops.significance: Start your tour of the historic buildings at the Visitor. Museum exhibits and the park film tell the story of the fort's history and its impact in the region.
This area served as both a ceremonial and practice space for the fort. It's where the daily military routines took place and where soldiers practiced maneuvers.

This building was originally built for enlisted quarters. In 1872 the east half of the building was converted into a hospital. Today, the west side of the building has been restored as a barracks, the east side as a hospital.

This building was used for making and/or repairing items needed in the daily operation of the fort. The building's three rooms housed several different kinds of workshops. On the right, as you face the front, is the bakery, in the middle is where the saddlers, carpenters, and wheelwrights worked, and on the left is the blacksmith shop.

This commissary warehouse was built in 1868. It's original purpose was to add more food storage space for the increased number of troops stationed at the fort after the Civil War. When the storage space was no longer needed it became the post school.
Fort Larned did not have a wall around it so the blockhouse was originally built for defense. It was later turned into the post jail.

The first of two warehouses built to store food supplies and the first sandstone building completed after the Civil War. The west end of the building was used as an arsenal to store ammunition until 1872.

The second sandstone building completed after the Civil War to hold supplies the army needed to keep troops stationed at this remote post. The supplies stored in the large warehouse area were distributed to soldiers and officers from the issue room on the west end of the building.

One of the two quarters built to house the company officers. These were the captains and lieutenants in charge of the enlisted men. Each of these quarters were designed to house two captains and four lieutenants.
The post commander and his family lived in this single-family dwelling.

One of the two quarters built to house the company officers. These were the captains and lieutenants in charge of the enlisted men. Each of these quarters were designed to house two captains and four lieutenants.

data.title: Historic Sandstone Buildings

data.description: Take a stroll through historic Ste. Genevieve to learn about the town and the many historic buildings cared for by the National Park Service and our numerous partner organizations. Use caution when following the tour as you cross streets and travel by foot as you explore the park and surrounding community.

images.altText: Town layout through several minature houses with dirt streets, trees, and animals
images.caption: Get a lay of the land by exploring the parts of historic Ste. Genevieve that stand today.
images.title: Historic Ste. Genevieve

stops.significance: The first stop is the town Welcome Center, head inside grab a map and explore the town diorama. Established by 1750, Ste. Genevieve stands as the oldest permanent European settlement in Missouri. The town as you see it today was built starting around 1785 when a massive flood forced the community to flee the riverfront to where we stand today. The diorama shows Ste. Genevieve in 1832 and highlights the layout of town. The town was built on a grid with everyone living next to each other. While you are exploring town you will notice many buildings that look like those on the diorama, as almost 70% of the houses you see still stand today.
stops.assetName: Ste. Genevieve National Historical Park Visitor Center

stops.significance: Green Tree Tavern is the oldest standing home in Ste. Genevieve, built in 1790 by Nicholas Janis, a wealthy merchant from Kaskaskia Illinois. This house is vertical log and built in the style of poteaux-sur-solle, which means the vertical logs sit on a full stone foundation. Throughout the history of the Green Tree Tavern the house will serve as many things including a meeting space for Free Masons, a tavern, an inn, and a tobacco store. The grounds of the Green Tree Tavern are available from sunrise to sunset for exploration, but the interior is only available on guided tours offered by the National Park Service. To make your reservations for a tour visit the Welcome Center.

The Louis Bolduc house highlights a lot of the key historical features of the colonial French homes within Ste. Genevieve. Built in 1793, the house served private residence until the 1950s when the Colonial Dames of America restored it to its 1790s appearance. The grounds of the Louis Bolduc house show off the palisade fences, outbuildings, and private orchards that were commonly found in Ste. Genevieve during the colonial period. To see the interior of the Louis Bolduc House, stop by the Center of French Colonial Life and book a tour.

Built c. 1820 for Louis Bolduc son-in-law Rene LeMeilleur and his wife Agatha Bolduc in a mix of American and French construction style. The Bolduc-LeMeilleur helps tell the story of the way the culture of Ste. Genevieve changed in the years approaching and following Missouri Statehood. This house is also managed by the Center of French Colonial Life where you can book a tour of the Louis Bolduc and Bolduc-LeMeilleur.

Home to one of the last “commandants” of Ste. Genevieve the Jean Baptiste Vallé house highlights the role of transition in Ste. Geneiveve. The house was built in 1794 as the home of Jean Baptiste Vallé who served as the leader of Ste. Genevieve for 6 months following his brother's death in December 1803. The house today shows a mix of French and American styles due to two renovations the house underwent in the 1800s, the first of which was Greek Revival style, the second was English Colonial Revival. The interior can be seen by reserving a tour with the National Park Service.

Constructed in 1818 by American Jacob Philipson this limestone American-Federal style house shows off one of the new architectural styles that arrives in Ste. Genevieve following the Louisiana Purchase. The Felix Vallé house was mainly occupied by Jean Baptiste Vallé’s son Felix and his family. The home also served as the Menard-Vallé General Store selling goods to the people of town. The Felix Vallé House is managed by Missouri Department of Natural Resources and available to see on guided tours.

Standing as the tallest structure in town the Ste. Genevieve Catholic Church is home to one of Missouri’s oldest parishes. The church that you see today is the 5th one to serve the community. Three log churches served the old town and current settlement from 1763 until the 1830s when the town outgrew the third log church. From 1832-1834 the town constructed a limestone church in the same spot as the current one which they used until the 1870s. When Ste. Genevieve once again outgrew the space, they expanded to the brick church we see today. The brick church today was built surrounding the limestone church and then in 1880 the limestone church was torn down from within. Today the church is open for visitors to explore daily, as long as there are no services occurring.

The Guibourd-Vallé House was built in 1806 for Jacque Guibourd who came to Ste. Genevieve after fleeing the Haitian Revolution. The house was home to the Guibourd's and then Jules Vallé and his wife Anne-Marie Vallé. Jules and Anne-Marie Vallé were antique collectors and today the house boasts a collection of antiques from 1800s France. The house is managed by the Foundations for the Restoration of Ste. Genevieve who offer guided tours.

Following the move from Old Ste. Genevieve to its current location the town created this cemetery. The first burial occurred in 1787 but due to the lack of documentation the first known burial is not until 1793 with Francois Leclerc. The cemetery was used for nearly a century until 1880 when a lack of proper grave marking and space caused the cemetery to run out of usable land. The last burial comes following the closure of the cemetery in 1894 when Odile Valle is interned with her husband Felix. Odile will donate three-fourths the cost of new Catholic Church and land for a new cemetery in order to be buried in Memorial Cemetery.

data.description: This History & Nature Trail is a 3/4 mile loop, half on a mowed path, and half on gravel road. The path explores the prairie landscape that surrounded the fort, as well as buildings and areas of fort operation no longer standing. There is no significant elevation change along the trail. The entire trail may be completed at a leisurely pace in about half an hour. The trail begins on the mowed path between the Hospital and Shops building. Look for marker #1 to begin the trail.

images.altText: Close up view of a sunflower.
images.caption: Wild sunflowers are a common sight on the Kansas prairie.
images.title: Fort Larned History & Nature Trail

stops.significance: The area behind the sandstone barracks was occupied by several early fort structures.
All Indian Wars era forts had cemeteries to bury their dead. Fort Larned had two post cemeteries during it's active Army period. This is the location of the first post cemetery.
The Pawnee River changed course long before the army came, leaving this dry river bed, which made an excellent natural defense on the east side of the fort.
This area is where the fort's horse and mules were kept.
Protecting the U.S. mail was the main reason the Army sent troops to this area in the fall of 1860.
Cattle, and the place to keep them, provided fresh beef for the soldiers' diets.
The Santa Fe Trail was an important communication and transportation route through the Southwest.
stops.assetName: The Santa Fe Trail at Fort Larned

stops.significance: The prairie ecosystem surrounded the fort for miles in every direction.
The site of the Cavalry Stables and a reconstructed dugout from the fort's early period.
The site of the early adobe officers' quarters from the fort's early period.
stops.assetName: Early Officers' Quarters at Fort Larned

stops.significance: This area on the south side of the fort was where the sutlers, or post traders, had their stores and other businesses.
This building is the reconstructed Sutler's Quarters, which served as the office for Cheyenne and Arapaho Indian Agency from 1866 to 1868.
stops.assetName: The Indian Agency at Fort Larned

stops.significance: The location of the ice house, where ice was stored in the winter for use in the summer.
Site of a collapsed dugout from the fort's early period.

data.title: History & Nature Trail

data.description: The Blue Blazes Whiskey Still Trail is a place where nature and history come together in harmony.

images.altText: A large metal cauldron, on top of a stone oven, draining into a wooden barrel.
images.caption: A whiskey still exhibit, common to what was once seen in the Appalachians, stands along the stream.
images.title: Blue Blazes Still

stops.significance: If you don't have much time to spend in the park and would like a short, easy hike, then the Blue Blazes Whiskey Still Trail is for you! This 0.3-mile, one-way trail is readily accessed from the gravel parking lot by the Visitor Center. The trail travels along the tranquil Blue Blazes Run and provides hikers with information about the stream's ecology and storied past during the Prohibition Era.

The trailhead to the Blue Blazes Whiskey Still Trail starts from the Visitor Center's gravel parking lot. Be sure to stay to the right of the trailhead to hike the trail. The Cunningham Falls Nature Trail also shares this trailhead and will be on the left-hand side, denoted by a yellow rectangle blaze. 

After crossing the wooden footbridge you will begin your short journey along the Blue Blazes. This trail does not have any blaze markers.
stops.assetName: Trailhead: Blue Blazes Whiskey Still Trail

stops.significance:
As it rains, water bubbles up from the pockets in bedrock deep within the earth and seeps from the ground. These seeps run down the mountain and merge into a stream called Blue Blazes Run. This water feature has some of the purest water on the mountain and is home to a number of macroinvertebrates such as mayfly nymphs and crayfish. 

Along with aquatic life, humans have used this stream for thousands of years. Archeological evidence found near the stream has proven Blue Blazes Run has been traveled and utilized by American Indians and settlers alike. Although people still enjoy the healthy stream, a dangerous invader is lurking downstream in Big Hunting Creek.
stops.assetName: Blue Blazes: Signs of a Healthy Stream

stops.significance:
The flowing clear waters of Blue Blazes Run are clean enough to support brook trout. This is the only native species of trout in Maryland and they are very fickle about their habitat. The towering trees above not only shade the stream to keep it cool year round, but their roots helps filter runoff entering into the stream. But an invasive species in Big Hunting Creek poses a threat to the stability and health of Blue Blazes Run. 

Didymo, or "rock snot," is a dangerous, non-native alga that is invading freshwater streams in the United States, like Big Hunting Creek. The alga clings to rocks and begins to spread, leaving a trail of death and destruction in the streams it contaminates. This alien species covers and smothers macroinvertebrate habitat, diminishing the population of macroinvertebrates and the trout that feed upon them.

The Blue Blazes Whiskey Still was the largest moonshine still found in Frederick County during the Prohibition Era. The still boasted eighteen 500-gallon vats that were used to produce moonshine. In fact, the Catoctin Mountain moonshine was so well known, people as far away as New York knew it by name. However, everything changed when Charles Lewis, a Foxville local, met with Vernon Redmond, a Frederick County deputy sheriff. Lewis was employed with the Blue Blazes Whiskey Still and, for unknown reasons, contacted Redmond to discuss raiding the still. They agreed on the evening of July 31, 1929.

At 6 p.m., the police drove up the mountain near the site of the still. They got out of their vehicles and walked the rest of the way, but the moonshiners were ready for them. Gunfire erupted as the moonshiners and police exchanged shots. When it was all over the police managed to take the still, but it was not without casualties. Clyde Hauver, a local deputy sheriff, was mortally wounded by a gunshot to his head.

When the dust had settled and the moonshiners had made their getaway, the police came across the largest illegal whiskey operation ever found in Frederick County. Eighteen 500-gallon vats filled with mash. Following the shootout that claimed the life of deputy Hauver, rumors began to emerge about what had caused the events of the raid to transpire. Some claimed Charles Lewis betrayed the moonshiners in exchange for amnesty, some claimed Lewis double-crossed the police so the moonshiners could scare off the sheriff's office from bothering them, and there were even claims of a love triangle dispute with Hauver accidentally getting shot. Some locals said the police were receiving bribes to turn a blind eye to the still, but took action when the moonshiners stopped payment. 

The trial resulting from the raid and death did not provide many answers. Two of the moonshiners were eventually convicted of murder, but locals believe the trial was rushed and justice was never served.

Farmers of the Catoctin Mountain area were faced with a number of problems in marketing the crops they produced. The most profitable market for their goods were in the more populated areas of cities and towns. In the days before good highways and before rails had been laid, the rugged mountains presented a barrier for horse-drawn transportation. Corn and rye were very bulky to transport but when converted to whiskey, they became more profitable.

While the average horse was capable of hauling only 4 bushels of corn at a time, the same horse could haul the equivalent of 24 bushels if the grain was manufactured into whiskey. The liquid whiskey occupied less space and was easier to carry to market. The price of whiskey depended on a number of other factors, as well. The better the grade of corn, the better the whiskey. The more plentiful the spring water happened to be, the better the whiskey produced with it. Finally the more skilled the distiller, the finer the blend of whiskey he could produce.

data.title: History and Nature: Blue Blazes Whiskey Still Trail

data.description: On this 1.3 mile walking tour you will discover a masterpiece of monumental landscape architecture built by American Indians as a sacred ceremonial center almost 2000 years ago. You will see remnants of earthen walls that once stood up to 12 feet tall, outlining huge geometric figures in the shape of circles, squares, and a parallel-walled avenue aligned to the winter solstice sunset. You will learn about Native peoples' connections to the plants, animals, and geology of the Scioto River valley.

images.caption: Aerial photo shows geometric earthworks outlined in the vegetation
images.title: Hopeton Earthworks

data.description: Virtual Tour Hopewell Furnace: an Iron Plantation from 1771 to 1883. Its workers produced various iron products: cast iron stoves to pig iron bars. In this rural setting, the resources for producing iron were available though being rural meant, Hopewell Furnace operated as a nearly self-sustaining place of life and work. In this tour you will see buildings that you’d expect to see at an Iron Plantation such as the Cast House and Blacksmith Shop, pastures and a barn with animals and even a store.

images.altText: 2020 Hopewell Furnace interpretive team
images.caption: Discover Hopewell Furnace through Virtual Tour presented by 2020 interpretive team
images.title: Hopewell Furnace through Virtual Tour

data.description: This short walking tour will guide you through the site of the Hoskins Farm. Joseph and Hannah Hoskins moved here during the American War of Independence. Fleeing Pennsylvania in the hopes of living far from the seat of war, they ironically ended up in the middle of the largest battle to be fought in the southern colonies. This tour will explain the role this farm played in the battle, as well as describe the day to day life of the Hoskins Family.

images.altText: A two story building with clap board siding stands with trees close by. A chimney on its side.
images.caption: The Hoskins House is a historic building and crucial landmark to the battle of Guilford Courthouse.
images.title: Hoskins Home

stops.significance: This is the beginning of the Hoskins Walking tour. You are standing on the preserved 7 1/2 acres of the original 150 acre plantation.
stops.assetName: Hoskins Farm Entrance and British Deployment Area

stops.significance: The Hoskins farm saw a brutal battle rage across its fields. These snake rail fences were built to keep cows and pigs out of crop fields. But on March 15, 1781, the North Carolina militia hoped fences like these would stop bullets and British soldiers.
stops.assetName: Snake Rail Fences at the Hoskins Farm

stops.significance: This is the main building of the farm where the Hoskins raised their family. It also served as a headquarters and field hospital during the battle of Guilford Courthouse.
The kitchen and surrounding area is where a great deal of the daily chores would have been done by the Hoskins family.
The Coble barn is a colonial barn but is not original to the site. It was moved here in the 20th century for preservation, and is a style that likely would have been built in this region.
stops.assetName: Coble Barn at the Hoskins Farm

data.description: Most of our visitors only stay in the park for an hour or two. If you’re one of them, this tour is for you! Hovenweep in a Hurry is a guided hike to Hovenweep Castle via Tower Point, 1.5 miles roundtrip and all on the canyon rim. Bring water and wear walking shoes and sun protection. As you go, this tour will give you a brief overview of the ancestral Puebloan people who called this canyon home. At the end of the tour, simply retrace your steps back along the trail to the visitor center.

images.altText: remains of Hovenweep castle, a large stone structure on the canyon rim
images.caption: Let's get going - we're in a hurry! This hike to Hovenweep Castle will give you everything you need.
images.title: Hovenweep in a Hurry

stops.significance:
Welcome to Hovenweep National Monument, established in 1923 by President Warren G. Harding to preserve the “finest prehistoric masonry in the United States.” The park visitor center, built in 2001, is the perfect place to start your visit. Restrooms, park maps, passport cancellation stamps, and more are available here. You can extend your stay with a picnic lunch at the tables in the parking lot. Before continuing on the tour, make sure you have water and sun protection (hat, sunglasses, and sunscreen) with you. 

During your visit, please be respectful of these sacred and sensitive sites. Stay on trail at all times and do not cross barriers, touch, or enter any site. Thank you for helping protect Hovenweep! 

Hovenweep National Monument turns 100 in 2023. What do you think the monument will be like 100 years from now?

At the overlook you can see many structures, but the closest is Stronghold House. Named for its appearance, archeologists aren’t actually sure whether this structure was built for defense.  The structure merely seemed formidable and strategically placed for those early explorers walking up the canyon beyond. The defensive theory is still possible, among many others! We do know many of the structures here were dwellings for the farmers who lived here and were built between 1230 and 1270 AD. 

What are your first impressions of Hovenweep’s structures?

The towers of Hovenweep are unique for their well-preserved state as well as their size, construction, and variation. We don’t know why some of the buildings here were built this way (although we can guess Eroded Boulder House provided natural walls and roofing). We do know why the farmers here weren’t building cliff dwellings like Mesa Verde’s: the canyon size and sandstone type doesn’t allow for large alcoves to house them! Instead, the people here were able to use their home’s landscape creatively, building large complexes along the sloping canyon walls and smaller structures tucked into natural rock formations.

Just as Hovenweep is unique from other Ancestral Pueblo sites, it is also very similar. Unit Type House demonstrates that, with it’s typical layout of storage rooms and a kiva. Even the kiva is of a similar type to those at nearby Mesa Verde. The people who lived here, the ancestral Puebloans, were part of a much larger cultural community spread throughout the southwest. Villages like this one would have communicated, traded, met with, and perhaps joined families with, other communities in the area. If you get the chance, compare the small farming communities of Hovenweep to the larger trading centers of Mesa Verde and Chaco Culture.

Arguably the best view on the trail, Tower Point reveals the structures of Square Tower Group and surrounding landscape. Look closely at the walls of the side canyon – can you see small alcoves? These are evidence of granaries, food stores of corn, beans, and squash. The people here were excellent dryland farmers, terracing the canyon and planting fields on the mesa top. They mostly grew the three aforementioned crops, had domesticated dogs and turkeys, and also hunted and gathered. The climate was a little wetter back then, but not much. They got water from the seep springs at canyon heads, from potholes, and by using check dams.

Hovenweep Castle’s multiple kiva depressions, later additions, and round tower reflect a larger community. We don’t know if people lived here, used the space as a community center, or both. We do believe the community here was egalitarian, with a group of elders making decisions for the community at large. 

For many years, people didn’t just survive here – they thrived. Families came together, children were born, and elders passed on. There were arguments and laughter, ceremonies and celebrations, dogs barking, children playing, and parents calling after them. The stars were as familiar to people as the canyons and buttes below. Some dwellings, like Hovenweep Castle, marked the solstices and equinoxes. 

Does this sound like your community?

The ancestral Pueblo peoples and the buildings and artifacts they left behind have mystified explorers, archeologists, rangers, and park visitors for years. Square Tower represents all that we have learned – how they were expert stone masons who farmed and watched the stars – and all we have not, like the purpose of many structures. We may never know the full answer, but places like Hovenweep invite us to discover, ponder, and connect to the past. 

We do know the answer to one mystery: where they went. People left the Four Corners region, including this canyon, by 1300 AD. We don’t know exactly why, but a severe drought caused diminishing resources and potential conflict. Also, the people here were always semi-nomadic, building communities and leaving them every so often. When they left, most probably went south to the communities near the Rio Grande. The modern Pueblo peoples, their descendants, still live there today.

data.title: Hovenweep in a Hurry

data.description: Explore the depth of human history in Arches National Park. The archeological record tells us that humans have been travelling through and living in this stunning desert landscape for thousands of years. We also know that traditionally associated American Indian tribes have been here since time immemorial. Early settlers, cattle ranchers, and park founders also made a lasting impact on the landscape. Archeological sites are fragile resources. Never touch, leave artifacts in place, and watch your step.

images.altText: Petroglyphs (pecked rock markings) horse riders and a herd of several bighorn sheep.
images.caption: Wolfe Ranch Petroglyphs
images.title: Wolfe Ranch Petroglyphs

stops.significance: A visit to the museum exhibits inside the Arches Visitor Center is an excellent introduction to the human history of the area. Watch the park film for added context.

data.title: Human History

data.description: Since time immemorial humans have been thriving on this redwood coast. This extensive tour spans the length and width of the parks. At these sites you will hear stories from Yurok elders, you see where the Tolowa people harvest the ocean's bounty, you can hike to a 19th century historic ranch, see a 1930s' Civilian Conservation Corps cabin, learn about redwood logging, see 21st century habitat restoration, or take a stroll to a camouflaged World War II radar site. This tour is listed from south to north.

images.altText: A grassy slope leads upto a wooden barn with a pitched roof. Trees surround the barn.
images.caption: Hiking to Lyons Ranch is like stepping back 100 years.
images.title: Historic Barn at Lyons Ranch

stops.significance: Museum exhibits, basketry and text talk about the Yurok culture and community that has lived in this area since time immemorial. An outdoors interpretive panel on the ocean-facing side of the visitor center shares a Yurok legend about the rocks seen on the horizon.
The Lyons Ranch is a preserved set of barns and other cultural sites from a successful sheep farming operation run the by Lyons family from the 1860s-1950s.
One of the last remaining World War 2 coastal radar sites, this is a short walk to get to. The buildings for the radar site were disguised as two farm structures.
stops.assetName: World War II Radar Station: B-71

stops.significance: The Klamath River has provided hunting, fishing and transportation for millennium to the Yurok. Coastal trade routes from Klamath to Crescent City are long established. Many of the landscape features seen from this view are very important to Yurok.   Interpretive panels at thus site talk about some of this history.

data.title: Human Stories: Living Off the Land (and Water)

data.description: Get to know the real Ben Franklin as you explore the streets and sites of his Philadelphia neighborhood.

images.altText: A color image of an 18th century portrait of Benjamin Franklin reading a stack of papers in his hand
images.caption: Benjamin Franklin frequented many of the sites of Independence National Historical Park.
images.title: Benjamin Franklin

stops.significance:
Benjamin Franklin may be remembered today as a scientist and statesman, but he started as a printer.  Working in a printing office much like this one, Franklin printed newspapers and almanacs. He earned lucrative government printing contracts and invested some of his growing wealth in printing shops in other colonies, and even in the Caribbean. Franklin retired from active participation in printing at the age of 42.

Park rangers at this site demonstrate how an 18th century printing press operated.  No tickets are required, and there is no admission fee.

The larger "ghost structure" indicates the site of Benjamin and Deborah Franklin's home. But they never lived in the home together.  

Franklin arranged with master carpenter Robert Smith to build the house and then he left for London. Deborah lived in the house with daughter Sally (Sarah), son-in-law Richard Bache and their children.  By the time Franklin returned briefly in 1775, Deborah had already died. Here, Benjamin Franklin died in 1790 at the age of 84.

Franklin's grandchildren demolished the house in 1812 to allow for commercial development. Only the foundations of the home remain today.

A statue of Benjamin Franklin, clad in a toga, stands in the niche above the door to Library Hall.  An avid reader, Franklin established the Library Company of Philadelphia, America's first subscription library.  

The original building on this site was demolished in 1884 and later reconstructed by the National Park Service.  Today, Library Hall serves as the research library of the American Philosophical Society, housing such treasures as the journals of Lewis and Clark.

When open, the site features a lobby exhibit open to the public.
stops.assetName: Library of the American Philosophical Society

stops.significance:
Benjamin Franklin demonstrated a passion for learning all throughout his life. To foster an open exchange of information, he founded the American Philosophical Society.  This building has served as the headquarters of that institution since 1789.

The members of the American Philosophical Society embraced the notion of promoting useful knowledge for the betterment of mankind. Early members included founders of the republic - Washington, Adams, Jefferson, Hamilton, and Madison - as well as doctors, tradesmen, and artisans.

Philosophical Hall is home to changing exhibits today.  For the exhibit schedule and hours, visit the website of the Museum of the American Philosophical Society.  Note:  donated requested at entry.
stops.assetName: Museum of the American Philosophical Society

stops.significance:
Benjamin Franklin pledged his life, his fortune, and his sacred honor in the cause of independence in this building. But he was a clerk and lawmaker here long before the American Revolution. Today we know the building as Independence Hall, but it was Pennsylvania's colonial capital building under British rule.

After having helped craft the laws of a British colony in the building's Assembly Room, Franklin returned to attend the meetings of the Second Continental Congress.  Here he signed the Declaration of Independence.  Eleven years later, Franklin returned again as elder statesman at the Constitutional Convention, urging the states to adopt the U.S. Constitution. Throughout his political career in this building, Benjamin Franklin held fast to his belief in the power of the people to participate in government.

The building is open by tour only.

About half the population of the city gathered for Benjamin Franklin's funeral in April 1790.  The procession to this burial ground included clergy, political leaders, printers, members of the American Philosophical Society, and ordinary citizens.  They came together to honor the life of an extraordinary man.

data.title: In Franklin's Footsteps

data.description: Find out how the words in the Declaration of Independence have inspired generations of activists and civil rights leaders.

images.altText: A color image of an 18th century portrait of Absolom Jones wearing the clothes of a minister.
images.caption: Absolom Jones was the first ordained African American priest in the Episcopal Church.
images.title: Absolom Jones

stops.significance:
Here Thomas Jefferson drafted the words "All men are created equal..." while his enslaved teenaged servant, Robert Hemings helped Jefferson dress, provided him with tea or a light meal, and coordinated his barber's visits. 

In this house - and throughout the colonies - the fight for political independence co-existed with the enslavement of men, women, and children, like Robert Hemings.  

Later generations of abolitionists and activists looked to the eloquent statement of human rights in the Declaration of Independence - written on this site - in their fight for personal freedom.

Enslaved maid Ona Judge seized her freedom from the President's House in Philadelphia while George and Martha Washington ate dinner. Look for a woman's footprints embedded in the ground.

The Washingtons held nine enslaved servants, including Ona Judge, at this house in Philadelphia.  President Washington rotated these servants out of state every six months so that they would not be eligible to obtain their freedom legally under Pennsylvania's Gradual Abolition Act.  

Judge eventually settled in New Hampshire, a free state.  But, under the Fugitive Slave Law of 1793, Judge remained a fugitive until her death in 1848.

People from all over the world come to stand in front of an old broken bell that doesn't ring.  But the Liberty Bell's message - liberty everywhere for everyone - is still heard loud and clear today.

The inscription on this State House bell went unnoticed during the Revolutionary War:  "Proclaim Liberty Throughout All the Land Unto All the Inhabitants Thereof."  Abolitionists seeking to end slavery were inspired by that message and used the bell as a symbol for their cause, naming it the "Liberty Bell."  

Since then, other activists - from women's suffrage to civil rights - have used this bell to in their fight for liberty and equality for all.  Join the likes of Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. and the Dalai Lama when you gaze upon this fragile bell and ponder its enduring message of liberty.

The fight for freedom and equal rights continued on - even after the Congress passed the 1793 Fugitive Slave Act in this building.  

The Fugitive Slave Act permitted slave catchers to apprehend fugitives in the north.  It also fined abolitionists caught assisting fugitives from slavery.  

Community leader Absalom Jones and other free black citizens argued that under the Declaration of Independence and the Bill of Rights all men were entitled to equal rights and liberties.  They asked for a revision to the law and protection from abduction from slave traders.  Their petition was referred to a committee, where it died.  But the fight continued on, and on, and on...

Generations of Americans have gathered in the shadow of Independence Hall to declare their rights.  It is where "We, the People" have linked their causes with the ideals of the Declaration of Independence.

Frederick Douglass - a fugitive from slavery - alluded to the Declaration of Independence when he spoke to abolitionists here on a hot afternoon in August 1844.  

Susan B. Anthony disrupted the Fourth of July celebration in 1876, distributing her Women's Declaration of Independence - before being ousted from the event.

Look around at the tranquil scene today and imagine the scenes of protest on this Square as each generation struggled to define 'We the People."

President-elect Abraham Lincoln stood inside Independence Hall and said that there is "...something in that Declaration giving...hope to the world for all future time."

The building has witnessed everything from Constitutional Convention sessions that wrote slavery into the nation's fabric to National Freedom Day wreath-laying ceremonies celebrating the 13th Amendment ending slavery.  Accused fugitives from slavery once even stood trial - for their freedom - on the second floor of this building.

The pursuit of liberty remains one of the nation's greatest hopes...and greatest challenges.

data.title: In Pursuit of Liberty
