data.description: Did you know that the Brandywine Valley was on of the earliest centers of the Industrial Revolution in the United States? From the late 1700s to the mid 1800s, innovators and entrepreneurs working in the Brandywine Valley were at the cutting edge of industrial development. Explore the history of this development and the impacts it had on the nation through this narrated tour.

images.altText: Ruins of a two story stone house surrounded by trees.
images.caption: Ruined house along Beaver Creek
images.title: Ruined house along Beaver Creek

stops.significance: This site provides a scenic vista point overlooking the Brandywine Valley, including views of farm land, grand estates, and the Brandywine River itself. From this overlook, we can get a wide perspective on the Valley, as we discuss the history of this special place leading up to the late 1700s industrial boom.

The mica, kaolin, and feldspar extracted from this pit is representative of the abundance of raw materials that the Brandywine Valley could provide. These raw materials were used to fuel the innovative industries that produced finished goods, both within the Valley and throughout the region. With these raw materials  close at hand, the Valley secured it's position as a major center of the Industrial Revolution in the United States.

This ruined two story house, built by the Green family in the 1780s, is one of the few surviving physical structures from the Brandywine Valley's industrial heyday. It stands as a reminder that this valley was once lined with mills, and the houses of the families and workers who operated them. These mills were cutting edge industrial enterprises which produced goods that were shipped around the United States and abroad, as well as serving as incubators for new technologies.

data.title: Industry in the Brandywine Valley

data.description: Located at one of the numerous peaks of Catoctin Mountain, and approximately one mile north of the Visitor Center, the Charcoal Exhibit tells the story of how once the mountain belched smoke and was lit with seemingly ceaseless fires. This half mile hike is easily accessed from the Thurmont Vista Parking Area as well as from nearby hiking trails. Step back in history and learn of the history of the Charcoal Industry on Catoctin Mountain.

images.altText: A wooden sled with a mobile device showing a map, imposed over top the image.
images.caption: The Charcoal Trail provides a glimpse into the mountain's history
images.title: Charcoal Trail App Tour

stops.significance: Located at one of the numerous peaks of Catoctin Mountain, and approximately one mile north of the Visitor Center, the Charcoal Exhibit Trail tells the story of how once the mountain belched smoke and was lit with seemingly ceaseless fires. This half mile hike, marked by a pink, triangle blaze, is easily accessed from the Thurmont Vista Parking Area as well as from nearby hiking trails. Starting in the late 1700s, the Charcoal Industry would endure on the mountain for well over a century until the Catoctin Iron Furnace would switch to coal in 1873. Step back in time and learn of the history of the Charcoal Industry on Catoctin Mountain.

The Catoctin Iron Furnace at the base of the mountain required fuel, and the surrounding areas were covered with it. Charcoal started its life here in the forest as a tree. Hundreds of woodcutters would come to work on the mountain, chopping down the chestnuts, oaks, and other hardwood trees. The cutters would clear a forest and leave a few trees behind to reseed the area. They would repeat this cycle every 25-30 years. One cord of wood (a 4 ft by 4 ft x 8 ft wood stack) would produce 16 bushels of charcoal.
stops.assetName: Charcoal Exhibit Trail: Wood - The Essential Ingredient

stops.significance: Cutters would transfer about a half cord of wood on to wooden sleds drawn by horses or mules. The wood haulers would carry the 4-foot cut logs to various charcoal hearth sites that dotted the mountain. This work would be carried out by a wide variety of people including whites, free African Americans, and slaves.
stops.assetName: Charcoal Exhibit Trail: Wood Hauler's Sled

stops.significance: Charcoal hearths required large clearings, 30 to 40 feet in diameter. This site was known to have been a charcoal hearth because of the blackened soil and level ground. The collier, or person who tended to the hearth and made charcoal, would rake and clear the area for the wood. The 4-foot logs would be stacked around the clearing as the hearth would begin to take shape.
stops.assetName: Charcoal Exhibit Trail: Preparing the Hearth

stops.significance:
The collier supervised the orderly stacking of the wood. First a chimney was built in the center of the hearth; then 30 to 50 cords of 4-foot logs were stacked around this chimney in concentric circles. The finished stack was covered with leaves and dirt. This controlled the amount of air that reached the fire. Hot embers were dropped into the chimney on a cool, humid night. The charcoal smoldering process was a round-the-clock job and would take two weeks to complete.

The charcoal was raked into small piles so that it could cool. This way any fires that would flare up would destroy only a portion of the finished product instead of the entire stack. The collier was responsible for the charcoal unit until it was delivered to the furnace. Since he was paid by the bushel, any charcoal that accidentally burned was his personal loss.

Colliers would monitor several charcoal hearths across the mountainside and had to live nearby. Because collier huts were in the vicinity of the hearths, a collier could quickly reach any of his sites to keep the charcoal smoldering and prevent flare ups. The huts were very humble living quarters offering only a small living space with a simple cooking area towards the back.

With the charcoal made, it was ready for transport to the Catoctin Iron Furnace. Teamsters would load their wagons with charcoal and begin their journey to the base of the mountain. The charcoal from Catoctin Mountain would be used to fuel the production of pig iron which could be crafted into a wide variety of household and farm products. During the Revolutionary War, the furnace also produced cannonballs for the American war effort. The furnace would run for over 100 years on charcoal fuel before switching to coal in 1873.
stops.assetName: Charcoal Exhibit Trail: Fueling the Furnace

data.title: Industry on the Mountain: Charcoal Exhibit Trail

data.description: This tour takes you through the Castillo's interior rooms and gundeck. It walks you through a basic overview of the fort's near 350 years of history. The tour begins after you cross the moat and step inside the fortress. Enjoy!

images.altText: Aerial Photograph of the Castillo
images.caption: Aerial Photograph of the Castillo
images.title: Castillo de San Marcos

park.fullName: Castillo de San Marcos National Monument
park.name: Castillo de San Marcos

stops.significance:
You have entered one of the most extraordinary places in the United States, incorporating over 335 years of history and culture. Construction of the Castillo de San Marcos began in 1672, making it one of the oldest standing structures in North America. The fort has undergone many renovations and changes over the years but appears today much as it would have looked at its final completion in 1756.
 
The Castillo was initially built by the Spanish to protect their vast empire in the Americas. Engineer Ignacio Daza designed a fortress using a bastion system. The star-like outline of the Castillo is formed by diamond shaped projections, called bastions, located on each corner of the fort. The design eliminates blind spots for the guards in the garitas,or sentry boxes, at each bastion point and increases the fort's firepower by allowing multiple cannons to fire on the same target creating a crossfire effect.
stops.assetName: Florida: Castillo de San Marcos National Monument

data.description: On May 10, 1863 Confederate General Thomas "Stonewall" Jackson died in the office building of the Fairfield Plantation. Today, this location is most associated with the death of Jackson, but the history here spans a much wider period before and after the Civil War. Follow along and discover the history of this complex place. If following this tour onsite, the distance covered will be less than a quarter of a mile and the tour will take about 30 minutes to complete.

images.altText: A small white building in a field of grass.
images.caption: The Jackson Death Site is the only building standing from what was once a busy slave plantation.
images.title: Jackson Death Site

stops.significance: In the aftermath of the Battle of Chancellorsville, Confederate General Thomas “Stonewall” Jackson died here in Guinea Station, Virginia on May 10th, 1863. This tour explores the history of Guinea Station and the people who lived and visited here during the Civil War. Explore the grounds of Fairfield, a historic slave plantation, where Jackson died and discover how the memory of his death was forged over time. Here in the parking lot, learn about the creation of the community of Guinea Station to understand why Jackson was here in 1863.

During the early 1800s, the Thornton family established Fairfield Plantation here along the Richmond, Fredericksburg, & Potomac Railroad. At the time of the Civil War, the plantation was home to roughly 70 enslaved people and the Chandler family. What was life at Fairfield like during the Antebellum period? How did the lives of the enslaved people and the Chandlers differ? Residents of Fairfield Plantation saw firsthand the devastation that war brought to Virginia. War also presented opportunities for freedom to people who lived in slavery.

Located along the Richmond, Fredericksburg, & Potomac Railroad, Fairfield Plantation was frequented by soldiers from both sides during the Civil War. Confederate General Thomas “Stonewall” Jackson spent his final moments in the plantation’s office building. What important events took place here during the war? How were civilians impacted by the repeated arrival of armies?

During the early 1900s, former Confederates preserved the building where Thomas Jackson died. His death became central to the Lost Cause, an ideology created by former Confederates that argued the Civil War was not fought over the issue of slavery. The landscape they forged during the early 1900s placed Jackson’s death at the forefront and overlooked the plantation that existed here for four decades. What does this site tell us about the people who created it? How should we remember the death of Jackson today? 

Thank you for joining this tour of the Jackson Death Site. This program was made possible in part by a grant from the National Park Foundation.

data.title: Jackson Death Site Tour

data.description: The Jackson Ward Podcast Walking Tour is a walking tour guided by a podcast that explores the history of the Jackson Ward community in Richmond, Virginia. It visits many different locations relating to life and individuals in Jackson Ward during the early 1900s, including the home of Maggie L. Walker.

stops.significance: The Hippodrome Theater served as a centerpiece of the cultural revolution that occurred in Jackson Ward during the 1920's and 1930's, hosting many different Black entertainers throughout its lifetime.

stops.significance: 212 East Clay Street housed two of the most prominent Jackson Ward businesses during the early 1900's and continues to stand as a prominent neighborhood building today.
The A.D. Price Funeral Home was one of the largest businesses in Jackson Ward and A.D. Price served as a member of the board of directors for Maggie L. Walker's bank the St. Luke Penny Savings Bank.
The former home of John Mitchell Jr., prominent newspaper and bank leader of Jackson Ward

Two prominent financial institutions resided on this corner of 2nd and Jackson Street

data.description: On March 30, 1942, more than 120,000 Japanese Americans were banished from their West Coast homes and placed in concentration camps during World War II. The very first group to be incarcerated was from Bainbridge Island, WA. This memorial serves as a reminder of these events: “Nidoto Nai Yoni” (Let it Not Happen Again)

data.description: Take a leisurely 1-mile loop trail through the Settlement, the 1860s home of Lyndon Johnson's grandparents, Sam Johnson Sr. and Eliza Johnson. You will see the Johnsons' original log home as well as structures built by later owners of the property. The trail is a relatively flat, granite gravel trail. Restrooms and water fountains are at the Event Center. Remember: • Bicycles only on pathways • Smoking only at the Event Center • Dogs must be on a leash no longer than 6 ft. • Do not feed or pet animals

data.description: Enter the Nisqually Entrance in the southwest corner of Mount Rainier National Park and begin the journey to Paradise. Drive along a historic winding road through old-growth forest with glimpses of Mount Rainier. Stretch your legs by walking short nature trails and viewing waterfalls. Visit Longmire, the park’s first settlement, before concluding your tour in the subalpine meadows of the Paradise area. While Paradise is open year-round, in winter the road past Longmire closes nightly.

images.altText: A road leads towards a glaciated mountain peak.
images.caption: Explore Mount Rainier National Park along the road to Paradise.
images.title: Mount Rainier from the Paradise Road

stops.significance: Start your journey at the Nisqually Entrance. This is the main entrance to Mount Rainier National Park and can be very busy with significant wait times on sunny weekends. To avoid congestion, visit on weekdays and early or late in the day.
Pause to get your first glimpse of Mount Rainier from Kautz Creek! This is also the first location with restroom and picnic facilities.
Stretch your legs on this short trail through old-growth forest.

Longmire is a National Historic Landmark District. Open year round, the area was the park’s first settlement, and continues to be home to much of the park’s administrative and maintenance facilities. Stop for visitor information at the Longmire Museum, food or supplies at the National Park Inn and General Store, and to explore the history of the area. Several short walks and longer hiking trails also start from Longmire.
Pause to view this scenic waterfall. Parking is limited and watch for traffic if walking along the road.
Detour from the main Paradise Road to travel this short scenic byway with excellent views of Mount Rainier and the surrounding valleys.  Closed during the winter.
This impressive waterfall is worth a stop! View the falls from above or take the short walk down to the lower viewpoint. Restrooms and picnic facilities also available.

You’ve arrived in Paradise! This popular area features wildflower meadows in summer, fall colors in autumn, and plenty of snow in winter. Stop by the Jackson Visitor Center for information, to view exhibits, and for food and gifts. The Paradise Inn is open during the summer. Hike the numerous trails, with options for all abilities.

data.title: Journey to Paradise

data.description: The Junior Ranger Loop is a 1.25 mile hike that can be enjoyed by nature-lovers of all ages! If you wish to complete the Junior Ranger program, pick up a copy of the Junior Ranger Booklet at the Carriage Barn Visitor Center during open hours or download a copy on our website. During the open visitor season (late May to October 31), wooden Junior Ranger Loop signs will guide your way.

images.altText: Park Ranger and visitors hiking on carriage road
images.caption: Hiking on Mountain Rd
images.title: Hiking on Mountain Rd

park.fullName: Marsh - Billings - Rockefeller National Historical Park
park.name: Marsh - Billings - Rockefeller

stops.significance:
Park at the Billings Farm & Museum Visitor Center and walk across the street and up the short, steep hill to reach the Carriage Barn Visitor Center. During open hours, you can grab a Junior Ranger book, visit Park Rangers, and visit the exhibit Conservation Stewardship.

Walk out of the Carriage Barn Visitor Center and you'll see some large Norway Spruce trees on your right. Find the largest Norway spruce in all of Vermont, ask a ranger if you can’t decide which one is the biggest.

This tree is one of the oldest trees in the Park, planted by people over 100 years ago.

The story of this park is about how people use and take care of the land. As you walk along the Junior Ranger loop, see if you can spot signs of people’s interactions with the land.

This is where the Marsh, Billings, and Rockefeller 
families lived. When George Perkins Marsh was growing up here over 200 years ago, he saw that many trees were being cut down to make sheep pastures.

Look all around you – imagine this area without any forests!
Marsh noticed that without trees on the hillsides many things happened: rains washed away soil leaving behind only rocks, animals lost their homes, rivers became too muddy, and people had a harder time living here.

Marsh wrote a very important book called "Man and Nature". It told 
people that if we take care of the land, it will take care of us.

The Belvedere was a recreational complex and pool house for the Billings and Rockefeller families. Inside, is a bowling alley and 1960s Fallout Shelter! Visit Recreation.gov to book a Fallout Shelter tour to see the inside. 

Continue past the Belvedere and take the right fork, going straight up the hill. On your left you will see a tree plantation with trees about 10ft tall. In 2005, Marsh-Billings-Rockefeller National Historical Park started a new plantation of Norway spruce trees to show the way Billings created new forests. A plantation is where just one type of tree is planted like rows of corn in an open field.
Between May-October, the wood barn has an exhibit that includes the Billings family's carriages and examples of artwork found inside the mansion.
stops.assetName: Woodbarn at Marsh-Billings-Rockefeller National Historical Park

stops.significance:
Marsh-Billings-Rockefeller National Historical Park was created to carry on the work of the families that lived here—to help people work better with nature. 

The Forest Center was built in 2008 to be used as a classroom and meeting space. It is the first building in the National Park system constructed entirely with Forest Stewardship Council (FSC) certified wood. A partnership project of the National Park Service and The Woodstock Foundation, the Forest Center has been awarded Platinum Leadership in Energy and Environmental Design (LEED) certification by the U.S. Green Building Council. View the exhibits outside the building for more information about Green Energy use in the National Park.

data.description: See the points of interest at the Korean War Veterans Memorial.

images.altText: A field of snow covered soldiers walking towards an American Flag
images.caption: Korean War Veterans Memorial covered in snow
images.title: Korean War Veterans Memrorial

stops.significance: The information kiosk is a place to pick up brochures, information, and to browse the the Korean War Veterans directory of service members.
stops.assetName: Korean War Veterans Memorial information kiosk

stops.significance: The United Nations wall is the granite curb on the north side of the statues. This wall lists the 22 countries that gave combat or medical support to the UN forces.
stops.assetName: Korean War Veterans Memorial: United Nations Wall

stops.significance:
Adjacent to the UN wall is a triangular "field of service." Here 19 stainless steel statues, the creation of World War II veteran Frank Gaylord, depict a patrol and evoke the experience of American ground troops in Korea. 

Granite strips and scrubby juniper bushes suggest the rugged Korean terrain and vegetation, while windblown ponchos recall 
the harsh weather. This symbolic patrol brings together members of the Army, Navy, Air Force, and Marines and portrays servicemen from a variety of ethnic backgrounds.
stops.assetName: Korean War Veterans Memorial: Soldier Statues

stops.significance:
At the end of the field of service sits a 128 foot circular pool. This design replicates how the Korean Peninsula protrudes into the Korean Strait and the East China Sea, where the fighting took place. This circular pool is known as the Pool of Remembrance.

Numbers of those killed, wounded, missing in action, and prisoners of war are etched into the curb at the water’s edge
stops.assetName: Korean War Veterans Memorial: Pool of Remembrance

stops.significance:
The granite Mural Wall is adorned with etchings of over 2,400 period photographs of Korean War service-members, obtained from the 
National Archives. The mural represents those forces that augmented and supported foot troops. The Army, Navy, Air Force and Marine Corps personnel and their equipment are depicted on the wall.
stops.assetName: Korean War Veterans Memorial: Wall of Faces

data.description: Go off the beaten path on a short, unpaved driving tour into the Lance Rosier Unit, the historical heart of the Big Thicket. See historic sites and dense, jungle-like forest. The tour begins on Rosier Park Road in Saratoga, Texas. Be aware that this area does not have any typical park amenities, such as trails or restrooms. Conditions may be muddy.

images.altText: Group of bald cypress trees, showing their wide trunks and green moss and lichen.
images.caption: Bald cypresses' wide trunks provide stability in the swamp.
images.title: Bald Cypress Swamp

stops.significance:
The Saratoga Oilfield, just outside the Lance Rosier Unit, was home to an oil boom in the early 1900s. Though the oil boom is long-gone, production continues to this day.

(Audio clip is a modern-day pumpjack)

Note: The oilfield is privately-owned.
The Oilfield Cemetery, surrounded by oil pumpjacks and equipment, dates back to 1888. Members of the pioneering Cotten family as well as many generations of Saratoga residents are buried here.
If you’re here to explore the Lance Rosier Unit, your GPS did not mislead you!
Who was Lance Rosier? Why is part of the preserve named for him?
Life abounds in this swamp, full of majestic bald cypress trees and their strange, knobby knees.

This bridge was used when this area was logged. Today, the bridge is closed to vehicles. However, hikers can walk over the bridge to explore the area along Little Pine Island Bayou and the vast dwarf palmetto patch nearby.
Teel Cemetery dates back to the late 1800s when Richard Teel and his family settled in the area.

data.title: Lance Rosier Unit Driving Tour

data.description: Welcome to San Juan Island! This is a great place to observe local marine mammals including the famous Southern Resident Killer Whales (SRKWs). This guide will assist those who are not familiar with the island in finding these marine mammals from shore. Remember that many locations on the island are private property. Do Not Trespass!! View a summary of the stops, resources, guidelines, and recommended equipment: https://tinyurl.com/46jan6hu

images.altText: an orca whale sticks their front half out of the grey water
images.caption: San Juan Island is one of the best places on Earth to view orca whales from land
images.title: Granny the Killer Whale

park.fullName: San Juan Island National Historical Park
park.name: San Juan Island

stops.significance:
If the killer whales are coming north, up the west side of the Island and past the Lime Kiln Lighthouse, the County Park is the next publicly available spot to view them. Some island kayak tours depart from Smallpox Bay in the County Park. The park has a good view north up to Mosquito Bay and west across the border to Canada

The space between the park and Low Island is very shallow and normally killer whales don’t cross between them.

If the killer whales are headed south, the next publicly available viewing area would be Lime Kiln Point State Park. If the killer whales are headed north, there isn’t a good viewing area available, unless they enter Mosquito Pass into Roche Harbor, which is rare.

Lime Kiln is the premier location for viewing killer whales when they are swimming out in Haro Strait on the Westside of San Juan Island. Among the park’s many amenities are designated wildlife viewing areas, an Interpretive Center, operated by Friends of Lime Kiln Society, and the historic lighthouse itself has been an active whale research lab for over 30 years! During peak season, volunteer docents are available to assist with viewing, sightings, information and questions. Parking Discover passes can be purchased on site, seasonally from the Interpretive Center, online, or in Friday Harbor at Ace Hardware or Kings Marine. The lighthouse also has a live streaming hydrophone and web cam that allows you to listen and watch for whales remotely!

Just south of Lime Kiln Point State Park on Westside Road are the three Land Bank parking areas.  You can view whales from the parking area or walk down the trail to watch for whales closer to the water. Killer whales will often pass very close to land here.  Watch out for sheer cliff edges.  Be careful not to trespass on private property; the land bank area is bordered by private land.

Just south of Lime Kiln Point State Park on Westside Road are the three Land Bank parking areas.  You can view whales from the parking area or walk down the trail to watch for whales closer to the water. Killer whales will often pass very close to land here.  Watch out for sheer cliff edges.  Be careful not to trespass on private property; the land bank area is bordered by private land.

Our park is an incredibly historic place, but its also an ideal place for whale watching. When the killer whales are passing the Salmon Banks on the West side of the island, they can be seen from South Beach[link] .  Normally killer whales stay in deeper water, so they don’t come up close to this beach.
When the killer whales are in Griffin Bay [link], they can be spotted by looking north from Redoubt Road [link].  With a good pair of binoculars, they can be seen as far as Turn Rock at the north end of Griffin Bay.  Be sure to keep an eye out for foxes and eagles while visiting the park.
There is more information at the American Camp Visitor’s Center during peak season.  Tread lightly on National Park grounds: stay on designated trails!

This is the southernmost tip of San Juan Island.  Transient killer whales (also called Bigg’s killer whales) are attracted to the seals and sea lions in this area which are their only source of food..
The proximity of Lopez Island makes this a very narrow pass.  If killer whales are in the area, chances are this will be a great viewing area, as you have a close view of the animals traveling through this narrow passage.  Look for harbor seals and sea birds on Goose Island, and Steller’s sea lions and bald eagles on the Whale Rocks.
This area consists of the Cattle Point Lighthouse Reservation [LINK] ) and the Cattle Point Interpretive Area (Washington State Parks).  Picnic tables and stairs down to the beach allow you to get closer to the marine landscape.  A large parking lot has free parking for 15 minutes at the interpretive area.  Limited shoulder parking is available at the lighthouse reservation.

If the killer whales are passing Griffin Bay, Jackson Beach Park has a good overall view of them.  Usually, killer whales stay closer to Lopez Island, so close encounters at Jackson Beach Park are rare.

This is the best viewing location for when the killer whales are passing the northeast side of San Juan Island through President’s Channel.  This park is primarily a kayak launch point and only offers a few parking spots for disabled drivers.  All other parking is at the top of the hill by the gated entrance, so you must walk down the steep hill.  Note that there is very limited turn around space at the bottom of the hill, so if you drive a large vehicle, it’s suggested that you don’t drive down.

data.description: Architect Henry Bacon modeled the Lincoln Memorial after the Parthenon in Athens, Greece. Bacon felt that a memorial dedicated to a man who defended democracy should echo the birthplace of democracy. See the points of interest at the Lincoln Memorial.

images.altText: Aerial view of the Lincoln Memorial
images.caption: Aerial view of the Lincoln Memorial
images.title: Lincoln Memorial

stops.significance: Though not completed in time for the memorial's dedication in 1922, the reflecting pool has become one of the most recognizable and filmed sites in Washington, DC. The reflecting pool and the long promenade of Elm Trees on either side are key features of the Lincoln Memorial landscape.

Above the colonnade inscribed on the attic frieze are the names of 36 states and the dates in which they entered the Union. A plaque was added in 1959 to commemorate the admission of Hawaii and Alaska.

This marker was added in 2003 to commemorate the 40th anniversary of the March on Washington. On this location in 1963, Martin Luther King gave his "I Have a Dream" speech. In the speech, he evoked the memory of Abraham Lincoln, the emancipation of the slaves, and the "shameful condition" of segregation in America 100 years after the American Civil War.
stops.assetName: Lincoln Memorial: I Have a Dream marker

stops.significance: Lying between the north and south chambers is the central hall containing the solitary figure of Lincoln sitting in contemplation. The statue was carved by the Piccirilli brothers under the supervision of the sculptor, Daniel Chester French, and took four years to complete.

Lincoln delivered the Gettysburg Address on November 19, 1863 during the dedication ceremony for the Soldiers' National Cemetery. This address was selected for its familiarity to many, but also because it displayed the president's strength and determination to see a successful conclusion to the American Civil War. That successful conclusion meant not just reuniting the nation, but finishing what our founders had started. This nation must be one in which all were “…created equal" was the rule of law and of practice.

Lincoln's March 4, 1865 Second Inaugural Address was selected for the north chamber of the memorial. This speech, delivered just one month before the conclusion of the Civil War, creates the policy for reuniting the divided states. The reelected president firmly believed that the northern states should welcome their southern sisters and brothers back into the Union with open arms.

data.description: This walking tour is an easy and approachable introduction to the historic structures of Mount Rainier National Park. At Mount Rainier, designers selected massive logs and glacial boulders as the building materials best suited for integrating new structures with their natural settings. Known as National Park Service Rustic architecture, this impressive architectural style contributes to the special sense-of-place quality which makes national parks a distinctive part of the American landscape.

images.altText: A two-story wood and stone building under a blanket of snow and surrounded by snowy forest.
images.caption: The historic Longmire Administration Building is an exemplary example of NPS rustic architecture.
images.title: Longmire Administration Building

stops.significance: There are three introduction exhibit panels to start the Longmire Historic District Walking Tour: one in front of the former service (gas) station, one next to the Longmire Museum, and one next to the parking lot behind the National Park Inn. The panels are identical, except for different "you are here" markers in the map as appropriate. This tour starts from the introduction exhibit panel in front of the service station but pick the location that works best for you. Longmire is open year-round, but the  panels are removed during the winter. However, you can still pick up a Longmire Historic District Walking Tour map at the Longmire Museum and view the buildings in winter.
stops.assetName: Longmire Historic Tour: Introduction Exhibit Panel

stops.significance: Built in 1911, this small building has served many uses over the decades.
stops.assetName: Longmire Historic Tour: General Store Exhibit Panel

stops.significance: While no longer in use, this service station still houses two historic red gas pumps.
stops.assetName: Longmire Historic Tour: Service Station Exhibit Panel

stops.assetName: Longmire Historic Tour: Museum Exhibit Panel

stops.significance: This building is arguably the most iconic building in Longmire and an excellent example of National Park Service Rustic Architecture.
stops.assetName: Longmire Historic Tour: Administration Building Exhibit Panel

stops.significance: This humble building is the oldest government-built structure in Longmire and still houses books and documents used by rangers researching the park today.
stops.assetName: Longmire Historic Tour: Library Exhibit Panel

stops.significance: The Nisqually Suspension Bridge connects Longmire to the east side of the Nisqually River and is still in use today.

stops.significance: The Longmire Community Building has one of the best views of Mount Rainier found in Longmire. From here, enjoy the walk back to the main Longmire area or take a moment to visit the Valor Memorial next to the Community Building.
stops.assetName: Longmire Historic Tour: Community Building Exhibit Panel

data.description: The homes along Bathtub Row were originally built for the staff of the Los Alamos Ranch School. When the Manhattan Project arrived in Los Alamos in 1943, school staff moved out and project staff moved into these homes. Bathtubs were considered a luxury in homes constructed for the Manhattan Project. One night at a party, Alice Kimball Smith referred to the occupants living on “Bathtub Row,” giving the homes their unique name. Take a walk down Bathtub Row to learn about these homes and the project scientist

images.altText: A car is in the driveway of an old house and a green street sign says, "Bathtub Row"
images.caption: Bathtub Row houses were aptly named as they had bathtubs instead of showers.
images.title: Bathtub Row

stops.significance: Bathtub Row was aptly named because houses that were constructed prior to World War II were equipped with bathtubs instead of showers. During the war iron used for lining the tubs was needed for the war effort. Bathtubs were considered a luxury in homes constructed for the Manhattan Project. One night at a party, Alice Kimball Smith referred to the occupants living on “Bathtub Row”, giving the homes their unique name.

During the Los Alamos Ranch School this building housed the electrical generator. After the establishment of the Manhattan Project, this building was converted to a home. George Kistiakowsky lived in the former power house as he worked on explosives at Project Y.

Hans Bethe and his wife Rose moved to the United States to avoid anti-Semitic persecution in Nazi Germany. While working at Cornell University, Bethe became known for his confidence and upbeat attitude. Oppenheimer wanted to recruit Hans Bethe to Los Alamos. The Bethe’s took up their Los Alamos residence in what is now the Hans Bethe House. Today, the Hans Bethe House is now part of the Los Alamos History Museum. Visitors are welcome to view exhibits in the home’s interior.

From 1943-1945 this house was home to Dr. J. Robert Oppenheimer, the Scientific Director of the Manhattan Project, and his family. Originally built in 1929, this house was used as home during the Los Alamos Ranch School. The home came equipped with a small sitting room, a kitchenette, and of course a bathtub! From the outside, the home’s most notable feature is a huge north window to let in the daylight.

data.title: Los Alamos: A Walk Down Bathtub Row

data.description: Explore the history of Los Alamos on this short walking tour and learn more about the different people who have called this area home.

images.altText: three girls and a boy smiling and holding hands stand on green grass.
images.caption: Junior Rangers explore, learn about, and protect their favorite parks.
images.title: Los Alamos Junior Rangers

stops.significance:
The human history of Los Alamos goes back thousands of years. The Ancestral Pueblo people lived here for about 400 years, from around 1150 to 1550 CE. These ancestors of today’s modern Pueblo people planted crops, hunted for meat and materials, and used volcanic tuff to build their homes. 

 

How is this similar or different to your home?  What sort of challenges or benefits did the Ancestral Pueblo people experience here?

Spanish explorers came to this area in the 1400s, and Hispanic settlers arrived in the 1600s and 700s. They grazed livestock on the high plateau in summer and moved to the lowlands in winter. Cash crops, like corn and beans, helped settlers earn a living. This one-room cabin, built by the Romero family, housed two parents and six children, who slept on the porch.  

 

Can you imagine what it would be like to live in a cabin like this? Where would you sleep or eat your meals?

The first students of the Los Alamos Ranch School—all boys—arrived in 1917. The school, started by Ashley Pond Jr., balanced studying with outdoor education. The students slept on screened porches and wore shorts all year long. They participated in Boy Scouts, went camping, and rode horses.    

 

When parents would visit their sons, they often stayed in this building, the guest cottage. Imagine your parents are visiting you at school here. What would you want to show them?  What activities or skills would you like to share?

The 1943 project that took over the school and ranch lands was called the Manhattan Project. It was also called Project Y, because the Manhattan Project referred to many sites across the country. The project brought together scientists and the US Military to design a new weapon to help win World War II. Robert Oppenheimer was the scientist in charge of Project Y. 

 

Everyone involved in Project Y had to keep their work a secret. They were designing and building a new kind of bomb, more powerful than any other weapon. It would use a nuclear chain reaction to release a huge amount of energy from atoms, the tiny building blocks of matter.  

 

Some of the scientists and military personnel stayed in this building during the project.  Do you think Fuller Lodge has always looked like it does today? Go inside to find exhibits and displays that talk more about the history of the building and see pictures of what it looked like during the Manhattan Project.

Ashley Pond is named after Ashley Pond! When homesteaders lived here, this small pond was a seasonal watering hole used by cattle. The Ranch School students would swam in the summer and ice-skated in the winter. The first buildings built for the Manhattan Project clustered around the pond. Today, those buildings are gone, but you can still walk in the footsteps of Manhattan Project scientists. As you explore the park. 

 

Project Y has many legacies. The development of modern Los Alamos is due to the project, and many residents still work for the Los Alamos National Laboratory, a direct descendent of Project Y’s scientific research.   

What would you like the legacy of your life to be? A legacy is a lasting memory or knowledge of an event.

Congratulations on finishing the Los Alamos Junior Ranger Tour! You learned about Ancestral Puebloan people, homesteaders, the Los Alamos Ranch School, the Manhattan Project, and Los Alamos today! What was your favorite stop? 

 

If you’re curious and want to learn more about the Manhattan Project, you can visit the park’s website at nps.gov/mapr.

data.title: Los Alamos: Junior Ranger Tour

data.description: Want to visit the historical buildings that were used in the making of the Oppenheimer movie? Then you have come to the right place! Filming of Oppenheimer took place in and around Los Alamos in 2022. Several Manhattan Project era buildings were utilized in the making of the movie including the Oppenheimer house. Check out the film locations on this tour in person, and see if you can recognize the locations when viewing the movie.

images.altText: A black and white portrait photo of a man in a black suit jacket and tie.
images.caption: A portrait of Robert J. Oppenheimer.
images.title: Oppenheimer Portrait

stops.significance: T-101, a civilian women’s dormitory, housed women civilians, or non-military staff who were working for the Manhattan Project. A lot of work was done to this building to make it into a movie set. Including covering some windows to control the lighting.

From 1943-1945 this house was home to Dr. J. Robert Oppenheimer, the Scientific Director of the Manhattan Project, and his family. An invitation to one of Oppenheimer’s dinner parties was one of the most coveted social invitations in wartime. On the set, several trees were added to surround the house where Robert J. Oppenheimer and his family lived.

During the Manhattan Project, the lodge provided meals and rooms for visiting scientists, and space for dances, plays, and other events. Fuller Lodge can be spotted in several scenes in the Oppenheimer movie, including the Christmas party and the award ceremony which took place on the large front porch.
Lamy Train Station was the first stop for most new arrivals and their families heading towards the secret city of Los Alamos.

data.title: Los Alamos: Oppenheimer Movie Manhattan Project Film Locations

data.description: Explore the sites in Los Alamos that played an important role in the town's Ranch School era, before the Manhattan Project came to town.

images.altText: Youths play ice hockey on a frozen pond.
images.caption: Ranch School students play ice hockey.
images.title: Ice Hockey on Ashley Pond

stops.significance: Sharing its name with the founder of the Los Alamos Ranch School, Ashley Pond makes a fitting start to the tour. Though it maintains a manicured appearance today, the pond served as a seasonal watering hole for cattle before the establishment of the Ranch School. Soon after Ashley Pond Jr. started his Los Alamos school, the community made the watering hold a central, year-round attraction. It became a year-round attraction due to the measures taken to supply the Ashley Pond with a continuous water supply. Students would swim in its waters in the summer and ice skate in the winter. The school grew up around the pond, and today you will still find historic school buildings nearby, including the next stop on our tour.

During the Ranch School days, this building served exactly the purpose you would imagine given its name. The ice house kept perishable goods cold throughout the year. The school sourced ice from the frozen waters of Ashley Pond in the winter. The main technical area of Project Y formed around the pond, encompassing the ice house in its growth. Today, a memorial made from the original materials of the house remain as the only reminders of this structure.

Constructed in 1917, Fuller Lodge served as the centerpiece for the Los Alamos Ranch School. Students ate meals here, and staff and guests used the quarters. The original building just included the central log structure. Workers later added three wings to expand the space.

Students and staff alike sought out this building when they had aches and ailments. The infirmary, built in 1918, served the school in this role for years. Eventually, it became a guest cottage for the school. It holds the distinction of being the oldest continually occupied structure in town! You can stop inside and explore museum’s exhibits to learn more about the town’s history before, during, and after the Los Alamos Ranch School.

Before this became the home to Manhattan Project scientists, it housed Los Alamos Ranch School faculty. As the first residence built for the school, the house earned the title “Master Cottage Number One." A. J. Connell, the school director, lived here for a brief period of time before teachers took up residence. After the house burnt down, Connell rebuilt it out of stone. Like Fuller Lodge, this building has expanded over the years with additions on either side of the main stone structure. Today, you can explore exhibits about the Cold War inside the house.

Like the Hans Bethe House, this building served as a Ranch School residence before housing scientists. Built for May Connell, sister of the ranch school director, this stone building has impressive windows that let in the New Mexico light. May, a New Yorker, adamantly rejected the idea of living in a log cabin when she moved to Los Alamos. This house certainly met her standards.

Perhaps the smallest structure on the tour, this building nonetheless played a crucial role during the Ranch School’s time. Known as the Power House, it housed the electrical generator that supplied energy for the school.

data.title: Los Alamos: Ranch School Days

data.description: The city of Los Alamos was constructed on land that has a long history of human use. Follow along this tour to learn some of the history of the Ancestral Pueblo people that have always called this land home and discover untold stories and connections to the Manhattan Project. This tour is best completed as you travel from Santa Fe to Los Alamos and has locations within two National Park Service sites. An America the Beautiful Pass or park-specific passes are needed to explore all stops on this route.

images.altText: A black and white image of a Pueblo woman holding a baby in front of an older white couple.
images.caption: Scientist Enrico Fermi talks with well-known San Ildefonso artist Maria Martinez.
images.title: Pueblos and Sceintists

stops.significance: Edith Warner and her Pueblo companion, Tilano, opened a tea house near the Otowi Bridge. Many scientists and staff often came to enjoy a meal followed by Warner’s famous chocolate cake. Edith Warner’s home at Otowi Bridge, became an icon for those first making the trip from Lamy Train Station to Los Alamos. Today, the bridge and surrounding area are part of the Otowi Historical District.

Tsankawi is the ancestral home of the modern pueblo of San Ildefonso. Using the soft volcanic rock to construct houses and the flat open lands between mesas for farming, Ancestral Pueblo people called this place home in the 1400’s and 1500’s. Life was not easy on these arid mesas. The people became experts in the art of dry farming, hunted the available wildlife, and collected any bounty nature provided.

Bandelier National Monument protects over 33,000 acres of rugged but beautiful canyon and mesa country as well as evidence of a human presence here going back over 11,000 years.  Petroglyphs, dwellings carved into the soft rock cliffs, and standing masonry walls pay tribute to the early days of a culture that still survives in the surrounding communities.

The human history of Los Alamos goes back thousands of years. The Ancestral Pueblo people lived here for about 400 years, from around 1150 to 1550 CE. These ancestors of today’s modern Pueblo people planted crops, hunted for meat and materials, and used volcanic tuff to build their homes. 

How is this similar or different to your home?  What sort of challenges or benefits did the Ancestral Pueblo people experience here?

Want to learn more about the connections between the Manhattan Project and the local Pueblo people? Stop into the Manhattan Project National Historical Park Visitor Center and ask about Floy Agnes Lee or Maria Martinez and the legacy they left. If the visitor center is closed the park website features many of the untold stories of the Manhattan Project.

data.title: Los Alamos: The Land of the Pueblo People

data.description: The Lost Mine Trail rises 1,100 feet over 2.4 miles (4.8 miles roundtrip) and takes about three hours to complete, so be sure to bring plenty of water and snacks. If your time and energy are limited, consider hiking only the first mile to a scenic overlook near Stop #10. From the very first step, the Lost Mine Trail leads hikers into a different world, a woodland-grassland ecosystem with great scenic views. Follow this guide to learn more about the plants and animals of the Chisos Mountains.

data.description: This self-guided tour combines driving and walking, and calls out the main sites to see throughout the Missouri National Recreational River. This tour can be completed year round and the destinations are worthwhile throughout the seasons. Duration will vary depending on time spent throughout each stop.

images.altText: Missouri River with blue water and blue sky with sparse clouds. Green covered landform in foreground
images.caption: Missouri River Near Fort Randall Dam
images.title: Missouri River Near Fort Randall Dam

stops.significance: Here at the visitor contact station in MNRR's headquarters building you can grab a few brochures and information about the park. A ranger will be present if you have any questions or would like any recommendations.
This capitol replica symbolizes Yankton as being the first capitol of the Dakota Territory from 1861-1883.

The Meridian Bridge is notable as the first permanent river crossing in the Yankton vicinity and as one of the final links in the Meridian Highway, an early north-south route from Winnipeg, Canada, to Mexico City, Mexico.

A dramatic view of the Missouri National Recreational River awaits visitors at Mulberry Bend Overlook. From the parking area, a short paved trail leads to two overlooks that offer views of a free flowing segment of the Missouri. This portion of the river exhibits characteristics that were common hundreds of years ago but are no longer seen on the "man-made" portions of the river.

Visit the Nebraska state park and check out views of South Dakota, Nebraska, and Iowa from the scenic overlooks while looking down at the exact point where the Wild and Scenic Missouri River begins. Make sure to visit the Missouri National Recreational River Resource and Education Center in the park to learn more about the Missouri National Recreational River through exhibits. This park also has connections to the Lewis and Clark National Historic Trail.
stops.assetName: Missouri National Recreational River Resource and Education Center

stops.significance: Looking for open space, rolling grasslands, and scenic views of the Missouri River? Located in the 39-Mile District, Niobrara State Park offers peaceful camping and hiking opportunities. This state park also has connections to the Lewis and Clark National Historic Trail.
Located on the banks of the Missouri River downstream from Fort Randall Dam, the recreation area offers a wide view of the Missouri River with great boating and kayaking opportunities.

data.title: MNRR Highlights: Explore the 39-Mile District and 59-Mile District

data.description: The Main Park Road is a great way to see many of the park's features. Whether you have a couple of hours or a couple of days, the stops along the road highlight the habitats and biodiversity for which the park is famous. The 38 mile (61 km) road begins at the Ernest Coe Visitor Center in Homestead and dead-ends at Flamingo. Because of this, please be mindful of your time constraints and consider visiting some of the spots on your way back out of the park.

images.altText: A paved, double striped road travels into the distance under a cloudy, blue and purple sunset sky
images.caption: Main Park road stretches 38 miles from the heart of the Everglades to its shoreline
images.title: Main Park Road Sunset

stops.significance: The Ernest F Coe visitor center is a good place to stop and get oriented to the park. Rangers and staff are available for questions, information and trip planning. There is a museum featuring some interpretive displays, as well as a bookstore selling gift items.
The Royal Palm visitor area has access to two of the most popular and accessible trails in the Everglades, the Anhinga Trail and the Gumbo-Limbo Trail.  A place vary popular for wildlife viewing

The Pine Rockland habitat is what most of early Miami and south Florida was built upon, leaving the largest stand of Pine Rockland habitat remaining in Everglades national park.  The pine rockland’s fire ecology provides the habitat with rich plant biodiversity.
Pa-Hay-Okee overlook gives visitors and elevated perspective of this vast wetland and prime views of the river of grass.
The .5 mile boardwalk trail winds through a large old-growth hardwood hammock.  Recent hurricanes have opened up the high canopy to allow for new growth
Guy Bradley trail links the Visitor Center Parking lot to the amphitheater. It hugs the mangrove shore line and provides wonderful views of Florida Bay. It is 1 mile one way
The Flaming Visitor Center, Marina and boat basin is a great and easy way to look for big wildlife.  Ask a ranger about wildlife and conditions and keep a look out for manatees and crocodiles

stops.significance: A show of wealth and status for the Ridgelys, an orangery allowed them to grow citrus fruits year round.
An additional sign of wealth was the Ridgely's ability to have ice year round.
The centerpiece of Hampton NHS, the Hampton mansion was the holiday home of the Ridgely's, the working place for many enslaved, and the architectural prominence that allowed Hampton to be preserved.
The falling gardens attract many to the site, with historic trees and maintained garden beds, the sites can be hard to imagine how much work went into creating the gardens.
These structures were used by service staff to help maintain the house.
The final resting place for Ridgely family members and two others...
The Ridgelys had a passion for horse racing, and their division among labor for the enslaved people working the stables reflected that.

data.description: On the morning of 21 July 1861, the Battle of First Manassas (Bull Run) began here on Matthews Hill. This 1-mile loop trail traverses the scene of the morning clash, moving along the opposing lines of battle.

images.altText: View towards Matthews Hill from Henry Hill
images.caption: View from Henry Hill looking towards the distant Matthews Hill
images.title: View toward Matthews Hill from Henry Hil

stops.significance:
At around 10am on the morning of 21 July 1861, the head of General Irvin McDowell's 15,000 man flanking column reached this position.  Upon emerging out of the woods, the Union vanguard collided with Confederate skirmishers atop Matthews Hill ahead. Both sides exchanged brief volleys of musket fire. These skirmishers belonged Nathan Evans' Confederate brigade, which had moved from their original location near the Stone Bridge to the Matthews Hill vicinity to contest this large federal column.  

 Soldiers of the 2nd Rhode Island Infantry deployed and started across the field toward the crest of the hill. For General McDowell, his chance at surprise was gone.  The battle was on.

As the Confederate skirmishers withdrew up the hill, the Rhode Islanders gave chance, moving through the ground you are standing on, into the low ground immediately to your front.  One Rhode Islanders recalled this first few moments of the battle: "“the sensation caused by the first shower of bullets around one’s head is very strange.” 

Soon, Union artillery arrived from Rhode Islands and two boat howitzers, pulled here by soldiers from the 71st New York State Militia.  

Soon, General Barnard Bee's and Francis Bartow's Confederate brigades arrived on Henry Hill and were immediately thrown into the maelstrom, bringing the amount of Confederates engaged to nearly 3,000 men.  

To counter this, General David Hunter, commanding the lead Federal division, moved the balance of his command on both sides of the Sudley Road.  Faced with overwhelming numbers, fatigue and low ammunition, the Confederates were forced to flee from the hill towards the safety of Henry Hill and fresh reinforcements.

You are now located at the site of the monument dedicated to 8th Georgia soldier George W. Stovall.  In 1861, the area around you was open, with two small pine thickets to the south and east.  This ground saw some of the most severe fighting on Matthews Hill. 

Stovall and the 8th Georgia arrived on Henry Hill during the fighting on Matthew’s Hill and were soon sent up to reinforce the fight.  As the 8th Georgia moved towards this position, they were struck by Federals on nearly three sides and almost surrounded.  In this chaotic fighting, nearly 200 men from the regiment became casualties, including Stovall. 

The 8th Georgia became the first Confederate unit to retreat from the hill.  During their retreat south, down the slope of the hill, they soon came under fire from Alabamians, mistaking them for advancing Federal troops.  Faced with mounting pressure from the front and flank, the remainder of the Confederate line began to collapse.  For Irvin McDowell, victory seemed imminent.

This comfort station was once a park police sub-station and was used as a shelter point for officers. Begin your tour by learning about some of the history of Meridian Hill from the wayside panels nearby.
Meridian Hill Park was not always parkland. Learn about the site and what used to be here before it was a park.

stops.significance: Modern apartment buildings surround the park now, but in the early days of Washington City, it was the site of single family homes and manor houses. Learn about two men who made their home in the Meridian Hill neighborhood.

stops.significance: The sculpture was erected as a gift to the American people from Charles Deering in memory of William Henry Scheutze. William Henry Scheutze (1853-1902), a naval officer who graduated from the U.S. Naval Academy in 1873, went on to serve as navigator on the U.S.S. Iowa during the Spanish American War and was active in the U.S. Naval White Squadron in Chicago. The gift was accepted under an Act of Congress (43 Stat. 21) on March 12, 1924.
There are a lot of sculptures in Meridian Hill Park. Learn the reason for the concentration of installations in the park and their significance from this informational panel.

stops.significance: A gift from the women of France to the women of America, the Joan of Arc Statue is the only equestrian statue of a woman in Washington, DC.
The statue was a gift from Carlo Barsotti of New York on behalf of Italian-born Americans. An Act of Congress approved February 14, 1922 (42 Stat. 366) authorized its erection on public grounds.

The Cascading Fountain is the longest fountain of its kind in North America.

The fountain is currently off and awaiting repairs.
Why is this place called "Meridian Hill?" Learn about the orientation of the City of Washington and the reason for the name of this park from this informational panel.

data.description: Learn about the annual migration of anadromous fish and how they navigate Rock Creek.

images.altText: A small fish with silver color scales that iridesce.
images.caption: Blueback Herring
images.title: Blueback Herring

stops.significance:
Rock Creek is a major thoroughfare for Blueback herring, Shad and Alewife. These anadromous fish live in salt water but spawn in fresh water. 

Fish that live in the Chesapeake Bay swim upstream, but obstacles can prevent them from successfully navigating to their ancestral spawning grounds. 

What barriers can you see that would prevent the fish from moving upstream?

Can you see any herring swimming in the shallows below you?

The dam was built after the main drive shaft in the mill had broken and the structure was no longer being used as a mill. The building was being renovated and was going to be opened as a teahouse. An enclosed porch was built where the tailrace and water wheel is currently located. The dam provided ambiance to park visitors who visited the site, but it prevented the fish from navigating further upstream.

*Do not walk out onto the dam. It is an historic structure as well as being unsafe to play or walk on.
What do you notice about the creek? What other obstacles might make the journey difficult for an anadromous fish?

data.title: Migration on Rock Creek

data.description: This 1.75 mile hike takes park visitors to some of the historically significant sections of the park.

images.altText: A black and white image of a car driving through a ford in a creek
images.caption: Wagons and automobiles used to cross Rock Creek using Fords like the one still visible in Rock Creek
images.title: Historic Milkhouse Ford

stops.significance: Picnic Grove #6 provides ample parking to access the beginning of this 1.75 mile hike through Rock Creek Park.

Joaquin Miller was a poet in the late 1800s. He came to Washington, DC and built this small cabin along 16th Street NW, near present day Meridian Hill Park. The cabin was relocated to Rock Creek Park during construction of Meridian Hill Park after Californians found out it was in danger of being torn down. Miller never lived in this cabin in Rock Creek Park.

Miller's niece ran a concessions business from the site in the 1900s and taught people to paint. In the late 1900s the Joaquin Miller poetry series began at the site.

Milkhouse Ford has existed for hundreds of years. A naturally occurring low place in the creek, the spot allowed farmers with wagons to traverse Rock Creek. Milkhouse Ford Road twists through Northwest Washington, DC and would have run to this spot.

Follow the rough path of the old Milkhouse Ford Road. 

Use your senses--What can you hear? What do you smell? What can you see?

Among the first park facilities was Camp Good Will, a summer camp for underprivileged white children accompanied by their mothers. Begun in 1904 by the Committee on the Prevention of Consumption, a local charity, it was sited between Milk House Ford and 16th Street. The construction of the golf course in the 1920s forced the camp to move to a spot near this site in 1923.

Washington architect Arthur B. Heaton contributed building designs and landscape architect John H. Small laid out the grounds for the new camp, now operated by the Summer Outings Committee of the Associated Charities. Civic clubs were solicited for construction funds, and an administration building, dining hall, nursery, two pavillions, two bathhouses, three dozen tent platforms, a pool, and ball fields were built. As it had previously, the camp served 150 mothers and children for two-week periods, with the attendees staying in tents.
stops.assetName: trailhead: cross trail #5 & Western Ridge Trail

stops.significance: How does your current location differ from your experience in the woods?  Military Road lies ahead of you through the trees and traffic noise is loud. Military Road was built in the 1860s to help connect to the forts that defended the city of Washington.
stops.assetName: Trailhead: Fort DeRussy Trail and White Horse Trail

stops.significance:
Fort DeRussy was an enclosed earthen fort built in 1861 to help defend the city of Washington during the American Civil War. The fort was actively engaged in battle during the 1864 assault on Fort Stevens. Large cannon (rodman guns) threw projectile across Rock Creek to help the other fort. Union soldiers successfully fended off the advancing confederate army.

NOTE:  Do not climb on the earthworks or enter the fortifications.

stops.assetName: Trailhead: Black Horse Trail junction with White Horse Trail

stops.significance:
Take a look at Milkhouse Ford from this side of the creek. Imagine being able to drive through the creek.  What problems do you think this would cause, if any?

Automobiles were able to drive through Rock Creek up through the mid 1990s. Sewer lines, fords and other obstructions had prevented anadromous fish from reaching their traditional spawning grounds. Chemicals and fluids leaked from cars and contributed to downstream water pollution. The concrete road bed was angled/lowered to allow fish like the alewife and herring to advance upstream. 

The old road is still visible where it was accessed from Beach Drive.
stops.assetName: Trailhead: Black Horse Trail at Milkhouse Ford

See the entire park or just visit the monuments you are most interested in. You can drive near most of the monuments but will need to park and leave your vehicle to reach each stop.

data.title: Monuments Tour

data.description: This tour highlights out-of-the-way sights that many visitors miss on their first visit. In particular, this tour explores the various ways people have commemorated the history of the park, and what has survived over the years, and what has gone missing. The park is made of four different units, and you'll visit all of them by the time we finish. Access to an automobile is highly recommended.

images.altText: A park bench faces away over a cleared hillside looking toward a horizon covered by trees.
images.caption: This view can be found on the Blue Trail in Jockey Hollow.
images.title: View From Stark's Brigade

stops.significance: The museum is a magnet for our visitors. It houses a collection of artifacts, the auditorium, the park film, and the Discover History Center. It is also where tours of the nearby Ford Mansion, Washington's Headquarters begin. If you haven't visited it already, it is highly likely you'll do so during the course of your visit to Morristown NHP. That's why the tour begins here.

Morristown was seen in passing by the French army as they marched south to besiege the British army in Yorktown, VA. This is the same French army that Washington heard of from Lafayette while encamped in Morristown at the nearby Ford Mansion during the Hard Winter in 1780. The alliance with the French helped win American independence from Britain. While the French did not camp in Morristown, the sight of a large foreign allied army parading through town would have drawn the attention of everyone in the community.

Washington's personal guards made their huts here. These several hundred men protected the Commander-in-Chief, his headquarters, and his papers. Though their huts no longer remain, the marker also helps tell the story of the National Historical Park's history as well as that of the men who once lived here.

This statue was donated to Morristown by Miss Ellen Mabel Clark to commemorate Washington's association with the community. This action predates the designation of Morristown's National Historical Park, and may have contributed to the public interest in the park's creation. The statue was, and still is, outside the boundaries of the park - but rests within easy view of the front steps of the Ford Mansion.

This stone marker was placed here by the Washington Association. Their interest extends beyond the Ford Mansion and Washington's Headquarters; they also helped preserve Fort Nonsense, Jockey Hollow, and other important historical sites in Morristown, well before the Park Service came onto the scene.

This site is a likely location for a signal beacon that would have been built and maintained by the small garrison of Continental Army soldiers on this hilltop. The height of the hill makes it ideal to overlook the town below, defend against attackers, and offers sightlines to other beacons nearby and surrounding communities.

This house was owned by Joshua Guerin, neighbor to the Wick and Kemble families. Together these three families owned the bulk of the Jockey Hollow park today. It is most likely that Jockey Hollow's name originated with the Guerin family's love of fox hunting and the horsemanship that went along with that pastime. The name persisted long after the hunts ended. While the home is one of the structures in the park that date back to the founding of the United States, it is a private residence, and not open to the public.

The simple marker on the hillside here speaks to the former presence of a Continental Army brigade - four regiments, nearly one thousand men - encamped in huts built by the men from trees felled as the snow started to accumulate. The lonely hillside was selected as a camp site with purpose, to help preserve the health of the men and give them ample supplies of timber to build with and burn for fuel.

The site also offers a good view of the valley below which is enjoyable for its own sake.

The Revolutionary War has its fair share of markers and monuments, though Jockey Hollow has seen a number of different uses over the years. Apart from farm fields and soldier encampments, the fresh water sources attracted the attention of the Morris Aqueduct Company in the 19th century. Ruins of the work can be seen in the park today along the Green Trail, and an interpretive brochure can be acquired at the Trail Center, Visitor Center, or online to help explain the significance of the trail's sights.

While waterworks and earthworks, AKA fortifications, are not usually discussed in tandem, they do have one thing in common. Their presence helps provide for the safety, security, and well-being of the local inhabitants. A town without drinking water does not remain inhabited for long.

The Pennsylvania Line mutinied against their officers in January of 1781. During the initial outbreak of hostility, the men killed one of their captains. The story holds that he was buried under a black oak nearby. A hasty grave dug for a man doing his duty turned into one of the earliest attempts to memorialize the events of the Revolutionary War in this part of the country.

This water tower's ingenious design and intriguing structure catch the eyes of many visitors to the park. Even though it has nothing to do with the Revolutionary War, its presence in the park today allows us to examine and appreciate how and why things are preserved for future generations to enjoy.

Feel free to explore the rest of the Cross Estate as well. The house nearby is inaccessible to visitors, but the grounds are open to explore, including the gardens to the side and at the rear of the house.

This site shows what the soldiers' huts look like today, after over two hundred years of exposure to the elements. Monuments and markers are erected in part because of their durability compared to the genuine article.

data.title: Monuments, Markers, and Memory

data.description: Follow the Morning Attack Trails to places where soldiers fought during the early hours of the Battle of Cedar Creek on October 19, 1864. The three trails combined are 1.5 miles long. All three are on national park land. Pick up a free trail guide at the trail entrances or at the Visitor Center. The guide follows stops marked on the trails.

images.altText: A mountain looms behind a grass field with mowed trails and a belt of trees.
images.caption: The Morning Attack Trails are mowed grass through fields
images.title: Morning Attack Trails

park.fullName: Cedar Creek & Belle Grove National Historical Park
park.name: Cedar Creek & Belle Grove

stops.significance: The Morning Attack Trails are three connected trails through a battleground, part of a surprise Confederate attack on the morning of October 19, 1864, during the Battle of Cedar Creek. Lt. Gen. Jubal Early’s Army of the Valley swarmed into the Federal camps along the bluffs above Cedar Creek. Despite heroic efforts by the Federal defenders, the Confederate assault drove the entire US Army of the Shenandoah out of their camps and north of Middletown.

From his camp west of the Valley Turnpike, US Gen. William Emory heard the pre-dawn surprise attack on the unsuspecting and vulnerable left flank of the US Army of the Shenandoah. In order to give the rest of the US troops time to respond, Emory ordered Col. Stephen Thomas’s brigade towards the fighting. They moved across the Valley Turnpike and through this ravine to the ridge above, pushing through retreating soldiers and hoping to stop the Confederate advance. The trail follows the route Thomas’s brigade took through the ravine.

Coming out of the ravine and through the wood line, Thomas’s brigade faced Confederates from Maj. Gen. John B. Gordon’s division. To their left, other Federal troops were retreating. Thomas’s brigade was now on their own against a much larger force. One eyewitness wrote, “Men seemed more like demons than human beings, as they struck fiercely at each other with clubbed musket and bayonet.” Finally, the 8th Vermont retreated, after desperate hand-to-hand fighting that bought time for other US troops to regroup west of the Valley Pike. Twenty years after the war ended, veterans erected a monument where the 8th Vermont made its sacrificial stand.

To the right of the 8th Vermont were the 160th New York, 12th Connecticut, and 47th Pennsylvania. They found themselves under heavy fire. One by one, these regiments fell to the Confederates. The 8th Vermont retreated last. A Confederate who chased them into the ravine wrote, “we found the whole force we’d been fighting down at the bottom of it to escape our fire. Poor fellows! It looked like murder to kill them huddled up there where they could not defend themselves and while we had nothing to do but load and shoot.” Half of Thomas’s brigade suffered casualties, with over 500 of them killed, wounded, or captured that day.

Confederate soldiers led by Maj. Gen. John B. Gordon advanced across the field from the south and east. They included veterans of the famous “Stonewall Brigade,” many of whom were from the Shenandoah Valley. They had been awake for most of the night, enduring a long night march while crossing freezing cold rivers. After a series of recent defeats, this day offered hope for victory. They had several advantages, including surprise. The rolling terrain to the east, combined with the heavy fog that morning, made it difficult to see them. They caught some US soldiers still asleep in their tents, but those that were awake and in line of battle offered tough resistance. The Stonewall Brigade fought Thomas’s brigade in this field and, after meeting stiff resistance from the 8th Vermont, forced them to retreat across the Valley Pike.

In early October, troops of the 8th Corps under future president Col. Rutherford B. Hayes camped along this ridge and to the east, where Interstates 66 and 81 now meet. Others under Col. J. Howard Kitching arrived in camp on October 17. While the army often woke up early and scouted for the enemy, much of their time was spent lounging in camp and reading mail from home. 1864 was a presidential election year. Abraham Lincoln was running for reelection against George McClellan, who ran on a peace platform. Hayes was also running for a seat in Congress. On October 11, these fields buzzed with activity as Ohio soldiers came to cast their votes. The Civil War was the first time that soldiers in the field could cast absentee ballots. These soldiers’ votes and their victory at Cedar Creek just a week later helped strengthen Lincoln win reelection in November.

With their camps overrun, Hayes’s and Kitching’s Federals withdrew toward this ridge to fight back against Gen. Stephen D. Ramseur’s advancing Alabamians, Georgians, and North Carolinians. One soldier under Ramseur’s command wrote “we descended like a wolf on the fold and aroused them by "Rebel yells" and peals of musketry, and they hastily fled.” By the time Thomas’s brigade emerged from the ravine, US troops here were retreating north toward Middletown or west across the Valley Turnpike towards Belle Grove. Hungry, cold, and wet after their pre-dawn march, many worn-out Confederate soldiers stopped to loot abandoned Federal campsites. One Virginian wrote “Some of the men stopped, secured well-filled haversacks… the temptation to stop and eat was too great.” From these fields the Confederates chased the US troops to Belle Grove and then north of Middletown. The Confederate assault stopped at Middletown, perhaps due to exhaustion or soldiers leaving their ranks to plunder the Federal camps.

data.title: Morning Attack Trails

data.description: To celebrate National Moth Week, join us on this accessible self-guided tour down the Interdune Boardwalk.

images.altText: Light yellow moth with dark markings on white background
images.caption: A pale yellow moth known as Eucosma metzleri, a moth named after the park’s moth researcher
images.title: Eucosma metzleri

stops.significance: Where do you thrive?  Moths thrive at White Sands National Park.  An endemic species lives no other place on earth; these white gypsum dunes are home to more endemic species of moths than any other single location in North America.
stops.assetName: Moth Tour - Why are Moths Important?

stops.significance: Grab a pair of binoculars and look for the unique white species of animals that thrive in the dunes. During the first two weeks of June, you may be lucky enough to see tiny white moths scurrying about on the sand next to the boardwalk.  Areniscythris whitesands is a very small, mosquito-sized moth endemic to the dunes. Unlike most moths, A. whitesands is active in the morning!

data.description: This waterfall guide provides an overview of Mount Rainier's waterfalls that can be viewed from park roads or trails.

images.altText: 168 foot waterfall with rainbow
images.caption: Narada Falls
images.title: Narada Falls

stops.significance: Chenuis Falls is a series of cascades over smooth bedrock ending in a beautiful pool.
Ipsut Falls is a two-tiered waterfall located near Ipsut Creek Campground.
Ranger Falls is a dramatic 3-segmented waterfall in the Carbon River area.
Spray Creek drops 354 feet over a lava cliff in a magnificent, veil-like waterfall.
Deer Creek cascades over 60 feet into a scenic gorge.
This small waterfall has a series of cascades, with the tallest dropping 30 feet over mossy bedrock.
The Ohanapecosh River drops nearly 70 feet in this 2-tiered waterfall with double plunge pools.
The powerful force of the Ohanapecosh River makes this one of the park’s most impressive waterfalls.
Named for an early park ranger, William Stafford, this waterfall drops about 30 feet into a clear plunge pool.
This 3-tiered cascade drops nearly 600 feet over a headwall of Stevens Canyon.
These falls were named for Martha Longmire by one of her sons while he was working on the Wonderland Trail in Stevens Canyon.
Located where Stevens Creek takes a sharp bend, Sylvia Falls is a single drop, fan-shaped falls with a height of 43 feet.
This popular waterfall is named in honor of Harry Carter, builder of much of the trail between Longmire and Paradise.
Located upstream of Carter Falls, this short waterfall cascades down about 34 feet.
Christine Falls is a 60-foot plunging waterfall framed by a historic arched bridge.
This tall waterfall is one of the park’s most spectacular, with the highest drop falling over 300 feet.
Also known as Bloucher Falls, Van Trump Falls is located just before Comet Falls along the Comet Falls Trail.
Visible from Paradise Valley Road, this waterfall cascades through the narrow Edith Gorge in several cascades.
This popular 60-foot waterfall has a braided cascade with Mount Rainier towering in the background.
The Paradise River plunges 168 feet over an andesite lava flow to the valley floor. On a sunny day, a colorful rainbow may add a bit of magic to the falls.
Visible from the Skyline Trail, this veil-like cascade was named for Sluiskin, the Yakama Indian who guided Mount Rainier’s first summit climbers.
This impressive waterfall emerges from the Wilson Glacier before falling over 300 feet into the lower portion of the Nisqually Glacier.
Hike or bike the Westside Road to this 140 foot waterfall along St. Andrews Creek.
