data.description: This self-guided interpretive tour takes you on a sensory experience of the Dune Life Nature trail.

images.altText: Aerial photo of white dunes meeting brown desert with a parking lot in the bottom right corner.
images.caption: The dunefield stretches for miles and miles, but it has to end somewhere!
images.title: Aerial Shot of Dune Life Trailhead

stops.significance: Welcome to White Sands National Park’s Dune Life Nature Trail! You are looking at the oldest dunes in the park. This is the scene for our mystery – how does anything survive out here? We’ll be following along with Katie the Kit Fox and the blue trail markers to immerse our senses into the dunefield and what makes it, and the plants and animals, so unique. Let’s solve a mystery!

Grab a handful of sand and let it run through your fingers. Now dig down a few inches, does the feeling of the sand change? The dunes are full of water. When it rains, the dunes hold onto the fresh water and store it for the plants to use. The relationship between gypsum sand and water creates the foundation for life to adapt to an otherwise harsh environment.
Touch was the first of our senses, but what’s next? Let’s move to the next stop and engage a primary sense the animals use: smell.

To fully appreciate your surroundings, close your eyes and focus on what you can smell. Does the dunefield have a distinct smell? What about the plants? Look to your left; this plant is a Hoary rosemary mint bush. Gently, without pulling them off, press some of the small leaves between your fingers. Smell your fingers. This sometimes minty, sometimes rosemary smelling plant is an important source of food for the pollinators that live in the dunes.
Now that we’ve taken in the scents of the dunefield, let’s move to our next stop and find out a little bit about the sounds that you could hear!

Close your eyes again. Listen. Identify two sounds you can hear – are they natural?  Are you hearing the wind? The cottonwood leaves? A distant thunderstorm? Now listen to some sounds that you might hear at night. How are they different?  Lots of the animals come out at night to hunt and avoid the searing mid-day heat.
With sound, we may not see what we can hear. Let’s move to the next stop to take in the sights of the dunefield.

Take in your surroundings; what do you see? 

In the distance, two mountain ranges stand tall, surrounding this basin. The dunes meet the Chihuahuan Desert, and plants spring up between the dunes. The many environments of the park - the dunes, the desert, the playas, and between the dunes - all coexist and support the plants and animals of the park. Like an island in a ocean, the dunefield is an isolated environment; many of the species that live here can only live here!

With all your senses engaged, let’s go find out if we’ve solved the mystery!
stops.assetName: Eye Spy with My Little Eye

stops.significance:
Now that we’ve explored the dunefield with our senses, how do you think the plants and animals survive? Animals and plants have used adaptations for thousands of years to find a home in this unique place.
	You may have noticed we still have one sense to go – taste! This one is super important; pull out your water bottle and take a big drink. Your adaptation for survival out here is your body’s ability to sweat and cool down. If you don’t hydrate, your body can’t cool itself down.
	Thank you for coming along with us to solve the dunefield mystery! Enjoy the rest of your trip and stay safe!

data.title: Mystery of the Dunes

data.description: This walking route starts at the Smithsonian Metro and takes you on an efficient walking route through all the major memorials on the National Mall.

images.altText: The Washington Monument at night reflected in the still water of the Reflecting Pool.
images.caption: The Washington Monument, World War II Memorial, and Lincoln Memorial Reflecting Pool.
images.credit: Carol M. Highsmith's America, Library of Congress, Prints and Photographs Division.
images.title: Washington Monument and Reflecting Pool

stops.significance: The Washington Monument Lodge is your one-stop shop for national parks passport stamps. Tickets for the Washington Monument are given out at the window in the rear of the building on a first-come, first-served basis. You may want to inquire about tickets later in the day and return to the monument at your assigned time. However, the tour inside the Washington Monument can be a time-consuming venture and it is not accounted for in this 2-4 hour tour of the landmarks.

Completed in 1884, the Washington Monument was the tallest building in the world at the time, a dizzying 555 feet, 5-1/8 inches. The monument was built to honor the first president of the United States, George Washington, for whom the city is also named. Looking up, you can see the windows on the observation deck, 500' in the sky.

The World War II memorial honors the service and sacrifice of Americans on the homefront and the warfront. Columns represent each of the U.S. states and territories at the time of the war, and a wall of stars represents the servicemembers who gave their lives in the conflict. Additional features include bas reliefs of different scenes from the war, quotes from notable figures, and two "victory pavilions" with bronze sculptures of eagles laying a laurel wreath above the Victory Medal. Visit the nearby information kiosk to access the WWII memorial database of servicemembers.
Where Constitution Ave., a busy thoroughfare now runs, there was once a canal that provided access into the city from the Potomac River. The house is now an information station for park visitors.

stops.assetName: 56 Signers of the Declaration of Independence Memorial

data.title: National Mall Half-Day Tour

data.description: For thousands of years, Native peoples have lived, raised families, and created culture in the Cuyahoga Valley. This flat, unpaved walk is a little over two miles out and back on the Towpath Trail. It explores the remnants these peoples left on the land. Be aware: at times, nearby Canal Road can be noisy.

images.altText: A sepia drawing of a prehistoric village of 7 loaf shaped buildings, surrounded by a circular fence.
images.caption: An illustration of South Park, a Whittlesey village near Stone Road.
images.title: South Park Village Illustration

stops.significance: Do you know who was here before you? What peoples walked this land before we did? How do we know about them? Take a walk north on the Towpath Trail to explore the lives of Indigenous peoples who were here for thousands of years. Watch for the Cuyahoga River to the west (left). Along the way, consider what has changed over many generations. What sounds would Native Americans have heard? What would the land look like? How has it changed? What will future generations know about us from what we leave behind?

The Cuyahoga River was a vital lifeline for Native Americans. It provided both food and transportation. What do you think might have been for dinner if you lived along the river 500 years ago? Imagine paddling this river in a wooden dugout canoe to seek beaver for trade. How do we know what Native Americans ate? Like us today, they left trash behind. What would your dinner trash reveal about you?

During the 1600s and 1700s, Native Americans found themselves pushed westward as Europeans crowded the eastern seaboard. At these western edges, conflict was ongoing. Native Americans found themselves pawns in a war an ocean away in Europe, but the struggle was also in their villages. Tribes and communities often fought or fled together. Learn about one such group, fleeing the violence of massacre, who rested here for almost a year. Owing to changes in the river and land, archeologists are unsure exactly where their village was. What would make you leave your home?

Past peoples lived at the South Park site for hundreds of years, building big villages and farming complexes. Sometimes they occupied, left, and re-occupied areas. We don’t know what these people called themselves, so we have given them a name. What these peoples left behind gives us a foggy peek into their lives. Check out both the Ohio Historical Marker and the park wayside exhibit. What do you think these peoples’ lives were like?

After reading the exhibits, you have three choices. You can continue north another ½ mile to Rockside Station and then double back. You can turn back a short distance and turn right to follow the 1½-mile roundtrip Hemlock Creek Trail. Or you can return directly to Canal Exploration Center. As you walk back the way you came, consider the many generations of Native Americans who lived, loved, raised families, shared stories, and passed on. What will future peoples be wondering about us?

data.title: Native American Heritage Walking Tour

data.description: Everything Natural Bridges has to offer is accessed via the scenic drive. Cruise the 9-mile driving loop, stopping for short walks to viewpoints of the bridges, archeological sites, and more. This tour will guide you through the monument, providing helpful directions and must-know facts.

images.altText: A stone sign marking the parking area for Kachina Bridge along a road in canyon country
images.caption: The 9-mile scenic drive provides access to all three natural bridges, beautiful views, and more!
images.title: Kachina Viewpoint and Trailhead sign

stops.significance: Stop at the park visitor center first. Here you can pay your park entry fee or show your pass, pick up a map, browse the bookstore, and more! Exhibits and the 10-minute park film will introduce the area and the monument’s history. The visitor center is also a great place to fill up on water and use restroom facilities.

Sipapu is the largest bridge in the park and named after the Hopi term for the opening between worlds. The viewpoint gives sweeping views of the bridge and the canyon landscape it spans. The viewpoint is particularly great for geology, with desert varnish streaking down the canyon walls and pot holes on the canyon rim. Below, you can see where an ancient river flowed through the canyon and carved out the bridge.

Natural Bridges is more than a geology monument! This special place was also home to the ancestral Pueblo peoples who once lived throughout the Four Corners area. Horse Collar Ruin is well preserved and easily seen from the overlook.

Kachina is the thickest bridge in the park at a whopping 44-foot width. From the viewpoint, you get a bird’s eye view of this massive sandstone bridge and the canyons below. The winding paved path is dotted with desert plant life, including yucca, juniper, and pinyon pine.

Owachomo is the thinnest, and perhaps oldest, natural bridge in the park. From the viewpoint, you can see Owachomo’s span against the canyon country backdrop. The viewpoint also allows for views of sweeping biological soil crust, a living crust that gives life to this arid environment.

Bears Ears Buttes and surrounding area are sacred lands to many local peoples, who come to visit, gather, and perform ceremonies. Although not within the monument boundaries, Bears Ears are an iconic landmark visible from many places in the Four Corners area. One of the best views of these buttes is this wayside here.

data.title: Natural Bridges Scenic Drive

data.description: All recorded sounds were recorded by Dr. Nathan Wolek the 2020 artist-in-resident. Close your eyes and listen to the sounds of Canaveral National Seashore. Multiple locations are recorded throughout the park including Apollo Beach, Playalinda Beach and Seminole Rest.

data.description: The New River Gorge Waterfall Tour follows the path of eight waterfalls starting north of the park near the town of Gauley Bridge and ending at the famous Sandstone Falls. Trails may contain uneven terrain, steep slopes, and distances of up to 2 miles round trip to reach the falls. It is possible to complete the tour in one day but not recommended. These waterfalls are also part of the West Virginia Waterfall Trail.

data.description: The fight at Concord's North Bridge occurred around 9:30 a.m., April 19, 1775. It was here that Colonial soldiers were first ordered to fire upon British Regulars. It was here the first British soldiers died. This self-guided tour will help you explore the significant sites, structures and landscapes associated with the battle at Concord's North Bridge and the events of April 19, 1775. Most of the sites are accessible by foot within half a mile of each other.

images.altText: An arched wooden bridge spans a small river. Trees display autumn color against an overcast sky.
images.caption: Concord's North Bridge, site of the "shot heard round the world."
images.title: Concord's North Bridge

stops.significance: This is the best place to park and begin the tour. North Bridge Visitor Center features a short video and exhibits about the North Bridge fight. It is generally open April through October. Parking is available year round.
Major John Buttrick led the Colonial advance to North Bridge and gave the order to fire. The bodies of Isaac Davis and Abner Hosmer, who were killed at the North Bridge, were brought to the house.
The minute man and militia companies gathered here and formed their column just prior to advancing to the North Bridge.

The Groton Road dates back to the late 1600s. On April 19, 1775 the minute and militia companies marched along this road as they advanced to the North Bridge and against the British soldiers posted there.
Captain David Brown lived here with his family. He led his men into battle on April 19, 1775 just yards from his home. The property had been in his family since the 1640s.
stops.assetName: The Captain David Brown House Site

stops.significance: The first time colonial soldiers were ordered to fire upon British soldiers happened here on April 19, 1775. The first British soldiers died on the east bank, along with two minute men from Acton upon the west bank.
This statue, representing a minute man of 1775, was created by sculptor Daniel Chester French and unveiled for the centennial celebration of the battle. on April 19, 1875.

Standing twenty-five feet tall, the 1836 Battle Monument was the first monument erected at the famous North Bridge battlefield in Concord Massachusetts. Although the monument towers over the bridge today, it’s construction and legacy remain fraught with controversy.
This gravesite marks the final resting place of the first British soldiers to die during the American Revolution, on April 19, 1775.
stops.assetName: Grave of British Soldiers at the North Bridge

stops.significance: This house still bears a scar of the battle. A retreating British soldier fired into it. It was later the home of prominent Concord resident John Shepard Keyes.

data.title: North Bridge Self-Guided Tour

data.description: Step back in time in downtown Oak Ridge as you discover the same shopping districts, lodging, recreation, and houses of worship that Manhattan Project workers and visitors would have enjoyed long ago.

images.altText: Elevated 1945 photo of a strip mall with parking lot at center and people walking throughout
images.caption: Jackson Square, 1945
images.title: Jackson Square, 1945

stops.significance: Jackson Square, originally called Town Center No.1, opened in 1943 and was often considered the primary shopping and entertainment hub in Oak Ridge during the Manhattan Project. Residents could find 24-hour grocery shopping at over a dozen stores, several restaurants, a bowling alley, a pharmacy, a movie theater, and dance hall among many other attractions. It was here that many Oak Ridgers gathered to celebrate the end of World War II.

The Guest House (now the Alexander Inn assisted-living facility) was the primary hotel for official visitors during the Manhattan Project. Constructed in 1943, several Manhattan Project luminaries stayed here over the duration of the war including J. Robert Oppenheimer, General Leslie Groves, and Secretary of War Henry Stimson. Room rates for all guests was $2 per night for a room with a private bath, or $1.50 per night with a communal bathroom.

Built in 1943, this standard military 700-series chapel was one of three military chapels constructed at Oak Ridge during the Manhattan Project. The chapel received its name during a prayer of dedication on September 30, 1943. 22 different congregations worshiped here during the Manhattan Project, with worshipers being segregated by both denomination and race. The United Church purchased the chapel in 1955 and continues to hold services to this day.

One of several locations throughout Oak Ridge constructed for Manhattan Project workers to exercise, the community tennis courts became popular for a reason other than tennis. On pleasant evenings these courts hosted outdoor dances for workers and residents. The first dance was held here on July 22, 1944, and soon became a weekly event during the war. Today, Oak Ridgers use the courts for recreation and the National Park Service and community partners occasionally host throwback dances here.

data.title: Oak Ridge: A Day in the Life During the Manhattan Project

data.description: Step back in time as you discover more places in Oak Ridge that Manhattan Project workers and residents would have visited for shopping, entertainment, and recreation long ago.

images.altText: Black and white photo of several young people in swimsuits gathered on a wooden platform at a pool
images.caption: The Community Swimming Pool was a popular gathering place during the Manhattan Project.
images.title: Oak Ridge Swimming Pool

stops.significance: Grove Center, along with Jackson Square and Jefferson Square, was a primary shopping and entertainment district in Oak Ridge during the Manhattan Project. The center included a grocery store, clothing store, and shoe store among many other businesses. Grove Center's main attraction was the Grove Theater, a state-of-the-art concert hall that held approximately 1,000 people. As you explore the area today, take time to see what events are occurring at the theater.

The community swimming pool, a spring-fed pool constructed in 1945, was a popular location for workers and residents to cool off on hot summer days during the Manhattan Project. Prior to the pool's construction, the site was home to a small pond called Cross Pond. This watering hole provided respite for people and livestock as they migrated toward middle Tennessee during the 19th century. The swimming pool remains a popular feature of the Oak Ridge community to this day.

data.title: Oak Ridge: A Day in the Life During the Manhattan Project (Part 2)

data.description: Explore the area that was once the Wheat community, a small rural community that existed for decades prior to the displacement of its citizens to make way for the Manhattan Project, specifically the K-25 Gaseous Diffusion Plant.

images.altText: A black and white photograph of a small church and graveyard on a wooded hillside.
images.caption: Wheat Church, 1948
images.title: Wheat Church, 1948

stops.significance: This Baptist church, constructed in 1901, is the last surviving structure of the Wheat community. Officially named in 1881 by local postmaster Henry Franklin Wheat, the Wheat community boasted a post office, several schools, a Masonic lodge, a service station, three churches, a small school and several residences and farms. In 1942, the federal government selected 59,000 acres of land in East Tennessee to develop what would become Oak Ridge. Manhattan Project administrators offered residents of Wheat and nearby communities between $35-45 dollars per acre to give up the land with no relocation expenses provided; many were told to vacate within two weeks.

The K-25 History Center is a free museum located within the remnants of the K-25 complex (now ETTP). The center tells the remarkable story of the K-25 Gaseous Diffusion Plant, a uranium-enrichment facility that was the largest building in the world during the Manhattan Project. It was on this massive site that the majority of the Wheat community existed. Multiple homes, businesses, and farms were destroyed and many residents were displaced to make way for this revolutionary scientific undertaking.

data.title: Oak Ridge: A Walk Through Wheat

data.description: The City of Oak Ridge has something for kids of all ages to enjoy. From world-class museums to outdoor activities and attractions, every member of your family will enjoy a day in the secret city.

images.altText: Black and white photo of child with two policemen
images.caption: A child receives a security clearance badge, 1945.
images.title: A Child Receives a Security Badge, 1945.

stops.significance: The Children's Museum of Oak Ridge, opened in 1974, holds a wide array of exhibits, including hands-on learning opportunities in art, science, environmental studies, history, geography, and world cultures. In addition, the museum is home to the Manhattan Project Oak Ridge Visitor Center. Park rangers are on hand to answer any questions you may have about the wealth of historic sites throughout  the city.

A.K. Bissell Park has something for both kids and adults to enjoy. This 38-acre park offers you the chance to picnic, walk, jog, play on the playground, or just relax on a nice day. The park is home to the International Friendship Bell, a massive bronze bell symbolizing peace and unity between the United States and Japan. Be sure to ring the bell during your visit. Also, the Secret City Commemorative Walk is located in the park. Take this short walk to learn more about the founding of Oak Ridge during the Manhattan Project.

The American Museum of Science and Energy is an Oak Ridge institution. Here you will find countless interactive scientific exhibits from the Manhattan Project to the present day. Children of all ages will enjoy the hands-on learning opportunities found within the museum.

The Oak Ridge Community Swimming Pool, constructed in 1945 as a place for Manhattan Project workers to enjoy on hot summer days, has been a staple of the community ever since. The pool holds approximately 2.2 million gallons (8 million liters) of water, making it one of the largest spring-fed pools in the United States. Located across from Grove Center, the pool is open during summer months.

data.title: Oak Ridge: For Kids

data.description: Walk in the footsteps of thousands of Manhattan Project employees as you imagine what it was like working in secrecy in the largest building in the world at the time.

images.altText: Aerial photo of large industrial complex in wooded valley.
images.caption: The K-25 plant was the largest building in the world during the Manhattan Project.
images.title: K-25, 1947

stops.significance: The Turnpike Gatehouse, one of many positioned throughout the secret city during and after the Manhattan Project, controlled access to K-25. Armed guards stood watch here 24 hours a day, 7 days a week. The interior of the gatehouse is closed to the public, excepting special events. Hiking trails begin in the parking lot and lead through the now-abandoned Wheat community, one of several rural communities that existed before the Manhattan Project.

The K-25 History Center tells the remarkable story of the K-25 complex from the Manhattan Project through the Cold War. Here you will find hundreds of exhibits on the revolutionary science that led to the development of the atomic bomb, as well as artifacts and information pertaining to the thousands of workers who called this complex home. Admission is free. Directly behind the museum sits a massive empty field. This was the site of the K-25 Gaseous Diffusion Plant, the largest building in the world during the Manhattan Project.

The K-25 Overlook and Visitor Center is located on the site of Happy Valley, the construction and workers’ community that sprung up during the Manhattan Project. As you explore the visitor center, you will find more information on Happy Valley, K-25, and the Manhattan Project as a whole. Standing in the parking lot and looking across SR-58 will give you a panoramic view of the now-demolished K-25 complex.

data.title: Oak Ridge: Visit K-25

data.description: Come visit the National Mall and see some of the more obscure memorials like the Arts of War and Peace, John Paul Jones, 56 Signers Island, the newly reopened Lockkeepers House and more! Walk the path less taken.

images.altText: A monument featuring a dark bronze , standing figure atop an ornate stone base.
images.caption: John Paul Jones Memorial
images.title: John Paul Jones Memorial

stops.significance: This memorial commemorates American Revolutionary War sea captain and “Father of the US Navy” John Paul Jones. His maritime exploits during the war terrified the British and boosted the morale of the American people. This memorial was dedicated by President William Howard Taft on April 16, 1912 the day after the steamship Titanic sank.

The Japanese lantern is in the grove where the first cherry trees from Japan were planted. The lantern is a symbol of the friendship between the people of  the United States and Japan. It was one of a pair of lanterns carved in 1651 in Nagasaki as a tribute to the recently passed Tokugawa Iemitsu, Second Shogun of the Tokugawa Dynasty. This lantern stood in Tokyo’s famous Ueno Park until 1954 when it was given to the National Mall. It is lit just once a year during the Cherry Blossom Festival.

In 1931 President Herbert Hoover dedicated the District of Columbia War Memorial to the music of a John Phillip Sousa led US Army Band. It honors all the citizens of the District of Columbia who served in the First World War. The names of the four hundred and ninety-nine District of Columbia citizens who died in the conflict are engraved on the memorial’s marble base. Today it is a popular spot for weddings on the National Mall.

The John Ericsson Memorial honors the Swedish-American inventor who advanced the building of early railroads, invented the screw propeller and designed the innovative Civil War warship Monitor which saved the Union Blockade. It was jointly dedicated in 1926 by both US President Calvin Coolidge and the Crown Prince of Sweden Gustaf Adolf.

The Arts of War and Peace are a set of four massive bronze gold leaf covered equestrian statues that guard the entrances to the Arlington Memorial Bridge and Rock Creek Parkway. Designed by American Sculptors James Earle Fraser and Leo Friedlander just before the Second World War, the project was abandoned by the US government during the war years. In 1950 the statues were cast in Italian foundries by the Italian Government as a gift for our assistance helping them rebuild postwar.

stops.assetName: Arts of Peace: Music and Harvest

stops.significance: The Vietnam Women’s Memorial was added to the Vietnam Veterans Memorial in 1993. It honors all the American women who served in the Vietnam War. Since all eight of the women listed on the Vietnam Wall were either U.S. Army or U.S. Air Force nurses it was decided to make the memorial a bronze statue of three nurses aiding a wounded soldier. It was created by the American Sculptor Glenna Goodacre the same artist who created the US Sacajawea dollar coin.

Beginning in World War I, the government maintained "temporary" office buildings on this site for use by the United States Navy and the Munitions Department. Nicknamed "Tempos," these structures remained until the 1970s when President Richard M. Nixon ordered their removal. The buildings were demolished in 1971 after they were no longer in use by the Navy. President Nixon then directed that a park be laid out on the land, leading to the creation of Constitution Gardens.

The Gardens were dedicated in May of 1976 as an American Revolution Bicentennial tribute. It has become an important water feature of the National Mall.

On July 2nd, 1984 Signer’s Island was added to Constitution Gardens on the two hundred and eighth anniversary of the unanimous vote for independence by the Continental Congress. The vote for independence was made July 2nd but its wording was not approved and ratified until July 4th, 1776, Independence Day. The signatures of each of the fifty-six signers of the Declaration of Independence are recreated carved in red granite on this unique memorial.
stops.assetName: 56 Signers of the Declaration of Independence Memorial

stops.significance: From 1815 till 1871 what is now Constitution Avenue was the western entrance to the Washington City Canal. The canal was then bricked over and reutilized as part of the city sewer system, but a visible reminder remains. Built in 1837 the Lockkeeper’s House housed the Lockkeeper and his family who operated the canal entrance and collected its tolls. One of the oldest structures on the National Mall, it was recently restored in 2018 and reopened to the public.

In 1683, the first German settlement in America at Germantown, northwest of Philadelphia was founded. Four hundred years later a visit by the Chancellor of Germany, Helmut Kohl, to President Ronald Reagan at the White House resulted in the creation of a garden on the National Mall. The garden celebrated four centuries of friendship between the American and German people. Four years later both leaders would dedicate a garden filled with trees and plants common to both nations.

President Thomas Jefferson wanted American cartographers to draw the longitudinal Prime Meridian thru the new capital of Washington DC. In 1804, a meridian wooden marker was placed directly south of the White House on what would later become the Washington Monument grounds. The original wooden marker was replaced with a larger stone marker in 1889. This site is also close to the original intended location for the Washington Monument.

data.title: Obscure Memorials of the National Mall

data.description: This hike takes you to a great viewpoint of the Billings Gap area between Blue Mesa and the landform to the east. The route follows the steep edge of Blue Mesa and offers views of badlands to the east and the broad grassy valleys to the north and south. The badlands’ blues, purples, grays, and whites seem to shift throughout the day and with the seasons. The summer monsoon adds a touch of green vegetation and wildflowers.

data.description: As you walk along this loop trail, look for the travertine mineral deposits, evidence of human history, and the interconnection of living things. Be advised pets are not allowed on this a 0.6-mile walking tour trail that ends in the Ohanapecosh Campground at Loop B. While it might be tempting, bathing is not permitted, and drinking is not advised as the water temperature is not hot enough to kill bacteria. Please Leave No Trace by staying on the trail to help us preserve and protect this place.

images.caption: Ohanapecosh Hot Spring
images.title: Ohanapecosh Hot Spring pools

stops.significance: Your adventure begins behind the Ohanapecosh visitor center, near a massive tree slice.
The plants that grow in wet conditions are adapted to their environment.
Different plants grow in different parts of the forest depending on the resources available.
Is it bad when a tree dies? Or does it provide a benefit to the forest?
The Ohanapecosh hot springs were once a health resort. The water temperature is not hot enough to kill bacteria. Bathing is not permitted, and drinking is not advised.
The hot springs deposit colorful minerals at this location.
The Ohanapecosh river is important to this area.
We return to the campground and observe the human infrastructure of the park.

data.description: Old-growth forests are forests that existed before 19th century settlement and logging. It is a window in time glimpsing back into ancient forests. On the Burnwood trail, visitors can see old-growth forest dating back to the 17th century. The Burnwood trail is 1.2 miles of easy walking on dirt trail with some elevation change. The trail is mostly shaded and enjoyable in any season. Visitors taking the tour should wear good shoes, bring water, and use insect repellent.

data.description: Learn more about how emigrants travelled the emigrant trail through Scotts Bluff National Monument on this 1 mile long (round-trip) hike of the Oregon Trail Pathway. While some sections of the trail are paved, others have a natural surface. Be aware of uneven and slippery surfaces.

images.altText: A woman stands on a paved trail and uses her smart phone to listen to an audio tour.
images.caption: The cell phone tour is now part of the NPS app.
images.title: Audio Tour

stops.significance: This is the start of the Oregon Trail Pathway. The trail is 1 mile (1.6 kilometers) round-trip and is rated as moderate in difficulty. There is an elevation change of 85 feet (26 meters). Most of the trail is asphalt paved. However, the mid-section of the trail features a segment of the Oregon/California Trails that was travelled by emigrants starting in 1851. This section of trail is naturally surfaced and can be slippery with uneven surfaces.

From this stop you should be able to see Mitchell Pass off to the west. Mitchell Pass became the preferred route for emigrants to bypass Scotts Bluff starting in 1851. You will also see a few emigrant wagons.
From this stop, different types of wagons that were used by emigrants and freight-hauling outfits can be seen.

At this point on the tour, you will traverse a short section of the actual Oregon Trail. Here, at Mitchell Pass, wagon trains that had spread out across the prairie, were forced to funnel into the narrow pass, just wide enough for one wagon.
Wide depressions left by wagon traffic, called swales, can be seen from this point.
This site is the location of artist and photographer William Henry Jackson's 1866 campsite.

data.title: Oregon Trail Pathway Audio Tour

data.description: Traveling with this mobile tour is like having a ranger in your pocket! Find trail sites to visit in Oregon and Washington and learn as you explore! This Auto Tour will start you on the eastern side of Oregon, near the border with Idaho. Guiding you to travel west, mostly following Interstate 84, you will end your tour in Oregon City, Oregon. You can also return to the menu and select "Trail Sites to Visit in Oregon" and "Trail Sites to Visit in Washington" to explore individual sites near you.

images.altText: A trail winds through a grass-covered area with slight hills.
images.caption: Visit Echo Meadows on the Oregon National Historic Trail.
images.title: Echo Meadows Swales

stops.significance: Keeney Pass was named for the early western pioneer, Jonathan Keeney. In 1831, at the age of 19, Keeney left Missouri to explore the Rocky Mountains. He joined Jim Bridger of the American Fur Company and spent his life trapping and trading throughout the west. Thousands of emigrants on the Oregon Trail used this pass to reach the fertile farmlands that laid further west. The countryside of Keeney Pass has largely been unchanged since this time.

Farewell Bend State Recreation Area is named after Farewell Bend, the last location where emigrants camped and watered along the banks of the Snake River after following the river for over 300 miles. The next morning they would turn northwest and head into the desolate Burnt River country. Restored cover wagons and exhibits at an Oregon Trail kiosk tell the story.

Birch Creek Trail Site is a Bureau of Land Management site where the actual path made by emigrants, livestock, and wagons traveling the Oregon Trail is still a hiking path. Visitors are welcome to hike this quarter mile long section of the Oregon Trail across the sagebrush plains as it heads toward the Snake River. The hiking part of this path ends at a barbed wire fence, which divides grazing allotments on public lands. Oregon Trail ruts then continue for a short distance from the fence before disappearing in the grass.

The National Historic Oregon Trail Interpretive Center is a 500 acre site managed by the Bureau of Land Management. The large interpretive center building contains exhibits that tell the compelling story of the Oregon Trail and the emigrant experience. In addition, the center contains a theater that hosts films, lectures, and dramatic presentations. On the grounds of the site are four miles of interpretive hiking trails, an amphitheater, a wagon encampment for living history demonstrations, and scenic views of the surrounding area. Oregon Trail ruts are visible from the center and can be visited. The site offers activities for all ages, for school groups, and for group tours. This is a particularly fine stop for families with children.
stops.assetName: National Historic Oregon Trail Interpretive Center

stops.significance: The National Historic Oregon Trail Interpretive Center is located at the top of Flagstaff Hill. The Oregon Trail reached this hill by going through the small valley, known as Virtue Flat, that lies just south of the center. Traveling through this valley was no easy task. Emigrants had to fight their way through shoulder-tall sagebrush just after spending four or five difficult days ascending Burnt River. The trek across Virtue Flats created 13 miles of still visible Oregon Trail ruts. Approximately one mile of these ruts lies on the interpretive center's grounds. The ruts can be reached by following hiking trails from the interpretive center or by driving a half-mile west of the center's entrance on Highway 86 to a turnout.
stops.assetName: National Historic Oregon Trail Center- Trail Ruts

stops.significance: The Grande Ronde Valley Oregon Trail Kiosk is located in the Charles Reynolds Rest Area off of Interstate 84. The kiosk's interpretive exhibits tell of the emigrant experience in the Grande Ronde Valley and their peaceful encounters with the valley's American Indians. Look back to the southeast (left side of the freeway when facing the westbound lanes of I-84) to see white posts marking the "powerful rockey" 1,300-foot descent of Ladd Hill to the Grande Ronde Valley.
stops.assetName: Grande Ronde Valley Oregon Trail Kiosk

stops.significance: For emigrants on the Oregon Trail, Ladd Marsh was another obstacle they had to overcome in order to reach the fertile lands of the Willamette Valley. After traveling through Ladd Canyon and descending Ladd Hill, the flat lands of Grande Ronde Valley at first were a welcome reprieve from hard travel. But that changed upon entering the marsh. The narrow-wheeled wagons become mired in the wet, muddy ground, exhausting already weary travelers. It was not until 1868, 25 years after the first wagons rolled through the marsh, that a new route was established that avoided the wet ground.

For emigrants, today's Birnie Park was more than just a place along the Oregon Trail. It was also an important camping and staging area. In order to leave Grande Ronde Valley and continue on the Trail, emigrants faced a nearly 1000 ft. climb up steep valley walls. Teams of oxen had to be combined in order to pull the wagons up this rise. The area now known as Birnie Park provided a perfect location to do this.

Oregon Trail Interpretive Park at Blue Mountain Crossing is where the Oregon Trail passed through the rugged Blue Mountains. Knowing that this was the last mountain range they would cross must have helped emigrants find the strength to climb the Blue Mountains. Trail swales and scars on stately Ponderosa pines made by passing wagons reveal the struggle emigrants faced in this rugged, and beautiful, mountain range.
stops.assetName: Oregon Trail Interpretive Park at Blue Mountain Crossing

stops.significance: "Tamástslikt" (pronounced "tuh-MUST-slickt") is from the Walla Walla Indian language, meaning "interpreting our own story." This museum and research facility is the only American Indian owned and operated interpretive center on the Oregon Trail. Its permanent exhibits explore the past, present, and future of the Cayuse, Umatilla, and Walla Walla people (the Confederated Tribes) and tell the Oregon Trail story from their perspective. This is a chance to see the pioneers through the eyes of Indian people.

Whitman Mission National Historic Site was established to preserve and share the story of Marcus and Narcissa Whitman's religious mission to the Cayuse Nation in the early nineteenth century, along with its lasting impacts and continuing relevancy. The Whitman's established their religious mission at Waiilatpu on the Columbia Plateau in 1836. During the 1840s, the mission also served as a way-stop on the Oregon Trail, providing emigrants with food, medicine, and, if needed, a place to stay during the winter. The Whitmans were killed in an attack on November 29, 1847.
stops.assetName: Whitman Mission National Historic Site, the Oregon Trail

stops.significance: The primary route of the Oregon Trail passed through Echo Meadows from 1847-1860. Just four miles from the Umatilla River crossing, emigrants did not stop or camp here, but they left signs of their passing nonetheless. Deep wagon swales were created as the emigrants passed through the meadows, which remain to this day.

Crossing the Deschutes River, near Deschutes River State Park , was difficult for emigrants. They frequently camped at the mouth of this large tributary of the Columbia River before crossing. In order to cross, some emigrant parties used the rocky islands near the river's mouth as stepping stones, while wagons were floated across and stock animals swam. Others forded the river using rafts. The lure of the nearby rich and fertile Willamette valley drove them ahead.
stops.assetName: Deschutes River State Park Oregon Trail Kiosk

stops.significance: Celilo Park is located along a stretch of the Columbia River where American Indians have been fishing for at least 10,000 years. In the past, they netted salmon migrating up the rapids and over Celilo Falls for food and trade. This important fishery became the hub of a vast Indian trade network that one writer called "the Wall Street of the West."

Columbia Gorge Discovery Center & Museum is located on a 54-acre point of land adjacent to the Columbia River and is the interpretive center for the Columbia River Gorge National Scenic Area. This area includes one of the oldest continuously occupied places in North America (over 11,000 years) and parts of the Lewis and Clark and Oregon Trails.

Obtained as a gift from Mark Mayer in 1924, the Rowena Crest Viewpoint is a paved overlook located near the top of the high bluffs on the south side of the Columbia River. It offers magnificent views of the Columbia River Gorge, interpretive exhibits, and hiking trails through a nature preserve. When the spring wildflowers are in bloom, this is one of the most stunning vistas in the Gorge.

Fort Vancouver was a supply depot and the headquarters for the Columbia District of the Hudson's Bay Company (HBC), a British corporation that monopolized the fur trade. Although HBC hoped to secure the Oregon Country for Britain, the post's humane and generous chief factor, Dr. John McLoughlin, often came to the rescue of American emigrants who arrived on his doorstep half-starved and penniless. He is regarded by many as a hero of the emigration era.
stops.assetName: Fort Vancouver National Historic Site, the Oregon Trail

stops.significance: This is where visitors register for a tour of the McLoughlin House.

McLoughlin House is named after John McLoughlin, the Chief Factor of Fort Vancouver. Pressured into retirement by Hudson's Bay Company because of his generosity toward American emigrants, John McLoughlin moved his family from the fort to this home in 1846. During his retirement, he became a U.S. citizen (in 1851), founded Oregon City, established several businesses there, and donated land for schools and churches.

The End of the Oregon Trail Interpretive Center contains a wealth of displays about the history of the Oregon Trail and the town of Oregon City. Before heading into the center, explore the outside grounds and gardens. Here, interpretive signs tell the stories of the Trail, the Tumwater Chinook and Clackamas Indian people, and the settlement of the Willamette Valley. Follow the sidewalk to reach the garden that contains the designated end of the Oregon Trail, which is marked by two monuments.
stops.assetName: End of the Oregon Trail Interpretive Center

data.title: Oregon Trail across Oregon & Washington

data.description: Since the late 1890s Paradise has served as a base camp for people attracted to the spectacular wildflower meadows and high-mountain recreation. Built between 1916 and 1942, structures at Paradise were designed in an alpine rustic style. As you walk the area, investigate the buildings’ individual histories, from the Guide House to the Paradise Ranger Station. History here evokes a continuity of spirit.

images.altText: Buildings from the early 1900s with steeply pitched roofs surrounded by trees
images.caption: Paradise Historic District
images.title: Paradise Historic District

stops.significance: Start the tour at the Jackson Visitor Center where the historic Paradise Camp Lodge used to stand from 1918 until the 1950s.
stops.assetName: Paradise Historic Tour: Paradise Camp Lodge

stops.significance: This historic structure, while not open to the public, is a classic example of alpine rustic architecture at Paradise.
stops.assetName: Paradise Historic Tour: Paradise Ranger Station

stops.significance: Enjoy the historic, rustic beauty of the Paradise Inn, which opened in 1917. Today it is a National Historic Landmark.

stops.significance: This building powered Paradise’s rope tow and transported skiers to the top of Alta Vista from the 1930s to the 1970s.
This memorial honors those who served in the U.S. Army’s 10th Mountain Division which trained at Mount Rainier during World War II.
stops.assetName: Paradise Historic Tour: 10th Mountain Division Memorial

data.title: Paradise Historic District Walking Tour

data.description: Gates of Lodore is located on the northern tip of Dinosaur National Monument. It is a long drive to the area and the wild, remote country adds to its sense of isolation. Here, the Green River, after winding across the broad valley known as Browns Park, turns toward the south and makes a direct path into the mountains in front of it. The Green enters into deep canyons filled with rapids that challenged Major John Wesley Powell who passed through here in 1869 on his voyage down the Green and Colorado Rivers.

images.altText: A large, steep walled canyon with a river cutting its way inside with shrubs growing along the side.
images.caption: The end of the trail peers into Lodore Canyon as the Green River travels through it.
images.title: Gates of Lodore

stops.significance:
Many canyons can be seen only distantly from their rims, or entered via long and strenuous hikes. Here, an easy walk takes you to the threshold of Dinosaur National Monument's canyon country for a look into its history and habitats. 

This tour is keyed to numbered points of interest along the trail as you approach the Gates of Lodore. Wear comfortable, sturdy shoes. Carry water and snacks. The elevation here is 5,500 feet (1,700 meters) above sea level so remember to pace yourself. Seek shelter immediately if thunder is heard or lightning is visible.

From its origin high in the mountains of the Wind River Range in Wyoming, the Green River rushes through steep-walled canyons and traverses sage-covered valleys. After emerging from the Flaming Gorge Dam, the river wanders placidly through an open valley beginning 30 miles upstream from here. Early trappers and traders to the area named this valley Browns Hole after Baptiste Brown, a French-Canadian trapper. He choose this area to settle because of its mild winters and plentiful beaver pelts.

Travelers that passed through the area later included John Wesley Powell on his historic float through the Grand Canyon. Powell gave the area its current name of Browns Park. However, most local cattle ranchers still referred to the valley as Browns Hole until a spirited young Elizabeth Bassett convinced them to adopt what she termed the much more “eloquent” name of Browns Park.

Browns Park is an isolated area, but it is not immune to change. Beginning in the 1870s, early settlers altered the landscape to suit their needs. Great cattle herds once roamed the range. Unlike native animals, cattle grazed on native grasses faster than they could reproduce and new invasive plants took their place. Cheat grass is one of the most common of these species. Originally introduced in grain shipments from the Mediterranean, it spread rapidly across the American west. Not only does it provide poor forage for native animals, but its seeds have the ability to hitchhike to new destinations by catching in fur or on your socks.

In contrast to cheat grass, lichens have been here a long time. The colorful patches on the rocks at your feet are alive. They are made of fungi whose filaments can cling to smooth rock and secrete acids that release minerals and algae which take shelter in the fungi and manufacture food for them both. Lichen help to create new habitat by breaking down rock and by naturally decaying themselves, creating a layer of soil where new plants can take hold.

The Green River is affected by events that take place far upstream of here. During spring runoff or after heavy rains, the water may be brown, gray or red with silt from nearby tributaries such as Vermilion Creek. In drier weather, the river may live up to its name, flowing cold and green all the way from Flaming Gorge Dam, which traps most of its sediments. The dam’s greatest affect is not the river’s color, but its flow. After its completion in 1969, the great spring floods of former years are now trapped behind the dam. This altered the habitat downstream and made it more difficult for native fish to survive. In response, dam operators release extra water in the spring to simulate natural flooding and create conditions for the fish to spawn successfully. For the rest of the year, gradual releases from the dam keep the flow at a relatively constant level.

Across the river you can see some of the oldest rocks in Dinosaur National Monument, far more ancient than the dinosaur fossils. Perhaps as much as a billion years ago, this area lay near sea level and was being slowly buried by pebbles, sand, and mud washed down from mountains. Partly due to the weight of these sediments, the land gradually sank and the sediments piled up, reaching a thickness of over 24,000 feet. Tremendous pressure and cementing action of dissolved minerals solidified the sediments into the conglomerates, sandstones and shales that today we call the Uinta Mountain Group.

The Uinta Mountains, a spur of the Rocky Mountains, were formed by compression of the Earth’s crust. Once level layers, they then buckled upward into a broad arch. The range is highest in north-central Utah and gradually flattens out east of here. This uplifting probably began about the time the dinosaurs went extinct, and most likely continued a little at a time over millions of years. Even as the land rose, it was being worn down by erosion. Many of the younger rock layers have been stripped off to reveal these ancient rocks that were once at the very core of the mountains.

If you have traveled from a moister climate, you might not think of this area as forested. The Utah juniper, however, manages to cover much of this arid country. What it lacks in stature, the juniper makes up for in toughness, longevity, the fragrance of its wood, and the beauty of its often gnarled, twisted trunks. Also, from a more utilitarian viewpoint, junipers have fueled many a campfire since prehistoric times, supported miles of fences and perhaps right now are providing you with a bit of welcome shade.

The junipers’ companion in much of the canyon country forests is the pinyon (piñon) pine. Though you might think of pines as growing best on snow-capped mountains, many species, especially the pinyon group are well adapted to lower, drier areas. All leaves have pores through which plants breathe but in pine needles these are sunk in deep pits. Along with a waxy coating the needles help to reduce the amount of moisture lost through evaporation.

You might expect to see cacti in this semi desert, but unless they are in bloom, you may have to look closely to find them. Dinosaur National Monument is a “cold” desert, where temperatures can top 100°F in summer, but may plunge well below zero in the winter. Since cacti survive by storing water in their fleshy stems, they are vulnerable to subfreezing temperatures. Only a few low-growing varieties, likely to be insulated by a blanket of snow during the coldest weather, live here. In spring they show off bright yellow, pink, and red blossoms, but in other seasons watch your step because you might feel one before you see it!

Like cacti, most of the plants here must conserve water in order to survive. Feel the leaves of this black greasewood. Their waxy surface helps to hold in moisture, just as waxed paper keeps food fresh. Both greasewood and its smaller cousin, shadscale saltbush, can absorb and store quantities of salt in alkaline soil that would kill many other plants.

Rounding out the three most common shrubs here is the one that is probably the best known, sagebrush. Its grayish color readily distinguishes it from the greener greasewood and its spicy aroma clinches its identity. Although sagebrush is less tolerant of alkaline soils than saltbush and greasewood, several different species cover vast areas of the Intermountain West.

Greasewood, shadscale, and sagebrush dominate a surprisingly complex habitat sometimes referred to as sagebrush steppe. Look around for signs of wildlife. Some species, such as sage grouse, are completely dependent on this habitat. Others like elk and mule deer come and go with the seasons. An abundance of wildflowers creates a patchwork of color every spring.

“Soon I see a bright star that appears to rest on the very verge of the cliff overhead to the east. Slowly it seems to float from its resting place on the rock over the canyon. At first it appears like a jewel set on the brink of the cliff, but as it moves out from the rock I almost wonder that it does not fall.”
-John Wesley Powell

Dinosaur National Monument is one of the darkest places remaining in the contiguous United States. Because there is minimal impact from artificial lights, you can still see the stars of our Milky Way galaxy with startling clarity. The majority of residents of the United States live in places where the Milky Way is no longer visible, even on a moonless night. Night skies are a vanishing resource and increasing development, even in many rural areas, expands the impact of light pollution. The skies above the monument are an important resource to enjoy and protect just like the fossils, stunning scenery, and wild rivers.

The Green River, after meandering calmly through Browns Park, turns southward and cuts directly across the Uinta Mountains, which rise 3,000 feet above the valley floor. No one knows for sure why this is the case, but one theory suggests that a few million years ago the river flowed eastward, away from the mountains. When that route was blocked by uplift along the present continental divide, drainage in this area was stagnated. Browns Park gradually filled to the brim with sediments. Meandering along on top of that fill, the Green River eventually spilled over the buried crest of the mountains and down their southern slope. This gave it the energy to begin down cutting once more and as it washed out most of the recent sediments, it also rasped its way into the older rocks to carve the Canyon of Lodore.

Today, the rugged walls along the Green River are a haunt of the bighorn sheep. These sure footed climbers were probably abundant here in the past based on the number of images of them that appear in the thousand year old rock art of the Fremont People. As the west became more settled with the arrival of Europeans, the bighorn sheep began to die out from a combination of over hunting, disease, and competition from domestic livestock. The last native bighorn sheep seen in Dinosaur was reported in 1944. In 1952 a new herd of animals from elsewhere in Colorado were transplanted into the area. Their population has increased significantly to the point where bighorn sheep are now a common sight along the river corridors. Due to their unique padded hooves, bighorn are able to climb the steep, rocky canyon walls with speed and agility, making them well adapted to life in Dinosaur.

“At noon the sun shines in splendor on vermilion walls… and the canyon opens, like a beautiful portal, to a region of glory. This evening, as I write, the sun is going down and the shadows are settling in the canyon… and now it is a dark portal to a region of gloom, the gateway through which we are to enter on our voyage of exploration tomorrow, what shall we find?” John Wesley Powell wrote these words as he camped near here on June 7, 1869, expressing the combination of excitement and fear he and his companions often felt as they made the first full length expedition down the Green River. Since most of this canyon country was still literally a blank spot on the map, Powell and his men had the opportunity to fill in the blanks with new names. Andy Hall, the youngster of the group, suggested the name of this canyon after recalling “The Cataract of Lodore” by the English poet Robert Southey: “All at once and all o’er, with a mighty uproar and this way the water comes down at Lodore.”

What Powell had called “the great unknown” is now explored by thousands of people every year in rafts and kayaks. River running is very popular in Dinosaur National Monument. The monument uses a permit system both for boater safety and to reduce the impact of too many people concentrated in narrow canyons. To some, imposition of such regulations is contradictory to the freedom of wilderness travel; to others, some control necessary to preserve the wilderness itself. How we protect our public lands, while also allowing for their use, is a continual debate. Rafters may not have been able to enjoy these wild rivers if proposed dams had been constructed within the monument boundaries. The Echo Park Dam would have flooded the entire Canyon of Lodore and also that of the Yampa River, the Green’s major tributary. Protestors of the dam pointed out that Dinosaur National Monument had been enlarged to protect these canyons in their natural state, not as artificial reservoirs.

“How does the water Come down at Lodore?” My little boy asked me thus, once on a time; and moreover he tasked me to tell him in rhyme. Anon, at the word, there first came one daughter, and then came another, to second and third the request of their brother, and to hear how the water comes down at Lodore, with its rush and its roar, as many a time they had seen it before. So I told them in rhyme, for of rhymes I had store; and ‘twas in my vocation for their recreation that so I should sing; because I was laureate to them and the king. From its sources which well In the tarn on the fell; from its fountains In the mountains, its rills and its gills; through moss and through brake, it runs and it creeps for a while, till it sleeps in its own little lake. And thence at departing, awakening and starting, it runs through the reeds, and away it proceeds, through meadow and glade, in sun and in shade, and through the wood-shelter, among crags in its flurry, helter-skelter, hurry-skurry.

data.title: Passage to the Gates of Lodore

data.description: Following the American Revolution, Salem was one of the most prosperous communities of the early republic. Daring and skilled maritime merchants traveled the globe, controlling valuable trade markets with the West Indies, Europe, Asia, and Indonesia. In 1938, Salem Maritime became the first ever National Historic Site incorporated into the National Park Service. On this walking tour, we’ll visit historic buildings and structures that span over 300 years of history.

images.altText: view from large sailing vessel of wood warehouse next to dock and multi-story brick buildings
images.caption: Explore the first National Historic Site in the United States.
images.title: Places of Salem Maritime

stops.significance: Once a headquarters and training facility for the Second Corps of Cadets, the visitor center offers exhibits, maps, brochures, films, and a traditional park store.

Serving as a park store, Waite & Peirce is named after the owners of the original FRIENDSHIP. Aaron Waite and Jerathmiel Peirce sent their ships to bring back exotic spices and other treasures to Salem during the Golden Age of American Maritime history.
During the Golden Age of Sail, Derby Wharf was the center of Salem’s maritime trade lined with warehouses, stores, and business.

The Pedrick Store House is a reminder of the warehouses that used to crowd the wharf. It was built in Marblehead by Thomas Pedrick, a successful member of the merchant community in pre-Revolutionary War Marblehead.
In port cities like Salem, the vessels sitting in the harbor were the pride of the community. Friendship of Salem is a replica of the 1797 Salem-built vessel Friendship.
One of four lighthouses used to navigate Salem Sound, the Derby Wharf Light Station is the wharf’s only surviving structure.

The Custom House served as the headquarters for the U.S. Customs Service in Salem from 1819 to 1936. This property became part of Salem Maritime National Historic Site in 1938. It was temporarily occupied by the U.S. Coast Guard during World War II.

The Public Stores was built at the same time as the Custom House in 1819 however, the two are not connected by any interior doors. The space served as a bonded warehouse, where the US Customs Service stored goods until duties and storage fees could be paid by merchants.
The Scale House was built in 1829 and used by the Customs Service until 1937. It housed scales and gauges used to measure imported goods arriving in Salem.

Elias Hasket Derby commissioned Samuel McIntire to build this wooden, three story mansion in 1781. However, construction was never completed. It’s possible Derby used it as a warehouse until his death in 1799.

Today this house offers us the unique opportunity to study the lives of working class families over a period of nearly 300 years and to see how the fruits of international trade reached all residents, not just the wealthy, in historic Salem.
Constructed in 1761, this building is the earliest surviving brick house in Salem. It is recognized as an excellent example of 18th-century domestic Georgian architecture.

From 1837 to 1851, Salem directories listed a West India Goods Store on this property. It may have served as a retail store for exotic, luxury goods from the West Indies. Over the years, the building has housed various tenants and businesses.
The St. Joseph Society built this three-story brick structure for Polish immigrants and their children helping to create a shared sense of ethnic and community identity.

data.title: Places of Salem Maritime

data.description: Saugus Iron Works National Historic Site, or Hammersmith as it was called, represents North America’s 17th century transformation from stone to iron tool manufacturing. In a venture intended to make the Massachusetts Bay Colony more self-reliant, English investors financed the creation of the Company of Undertakers for the iron works in New England. These workmen would help Massachusetts achieve its goals. Use this walking tour to get acquainted with the grounds, buildings and history at the iron works.

images.altText: three people follow a path around the back of a house to a wood-sided museum with bright red door
images.caption: Explore the grounds and structures of Saugus Iron Works.
images.title: Places of Saugus Iron Works

park.fullName: Saugus Iron Works National Historic Site
park.name: Saugus Iron Works

stops.significance: The Iron Works House is the oldest building at the site and is an excellent example of first period architecture.
In the 1950s, this clapboarded building was converted into a museum to house thousands of artifacts unearthed during the archeological investigations at the time.
This square-based stone structure processed charcoal, bog ore and gabbro to make iron.
Patterns were pressed into the sand floor to make iron molds.
Forge workers produced wrought iron merchant bars, the primary product of the iron works.
In this building, merchant bars were further worked to create other semi-finished products that blacksmiths could use.
The iron works was situated at a place along the Saugus River where the Atlantic tide reaches its highest point allowing shallow draft boats to transport raw materials in and finished products out.
In 1646, Jenks obtained a patent from the Massachusetts General Court which gave him exclusive right to build water mills for making scythes and other edge tools.

data.title: Places of Saugus Iron Works

data.description: Henry Wadsworth Longfellow's poetry touches on universal themes, but in many instances it is specifically located through references, imagery, and inspiration to his Cambridge neighborhood.

images.altText: manuscript of a stanza of poem "To A Child" signed by Henry W. Longfellow
images.caption: The most famous stanza of "To A Child," copied out by the poet in 1875
images.title: To A Child

park.fullName: Longfellow House Washington's Headquarters National Historic Site
park.name: Longfellow House Washington's Headquarters

stops.significance: "To A Child," published in The Belfry of Bruges and Other Poems, 1845.
"The Herons of Elmwood," published in Keramos and Other Poems, 1878.

In "To the River Charles," published in Ballads and Other Poems, 1842, Longfellow directly addresses the river, which was part of the viewshed from his rooms at the Craigie house.  In the eighth stanza, he alludes to "three friends, all true and tried" who share the river's name. These friends are identified as Charles Sumner, Charles Folsom, and Charles Amory.

When Longfellow worked at Harvard, he would walk down the street and pass this house and adjacent blacksmith shop on his way to work. Here lived Dexter Pratt, the blacksmith who provided some of the inspiration for Longfellow's poem "The Village Blacksmith."
"In the Churchyard at Cambridge," published in Birds of Passage, 1858; "The Burial of the Poet"

Longfellow wrote "The Bridge," published in The Belfry of Bruges and Other Poems, 1845, about the current bridge's predecessor, the West Boston Bridge.  It was that wooden bridge that he often crossed on foot from his home in Cambridge to visit both his publisher and his unrequited love, Fanny Appleton.

data.title: Poetry of Places

data.description: The rolling hills and idyllic landscape of Port Oneida have remained relatively unchanged since the turn of the 20th century. Most of the houses appear much as they did in the last century with only minor changes or “modernization.” Through this well-preserved rural landscape, we can catch glimpses of a rural community’s hard work and struggle to farm the land and provide for and raise their families. These historic properties are being preserved by Lakeshore and its partner Preserve Historic Sleeping Bear.

images.caption: Port Oneida offers varied spectacular views.
images.title: Port Oneida

data.title: Port Oneida Rural Historic District

data.description: Learn about early mining in the park. The Cabin Branch Pyrite Mine operated on what is now the eastern side of the park from 1889-1920, mining pyrite for its sulfur content. Hike this trail to see the remains of some mine buildings as well as learn about forest restoration of the area after the mine was closed. The trail is around 1.5 miles round trip.

images.altText: Rows of neatly trimmed bushes and trees form an arc around two marble slabs marking graves.
images.caption: Neatly trimmed plantings surround the President's and First Lady's graves.
images.title: Gravesite of President & Mrs. Hoover

stops.significance: On August 12, 1965, an act of Congress established this park as a national historic site. Since then, the National Park Service has preserved and interpreted the historic structures and landscape of this 187-acre park. In the late 1930's, President Hoover and his wife, Lou Henry Hoover, chose this place to celebrate the values they believed helped shape his life.

West Branch boomed between 1869 and 1873. New buildings constructed in the neighborhood near the Hoovers' small cottage on Downey Street included the Laban Miles House, the Garvin House, and the Methodist Church, which is no longer standing.

In 1871, shortly after their first wedding anniversary, Jesse and Hulda Hoover built their simple but sturdy two-room cottage in the budding town of West Branch, Iowa. Their second child, future president Herbert Hoover, was born in the bedroom on August 10, 1874. In the years following his presidency, Herbert and Lou Hoover restored the president's humble birthplace, which he called, "physical proof of the unbounded opportunity of American life."

Built in 1957, this building represents the kind of blacksmith and wagon shops that were common in the 1870s. It is based on the sketches of Herbert's older brother Theodore, from his recollections of what their father's shop looked like. The re-built blacksmith shop sits west of the original shop's location just a stone's throw from the Birthplace Cottage.
stops.assetName: Blacksmith Shop (Herbert Hoover National Historic Site)

stops.significance: Herbert Hoover recalled, "Iowa in those years was filled with days of school, and who does not remember with a glow, some gentle woman, who with infinite patience and kindness, drilled into us those foundations of all we know today."

Herbert Hoover grew up in a religious community that valued peace, simplicity, integrity, and service to others. The plainly furnished Friends Meetinghouse, built by the Society of Friends, or Quakers, in 1857, is the physical expression of those values. Now two blocks from its original location, the Herbert Hoover Birthplace Foundation relocated and restored this meetinghouse in 1964.

The bronze, seven and a half foot tall statue "Isis, Goddess of Life" is the work of Belgian sculptor Auguste Puttemans. It was a gift from the people of Belgium in gratitude for Hoover's famine relief efforts on their behalf during the First World War.

Part of the National Archives, this presidential library allows people to explore the legacy of Herbert Hoover's presidency. It opened to the public on August 10, 1962— Herbert Hoover's 88th birthday. President Hoover himself attended the dedication, along with fellow former President Harry S. Truman.

Five days after he died on October 20, 1964 at the age of 90, the 31st President was laid to rest in this quiet, grassy hillside. More than 100,000 people lined the funeral procession route from Cedar Rapids to West Branch on that warm fall day.

data.description: The historic White Haven estate is the centerpiece of Ulysses S. Grant National Historic Site. Guided tours of Grant's home White Haven are offered on a daily basis. There is no fee to take the tour. Tours meet at the front desk inside the Visitor Center. Tours are usually offered at the top of each hour with the first tour beginning at 10:00 a.m. and the last tour at 4:00 p.m. Advance reservations are not required to take a tour, but spots are offered on a first-come, first-serve basis.

stops.significance: A massive rock structure built by Kamehameha I and his warriors with no mortar and water worn rocks that came from the seashore valley of Pololu. This heiau (temple) played a crucial role in the ruler's ascendancy. With the death of Kamehameha's cousin Keoua, all opposition ended on the island of Hawai'i, and the prophecy began to come true. By 1810, through conquest and treaties, Kamehameha The Great, builder of Pu'ukohola Heiau, was the revered king of all the Hawaiian Islands.

data.description: Nestled deep in a hollow at the headwaters of the Rapidan River in Shenandoah National Park is a little piece of history. Rapidan Camp was the beautiful, rustic getaway of President Herbert Hoover and First Lady Lou Henry Hoover. Experience this serene spot yourself and explore its history through this self-guided tour. The camp is not accessible by private vehicle. Hike in from Milam Gap or join a Ranger Tour.

data.description: Alcatraz Island lies within Ramaytush Ohlone territory. There is no evidence (scientific or oral tradition) regarding Ohlone use of the island. In 1969, a group of Native American students, who later known as “Indians of All Tribes,” came to occupy the island in a political protest. These students fought for inclusion into the educational system that denied them their cultural existence. On this tour, learn the story of the 19-month Indian occupation of Alcatraz Island. The tour is 0.5 mi (0.8km) one way.

data.description: We often think of the desert as being a dry place, but if you look closely, you will find that water is truly the desert's "architect". The presence or absence of water affects the variety of plants and animals living here, and the ways in which humans have been able to use this area over time. As you walk the nature trail, let this tour be your guide, but also use your own observational skills to search for adaptations that plants and animals have evolved to survive in the Chihuahuan Desert.
