data.description: Take a self-guided tour as you float the Niobrara National Scenic River. This tour identifies landmarks along the river where you can stop and explore, finding waterfalls and scenic views, and rapids for you to avoid too!

images.altText: Two feet hanging over a kayak as it floats along a calm river.
images.caption: Explore the Niobrara River from the comfort of your kayak.
images.title: A gentle float

stops.significance: Fort Niobrara National Wildlife Refuge's Launch Site is the first public launch on the designated 76 miles of Niobrara National Scenic River.

While this is not an active stop on the tour or a river feature you should be looking for, know that you are floating through a National Wildlife Refuge! You might catch a glimpse of the unique wildlife along the riverside and that the first four miles of river are protected as both a National Scenic River and a National Wildlife Refuge.

The Fort Falls are a popular stop for many of our visitors because they are so easy to get to. Just a quick hike up from the water and you're shaded in the cool canyons that are home to waterfalls, deciduous and coniferous forests and hybrid species unique to our riverbanks.

These small rapids might not even be noticeable, but they are on the floaters left, across from the Fort Falls Trail sign. They are Class I Rapids, just know that the current at the end of the rapid will want to spin your vessel to the left.

After exiting the Fort Niobrara National Wildlife Refuge, you'll come across the Berry Bridge, a popular landing for floaters using private outfitters to make their trip possible. On the floater's right, there is a waterfall known as Berry Falls. See how the Falls are convex, they stick out? This formation is unique to the Niobrara River's waterfalls and you'll see it again later on the tour.

On your right, there is a sign before the walking bridge for the Smith Falls Landing. You're going to want to pull off here and take another quick walk up to the Smith Falls, the tallest waterfalls in Nebraska!

Smith Falls State Park has been in existence longer that the Niobrara National Scenic River has been protected by the National Park Service.  The story of the Smith Falls is a great example of how deeply the people of the Niobrara River Valley care for and preserve the river and its features.

Nickols Landing is a popular public access point for the Niobrara located at Smith Falls State Park. This is a great landing or launch point, or a good place to stop for lunch if you want to learn more about Smith Falls and stop in at their visitor center.

Brewer Bridge is one of the most popular public access landings on the river. Many outfitters also use it to pick up or drop off floaters.

There is a bridge right before the landing on the floater's left. There are bathrooms, trash, and drinking water at this landing if you need to test out your land-legs before continuing downriver.

Conner Rapids are a good feature to note because it means that you are entering the section of river with more private landings and rapids.

Conner's Rapid is a class I rapid that beginners can handle. Stick to the floater's left and try to stay out of the middle where the water might hit both sides of the boat and make for a rougher ride.

Keep your eyes peeled for more challenging rapids over the next 10 river miles that you might need to portage - pull out and resume floating below.

These Class II Rapids will push your boundaries as a beginner, but no need to fear. Trust your vessel and know that you might get a little wet but you'll be just fine. 

Fritzes Island is a fun rapid and depending on depth, you might not think this one is a challenge!

Fritzes Narrows are almost not visible and as a class I rapid, we have never had an issue sticking to the middle of the channel where the water is deepest to pass through these little rapids.

If the river is at the right height, you might not even notice these, so if you pass under the County Line Bridge, you've already passed them. You must be a good floater!

Watch for the signs! Rocky Ford is a class III rapid that you're going to want to portage. You can follow the signs to pull out of the river on the floater's left and resume your float further downriver. 

Experienced floaters looking for an advanced experience can spend extra time here making laps in the whitewater.

Look to your left! This is a portage point. You need to pull over and carry your vessel further downstream to continue. 

Egelhoff's Rapid is a class II+ and we do not recommend any beginners try tackling this feature.

One at a time now! The Egelhoff Narrows are a class I rapid that beginners can float, just know that there is a slight whirlpool effect at the end of the chute so stick to the main channel and be ready to ride that one out and get turned around again.

Portage Highly recommended. Floating the Norden Chute risks life and limb for all floaters, even those with vast experience.

The Norden Chute, while powerful and beautiful, is also dangerous. The water that flows over the chute circulates under the surface and has hydraulic sucking forces that you do not want to be caught in. There may also be debris and rebar under the waters of the Chute. 

Even the most experienced floaters should not attempt the Norden Chute.

Over the Norden Bridge and to the floater's right is the Niobrara Valley Preserve. The Preserve is open to the public and can be accessed by making the less the quarter-mile jaunt into the preserve headquarters and trailheads. There are hiking trails, information, and more for visitors to explore at the Nature Conservancy along the Niobrara River.
Eagle Rapids are the last featured rapids on the Niobrara NSR. These class II+ rapids are another portage and floaters can stay safe by bypassing them and continuing safely downstream.

The Highway 7 Bridge is a public access point for floaters on the Eastern Niobrara River. There is a State of Nebraska, Wildlife Management Area on the floater's right, after the bridge, where primitive camping can be done. No fires are allowed here, but floaters can pull their vessels up the bank and into the trees in a pinch.

The Highway 137 Bridge is the end of the designated Niobrara National Scenic River. The landing and parking area is located on the floater's left, before the bridge.
Feb 2020 Note: This landing was damaged in 2019 and is awaiting repair by the NEDOT. Please check our alerts for more information.

data.description: In 1966, following the death of President Kennedy, the family purchased the birthplace as a memorial. Rose Kennedy restored the home to her recollection of its 1917 appearance, and gave this home to the American people in 1969. In an effort to capture Mrs. Kennedy's memories of that period, the National Park Service produced an audio tour of the birthplace, in which she describes family activities and furnishings and shares personal anecdotes that convey the spirit of the place.

images.altText: Woman in white hat standing next to twin bed
images.caption: Rose Kennedy stands next to the birth bed in her former bedroom at the site's dedication in 1969.
images.title: Rose Kennedy in Parents' Bedroom

park.fullName: John Fitzgerald Kennedy National Historic Site
park.name: John Fitzgerald Kennedy

stops.significance: This was the first home shared by President Kennedy’s father and mother, Joseph P. and Rose Fitzgerald Kennedy, and represents the social and political beginnings of one of the nation’s most prominent families. Through her audio tour, recorded in 1969, Rose Kennedy shared her memories of her family’s life in this house fifty years earlier.  Her sometimes-nostalgic recording reflects her desire for visitors to learn “how people lived in 1917 and thus get a better appreciation of the history of this wonderful country.” What she chose to point out, the particular anecdotes told and what she chose to eliminate from the story reflect her highly personal interpretation of the family’s early life. Today, visitors to the site may not see a perfectly accurate reproduction of the house in 1917, but they get a special perspective into how Mrs. Kennedy wanted to present her former home.

Rose Kennedy describes the living room as the main family gathering space, where she darned stockings and read to the children and Joe Kennedy read the paper or books in the evenings. Through subtle clues, the living room furnishings show signs of the Kennedys’ wealth, education, and culture. The piano, described as another family activity, illustrates the importance of music to Rose Kennedy and her family. The Kennedys also owned a Victrola, which would have offered recorded music, which she chose not to include in the refurnishing.

In the room where John F. Kennedy was born, his mother focuses her description on the bed where she gave birth and her first moments with her baby. During the 1960s refurnishing, project lead Robert Luddington pursued reproductions of the Irish linen bedspreads described here, but they were never completed to Rose Kennedy’s satisfaction. One machine-made reproduction is on the bed of the guest bedroom.

Rose Kennedy used the nursery to focus on the children’s christenings and childhood entertainments. The christening gown exhibited today is a reproduction; the original is kept in storage for its long-term preservation. Rose Kennedy intentionally juxtaposed the two books highlighted. The King Arthur story, featuring noble deeds, represents those she carefully selected from book recommendations (and perhaps a nod to the later mythology around President Kennedy and “Camelot”). The Billy Whiskers stories, in contrast, were gifts from their grandmother and beloved by the children, but less appreciated by their mother for the mischievous stories and “crude” illustrations.

As more children were born, the Kennedys would later turn the guest bedroom into a second children’s room. The machine-embroidered Irish linen bedspread was reproduced in the 1960s for Rose Kennedy, though she was never entirely satisfied.

Rose Kennedy’s description of her study reinforces her role overseeing and running the household. She particularly emphasizes her card file system on her children, an illustration of her organized, “scientific” approach to motherhood.

The dining room has the highest concentration of original furnishings, including the table, chairs, and most of its setting. Rose Kennedy emphasized this “most important room in the house for much of our family life” with anecdotes of family community and parental instruction, although many of these conversations probably took place at Abbotsford Road house where the Kennedys moved in 1920.

Rose Kennedy describes a busy kitchen full of activity. The Kennedys employed two domestic servants – a live-in cook and nurse – who did much of the work in the kitchen. During the refurnishing project, Kennedy had the least specific memories of this room, and most of its furnishings are reproductions or period pieces. Amidst the memory of “hectic hours” of cooking and washing, Rose Kennedy also underscored the importance of her neighborhood and her religion as part of her family life. When the house first opened, visitors came through the front door, explored the museum space, and exited through the back door near the kitchen. Today, visitors exit into the basement visitor center. Like Rose Kennedy, we hope you have enjoyed your visit to the Kennedy home and her insight into its significance.

data.description: In this accessible and family-friendly short walking tour, explore native plants and their traditional uses along this trail. People have lived in this area for centuries, long before it became a park. Understanding how to use native plants made life more enjoyable; plants served as food, fuel, and other valuable resources. This area offers restrooms and accessible hiking opportunities to the Running Eagle Falls and along the Running Eagle Falls Nature Trail.

images.altText: A small wayside of an illustrated serviceberry with explanatory text.
images.caption: Learn about native plants along this nature trail.
images.title: Running Eagle Falls Nature Trail

stops.significance:
Glacier National Park is home to at least 1,132 species of vascular plants (those containing vessels that conduct water and nutrients). There are 88 annual or biennial plant species and 804 types of perennial herbs. Included in these numbers are 127 non-native species. Sixty-seven vascular and 42 non-vascular plant species found in Glacier Park are listed as "sensitive" by the State of Montana.

What role do plants play in your life?

Look out at your surroundings. Take a few minutes to take it all in. What do you see? Can you spot Pokintsomo, or Cow parsnip?

Although the difference between a "tree" and a "shrub" is qualitative, botanists count 90 or so species in Glacier Park as shrubs and 20 as trees. 

Visitors to Glacier are permitted to pick, by hand, a quart of berries a day. In order to protect the natural environment most other types of harvesting, including harvesting of mushrooms, is prohibited. Make sure you know how to identify berries before consuming them.

“This abundance of berries feels like a pure gift from the land. I have not earned, paid for, nor labored for them. There is no mathematics of worthiness that reckons I deserve them in any way. And yet here they are—along with the sun and the air and the birds and the rain, gathering in the towers of cumulonimbi. You could call them natural resources or ecosystem services, but the Robins and I know them as gifts. We both sing gratitude with our mouths full.” - Robin Wall Kimmerer

Can you spot an okonoki or serviceberry? 

Visitors to Glacier are permitted to pick, by hand, a quart of berries a day. In order to protect the natural environment most other types of harvesting, including harvesting of mushrooms, is prohibited. Make sure you know how to identify berries before consuming them.

Look around - do you see something red or orange? Do you see white flowers? Mountain ash are fairly small and their clumps of orange berries add winter color to the Glacier landscape.

Glacier National Park’s Red Buses are iconic pieces in the Park’s history. Glacier currently has over 30 Red Buses -- all from the 1930’s -- in operation that drive visitors around the park and transport over 60,000 tourists each summer. The earlier model Red Buses, which arrived in Glacier National Park in 1914, provided the first motorized transportation to visitors in any national park. The red color of the buses was inspired by the ripe Mountain Ash berry that is found in Glacier National Park.

These are not recommended for picking. While safe to eat, they are not tasty.

When ripe, bright red thimbleberries pop out among the green leaves. Can you spot one of these tasty treats? 

Rubus parviflorus, commonly called thimbleberry, is a species of Rubus, native to western and northern North America, and the Great Lakes region.

Visitors to Glacier are permitted to pick, by hand, a quart of berries a day. It's recommended to pick and enjoy thimbleberries while fresh, as they do not keep well. In order to protect the natural environment most other types of harvesting, including harvesting of mushrooms, is prohibited. Make sure you know how to identify berries before consuming them.

Have you had huckleberries? This berry is very popular among visitors and locals!

The huckleberry (Vaccinium membranaceum) is closely related to some of your other favorite berries. The cranberry, blueberry, bilberry, and even the lingonberry are all part of the same genus as the huckleberry, Vaccinium.

Species of Vaccinium like acidic soil, and grow on every continent but Australia and Antarctica. They are an important food source for butterflies, moths, birds, grizzly bears, and, of course, people. Glacier’s grizzly bears have been known to eat 30,000 berries in a single day!

Visitors to Glacier are permitted to pick, by hand, a quart of berries a day. In order to protect the natural environment most other types of harvesting, including harvesting of mushrooms, is prohibited. Make sure you know how to identify berries before consuming them.

This is a species complex of flowering plants in the family Adoxaceae, native to most of Europe. Common names include elder, elderberry, black elder, European elder, European elderberry and European black elderberry. It grows in a variety of conditions including both wet and dry fertile soils, primarily in sunny locations.

In 1961, Glacier National Park Naturalist Donald Robinson wrote: 

"To some people, trees merely furnish a convenient patch of shade, a spot to hold a picnic, or a means of beautifying the landscape. Others are beginning to realize more and more the value of trees and forests to our immediate welfare and our American way of life. Our entire course of history is closely tied in with the forests and their uses. Our present day economy relies to a great extent on the presence of our remaining forests. Not the least of these values is the recreation and inspiration derived from the few remaining virgin stands set aside by the people, in our national parks and other National Park Service areas."

"Black cottonwood is typically a Pacific Coast tree, seldom reaching as far east as the Rocky Mountains. In Glacier National Park, it is found along watercourses and lakes at low elevations. On the western slopes, it grows much larger than on the east, mainly because of the less severe weather and heavier forest cover."

Look up and around. Take in your surroundings. What do you see? Can you spot thinleaf alder? 

Thinleaf alder, is common at lower elevations along streams and water courses. It also forms dense thickets at times, but the trunks grow more or less erect or branching out in several directions, seldom over 15 feet in height.

data.description: Russian America was the term for Russian colonial possessions in North America (namely Alaska) from the mid-1700s to 1867. Its capital, Novo-Arkhangelsk is now present day Sitka. Following the Aleutian chain of islands in pursuit of sea otter pelts, Russian ships landed on the shores of Sitka in 1799. The stops on this tour bring to light what we may not have learned in school about that brief but important time in Alaskan history.

data.description: Explore the outdoors at Sagamore Hill! This tour features several stops of significance to the Roosevelt Family, such as the Roosevelt Home, the pet cemetery, Old Orchard, and the beach on Cold Spring Harbor. This tour is approximately 1.7 miles long and can take one or two hours to complete. Most of the paths are paved, with dirt sections on the carriage path and nature trail. The nature trail section, which begins adjacent to Old Orchard, has moderately steep sections and some beach walking.

images.altText: A park ranger points to a large gray and brick colored house with several visitors nearby.
images.caption: Explore the outdoors at Sagamore Hill!
images.title: Grounds Walk

stops.significance: Located along the main walking path leading to the Roosevelt Home, this wayside exhibit shows an illustrated aerial depiction the buildings and fields of the Sagamore Hill property circa 1918. It serves as the first stop on the self-guided audio tour.

Sagamore Hill was the home of Theodore Roosevelt, 26th President of the United States, from 1885 until his death in 1919. The home served as the “Summer White House” during Roosevelt’s presidency. The Queen Anne or shingle style house has 23 rooms and sits atop the highest point on Cove Neck, affording the family a view of Oyster Bay harbor to the west (which today is blocked by trees across the road). Roosevelt was most concerned with comfort and function rather than style or grandeur when planning the house and wanted a large "piazza" or porch facing the water, a library and parlor, plenty of bedrooms for family and guests, and large fireplaces. The rooms of the home are filled with mementos of Roosevelt’s many hunting trips, gifts from around the world, and reminders of his major accomplishments as a soldier and statesman.

The site of the Roosevelt’s tennis court was located near present-day Sagamore Hill Road. Theodore and the rest of the Roosevelt family enjoyed friendly competition in this shady spot at the bottom of the hill, often making up their own special rules of the game, which allowed for a “let” if a ball that might have landed fairly hit an overhanging branch. There are no known photographs of Theodore Roosevelt playing tennis – he believed that the game was considered a sport for society’s elite and a photo of him engaged in a match might spoil his public image.

The Roosevelt family had a menagerie of pets including dogs, guinea pigs, horses, and even a badger. Many of their pets were buried at the pet cemetery, in a shady spot north of the Roosevelt Home. Some of the pets had their names engraved on a stone under the heading of "Faithful Friends," though there were many more animal companions buried here than are named on the memorial.

The Roosevelt's garden was located on three acres north and west of what is now the parking lot. The family grew vegetables, such as potatoes, beans, lettuce and carrots, as well as fruits such as berries, grapes, peaches, and plums. In addition to food for the table, Mrs. Roosevelt kept a cutting garden for decorative flowers to adorn the Roosevelt home. The structure near the the present-day road was the gardener's shed, where gardener Alfred Davis lived and worked tending to the fruits and vegetables while keeping the Roosevelt children from trampling the flowers and eating too many berries.

Formerly the residence of Theodore Roosevelt Jr, the home now serves as a visitor center and museum. Ted and his wife Eleanor Alexander Roosevelt built the house they called “Old Orchard” in 1937-1938 on four acres of land purchased from Ted’s mother in the Sagamore Hill apple orchard.

Explore the woodlands and beach of Sagamore Hill on the nature trail. The trail is a 0.7 mile loop of easy to moderate difficulty that leads through an oak-tulip forest to a salt marsh and beach. Visitors can see a variety of wildlife such as songbirds, herons, egrets, osprey, bald eagles, fiddler crabs, white-tail deer, and ducks depending on the season. This short trail includes some steep uphill and downhill sections.

On the easternmost boundary of Sagamore Hill lies Eel Creek and Cold Spring Harbor. Eel Creek is a saltwater tidal creek and salt marsh which is home to marsh grass, mollusks, crabs, fish, and wading birds. On the opposite side of the footbridge is a beach on the western shore of Cold Spring Harbor and Oyster Bay National Wildlife Refuge. During the Roosevelt family's time here, they maintained a footbridge, a shack for changing into swimming attire, and a shed to store rowboats. The children enjoyed swimming and playing in the sand, while TR's favorite activity was rowing.

data.description: Coast Salish people have fished in the waters off of San Juan Island since time immemorial. The first trade between Euro-Americans and Native people on this island was for preserved salmon. In the 19th and 20th centuries a major fish preserving industry grew, prospered, and declined on San Juan Island. This tour explores the ecological causes for this industry, the Native Americans, European and Asian immigrants, and old island families who were a part of this industry.

images.altText: Black and white photograph of an industrial floor filled to overflowing with salmon
images.caption: San Juan Island's seemingly limitless fish resources led to a thriving salmon canning industry
images.title: Salmon Cannery Floor, Friday Harbor

park.fullName: San Juan Island National Historical Park
park.name: San Juan Island

stops.significance:
In 2007, Bill Jakle who grew up in this area, "remember[ed] [that] when I was a kid they had 60 men, at least, on those lifting places. And they had cookhouses and bunkhouses on South Beach."  

Little remains of this thriving f industry, but San Juan Island's abundant fishery has provided income and sustenance for thousands of years. Coast Salish people lived for thousands of years in what are today’s park lands, where numerous people fished for salmon and halibut and preserved their surplus for trade and winter sustenance. Hudson's Bay Company traders first came to San Juan to purchase excess fish from the Tribes who lived and thrived here for generations. 

 In the late 19th century, enhanced canning technology attracted big business to the Salmon Bank. Major corporations, such as the Alaska Packers Association employed fishermen, purchased fish from locals, and canned their haul on this island. Though the yield has declined substantially, if you look to these waters in summer, you can see fishing boats.

This rock takes its name from the Alaska Packers Association (APA), a major corporation/cartel that set prices and production quotas in the salmon industry. The APA was one of three major corporations that by the early 20th century came to dominate the salmon industry and deplete fish populations on San Juan Island.  

 The fish traps that these corporations built demanded large amounts of capital and labor to operate. Their extreme efficiency made independent fishing less profitable, and corporations took much of the harvest that Coast Salish and independent Euro-American fishers once caught. 

 

Nonetheless, corporate fisheries provided opportunities for local people. Their canneries purchased the fish caught by independent fishing entrepreneurs like Henry Cayou, hired local men and women to work in their salmon operations, and purchased supplies from local farmers.

The fishing industry's extreme efficiency decimated the salmon stocks. With less fish in the water, the salmon industry declined.

This protected cove was used by Coast Salish people prior to and after the settlement of the island for reef net fishing. Reef netting is a unique form of indigenous fishing developed by indigenous Coast Salish Tribes in the San Juan Islands.  

Reef net fishing sites use two parallel canoes with an attached net between them. Cedar bark rope interspersed with eelgrass is attached to the nets and canoes, creating an artificial topography that makes the net itself appear to be the ocean floor. This technology lured the salmon into swimming up and into the net where they were trapped. When the net grew sufficiently full, Tribal fishermen pulled up the net, catching dozens of fish at one time.

At this site, Henry Cayou, a Coast Salish entrepreneur, operated the most successful independent fish trap in the San Juan fishing industry in the early 20th century.  Bill Jakle, who grew up in the fishing industry, called Cayou, "a rich Indian" because of his successful trip which allowed him "to catch king salmon headed for the Fraser River. Sometimes he'd get 20 ton lifts." 

 Though Cayou often sold his fish to the major fish packing companies, he also owned his own cannery on Lopez Island. He was also a successful local politician and was responsible for bringing electricity to the San Juan Islands by founding the Orcas Power and Light Corporation. 

Today, the Cayou Channel between Orcas Island and Shaw Island is named after him to honor his impact on our community. Numerous Cayou descendants live in the San Juan Islands. Henry Cayou's historical legacy demonstrates the prominent and important role that the fishing industry played in our community in the early 20th century.

From this site, as you look south, you will notice a hulking abandoned industrial building. This structure, constructed in the early 20th century by local farmer John M. Jackson was one of the salmon canneries that processed and preserved fish from our island's waters. 

 

San Juan Island's fish canneries took advantage of the abundant local salmon harvest, packing the best and freshest fish for sale in distant markets. At the peak of the industry, nearly 1,000 people worked in the salmon canneries, making it one of the island's major employers. To get such a large amount of labor to the island, the packeries employed individuals who were normally discriminated against in the industry due to their race or ethnicity. In the late 19th century, it employed Chinese men and Native American women and in the early 20th century, Japanese immigrants made up much of the workforce. 

Imagine this building in its prime:  filled with 100s of workers, thousands of salmon, and the machines that canned and preserved  them.

Here at the Whale Museum, you can learn about Southern Resident Killer Whales, a critically endangered species whose health and population numbers rely upon healthy salmon populations. Southern Residents rely primarily on chinook salmon as a food source, requiring about 400 pounds of salmon per day to maintain their health. They spend several months every summer and fall in our waters, so the health of the salmon population is critical to their survival and recovery. 

 Southern Residents' mouth structure has evolved differently than other killer whales to facilitate salmon hunting; unlike Biggs Killer Whales, they do not hunt for or eat seals or sea lions. Their salmon consumption is so immense that scientists believe that killer whales consume more salmon than seals, sea lions, and commercial fisheries. While salmon populations have increased moderately in the past 50 years, the health of Southern Residents is a major factor that regulates the legal limit for salmon fishing in our island.

data.description: Santa Fe is the oldest capital city in the US, founded in 1610, and the highest US capital at 7,000 feet. This tour leads you from the busy Plaza and other major tourist locations to lesser known sites along quiet, old Santa Fe streets. We recommend that you start at the Santa Fe Plaza, the hub of the southwest connecting the Santa Fe Trail with the Old Spanish Trail, and El Camino Real de Tierra Adentro. All three are national historic trails.

images.altText: Two story gothic-revival chapel.
images.caption: Visit Santa Fe, New Mexico for a step back in time.
images.title: Loretto Chapel

stops.significance:
Welcome to Santa Fe, where three historic trails meet at the historic Santa Fe Plaza! Santa Fe is the oldest capital city in the US, founded in 1610, and the highest US capital at 7,000 feet.

We recommend that you start at the Santa Fe Plaza, the hub of the southwest connecting the Santa Fe Trail with the Old Spanish Trail, and El Camino Real de Tierra Adentro. All three are national historic trails.

You can follow the Santa Fe Trail Walking Tour to visit sites within the historic core of the city.

The Plaza marked the Southwestern end of the 900 mile Santa Fe Trail that stretches from Santa Fe to Old Franklin, Missouri. It was also the north marker for the old Camino Real de Tierra Adentro, the 650 mile trail that continues down to Mexico City.

The 33 foot tall Soldiers’ Monument, a granite monolith built in 1868, honors Union soldiers who died at the 1862 Civil War Battle of Glorieta, as well as Santa Fe Trail pioneers and travelers.

Placed in 1901, the Daughters of the American Revolution's (DAR’s) backpack-sized Kearny monument is on the northeast side of the plaza facing the sidewalk. The large grey stone honors General Kearny, the man who led a 1,600 man 'Army of the West' across the Santa Fe Trail in 1846. He claimed then-Mexican land for the US, and seized New Mexico without firing a shot.

The four foot End of the Trail monument near the Plaza’s southeast corner was erected in 1911. It is one of the DAR’s 170 surviving Santa Fe Trail markers erected in 1905-1914.

Since 1610, this block-long, one-story adobe building has housed the offices and living quarters of 58 Spanish Colonial Governors, 16 Mexican Governors, four military and three civilian governors during U.S. rule, and 17 Territorial Governors. The building endured the 1680 Pueblo Indian Revolt; the 1692-1693 Spanish reconquest; the 1846 arrival of Brigadier General Kearny (who raised the U.S. flag here and declared New Mexico a part of the U.S.); and the 1862 invasion of Texas Confederate troops. 

Santa Fe Trail traders once rented rooms here from which they sold their wares. At night in his living quarters here in 1878-80, New Mexico Territorial Governor Lew Wallace completed his second novel, Ben Hur, which made him rich and famous. 

Both the Palace of the Governors and the New Mexico History Museum have exhibits related to the Santa Fe Trail.

Roadrunner Cowbelles’ Trail Plaque: Along with an iron hitching rail on Washington Ave., this 1976 bronze plaque honors early Santa Fe Trail drivers. 

Cemented into a brick wall is an old weathered bronze plaque. It reads, "Roadrunner Cowbelle's dedicate this hitching post at the end of the trail to American gentleman and their horses for their glorious role in winning the west."
stops.assetName: Roadrunner Cowbelles’ Santa Fe Trail Plaque

stops.significance:
At 109, 111 & 115 East Palace Avenue, peek into the plazas that date back to the Santa Fe Trail era, located behind the buildings along Palace Avenue - they host shops and restaurants today.

In 1828 to the mid-1830s, the home that became Trujillo and Prince plazas was the modest residence of French-Canadian fur trapper and trader Antoine Robidoux, Brigadier General Kearny’s interpreter in 1846. His widow sold it to Territorial Supreme Court Chief Justice L. Bradford Prince in 1879. Sena Plaza, the home of Juan Estevan and Maria de Rosario Sena y Alarid was given to their son, Manuel, in 1844. He and his son, Civil War hero Jose, Sr., expanded it into a 33-room home by the 1860s; Prince bought it in 1886.

Overlooking the northeast side of the Plaza is the Italian-style Catron Block, built in 1891. Powerful lawyer, banker, and politician Thomas Catron occupied its second floor offices. It replaced Santa Fe Trail merchant James Johnson’s two-story adobe and wood-frame building, a Santa Fe Trail landmark built in 1847. In the 1870s, Johnson’s building housed Catron’s offices, the First National Bank, and the Santa Fe Daily New Mexican. Catron acquired it in 1881. The Catron Block stayed in the family until 1927.

William and Mary Dodson Donoho, who crossed the Santa Fe Trail from Missouri, operated an inn here known as Los Estados Unidos (spanish for United States) House in 1833-37. By 1847 it had become the Santa Fe House. By 1848 it was the U.S. Hotel, offering liquor and gaming. It became the Exchange Hotel in 1851. The one-story, flat-roofed, Territorial Style adobe hotel began losing clients after 1880, as more modern hotels arose. It was razed in 1919.

The La Fonda inn opened in 1922. The Atchison, Topeka and Santa Fe Railway bought it in 1925 and leased it to Fred Harvey. In 1927 it underwent its first expansion, got its Pueblo Revival look, and was a Harvey House until 1968.
This DAR-placed, 1905 cast bronze plaque is set at eye level in an exterior adobe stucco wall on the west side of Old Santa Fe Trail, across from the La Fonda hotel.
stops.assetName: Santa Fe Trail Plaque, Old Santa Fe Trail

stops.significance: The Spanish Colonial presidio (military garrison) chapel, Nuestra Senora de la Luz (Our Lady of Light), was built here circa 1760, and razed in 1859.

Quebec-born Santa Fe Trail trader Francois Aubry, whose enduring fame came in 1848, after racing on horseback across the

Santa Fe Trail from here to Independence, Missouri in record time (five days, 16 hours) to win a $1,000 bet, died here in 1854 after a bar room argument with ex-newspaperman Richard Weightman. His friends, the Montreal-born Mercures, Joseph and Henri, tried to intervene, but Aubry’s knife wound was fatal.
stops.assetName: Mercure Brothers Store Site (La Plaza Galeria)

stops.significance: Westport, Missouri merchants Gustavus Elsberg and Jacob Amberg crossed the Santa Fe Trail in 1856, and opened the two-story Ellsberg & Amberg Building here in 1864. They parted ways in 1869, but their 26-room building lasted until 1917. When Santa Fe Trail land baron Lucien Maxwell founded this bank in 1870 and sold it in 1871 to Santa Fe law partners, Thomas Catron and Stephen Elkins, it was housed in the James Johnson Building, across the Plaza. In 1954, a former 1921-24 movie theater here was transformed into the Pueblo Revival Style bank building you see today.
stops.assetName: Ellsberg & Amberg Store Site (1st National Bank)

stops.significance: In her published memoirs (1954; Land Of Enchantment), Santa Fe Trail traveler Marian Russell recalled her widowed mother, Eliza, operating a $45 a month boarding house here in 1852-54. Circa 1871 it was replaced by the 16-room Ft. Marcy HQ Building. The NM Fine Arts Museum, home today to SF artist Gerald Cassidy’s 1930 oil painting, End Of The Trail (1850; aka Santa Fe Plaza, ), replaced the old building in 1917.
stops.assetName: Eliza Sloan Boarding House & Ft. Marcy HQ Building Sites (New Mexico Museum of Art)

stops.significance: A commercial building since 1980, this restored two-story adobe house, crowned by an Italian Style portico (entry porch) to its second floor front balcony, was built circa 1890 for Santa Fe Trail trader Delgado, who bought the land in 1877. The home stayed in his family until 1970.

Born in Sonora, Mexico, Doña Maria Gertrudes Barcelo operated her lavishly decorated saloon and gambling hall here from 1832-36 until her death. Reputedly the best monte dealer in Santa Fe, the red-haired, cigar-smoking “Doña Tules” soon grew wealthy. Scorned by many of the city’s residents, the business woman shrewdly welcomed the U.S. by funding its 1846 wartime expedition to Chihuahua.
stops.assetName: Doña Tules’s Gambling Hall Site (Bokum Building)

stops.significance: Doña "Tules" Barcelo’s one-story, flat-roofed, courtyard home was just across the street from her saloon and gambling hall. Born around 1800-1811, she died here in 1852. The Pueblo Revival Style court house replaced it in 1940.
stops.assetName: Doña Tules’s Home Site (Santa Fe County Courthouse)

stops.significance: One of two surviving Ft. Marcy officers’ quarters built around 1871, it became a 10-day vacation home for former President Ulysses S. Grant and his family in 1880. Bought in 1904 by Bergere, the England-born son of a wealthy Italian shipping magnate, the 7-room home got a full second floor and Pueblo Revival Style makeover in 1926. It stayed in the family until 1975. Only the central hallway’s cherry wood staircase and one fireplace remain from the old Santa Fe Trail days.
stops.assetName: Alfred Bergere House (Georgia O’Keeffe Research Center)

stops.significance: This surviving Ft. Marcy officers’ quarters, once the Quartermaster’s home, was remodeled in the Pueblo Revival Style in 1916. It became the lifetime home of the Edgar Lee Hewett, the Director of the Museum of New Mexico (in 1909) and School of American Research (1917). Hewett died in 1946 and his wife in 1960. After President Teddy Roosevelt gave downtown Ft. Marcy’s 17 acres to the city in 1904, the other 5 officers’ quarters (and military post buildings) were eventually razed.
stops.assetName: Edgar Hewett House (Museum of NM Foundation Office)

stops.significance:
Built circa 1786 for Lobato, an armorer and soldier of Santa Fe’s Royal Spanish Garrison. Santa Fe Trail trader Don Gaspar Ortiz y Alarid bought the buildint in 1852. The ruins of Santa Fe’s fortress and powder magazine, La Garita (little guardhouse), built in 1807, stood just northeast of the house until 1954. 

Private residence; photo permissions not granted.

Built in 1846, this U. S. fort was the first in New Mexico Territory (and is the only fort left in the United States from the Mexican American War). Built for 280 men, this irregularly shaped star fort was never garrisoned. Located on a hill 50 yards higher in elevation than the Plaza, its 14 cannons could have confronted an approaching Mexican army or suppressed a local uprising.

Begun in 1869, this sandstone-block, neo- Romanesque Style church was never finished; its plans called for two 165-foot tall steeples and an 85-foot tall dome. It slowly enveloped La Parroquia (the parish church), a Santa Fe Trail landmark that was dismantled starting in 1884. In the north transept, a remnant of the early 1700s parish church, is a two-foot tall bulto (statue) of the oldest Marian figure in the U.S. It came here from Mexico in 1625. Hungary-born NYC sculptor Jeno Juszko’s seven-foot tall, bronze statue of Jean Baptiste Lamy honors the France-born cleric who arrived here in 1851. An energetic visionary, Lamy started a school for girls in 1853; a school for boys in 1858; and a hospital and orphanage in 1865. About 2,000 people viewed the statue’s 1915 unveiling.
stops.assetName: La Parroquia Site (Cathedral Basilica of St. Francis of Assisi)

stops.significance: Santa Fe Trail bride Susan Magoffin and her husband, trail trader Samuel, lived here in a flat-roofed, four-room adobe home built before 1836, for five weeks in 1846. Here she continued writing in her diary, published in a 1926 book, Down the Santa Fe Trail & Into Mexico. Santa Fe attorney Eugene Fiske bought the home in 1881 and expanded it. The Fiskes sold the house in 1912. In 1949 it was razed to make way for the La Fonda’s first parking lot.
stops.assetName: Magoffin-Fiske Home Site (La Fonda Parking Garage)

stops.significance:
This Gothic Revival chapel, started in 1873 and completed in 1878, was built by young French architect Projectus Mouly for the Sisters of Loretto. In 1855, Jean Baptiste Lamy moved the Loretto Academy here into a former hotel he bought in 1854, La Casa Americana (the American House). That two-story, pitched roof building stood here (next to the south side of the chapel) until 1882 when a two-story convent replaced it and a three-story girls’ school was built on the north side of the chapel. The convent and school were razed in 1971 to make way for the Inn at Loretto.

The chapel is famed for its 20-foot high, circular staircase, built in 1878. While the Lorretines insisted the builder was St. Joseph, recent evidence points to French master carpenter Francois-Jean Rochas.
stops.assetName: Loretto Chapel (Chapel of Our Lady of Light)

stops.significance: Here Santa Fe Trail traders once camped and their animals drank and grazed. The 12-acre, tree-shaded park was built in 1935.
Italy-born Santa Fe Trail trader Tudesqui bought this modest adobe home in 1839. When it was built is unknown. Purple wisteria bloom in its tiny courtyard every June.

Owned in 1747 by Gregorio Crespin, the house’s vigas (ceiling beams) date back to 1720. Owner Benito Roibal served in the Santa Fe militia in the mid-1860s and traveled the Santa Fe Trail as a soldier.

This adobe chapel is a Santa Fe Trail landmark, and was in use before 1626,. Partly destroyed in the 1680 Pueblo Revolt, it was rebuilt in 1710. Its bulto (wooden statue) of St. Michael predates 1709; its wooden reredos (altar screen), painted in 1798, sits above the original altar. Its jewel-studded bell was cast in 1856. The church served the Barrio de Analco (the District on the Other Side of the Water) and St. Michael’s College daily until 1967.
stops.assetName: San Miguel Chapel in Santa Fe

stops.significance: When Santa Fe Trail trader James Johnson bought this adobe home in 1849, he expanded it to 19 rooms under a single, unifying zaguan (vestibule). Behind his Territorial Style home, Santa Fe Trail merchants kept their horses and oxen in his corrals before their return trip east.

Built in 1776-96, this cruciform adobe church is the oldest extant shrine to Our Lady of Guadalupe in the U.S. Its vigas (ceiling beams), corbels (brackets), and choir loft came from the military chapel, La Castrense. It’s at the east end of Agua Fria St., a remnant of El Camino Real de Tierra Adentro (the Royal Road to the Interior Land), later known as the Chihuahua Trail. Outside is Mexican artist Doña Georgina Farias’s 12-foot tall, 2008 bronze statue, Nuestra Senora (Our Lady) de Guadalupe.

data.description: Take a drive through the Saratoga Battlefield and learn about the historic battles that took place here in 1777. There are stops along the 10-mile road with accompanying audio that gives you a chronological history of the Battles of Saratoga.

images.caption: Tour Road

data.title: Saratoga Battlefield Road Tour

data.description: This outdoor memorial marks the site of the British Surrender after the Battles of Saratoga. This was the first time in world history that the British Army surrendered to another country. On the morning of October 17, 1777, a British army over 6,000 strong made preparations to surrender arms and ordnance to the Northern Army forces of the United States of America.

images.altText: Two cannons on a grassy lawn near a short stone informational wall sign with bronze plaques on it.
images.caption: Saratoga Surrender Site
images.title: Saratoga Surrender Site

stops.significance: This outdoor memorial marks the site of the British Surrender after the Battles of Saratoga. This was the first time in world history that the British Army surrendered to another country. On the morning of October 17, 1777, a British army over 6,000 strong made preparations to surrender arms and ordnance to the Northern Army forces of the United States of America. British Lt. General John Burgoyne rode to meet his conqueror, Major General Horatio Gates, and the two generals and their staffs retired to this hilltop to mark the occasion.

data.title: Saratoga Surrender Site

data.description: The treacherous currents and offshore rocks here have foundered many ships. In addition, Point Reyes is one of the windiest and foggiest places on the Pacific Coast. From shipwrecks to lighthouse and harrowing tales of heroism, discover the rich maritime history of the Point Reyes area on this tour. Internet and cell service are limited; downloading the app prior to your arrival is recommended.

images.altText: A short three story lighthouse on a rocky cliff overlooking the ocean at sunset.
images.caption: The Point Reyes Lighthouse has illuminated the headlands since 1870.
images.title: Illuminating the Point Reyes Headlands

stops.significance: Begin at the Lighthouse Visitor Center to set the scene for this maritime tour. Imagine being a ship out at sea as you walk up the Lighthouse Road and look down at the steep and rocky shoreline of Point Reyes. The visitor center has exhibits and information about early shipwrecks and maritime history at Point Reyes.

When the Point Reyes Lighthouse is open for tours, it provides a glimpse into the 19th Century, when machines were king. Enormous metal structures were created on a colossal scale for art, science, and industry. The first-order lens—with 1032 pieces of hand-ground crystal—and the clockworks that drive it are in good condition and look almost as if they had just arrived.

The brass nameplate proudly announces its origins in Paris and the date of manufacture (1867). Take a walk back in time and visit the compelling beauty and distinctive lighthouse.

Before the establishment of Life Saving and Lifeboat Stations, the remains of vessels littered the beaches and the rocks along the United States coastline. Horrified spectators witnessed the drowning of passengers and crew, helpless to do anything. In the same waves that smashed hulls and took lives of the unsuspecting, some heard a call to action. In 1890, the United States Life-Saving Service (USLSS) established a station at Point Reyes with a keeper and a crew of seven surfmen on a lonely stretch of the Point Reyes Beach, which was notorious for its pounding surf and bad weather. The surfmen patrolled the beaches of Point Reyes with an ever-vigilant eye, looking for shipwrecks and their desperate crews. They walked the beaches day and night, with the fog chilling them to the bone and the wind blasting sand at the unprotected skin of their faces. The surfmen's positions were poorly paid, difficult, and full of danger. In 1927, operations moved from the Point Reyes Beach to the protected waters of Drakes Bay

stops.assetName: The Historic KPH Maritime Radio Receiving Station at Point Reyes National Seashore
The U.S. Life-Saving Service Cemetery at Point Reyes National Seashore

data.title: Saving Lives at the Seashore

data.description: The Scenic Drive is an 8-mile (13 km) paved road. Allot 2 hours roundtrip to drive the Scenic Drive and the two dirt spur roads that lead into deep canyons, Grand Wash and Capitol Gorge. These dirt spur roads are usually suitable for passenger vehicles and small RVs up to 27 feet in length. Roads may close due to snow, ice, and flash flooding. An entrance fee is charged for the Scenic Drive. Pay at the self-pay station at Stop 1 or purchase a pass for all federal lands at the visitor center.

images.altText: A silver car on a paved road next to huge banded cliffs of brown and tan.
images.caption: The Scenic Drive is an 8-mile (13 km) paved road.
images.title: Scenic Drive

stops.significance: Capitol Reef’s sedimentary rock layers tell us stories from Earth’s ancient past.
What is the Waterpocket Fold? The tilted cliffs along the Scenic Drive are part of this massive wrinkle in the Earth’s crust.
Ancient environments determine today’s rock types and colors.
Erosion changes the landscape, from small holes in the cliff, to huge natural arches.
What are those long black streaks striping the cliff walls?
Juniper trees showcase dark twisting bark and light blue berries.
Summer monsoon season brings heavy rain and flash flooding to Capitol Reef. The torrents of water can be spectacularly beautiful, but also deadly.
The incredible, edible pinyon pine helps many species survive in a harsh desert environment.
Desert bighorn sheep are often spotted in Capitol Gorge along narrow cliff ledges.
Why is it called “Capitol Reef?”
The Capitol Gorge trail features natural pools of water and markings from early pioneers and travelers.

data.title: Scenic Drive Wayside Tour

data.description: The park's self-guided driving tour takes you around the park to key locations during the Battle of Second Manassas. The 13 stops on this tour will take you chronologically through the battle. Each stop has a parking lot and interpretive signage which provide information about the importance of that site in the overall battle. Walking trails with interpretive signage begin at most driving tour stops.

images.altText: Two cannons sit in a foggy, open field
images.caption: Two cannons sit in an open field
images.title: Artillery at Manassas

stops.significance:
On August 28, 1862, Federal and Confederate soldiers clashed on the fields around the Brawner Farm. In the immediate vicinity of the house, Union troops of the future "Iron Brigade" clashed with the "Stonewall Brigade." More troops were fed into the struggle by both sides, and the lines exchanged volleys for nearly two hours, in places only 80 yards apart. Darkness brought an end to the bloody fighting. Nearly one-third of those engaged became casualties during this stubborn combat.  Overnight, the Union Army began converging on the Old Bull Run Battlefield. The Battle of Second Manassas had begun. 

The Brawner Farm Interpretive Center, open seasonally, provides an overview to the Second Battle of Manassas. 

The Brawner Farm Loop Trail traces the opposing lines of battle during the 28 August clash.  The trail, which begins and ends at the farmhouse, includes interpretive signage along the way that relates the story of the opening fighting at Second Manassas.

As the battle at Brawner Farm began, Capt. Joseph Campbell's Battery B, 4th U.S. Artillery, deployed here. The fire of these six guns effectively silenced the opposing Confederate batteries.  The 6th Wisconsin Infantry charged through this area to engage Confederate soldiers approaching from the north.  

Two days later, on the afternoon of August 30, 1862, Capt. William Chapman's Dixie Artillery occupied this same elevation contributing to the repulse of the huge Union attack on Stonewall Jackson's line at the Deep Cut of the unfinished railroad. A converging fire of 36 Confederate cannon from massed batteries on the Brawner Farm shattered the Union infantry maneuvering over the open fields. Chapman's four guns joined this concentrated fire to strike the flank and rear of the wavering Union troops, hastening their retreat.

This structure served as a field hospital during both First and Second Manassas. Built in 1848, its early years were spent as the home of farmer Henry P. Matthew and his family.

During the Second Battle of Manassas, two wounded Union soldiers, Eugene P. Geer and Charles Brehm, both of the 5th New York Infantry, found their way into one of the upstairs rooms of the Stone House, where they carved their names into the floorboards. Brehm survived, but Geer died of his wounds. Their carved names can still be seen in the floorboards today.


While here: 
The House, open seasonally, includes exhibits of the history of the house and its use before, during, and after the Civil War. On the second floor are two carvings from soldiers from the 5th New York who were wounded on 30 August 1862. 

Climb Buck Hill
A short trail behind the House leads to the summit of Buck Hill. An interpretive panel at the top describes the hill's role as Union General John Pope's headquarters at Second Manassas.
stops.assetName: Auto Tour Stop #3: The Stone House

stops.significance:
The Matthews Hill landscape witnessed severe action in both First and Second Manassas. 

On 21 July 1861, the head of US General Irvin McDowell's flanking column reached this area shortly after 10 a.m.  More than 13,000 Union troops lagged behind schedule and strung out for nearly six miles, with the rear of the column still on the Warrenton Turnpike east of the Stone Bridge.

Upon emerging out of the woods, the Union vanguard collided with Confederate skirmishers atop Matthews Hill. Soldiers of the 2nd Rhode Island Infantry deployed and started across the field toward the crest of the hill. The Matthews Hill walking trail begins in the parking lot and traverses the scene of this opening clash of First Manassas. 

13 months later, on 29 August 1862, this area was the staging area for many of the Federal attacks against "Stonewall" Jackson's entrenched position along the Unfinished Railroad. Across Sudley Road, Federal artillery batteries provided support for the infantry assaults across these fields.

Before being defined as a battlefield, this landscape existed as the crossroads hamlet of Sudley Springs. Although it consisted of fewer than a dozen households in 1860, three features distinguished Sudley Springs from neighboring communities - a prosperous mill, a prominent church, and a popular mineral spring.

During First Manassas, throughout 21 July 1861, nearly 13,000 Union soldiers crossed Sudley Springs Fords and passed by here on their way toward the fighting on Matthews and Henry Hill. 

During the Second Battle of Manassas, on August 29, 1862, Federal tropos repeatedly attacked Stonewall Jackson's left flank - Gen. Maxcy Gregg's South Carolina brigade - in this vicinity. Exhausted and with their ammunition depleted, Gregg's troops were driven back by the late afternoon assault of Gen. Philip Kearney's Union division. Only darkness prevented a fatal collapse of the Confederate line.

"Stonewall" Jackson's wing of the Confederate army covered a front of about one and one-half miles, extending from near the Sudley Church to a point near the Brawner Farm. The center of his line rested near Driving Tour Stop #6. The focal point of Jackson's position was the bed of the unfinished railroad. The grade is still visible as it moves through the park today. 

During 29 August 1862, Union soldiers attacked various portions of Jackson's line along the Unfinished Railroad with some success but failed to follow these up with support.  

A trail from the parking lot traverses an area where Union soldiers under General Cuvier Grover launched a bayonet charge and momentarily breached the Confederate line.

The grounds around you saw the largest Federal attack of Second Manassas.  On the afternoon of 30 August, 1862, Union General Fitz John Porter launched an assault against the Confederate position at the top of the rise in front of you.  Some 8,000 US soldiers moved out of the woods along Featherbed Lane in dense formations towards the Confederate position along the Unfinished Railroad. 

The Federal infantry made a momentary breakthrough, but without enough support and exposed to raking Confederate artillery fire from the Brawner Farm less than one-half mile to the west, the Union assault was shattered a bloodily repulsed. 
 
Take the trail from the parking lot to walk in the footsteps of this Federal assault.

The small frame house stands as the only surviving original structure of the crossroad village of Groveton. Widow Lucinda Dogan and her five young children moved here shortly after their residence, “Peach Grove,” burned in 1860. The family joined to smaller outbuildings to create the present dwelling.

Fighting swirled around this hamlet on the evening of 29 August during the twilight reconnaissance and on 30 August during James Longstreet's Confederate counterattack.

This area saw active combat during on multiple days of Second Manassas. 

At twilight 29 August 1862, Confederate soldiers under General James Longstreet collided with Union soldiers under General John Hatch during a reconnaissance of the Union position.

On the afternoon of 30 August 1862, seeing the Union lines in disarray following the repulse of Porter's assault at the Deep Cut, Longstreet pushed his massive columns forward and staggered the Union left flank.  

A brief, futile stand on this ridge by the 5th and 10th New York Regiments ended in slaughter. In a matter of minutes, the 5th New York lost 123 men - the greatest loss of life in any single infantry regiment in any battle of the Civil War. 

The monuments along New York Avenue were placed after the war by veterans of the 14th Brooklyn, 5th New York and 10th New York regiments to remember the cost of war.
stops.assetName: Auto Tour Stop #9: New York Monuments

stops.significance:
In 1860, Benjamin Chinn and his family lived here in a two-and-a-half story frame farmhouse. Known as "Hazel Plain," the modest plantation comprised several hundred acres. The property was typical of those in Prince William County, yielding wheat, corn, oats, and potatoes for cash and subsistence. Like roughly one-third of their immediate neighbors, the Chinn family owned slaves.

War engulfed the Chinn homestead twice in thirteen months.  Confederate infantry surged through the Chinn property as they pushed back a Union brigade of Vermonters along the ridge. 

On the afternoon of 30 August 1862, James Longstreet's Confederate columns reached this position. Stretched along this ridge, Union soldiers desperately struggled to delay the Confederate attack to allow General John Pope to form a rear-guard on Henry Hill. 

A paved trail from the parking lot follows the ridge with panels describing the fighting in both battles that took place on this landscape.

The final clash of Second Manassas took place here along the Sudley Road.  Union General John Pope pieced together a rear-guard consisting of soldiers from Ohio, western Virginia, Pennsylvania and the US Regulars, supported by artillery.  Waves of Confederates attacked this position into the evening.  Over night, John Pope's defeated army began to retreat eastward toward the defenses of Centreville.

The plantation house of Francis Lewis, known as Portici, stood atop the ridge to your east. Massive brick chimneys flanked the frame house. The house was destroyed by fire in 1862.

The house served as Confederate headquarters during the First Battle of Manassas. Following the Battle, the house served as a hospital. Among those taken care of here were Union officers Orlando Wilcox and James B. Ricketts. 

The grounds of Portici served as the site of the 1861-1862 winter encampment for a brigade of Alabamians and Virginians commanded by General Cadmus Wilcox.  

Some of the last fighting at Second Manassas occured on these fields on 30 August 1862 when Confederate cavalry, on a mission to cut off the Union army's line of retreat, were stopped by Union cavalry.  

From the parking lot, take the mowed trail up to the Portici House site and the scene of the 1862 cavalry engagement.

The Fauquier and Alexandria Turnpike bridge over Bull Run, known simply as "the Stone Bridge," was originally built in 1825. Its ability to carry traffic across the steep sided stream even at times of high water gave the Stone Bridge a key role during the Civil War.

Following the defeat at Second Manassas, Union forces used the bridge as their primary line of retreat. In the early hours of August 31, as the last Union soldiers crossed it, the bridge was destroyed.  The current bridge was built in the mid-1880s with traffic diverted to a secondary bridge in the mid-1920s. 

From the parking lot, a 1.3 mile loop trail provides picturesque views of Bull Run and displays of wildflowers, including bluebells, in the spring and colorful foliage in the fall. This trail winds its way up to the heights above Bull Run. Along the way, you will pass interpretive panels at points of importance at First Manassas.

stops.significance: The hospital served as a place of treatment for sick and injured soldiers, however medical practices of the time often impeded recovery rather than aiding it.

To the infantry soldier, the barracks was a place of shelter where he could lay his head down at night, however it also represented work, because it was the infantry soldier who formed the backbone of the army and performed the majority of the labor and construction at Fort Scott.
The stables provided a safe place where dragoons could care for their horses and groom them for the task of patrolling and protecting the frontier.

The barracks provided the soldiers with many of the necessities of life (sleep, food, warmth, shelter, clean clothes) and some of the luxuries (recreation, companionship), yet many were discontent with living conditions.
In furnishing their quarters, officers and their wives sought to bring the comfort and culture of the East to the frontier.
:  From the post headquarters, the commanding officer coordinated the various functions vital to the operation of the military post.
The architectural features and construction elements seen at this and other buildings were meant to impress and to instill a sense of pride in those who lived and visited here
The barrels and boxes of the quartermaster storehouse contained food and other supplies that played a critical role in the army’s well being and survival.
Bread baked in the ovens of the bake house required skill from the bakers in order to meet the quality needed to maintain the health of the soldiers.

The guardhouse provided a secure holding facility for prisoners and shelter for guards who played a vital role in the fort’s protection and security by patrolling the fort, enforcing regulations, and watching prisoners.

The parade ground served as a place for the officers and enlisted men to stand on ceremony and to demonstrate their pride in the U.S. Army.  Its central location prompted the placement of certain elements vital to the fort.

data.description: The 3/4-mile-long, paved Circle Trail is open 24 hours a day all year long. It offers a chance to learn the cultural, historical, and natural history of this site. For centuries, Indigenous people have journeyed to this area to quarry pipestone and carve pipes to pray with. Pipestone National Monument exists to protect the rights of all American Indians enrolled in federally recognized tribes to quarry this soft, red stone. Enjoy the experience of the trail at your leisure any time!

images.altText: A family walking the trail on a sunny day
images.caption: The trail is open 24/7
images.title: Strolling the Trail

stops.significance: The Visitor Center has a short film about the site's cultural significance, brochures, exhibits, a park store, park staff to answer questions, and cultural demonstrators during the summer.

This spot is a chance to view the layers of a quarry pit up close. Quarriers must break through 6-10 feet of Sioux Quartzite (harder than steel!) with sledge hammers and wedges to reach the softer pipestone layer after days, weeks, or even months of hard work. If you look closely at the bottom of the wall at the end of the quarry, you can see the exposed pipestone.

Use caution - footing is uneven and the stone is as slick as ice when wet!
This is where visitors may take the South Quarry Trail to the right and view quarry pits from the trail. This trail is an out-and-back (1/2-mile round trip).
stops.assetName: South Quarry Trail Junction - Circle Trail

stops.significance: Where Abbie Gardner remembered Dakota leader Inkpaduta and his band camping at the quarries while fleeing from U.S. forces.

At this location, visitors can view an expanse of tallgrass prairie that once covered millions of acres. This prairie boasts over 500 plant species and can be an excellent spot to hear wildlife such as songbirds and boreal chorus frogs when conditions are right. Many Indigenous people use the ash tree at this location for prayer ties and offerings (please do not disturb these important items).

Beautiful outcroppings line the eastern side of the trail. Although the colors in the stones vary from light pink to an almost dark purple, none of the stone visible along this point of the trail is actually pipestone. It is all Sioux Quartzite.

The Oracle is the profile of a face in the rocks surrounded by cottonwood trees that serves as a reminder that this sacred site is a storied landscape.  Many quarriers, such as Cindy Pederson, are a wealth of stories that tie the land, the people, the water, and even the stars together. Sometimes they share these stories with visitors, adding a meaningful layer to the experience at the pipestone quarries.

**Please do go past the overlook. After enjoying the view, please return to the paved path at the bottom of the stairs. Any "off trail" paths have been created by either wildlife or visitors creating social trails. These are not actual trails.**

One of the best spots for photos or just clearing your head! Many people come just to see the waterfall while others walked away surprised it was even here. Visitors sometimes cross paths with artists like local flute player Bruce Wiegle as they draw inspiration from Winnewissa Falls.
A significant site used for centuries by Indigenous warriors to prove their bravery.
Where Joseph Nicollet and other members of his famous 1838 expedition carved their names in the rock. This rock was later used as the center point of a 1-square-mile reservation.
The wavy patterns in some of the stones are ripple marks that reveal evidence of a time in which all of the stone was sand underneath a moving body of water.
Looking up at the same pillar that is called "Leaping Rock" from below, one can see the profile of a face. This is known as "Old Stone Face" from this vantage point.
To your right along the trail is a large patch of smooth sumac. Around late August/early September the leaves of this plant turn a brilliant fire engine red.

This lake was created in the 1930s by the CCC-ID as part of Roosevelt's New Deal. The intention was to provide a swimming hole for Native American children at the Pipestone Indian Boarding School which ran from 1893-1953. Today, the water is extremely contaminated. Please do not go into the water or let pets drink from it.

The stone extracted from the quarry pit nearest the wayside comes out red with white spots, creating beautiful patterns. It is hypothesized that somewhere near this area is where the earliest quarries would have been.

These large, granite boulders have been - and still are - sacred to many people for centuries. Understood as guardians or keepers of the quarries, quarriers pray and give offerings at this location. Please do not climb on the boulders and keep a respectful distance.

data.title: Self-Guided Circle Trail Tour

data.description: This tour is the 9 mile, 10 stop auto tour of the battlefield. Each stop has a parking lot and interpretive signs providing additional information about each location. Some of the stops also are great places to start a short hike of the surrounding area.

images.altText: civil war cannon
images.caption: Cannon at Antietam
images.title: Artillery piece

stops.significance: The church is one of the most recognizable structures on a Civil War battlefield.  Action swirled around this building during the battle.
Union forces spent the night before the battle on this farm.  At daybreak they advanced from this area south, toward the Cornfield.

There was a small skirmish the night before the battle for control of these woods.  On the morning of the 17th, both sides fought over this ground and Union Gen. Joseph Mansfield was mortally wounded a few hundred yards northeast of this spot.
A Confederate counterattack in this part of the field inflicted 2300 Union casualties in roughly 30 minutes during the morning of the battle.
The Mumma Farm was burned during the battle by the Confederates.  The family was not compensated for their loss.
Confederate forces defended the Sunken Road against numerous Union attacks.  The line broke at noon, but with no troops in the area to capitalize, the Union attacks stalled out.
stops.assetName: Sunken Road at Antietam Tour Stop 7

stops.significance: This bridge is one of the most recognized landmarks of the Civil War.  Confederate troops held the high ground overlooking the bridge until the third Union assault carried the bridge.

The last part of the battle unfolded on the fields around you. 8000 Union troops moved east to west and eventually gained the high ground to the west, only to be turned back by the timely arrival of Confederate reinforcements.
The Antietam National Cemetery is the final resting place for 4800 Union soldiers.
