data.description: We suggest you begin the 16-mile tour at the visitor center, where the new interactive campaign map, exhibits, and a 20-minute film explain the campaign and siege of Vicksburg. The numbered stops on this tour are keyed to the map on the back of the park brochure. During the tour, visitors will notice either red or blue metal markers placed by the War Department as the first interpretation of the park. Blue markers pertain to Union lines or emplacements. Red markers pertain to Confederate forces.

images.altText: Pink, wavy clouds float over the Memorial Arch at the beginning of the park tour road.
images.caption: All tours of the park begin by passing through the Memorial Archway.
images.title: Self-Guided Tour

stops.significance: This location demonstrates the dominance the Union artillery would have over the Confederates throughout the siege.
Understanding part of the civilian experiences during the siege of Vicksburg.
Understanding the strength of the Confederate fortifications and how the Union army tried different methods in attempting to capture Vicksburg,
John Wesley Powell's involvement in the siege of Vicksburg.
General Grant's army realizes how difficult capturing Vicksburg was going to be.
Thayer's unique approach and tunnel.
Understanding the uniqueness of sailors manning a battery on the Union siege lines.
Understanding the sacrifices made during the Vicksburg campaign.
Understanding the importance of the elevation and the Mississippi that made Vicksburg a focal point of the Civil War.
The strength of the Confederate defenses forced the Union army into siege operations.
The futility of the Union assaults on the Confederate forts.
The heroism displayed during the siege and the changing of the landscape from battlefield to Jewish cemetery.
This fort was the only place the Union army was able to capture portions of the Confederate defenses but were forced back.
How close the Union soldiers were to the Confederates and why the park has so many trees.
How fast Union engineers were able to dig approach trenches and force the surrender of Vicksburg.

data.title: Self-Guided Park Tour

data.description: This walking tour highlights seven major places in the park that focus on the prehistoric and Civil War history of the area.

images.altText: A view of the Lesser Temple Mound and Funeral Mound from on top of the Great Temple Mound
images.caption: A view of the Lesser Temple Mound and Funeral Mound from on top of the Great Temple Mound
images.title: On Top The Great Temple Mound

stops.significance:
The Visitor Center has a unique history. Construction for it began in 1938, two years after President Franklin D. Roosevelt proclaimed the Ocmulgee site a National Monument. However, construction was suspended in 1941 due to World War II. For ten years the Visitor Center sat incomplete before its construction was finally finished November 1951. 

The Visitor Center’s purpose was to house the park’s administration, museum exhibits, and the artifact collection generated by the excavations here in the 1930s and 40s. The building was designed by National Park Service assistant architect James Swanson. The style is Art Deco and is designed to look like one of the clay pots discovered during the excavations. Notice how the structure consists of stucco concrete with glass blocks and rounded corners – a unique style for a NPS visitor center. Look up at the red cornice, which was inspired by the “Lamar Bold” pottery style discovered here. The Visitor Center is listed on the National Register of Historic Places.

The white house in the field to your left is the Dunlap House, constructed by Samuel Dunlap in 1856 as part of his 400-acre cotton plantation. On July 30, 1864, Union General George Stoneman and his troops occupied the Dunlap House as temporary headquarters. Stoneman wanted to take Macon and free Union prisoners held at Camp Oglethorpe in Macon. When Stoneman couldn’t take Macon by storm, he began lobbing shells into the city. That afternoon General Stoneman retreated from Macon, but the Rebels captured Stoneman at Sunshine Church north of Macon and sent his troops to the prison camp at Andersonville. The Confederates constructed the U-shape earthworks here to protect the Walnut Creek railroad trestle from future attacks.  

Fighting took place here again in November 1864 at the Battle of Walnut Creek, when Union Calvary was sent to divert attention from General Sherman’s March to the Sea through Georgia. The Dunlap House now houses park staff, and is one of the oldest houses in Macon.

The Earth Lodge was built by the Mississippians who lived here from 900 to 1250 CE. The Lodge was a ceremonial council chamber, and the clay floor dates to 1015 C.E. Across from the entrance is a bird effigy platform. The three seats atop it were likely reserved for the chief, second chief, and the public speaker. 47 seats descend in height as they move away from the platform, suggesting a seating hierarchy. Each seat has a small oval depression in front of it, which may have been used to present ceremonial objects. The firepit in the center was likely used for ceremonies.

The Lodge was burned in the late 13th century; perhaps as a ritual for renewal or purification, or possibly because the building had deteriorated too much for any further use. Either way, as the roof caved in, it buried and preserved the clay floor for 800 years until it was rediscovered in 1934. To preserve and protect the prehistoric floor, reconstruction of the Earth Lodge began in 1936 and was completed in 1938 by the CCC and WPA.

The Cornfield Mound dates to the Mississippian period. The Mississippians were master farmers who grew corn, beans, squash, sunflowers, and tobacco. When archaeologists excavated this mound in the 1930s, they discovered cultivated rows and a charred corncob, leading them to believe that the Mississippians used the area as a cornfield before building the mound over it. The Mississippians farmed most of their crops near the Ocmulgee River, while this cornfield was likely used for ceremonies since it's near the Earth Lodge. Look at the prehistoric trenches on the right-side of the Cornfield mound with the Earth Lodge behind you. These trenches were partially excavated and left unfilled. The trenches are between 3 to 9 feet deep and 15 to 25 feet wide. The parallel trenches remain in sections as a series of oval depressions in semicircular bands. The purpose of these trenches is unknown; they may have been for irrigation or as a defensive barrier, but most likely they were borrow pits for building the mounds.

While the trading post is no more, the wooden beams here outline where it was established in 1690 C.E. by Charleston traders. The British competed with the Spanish operating in the area. The Indians preferred British trade items over Spanish because British goods were superior, their trading prices lower, and their demands on Indian culture were less. Indians traded deerskins for guns, beads, bells, and other European goods until around 1715, when the Indians were unable to produce enough deerskins to compensate for the European goods. Some traders, reacting to the London-based capitalist demands for payment, sold Indian women and children into slavery in the Caribbean. This led to the Yamasee War. The colonists defeated the Indian uprising in 1717, but by then the trading post here had been burned and abandoned. 

The site was excavated in 1935-36. Artifacts collected include gun parts, flints, musket balls, glass shards, beads, kaolin pipes, axes, knives, and copper bracelets.

The Funeral Mound is the only burial mound in the park. It was where the Mississippian village leaders were buried. The mound was built in seven stages with structures on top of each level, which were probably used to prepare the dead for burial and the accompanying ceremonies. Massive log tombs were contained in its lowest level and over a hundred burials were placed throughout the mound with elaborate copper and shell ornaments that suggest high-status burials. The 1870s railroad construction bisected the mound and left only the southern portion intact. Archaeologists later excavated this section in December of 1933. The mound’s current height is at the third level of the mound and is 20 feet high. When the mound had the seventh and final level during the Mississippian period, it would have been 280 feet long, 100 feet wide, and 25 feet high. Out of respect for those buried here, please do not walk on this mound.

The Great Temple Mound (GTM) is the tallest mound in the park, standing at 55 feet tall. All of the mounds built by the Mississippians were built by hand using basketfuls of dirt. It’s estimated that 10 million baskets of dirt, weighing around 60 pounds each, were used to build the GTM! Imagine the organization and diligence required by the entire village to accomplish such a feat. The mounds were used by the elite of the society of building their houses and temples on top of them. The GTM was most likely where the Mississippian chief lived, while the Lesser Temple Mound (LTM) may have been where the second chief lived. 

The LTM was partially destroyed by railroad construction in 1843 and is now a quarter of its original size. Excavation of the mound in 1934 revealed that the LTM had been built in four phases. A small village site with earth lodges and homes were also found between the GTM and the LTM.

data.title: Self-Guided Tour

data.description: Explore the living community of Nicodemus by foot as explore the oldest lived in African American settlement west of the Mississippi. The walking tour route is about .6 miles (1 k). The path follows flat paved, and dirt roads and seen by car, bicycle and covered wagon. There are a few ways to explore Nicodemus by walking tour. Self-guided tours are possible by using the Nicodemus Walking. The walking tour does go through busy streets and near private homes and residences.

images.altText: Park Ranger leading a tour.

stops.significance: The beginning of the self-guided tour! Nicodemus Township Hall is owned by the Town of Nicodemus and is used by the Park Service as a visitor center.

The Saint Francis Hotel Switzer Family Residence was used for a variety of purposes throughout the Nicodemus history. The original owners were Zachary and Jenny Fletcher. The two-bedroom hotel was also used as the first post office, schoolhouse, general store, candy shop and stagecoach station. Later the hotel was used by the Switzer family as a family residence.

The great plains and grasslands of Kansas lacks an easily accessible source of wood for building which lead to the hotel being made of limestone bricks. These lime stone bricks can viewed on the west side of the structure where the stucco has fallen away. Former Green Bay Packers player Veryl Switzer was raised in the residence in 1930s and 40s. Veryl later became community leader in preserving Nicodemus' historic buildings like the one he grew up in.

The A.M.E. church has just received major restoration, the project entailed restoring the floors, walls, ceiling, and altar. The church will be open for visitation and visitors will be able to see the oldest structure still standing in Nicodemus.

Settler's quickly established a school for children once arriving at Nicodemus. In 1879 the town established the first organized school in the country with the title "School District No. 1." Many different structures were used a schoolhouses such as sod dug outs, and the Saint Francis hotel. Due to many first settlers being born into slavery a large importance was put upon education especially reading and writing. Within a few years many settler's were literate with two news papers being printed within the town. The current school house was built in 1918 before closing in the 1960s due low enrollment numbers. The building was purchased by the American Legion in 1983.

The First Baptist Church has a unique history in Nicodemus. Church/religion was very important for the settlers of Nicodemus as the town was settled by several Preachers. The First Baptist Church was established in 1878, in the beginning the Nicodemus Colony members attended church services in a dugout. Members of the church when wanting to be baptized were baptized in a creek located on Thomas Johnson's Homestead north of town. Thomas Johnson was a deacon of the church and arrived with the first colony in September 17, 1877.  Eventually the congregation was established enough to build a small structured church. As the town grew the church grew and the congregation needed a larger building. A larger building was built in 1907 and the older generations tell the story how the larger church building was built around the smaller building and the smaller building was demolished piece by piece and removed out the door and windows of the newer church building.

Nicodemus may not have the bustling community center that it once did, but people still live and work here. We have seen the Historic buildings that represent the different pillars that support the community. The Township Hall for self-government, The St. Francis Hotel as business and home, The School House for education, and the Churches for religion. Thank you for joining us for this guided audio tour through the town of Nicodemus.

data.title: Self-Guided Walking Tour

data.description: Discover the history behind the buildings in the reconstructed Fort Vancouver, each of which is built on the archaeological footprint of the original structure.

images.altText: The wooden bastion, a tower in the corner of the Fort Vancouver palisade wall.
images.caption: Fort Vancouver's palisade wall and bastion.
images.title: Fort Vancouver

stops.significance: The Fort Vancouver Garden was an important part of life at Fort Vancouver. It provided food for those living inside the fort, and a place for the fort's upper class to relax.
At the Contact Station you can pay entrance fees or present your America the Beautiful pass, and get information on your visit from a national park ranger.
The Chief Factor's House was the residence of the leaders of Fort Vancouver and their families.
Food for the residents and guests of the Chief Factor's House was cooked in this Kitchen.

Fort Vancouver's residents got their water from this well. When you look down into the well, you are seeing the last remaining structure of the original Fort Vancouver. While the fort's buildings burned down in the 1860s, this well was preserved underground, and later uncovered by archaeologists!
The Bake House provided bread and sea biscuits for fur traders on long fur trapping brigades and for sailors aboard the ships that visited Fort Vancouver.
At the Blacksmith Shop, the fort's blacksmiths made animal traps, farming equipment, building hardware, and other necessary supplies.
Fur trappers could bring their furs to the Indian Trade Shop to trade. Medical care for the fort's officers was provided at this hospital.
Furs were sorted and packed for shipment at the Fur Store.
The Bastion is an iconic symbol of Fort Vancouver. It was not used for defense, but instead had ceremonial and lookout functions.
At the Carpenter Shop, the fort's carpenters made a wide variety of items necessary for life at Fort Vancouver.
The Jail housed those who were accused of breaking Hudson's Bay Company rules.

Scenic nature trail overlooking San Diego Bay.
Learn about what work and family life was like surviving at the tip of Point Loma and maintaining the lighthouse.
Scenic viewpoint and whale watching overlook.
Fire control station for Battery Humphreys, a World War II coastal artillery emplacement.
This offers sweeping views of the city of San Diego and San Diego Bay. This stop concludes the tour. You may continue to explore the park from here.

Take a moment to orient yourself: “north” is up the valley; “south” is facing the water. There are several street crossings – please remember to look both ways!

data.description: This tour retraces the walk of Elizabeth Eckford during the 1st attempt to integrate Central High School on Sept. 4, 1957. The language in the audio narration & written transcript is directly from eyewitness & published accounts & includes racial epithets. The inclusion of this strong language is meant solely to convey the courage of the African American students in the face of charged racism & bigotry. We ask that you please use appropriate guidance when using this resource.

images.altText: A drawing of Elizabeth Eckford with shadowy characters and the word "hate" behind her - Sept. 4, '57
images.caption: Elizabeth Eckford and September 4, 1957
images.title: Words That Matter

park.fullName: Little Rock Central High School National Historic Site
park.name: Little Rock Central High School

stops.significance: A timeline of events between 1954 and 1957 leading up to the Little Rock Central High desegregation crisis.
stops.assetName: Little Rock Central High School National Historic Site Visitor Center

stops.significance: A narration from several of the Little Rock Nine and the Governor of Arkansas immediately before the first day of school at Little Rock Central High in September 1957.

The northwest corner of Park Street and W. Daisy L. Gatson Bates Drive (formerly 14th Street) is a stop on the Little Rock Central High School NHS self-guided audio tour. From this location on September 4, 1957, members of the Little Rock Nine and minsters gathered before crossing 14th Street and attempting to integrate Central High School for the first time in its history.
stops.assetName: NW Corner of Park Street and Daisy L. Gatson Bates Drive

stops.significance: The southwest corner of Park Street and W. Daisy L. Gatson Bates Drive (formerly 14th Street) is location where Elizabeth Eckford, one of the Little Rock Nine, was initially turned away from entering Central High School by the Arkansas National Guard on September 4, 1957.
stops.assetName: SW Corner of Park Street and W. Daisy L. Gatson Bates Drive

stops.significance: Adjacent to the North Curvilinear Front Sidewalk at Central High School is the location where Elizabeth Eckford is first identified by segregationists and converged upon as she proceeds down Park Street on September 4, 1957 - the first attempt to integrate Little Rock Central High School.
stops.assetName: North Curvilinear Front Sidewalk at Central High School

stops.significance: Near this location, Elizabeth Eckford (one of the Little Rock Nine) is turned away and denied entrance on to the grounds of Central High School for a second time by Arkansas National Guardsmen; this first attempt to integrate Little Rock Central High School occurs on September 4, 1957.
stops.assetName: North Junction of Front Curvilinear Sidewalks at Central High School

stops.significance: Near this sidewalk junction, Arkansas Democrat photographer Will Counts captures lone walk of Elizabeth Eckford and the faces of discrimination and ignorance behind her as she proceeds down Park Street. Repeatedly denied access to Central High School by the Arkansas National Guard, Eckford decides to seek solace on a bus bench a half-block ahead of her.
stops.assetName: South Junction of Front Curvilinear Sidewalks at Central High School

stops.significance: Elizabeth waits for a bus after being locked out of Ponder’s Drug Store when she tried to call for a taxi. While waiting on the bus bench, she is approached by several individuals (L.C. Bates, Terrence Roberts, CBS newsman Robert Schakne, NY Times Reporter Benjamin Fine, and Grace Lorch) but remains surrounded by the crowd. When a city bus arrives, she boards, leaves for her mother’s workplace, and accompanied for a short time by Grace Lorch, the wife of a white professor at Philander Smith College who supported integration.

This stop looks at key events that occur after September 4 including the entry of the Little Rock Nine into Central High under escort from the 101st Airborne. 

The station was built in the Spanish Colonial Revival style, a popular design for gas stations in the 1920s and 1930s. Magnolia Oil (later Mobil), a pioneer in regional architectural styles for gas stations, frequently made use of the Spanish Colonial Revival style. The station walls are masonry with a stucco exterior and the building has a red barrel tile roof. The main body of the building is one story with a one-story canopy supported by two large square columns and extending out over the service area. Three restored gas pumps are located on a raised base on either side of the columns. Throughout the years, the building served as a gas station, a hangout for students, a temporary “office” for reporters during the 1957 desegregation crisis, a storage space for a wholesale florist business, and a National Historic Site visitor center until 2007.

data.title: Self-Guided Walking Tour with Audio & Transcript

data.description: A Self-Guided tour of Plains, Georgia.

images.altText: A brown metal sign that reads welcome to Plains Georgia the home of Jimmy Carter 39 president
images.caption: Welcome to Plains, Georgia
images.title: Plains, Georgia Welcome Sign

stops.significance: Plains High School is where both Jimmy and Rosalynn Carter attended grades one through eleven. Today Plains High School is the main visitor center and museum for the Jimmy Carter National Historic Site.
stops.assetName: Plains High School Visitor Center and Museum

stops.significance: Plains Baptist Church is where Jimmy Carter attended church as a child, and later attended church after his return from the Navy in 1953.
Apartment 9A is the low income housing that Jimmy and Rosalynn Carter and their three sons moved into upon their return to Plains in 1953.

Carter Home Overlook is where visitors can see the managed landscape of the Carter home, catch a glimpse of the Carter Home, and see the pond that Jimmy Carter had installed after his return from the White House.
Plains United Methodist Church is the home church of Rosalynn Smith Carter. This is the church that Jimmy and Rosalynn Carter were married in on July 7, 1946.
Plains City Hall is where the Carter family would have registered their home, paid utilities and licensing fees, and came to public meetings about the city of Plains.
Plains Depot is the oldest building in Plains and the site of the 1976 Presidential Campaign Headquarters for Jimmy Carter.
Plains Pharmacy served as the cultural hub for the younger people in Plains and was where the Carter family would have filled prescriptions for medicine.

The Graham Store is where Mr. Graham, a well respected African-American gentleman, ran a dry goods store. The school children, including Jimmy and Rosalynn, would have stopped by after school in hopes of getting a piece of pie fresh out of the oven.

Plains Historic Inn and Antiques Mall plays a central role in the history of Plains, Georgia. When the building was renovated into the Inn (2002), President and Mrs. Carter assisted with the renovations and made suggestions about how the rooms were furnished.
stops.assetName: Plains Historic Inn and Antique Mall

stops.significance: The Old Bank building was a bank and later a post office for the town of Plains. Before the post office moved into the building Jimmy Carter and his cousin sold ice cream and hamburgers from the store front. Later after the post office moved, Hugh Carter used the building as the offices for his worm farm.
Plains Trading Post served as a store, a hardware store, and a grocery store before becoming a souvenir store during the 1976 Presidential Campaign.

Plain Peanuts originally was built as a hotel and then it became a hospital. Later Earl Carter ran his peanut warehouse and insurance agency from this building. Jimmy Carter used this location for his peanut warehouse until 1961.
Billy Carter Service Station is where reporters covering the 1976 Presidential Campaign would gather to talk to residents and to hear Billy Carter share his opinions on matters of the day.

data.title: Self-Guided tour of Plains, Georgia

data.description: Self-guided tours of Plains High School are available from 9am until 5pm daily. Visitors may request the introductory film at the front desk. This 25 minute films plays in the restored auditorium and is an overview of President Carter's life, times, and achievements. The rooms of Plains high School are self-guided and have audio, audio-visual, and tactile elements in the rooms. Feel free to explore at your own pace.

data.description: Welcome to Slatersville, one of six sites that make up Blackstone River Valley National Historical Park. At first glance, Slatersville looks like a classic New England small town, but in reality, Slatersville is America's first planned mill village. Its true heart is the massive stone mill. Join us as we explore this rich cultural landscape and uncover the story of America's first planned industrial community.

images.altText: Mill buildings adjacent to a raceway.
images.caption: Historic View of the Western Mill Complex, Slatersville, RI
images.title: Slatersville Western Mill Complex

park.fullName: Blackstone River Valley National Historical Park
park.name: Blackstone River Valley

stops.significance: The river and it's drop of 40 feet in 1 mile at this location provided the ideal location for water-powered mills. Eventually the water-power available at this site powered the three textile mills.

The company store became an important part of a mill village. Here worker's were provided with all the necessities of life, but could pay off debts against their paychecks. This indebted many mill employees to their employers.
This is one of the only remaining structures that was once part of the Western Mill Complex.
stops.assetName: The Western Mill and Slatersville Library

stops.significance: This area made up the heart of Slatersville's industrial core. Three mills still stand as a testament to the growth and development of the operations here.

The Church was another important element of a mill village. The mill church provided employees with the one of the only places to socially gather outside of the mill, but also reinforced the values and mores mill owners wanted from their employees.

Slatersville worker housing is a great example of the living conditions of employees here in Slatersville. Here entire families lived in the place where they also labored. This family-based system came to be known as the Rhode Island System of Manufacture.
The former home of John Slater demonstrates how perspectives and practices of industrialists changed with succeeding generations of owners.

data.title: Slatersville: America's First Planned Mill Village

data.description: This tour is meant to be conducted at your own pace, as the sites mentioned stretch over the length of Delaware. Please be careful when travelling, and make sure to look up the hours and visitor information for each site beforehand. Contact information, hours, and how to make reservations, if they are necessary, can be found both in the First State National Historical Park section of the NPS mobile app and on the Park’s website, at www.nps.gov/frst.

images.altText: A black & white image of Samuel Burris as an older man
images.caption: Samuel Burris
images.title: Samuel Burris

stops.significance: The John Dickinson Plantation was the home of one of the most famous of the Founders, John Dickinson, often referred to as the "penman of the Revolution". While Dickinson wrote so eloquently about concepts like freedom and liberty, he also enslaved people on his plantation. It is through the life of Dickinson and all the others, free and enslaved, who live here that we can explore the contradictory truths at the heart of the American Revolution.

The Dover Green has been the center of this community since the city's founding. It has been the stage for numerous historical events, including the auction of Samuel Burris into slavery in 1848. By exploring the life of Burris, we can a better understanding of how the Black Americans, both free and enslaved, lived in Delaware before the Civil War.

Fort Christina marks the nucleus of the colony of New Sweden, the first successful European colony in what would become Delaware. Though slavery was not present at its beginning, and only gradually grew over the course of New Sweden's existence, it was nevertheless the germ from which the institution grew in the Delaware region. We cannot fully explore the history of slavery in Delaware without looking at how it began.

This is one of many markers placed by the 1892 Hodgkins survey of the "12-mile arc", the unique circular boundary between Delaware & Pennsylvania. Though the border had been established in the late 1600s, its circular shape made it difficult to survey and demarcate until the late 1800s. While the marker itself was placed after slavery was abolished in the United States, the border it represents was established long before that, and for many thousands of enslaved people seeking freedom, this was the last barrier they had to cross before they were on free soil.

data.title: Slavery and the Underground Railroad in Delaware

data.description: The Guadalupe Mountains rise out of the surrounding desert, providing habitat for a variety of unique plants and animals that are not found anywhere in the surrounding arid lands. The riparian woodland surrounding Smith Spring is one of the unique ecosystems found within the Guadalupe Mountains. The hike is a 2.3-mile loop with a 400-foot elevation gain. Allow from one and a half to two hours to complete. Bring plenty of water, a trail map, and comfortable hiking shoes.

images.altText: Water flows into a pool under a canopy of trees
images.caption: Smith Spring is a destination along the east side of the Guadalupe Mountains
images.title: Smith Spring pool

stops.significance: The Frijole Ranch Trailhead has a restroom and picnic tables. The historic Frijole Ranch is just a short walk from the trailhead.

It is not hard to imagine why Frijole Ranch was constructed at this site. Frijole Spring provided the water that was essential to survival here in the desert. Because of this water, the area is a great place to find a variety of birds and other wildlife. Scrub jays, chipping sparrows, house finches, Say's phoebes, white-winged doves, and ladder-backed woodpeckers are year-round residents. In winter watch for pyrrhuloxia, phainopeplas, cedar waxwings, and western bluebirds. In spring and summer, look for summer and western tanagers, plumbeous vireos, Cassin's kingbird, blue grosbeak, and a variety of warblers.

Before starting out on the trail, take some time to explore around Frijole Ranch. Interpretive signs will tell you about the history of the Smith Family and later the Kincaid Family who called this place home. If the museum is open, there are exhibits inside that chronicle over 10,000 years of human history in the Guadalupe Mountains.
Manzanita Spring is reached via an accessible trail and is a small pool of water in an otherwise seemingly barren desert landscape.
Perhaps the very best place in the park to rest and reflect, Smith Spring is a lush oasis tucked up against the Guadalupe Mountains Wilderness.

data.title: Smith Spring Trail Loop

data.description: While you hike through one of the quietest places in the West, natural sounds will prevail, including the call of birds and the rustle of wind through the plants. Though we may associate this place with quiet, the landscape can speak to us - if we are ready to listen. Numbered signposts along the trail correspond with this tour, taking you through different habitats and millions of years of time.

images.altText: Sandstone cliffs winding downwards on a gentle slope with juniper trees growing amongst them..
images.caption: The Sound of Silence wanders through stunning desert landscapes.
images.title: Sound of Silence Trail

stops.significance:
While you hike through one of the quietest places in the West, natural sounds will prevail, including the call of birds and the rustle of wind through the plants. Though we may associate this place with quiet, the landscape can speak to us - if we are ready to listen. Numbered signposts along the trail correspond with this tour, taking you through different habitats and millions of years of time.
The trail is easy at first, but it gets more difficult the further you hike and includes a short rock scramble near the end. Trail conditions vary depending on weather. The lack of shade can be potentially dangerous during the summer heat. It is best to hike in the early morning when temperatures are cooler. Recent rain may make sections of the trail muddy and slick. Please stay on the trail unless you are on solid rock or sand. Desert soils are delicate and may be destroyed by walking on them - you will hear more about these biological soil crusts later. Pets and bikes are not permitted.

Dinosaur National Monument is best known for its dinosaur fossils, but it protects so much more. 23 geologic layers are exposed in the monument, spanning more than one billion years of Earth's history. Sparse vegetation reveals these layers that tell us about the distant past. 

Look to the west and view geologic layers through time. Frontier Formation and Mowry Shale to the south (on your left) are younger rock layers, dating to the late Cretaceous, approximately 98 million years ago. The Nugget Sandstone to the north (on your right) is much older, extending back to the Triassic, 200 million years ago. In front of you is over 100 million years of climatic and environmental change.

Change can be continuous and slow or incredibly quick in a desert environment like this. Soon you will encounter an intermittent stream bed (referred to as a wash). It is often dry, but water roaring downhill after intense thunderstorms can rapidly reshape the landscape.

Many sections of this trail never look the same way twice, and this wash is a good example of constant change. Water is a powerful force that shapes soils as well as rocks. Water can build as well as erode. Plants nourished by water soften the landscape and make it possible for animals, birds, insects, and reptiles to live here. Listen and watch for signs of life as you proceed.

Signs of animals include the game trails that elk and deer create as they crisscross the washes that the Sound of Silence Trail follows. Don’t be tempted to follow these tracks up and out of the wash though — they will lead you through some rough territory!

You might expect a large Fremont Cottonwood tree like this to grow near a more obvious source of water. What does its presence here tell us? The surrounding rocks funnel seasonal rainwater to its thirsty roots. This tree, with leaves that sing and whisper in the breeze, provides habitat for birds and insects, and shade for all. Rabbits, deer, and elk feed on its shoots and stems. Insects live on it that are food for birds. Hawks and bats may use cottonwoods as sites to nest or roost. Even in death, tree cavities are refuges for many species of animals. Ahead you will find other refuges used by animals to escape the mid-day sun.

Take a close look at the earthen bank on your right for evidence of flowing water — sometimes swift and other times slow. Faster water can carry larger particles. Can you find a layer that was accompanied by the sound of rushing water? Slower water can only carry fine sediments. Try to find a layer that would have been deposited by a quiet trickle. The surrounding cliffs, slowly eroded by wind and water, add to the diverse, sorted sediment layers. Erosion continues with each new rainstorm moving more sediment downstream. Differences in the sediment layers help natural cavities develop. Holes may be enlarged and used by squirrels and birds, as nesting sites. Listen carefully and you may hear the scratchy call of a Rock Wren or the melodic song of a Canyon Wren. Look carefully and you may see a Golden-mantled Ground Squirrel peeking out of a hole, its high pitched alarm call warning others of your presence.

The rounded bluffs of Nugget Sandstone towering above you are remnants of a vast desert that once covered much of what is now the western United States. Thin diagonal layers called cross-beds formed as wind blown sand dunes moved across the desert 200 million years ago. The steep fronts of these dunes were hundreds of feet high. Trace fossils in the Nugget Sandstone include the tracks of scorpions, spiders, and Brasilichnium, an early relative of mammals. Bones from an early Triassic dinosaur have also been found in this rock layer.

Enjoy the view as you study the plants growing all around you. Does the pattern of their placement say anything to you? The bench of land you are on overlooks a riparian area, filled with Fremont Cottonwood trees growing where water is more plentiful and soil is deeper. On the rocky ledges above are junipers, which can survive on very little water. In between, where you are now, are shrubs like greasewood and sage. Many vegetation patterns occur throughout Dinosaur National Monument, influenced by elevation, amount of water, minerals in the soils, or sunlight. In turn, these zones provide a variety of unique habitats for wildlife.

Within this shady rock overhang, can you spot a portion of a packrat debris pile, also known as a midden? It is above your head, in the crevice between the two large rocks that form the overhang. Look for twigs, rocks and fecal pellets, all held together by shiny crystallized urine. Middens can tell us about past environments. They may exist and be added to for thousands of years. Radiocarbon dating has identified middens up to 50,000 years old. Middens may contain leaves, seeds, fruit, twigs, pollen, bone, shells and scales, leading to identification of past environments. We know from middens that Douglas Fir and Ponderosa Pine once grew in this area, during a cooler and wetter time. As the climate changed over the last 10,000 years, these species retreated to higher elevations where they are still found.

While native plants like the greasewood, rabbitbrush, and sage are important habitat, what about the rock walls themselves? The large cliff to the south has, in past years, been the nesting place of Peregrine Falcons. Once an endangered species, their numbers have now grown. Thanks to a ban on the pesticide DDT, and protected nesting places like this cliff face in Dinosaur National Monument, you may see a Peregrine Falcon soaring overhead. Listen carefully for the highpitched “kak, kak, kak” call.

Hidden within these hills are clues of their origin. Look for ripple marks on some of the rocks, and imagine the lapping sound of waves, a message from the past. You are now walking through the remains of a shallow, watery environment from 250 million years ago called the Moenkopi Formation. Muds and sands were deposited in thin beds on the edges and bottoms of watery areas. Reptiles and amphibians moved stealthily along shorelines and through these shallow waters, in a time before the dinosaurs. Invertebrates burrowed in the muds of the floodplains, and ammonites (a type of mollusk) swam in the seaways. Although the weathered soils of the Moenkopi Formation may look inhospitable, flowering plants like Desert Paintbrush, Pale Evening Primrose and the dramatic Prince’s Plume grow here. What are these plants telling us? These soils are high in selenium, which the Prince’s Plume utilizes so that it is unpalatable and even toxic if consumed.

What is happening beneath our feet to result in such a dramatic landscape at the surface? The noticeable curve of Split Mountain is part of an anticline - an upward fold of rock. While Split Mountain arcs up, other features seem to sag. The sags are called synclines. This underlying rollercoaster of rock formed when formerly flat sedimentary layers were compressed and wrinkled. Forces related to the building of the Rocky and Uinta Mountains 70 - 40 million years ago caused the uplifting, tilting, faulting and folding of the rock layers. While some layers erode into mounds, others stick out as ridges.

Soils in an arid environment are fragile. Take a minute here to inspect the crusty biological soil. It is mostly cyanobacteria (sometimes called blue-green algae), and also includes lichens, mosses, green algae, microfungi and bacteria. It takes many years for this soil to form and support life. While cyanobacteria are mobile and will regenerate if disturbed, lichens and mosses are not, and will die if trampled. Blown by wind or moved by other forces, it is estimated that lichens will recolonize an area in 45 years, while it takes mosses an estimated 250 years. These crusts control erosion and fix nitrogen, helping other plants to grow. Please stay on the trail to help preserve these unique soils.

All around you is Ephedra viridis, commonly called Mormon Tea because it was used by early Native Americans and settlers to make an invigorating tea. It is an important browse crop for livestock and also deer, elk, and sheep, especially in the winter months.

This spot provides a place to rest, rejuvenate, and cool down before climbing the rocky ridge ahead. Solitude and refuge are two things that national parks and monuments offer. These are places to reflect, learn, and experience nature. Also protected are other qualities such as dark night skies and natural quiet — rare commodities in cities where many of us live. Growing around you on the slope are Utah junipers. The most common tree species in Utah, it covers one-fifth of the land area of the state. It seems like they can grow nearly anywhere, even out of solid rock. Their roots are the secret. A massive system that makes up 2/3 of the tree’s total mass, the tap root can be 25 feet deep and lateral roots may extend out 100 feet. The juniper berry is actually a tiny pinecone, and is eaten by rabbit, fox, coyote, and many species of birds. Junipers grow slowly. Older trees, which may be 650-850 years old, have sculptural qualities. Even dead, a juniper may stand silent and strong for several hundred years.

In the distance to the south you might be able to pick out the Green River. This source of water in the desert attracted not only the Fremont and Ute people who once dwelt here, but before them, people going back 10,000 years. Petroglyphs, pictographs and former dwelling sites dot the landscape. John Wesley Powell boated through here on his way down to the Colorado River about 150 years ago. He made natural history observations, mapped the area, and named many features. The Green River remains a source of adventure and sustenance today.

On this ridge, take a moment to rest in the shade of the small Singleleaf Ash tree, a species unique to the American Southwest. Surviving by means of deep roots and sheer perseverance, they often take on a dwarfed appearance. Unlike most species of ash trees, which have compound leaves, this western ash has a single leaf on each stem. The red rock ridge underneath you is the Chinle Formation, formed during a time when rivers, marshes, and small lakes covered the landscape. Plants would not have included a flowering tree like the Singleleaf Ash. Instead, conifers, cycads, ferns, and horsetail plants grew here. Dinosaurs made their first appearance in this time period, about 225 million years ago. Coelophysis, a three-toed, therapod dinosaur about the size of a large dog, roamed the land. Large crocodile-type creatures called phytosaurs lurked in the waters. Imagine how different the sounds of the Triassic would be from the sounds of today!

For those feeling fit and adventurous, an optional side trip is available at this spot. Climb the sloping rock stretching to the sky to the west. Step carefully, move slowly, and when you reach the top, you will be rewarded with a 360° panorama. Alternatively, you can enjoy the view from the shade of the juniper tree beside the trail marker, and contemplate that you are standing at the northern edge of the Colorado Plateau. Encompassing 240,000 square miles, this area is sometimes known as “Red Rock Country” and centers on the Four Corners area where Colorado, Arizona, Utah and New Mexico meet. There are 27 National Parks and Monuments, 30 wilderness areas, millions of acres of National Forest and many other protected areas in this high desert region of the plateau. Dinosaur National Monument is the northernmost of these parks. Each place has a unique contribution to the story of the southwest.

For many of us, the simple beauty of the land’s colors and textures may be enough to satisfy, awe, and inspire. These places also allow geologists, paleontologists, biologists, and archeologists to more deeply investigate and study the Earth and our history. On this hike, you have seen the silent reminders of many changes —sometimes occurring over millions of years, or sometimes occurring very quickly. Sediments, rocks, plants, animals, and the other features of the landscape all speak to those who slow down and take the time to hear what they have to say.

data.title: Sound of Silence Trail: Tilted Landscapes

data.description: While one can get lost for days on end at a place like Grand Canyon, we don't always have the time. Thankfully even a short trip to Grand Canyon can still yield some amazing views and life long memories. The following is our Ranger Recommended 1–2 visit for the South Rim that includes a short walk, and our free shuttle bus service, but remember that there is no wrong way to visit the canyon. Relax, enjoy the views, and thanks for visiting.

images.altText: A small group of people look out over Grand Canyon from behind a metal railing
images.caption: One of our favorite canyon views!
images.title: Mather Point

stops.significance: Grand Canyon Visitor Center is a great place to start any trip to the canyon! The park film plays every 30 minutes, additional exhibits and displays tell the canyon's stories, Rangers are on hand to trip plan and answer questions you may have about local animals, plants, or rocks, and the nearby stores can help set you up with snacks, drinks, or souvenirs.

From Mather Point you have a visual range of over 60 miles looking at Grand Canyon from East to West. A sharp eye will pick out the Desert View Watchtower far to the east, the Grand Canyon Lodge on the North Rim, Phantom Ranch down in the canyon depths, and even a small patch of the Colorado River, complete with white water. 

Take your time to wonder around the area and appreciate the views.

The Yavapai Geology Museum is an excellent place to take a moment to answer some of those big questions, How? Why? What? that you might be pondering after seeing the canyon for the first time. It's also a great view of the canyon that has two views of the Colorado River, one of which also provides a view of the Kaibab trail's foot bridge across the river.

stops.assetName: Yavapai Geology Museum - Kaibab Rim (Orange) Route

stops.significance: Yet another wide sweeping panoramic view of the canyon this view looks slightly more to the East than Mather Point and offers a clearer view of the dramatic formations off in that direction. Far below you can see the South Kaibab Trail and sharp eye (or pair of binoculars) may spot hikers in the canyon. A short walk to the east of the viewpoint can yield some dramatic views and quieter nooks to stop and enjoy for a moment.

stops.assetName: Grand Canyon Visitor Center Shuttle Bus Terminal

data.title: South Rim; The 1–2 hour visit.

data.description: The New River Gorge National Park and Preserve encompasses over 70,000 acres of land as it follows the New River through the lower reaches of West Virginia. Beginning at the Grandview, this riverside driving tour ventures along the Park’s most scenic roads to the southern tip of its boundary, directing visitors towards some great views, recreational opportunities, and historic sites along the way.

images.altText: Map of the southern area of the park. North is at the top. Grandview and Sandstone are shown
images.caption: Map of the southern area of New River Gorge National Park and Preserve
images.title: Map of the tour area in the park

park.fullName: New River Gorge National Park & Preserve
park.name: New River Gorge

stops.significance: Note: Looking for camping opportunities in the South District? Meadow Creek Campground is located about a mile up the road from the Sandstone Visitor Center, and is a year-round, tent-only, first-come first-serve campground.

The Sandstone Falls overlook is the first official park vista that visitors will pass on Route 20 during this tour. Just as the name entails, this overlook provides a spectacular cliff-side view of Sandstone Falls nearly 600 feet above the water. This stop also has picnic tables and a restroom.

Brooks Island Overlook peers over the mile-long Brooks Island, a perennial bald eagle nesting site. Since 2010, three mated bald eagle couples have used the established nest in an American sycamore tree to incubate and raise their chicks. Though once listed as a threatened and endangered species, the bald eagle population within the country has steadily improved, and their sightings in the park have become more frequent! Two other nesting sites have been confirmed within the park in more recent years.

The Gwinn Ridge Trail is a moderately strenuous 3 mile loop on the Brooks Mountain ridge-top that winds through a hilled meadow and old-growth forest. As one of the lesser-known trails in the park, Gwinn Ridge trail provides visitors a quiet hike, and, if trekked in the winter, good views.  

Note: Though not affiliated with the New River Gorge National Park and Preserve, the Three Rivers Avian Center is also located on Brooks Mountain Road. This “private nonprofit organization [is] dedicated to wild bird conservation and to educating and involving people in ecosystem stewardship,” and is open to public tours by appointment or between the 1st Saturday from May- October from 1 to 5 pm.

Though not technically under park jurisdiction, the charming town of Hinton is designated the southern gateway to the gorge and offers different opportunities for visitors who may be passing through, including Amtrak access, a railroad museum, several local restaurants, antique and retail shops, and historic sites which have ties to the region’s railroad and coaling industry. The Hinton Historic District is listed on the National Register of Historic Places and is comprised of over 40 different historic structures within the downtown area. Thanks to the effort of the city, several of the buildings are being revitalized with renovations and restorations.

For more information on Hinton and all that the surrounding area has to offer, visit the New River Convention and Visitors Bureau located at 300 2nd Avenue or exploresummerscounty.com.

First established in the 19th century, Richmond-Hamilton Farm now remains as one of a handful of historic homestead sites in the park. The fertile, flat land in this area provided the ideal environment for settlers to engage in subsistence farming – a traditional lifestyle of self-sufficiency that existed outside the advent of the coaling and railroad industry within the region. Homesteaders, such as the Richmond-Hamilton family, relied on the production of their own food, shelter, and water to survive, though trading and bartering resources with neighbors was also common practice. The Richmond-Hamilton farm showcases the standard homesteading format with a main house and several additional outbuildings that support the subsistence lifestyle, which often include a barn, shed, springhouse, and outhouse. Since its acquisition into the park, Richmond-Hamilton Farm has been preserved and restored, and is now regularly maintained as a historic site for visitors.

Another low-traffic hike, the Big Branch Trail offers a strenuous 2-mile loop through a peaceful forest landscape. Hikers of this trail will pass by two waterfalls, as well as the remains of an old homestead. During the springtime, this trail boasts colorful blooms; in the winter, the trail allows for ridge-top views of both the gorge and Brooks Falls.

Brooks Falls, the smaller sister to Sandstone Falls, is a 4 foot drop that spans the 1000 foot width of the river. Though the name suggests it as a waterfall, Brooks Falls is perhaps better described as a runnable, Class III rapid. The Brooks Falls Roadside Park provides a small observation of the falls, as well as restroom facilities, picnic spots, and river access. *CAUTION* Always wear a life jacket when wading or swimming in the shallow river access eddies.

Sandstone Falls is the largest waterfall in the New River Gorge National Park and Preserve, with a river wide crest of 1500 feet that plunges from heights of 10-25 feet. These falls were created over thousands of years as water cut through and disintegrated the soft conglomerate rock layer that sits underneath the initial sandstone riverbed. This erosion resulted in a terraced waterfall formation with many small islands – several of which are home to the unique Appalachian flat rock ecosystem. Visitors are invited to explore the area with the established observation areas, waysides exhibits, and trails. The Sandstone Falls Boardwalk crosses over small tributaries and islets, and ends with an impressive view of the falls. The scenic Island Loop Trail leads visitors around the lower island where a grist mill once operated. 

*CAUTION* Several spots on the west bank of the river are suitable for wading and swimming, though visitors should always exercise caution by wearing a life jacket and shoes.

data.title: Southern Scenic Driving Tour

data.description: Just a day after the Battle of the Wilderness, the US and Confederate armies clashed again in the small community of Spotsylvania Court House. Drive the battlefield to the places where these armies experienced relentless fighting and where the nature of the Civil War was shifting in the summer of 1864. This tour follows the route indicted by the numbered stops on the circular battlefield tour signs on the park map and out in the landscape.

images.altText: A filed with a stone obelisk in the distance and trees lining the horizon.
images.caption: The 126th Ohio Monument sits visible from the Bloody Angle.
images.title: The Bloody Angle

stops.significance:
The Battle of Spotsylvania Court House, fought from May 8-21, 1864, introduced a new kind of war to the armies. Soldiers experienced fighting that not even three years of warfare had prepared them for, and civilians who lived on the landscape found themselves stuck between the warring forces.

This eight-stop tour of the battlefield is setup mainly as a driving tour, following the park roads, though there are walking trails that can be utilized as well. Throughout the tour, please help preserve the trenches by not walking on them and remaining on the trails.

Before the war, the small lanes and paths that crisscrossed the countryside were little more than mundane roads utilized by farmers. When the armies came, roads, no matter how small, became vitally important for moving troops into position. One such path is here—so unimportant before the war that it did not even have a name. 

On May 10, 1864, Federal soldiers under the command of Col. Emory Upton used the nondescript path to attack Confederate fortifications less than a mile away. From here, you may walk the half-mile roundtrip trail to the site of Upton’s attack.

Some of war’s most infamous fighting took place here over 24 hours, starting with a pre-dawn attack by nearly 20,000 Federal soldiers against the Confederate position known as the Muleshoe Salient. By the time the fighting ended here, there were almost 17,000 casualties between the two armies, and a bend in the earthworks became forever known as the Bloody Angle. The fighting here completely upended the norms of Civil War combat. Soldiers used to fighting for only short periods of time were thrown into the maelstrom for hours on end. 

After the war, veterans returned to place monuments, marking their positions during the battle. 

A series of walking trails go around those monuments and into the Bloody Angle. Be mindful that there are likely still soldiers buried within these trenches. Please be respectful by not walking on them.

The Harrison House, of which only the foundation remains, represents the common household transformed by the Civil War into a place of fighting and violence. On the morning of May 12, 1864, Robert E. Lee’s headquarters were situated near the front yard of the house, and from here, Confederate counter-attacks were launched towards the Bloody Angle. Out of sheer desperation, Lee himself tried to lead some of those attacks, attempting to stave off disaster and Confederate defeat.

When the Civil War began, 50% of Spotsylvania County's residents were enslaved. Even before the armies came here in the spring of 1864, people here felt the war’s effects. 

Two enslaved people who lived here at the McCoull House fled to Union lines in 1862, part of the steady flow of almost 10,000 enslaved from the greater Fredericksburg area who made their way to freedom in 1862. Two years later, the war came right to the front steps of the McCoull House, and fighting swirled around the yard on May 12, and six days later on May 18. 

By the time the fighting ended, a passerby wrote, “Of the woods, thinned and despoiled by the storm of iron and lead, only a ghostly grove of dead trunks and dreary limbs remained.”

The tactics and strategy of warfare had changed by 1864. Earlier in the war, battles were marked by engagements maneuvering around open fields; by the time they reached Spotsylvania, armies were digging more and more elaborate trenches. The Eastern Face of the Muleshoe Salient present some of the best-preserved trenches anywhere on the battlefield and the opportunity to examine the changing methods of warfare.

The importance of earthworks and trenches was evident here at Heth’s Salient. Despite being attacked numerous times throughout the battle, the Confederate defenses here never buckled. Throughout the battle the earthworks protected the Army of Northern Virginia’s right near the Fredericksburg Road. Federal soldiers attacking this position included the 17th Michigan, whose monument, dedicated in 1997, is located here. 

The Confederate trenches are still visible about a quarter mile from this stop, but there are no established trails and reaching them requires walking through thick foliage.

As the Battle of Spotsylvania Court House reached its conclusion, both sides looked to control the Fredericksburg Road. Whichever side possessed the road had the ability to help or hinder the arrival of reinforcements and supplies. 

The battle’s last fighting took place to determine which army owned the Fredericksburg Road. With the battle’s end on May 21, the armies marched away, leaving behind the catastrophic debris of the last thirteen days. 

The memory of the battle and how it was commemorated took center stage in the latter years of the 1800s as veterans returned to put up monuments and preserve land where they had fought years before.

data.description: Explore the battlefield by car, bike, or on foot. Each stop will tell the story of a critical phase of the Battle of Stones River allowing you understand how it became one of the most important victories in the American Civil War.

images.altText: Map depicting the park boundaries and surrounding area.
images.caption: Park Map
images.title: Stones River National Battlefield Map

stops.significance: Check out our museum, orientation film and America's National Parks store before beginning your tour. Don't forget to pick up park folder that contains a park map and other information to help you explore the battlefield.

On December 30, 1862, the Union Army of the Cumberland, commanded by General William S. Rosecrans, arrived at Murfreesboro. Troops occupied this area along McFadden’s Lane (called Van Cleve Lane today). As night fell, soldiers struggled to sleep in the freezing mud without campfires, knowing a major battle was imminent. For thousands, that night would be their last
stops.assetName: Auto Tour Stop 1 - Eve of Battle

stops.significance: Union soldiers fiercely defended their position here. Confederates launched attack after failed attack, causing heavy losses to both sides. Bodies piled up in the rocks, and blood soaked the ground. The Union retreated, but the delay gave their army time to form a new line along the Nashville Pike.
stops.assetName: Auto Tour Stop 2 - The Slaughter Pen

stops.significance: The desperate fighting here was key to the outcome of the battle. The Union army set itself for a final stand to protect its lifeline. Infantry and massed artillery beat back wave after wave of Confederate attacks until darkness brought the fighting to a close.
stops.assetName: Auto Tour Stop 3 - The Struggle for the Nashville Pike

stops.significance: The fighting here was part of the afternoon struggle for control of the Nashville Pike on December 31, 1862. The Army of the Cumberland's Pioneer Brigade was made up of experienced soldiers with no practice fighting as a unit, and the men of the Chicago Board of Trade Battery were getting their first taste of combat. These untested units beat back battle-tested Confederates helping to hold the line protecting to road back to Nashville.
Stones River National Cemetery is the final resting place of more than 6,100 Union soldiers along with veterans of the United States Armed forces and family members who served into the 1970's.

This was the only Union position that held throughout the first day. Artillery and infantry halted the first attack at 10 am and beat back three more as the day wore on. By dusk the Confederate dead and wounded covered the fields of Hell’s Half Acre.
stops.assetName: Auto Tour Stop 5 - Hell's Half Acre

stops.significance: Men of Col. William B. Hazen's Brigade built this monument in 1863 to commemorate their actions during the Battle of Stones River and other engagements in Tennessee.

Union soldiers hid behind stone and rail breastworks as men fled across the river chased by Confederates. Union cannon firing from above McFadden’s Ford halted the Confederates with shot, shell, and canister, killing and wounding over 1,800 men in less than an hour. This was the battle’s final action.

data.title: Stones River Battlefield Tour

data.description: Following the Civil War there were over 30,000 freedmen living in the Shenandoah Valley. Recognizing the need for education, the Freedmen's Bureau, the Freewill Baptists of New England, and John Storer, came together and Storer College was born. The school survived for 88 years, enriching the lives of hundreds of students. Today you can walk the grounds of this former college campus. The route below starts at the Lockwood House but you can follow it in any order you prefer.

images.altText: Smiling African American man looks directly into camera. He is holding a display board
images.caption: Let Storer Alum like Elbert Norton give you a tour of the campus
images.title: Storer College tour

stops.significance: Storer College was founded in October 1867, becoming the first higher education institution in West Virginia open to African Americans and operating continuously until 1955. What began as a one-room missionary school here in Lockwood house for formerly enslaved men and women grew into a college that provided both an education and a sense of community for African American students. Today, Harpers Ferry NHP preserves the former campus and the stories of those who lived, learned and taught there.

stops.assetName: Information Panel: The Battle We Wage...

stops.significance: Storer alum George King class of 1947 tells us about the end of Storer College.

data.description: The road from White River to Sunrise is a journey through the geologic history of Mount Rainier. Volcanoes and glaciers have dramatically shaped the landscape. The first part of the tour is intended for listeners driving along the Sunrise Road. Once you reach Sunrise, the second part of the audio tour takes you on a short walk to view glaciers. White River and Sunrise are open during the summer season only, typically from July to mid-September.

images.altText: A glaciated mountain rising above subalpine meadows next to a road.
images.caption: The Sunrise Road features spectacular views of Mount Rainier.
images.title: Mount Rainier from Sunrise Road

stops.significance: Begin your tour at White River Entrance or the White River Campground. If using the audio component of this tour, please connect your mobile device to your vehicle’s sound system before you begin driving. Do not stop your vehicle in the road and block traffic. While we encourage you to enjoy the impressive views while traveling up the road, please stay aware of the road and drive safely. The Sunrise Road is steep and winding. Watch out for bicyclists and other drivers on the road, as well as wildlife. The Sunrise Road is open during the summer season only, typically from early July to late September.

As you begin your journey to Sunrise, note the exposed hillsides on the left side of the road created by the road cut. There are several pullouts along the lower part of the road, but a particularly good example of an exposed hillside is at the pullout 1.6 miles from the gate.
Across the road from the pullout is a rock formation that looks like dark grey columns embedded in the hillside. These columns are remnants of an old lava flow that helped form Sunrise Ridge.
Sunrise Point offers unparalleled views of the surrounding Cascade Range in addition to views of Mount Rainier.
If the weather is clear, you will be treated to some of the best views in the park while driving this last section of the road.
At an elevation of 6,400 feet, Sunrise perches on a shoulder of Mount Rainier. It is the highest point in the park accessible by car.
From the first Emmons Vista Overlook, the whole northeast side of the mountain is visible, from the summit to the bottom of the White River Valley.

View the Emmons Glacier and the White River Valley from the second Emmons Vista Overlook. This is the last stop in the Sunrise Geology Audio Tour. Please take your time returning to the trailhead and enjoy your visit to Sunrise! Exhibits in the Sunrise Visitor Center further explore the dramatic geology of Mount Rainier and the Sunrise area.

data.title: Sunrise Geology Audio Tour

data.description: Enjoy the sights and learn more about this landscape that has been shaped by volcanic activity. The meadows here are fragile, do your part by staying on the trail to protect these precious places. To begin this guided loop, start at the trailhead near the Sunrise parking lot, just east of the restrooms. Be prepared for an elevation gain of 300 feet along this trail. As a reminder, pets are not allowed on trails or in wilderness areas throughout Mount Rainier National Park.

data.description: As a boy, Lyndon Johnson knew the home of his Uncle Clarence and Aunt Frank Martin as "the big house on the river." In 1951 he took ownership of the house from his widowed aunt, and the expanding home and associated LBJ Ranch became a center of political activity for nearly 20 years. During the presidential years, the nation and world came to know the big house on the river as the Texas White House. President Johnson spent 25% of those five years at the ranch. data.description: On the morning of June 27, 1864, three Union brigades assaulted the Confederate position at Pigeon Hill. While furious, the overall assault would eventually falter. This tour will give you some of the local history of this area and take you through the elements of the attack and the defense.

images.altText: A black and white photo shows a burnt and blown up landscape after a major Civil War battle
images.caption: After the two armies left, the destruction in their path was still left behind.
images.title: The Front of Kennesaw Mountain

stops.significance: In and around this area was a thriving middle class community of New Salem that was active during and after the Battle of Kennesaw Mountain.
stops.assetName: Pigeon Hill and the New Salem Community

stops.significance: This was the site of where the 63rd Georgia confederate infantry attempted to defend the initial union assault.
From this site, Brigadier General Francis Cockrell's Missouri Brigade defended a furious attack from the rugged heights of Pigeon Hill.
This set of earthworks were used by Lumsden's Alabama Artillery Battery during the Battle of Kennesaw Mountain.
The final part of the Union assault at this position occurred here. The steep terrain and high ground ensured the successful Confederate defense.

data.title: The Action at Pigeon Hill

data.description: The Ancestral Sites Trail takes visitors from the E.E. Fogelson Visitor Center, through the Pecos Pueblo site, and to the ruins of the 1717 Franciscan Mission Church. Waysides help visitors see how life at the Pecos Pueblo and Mission may have looked, while a trail guide gives deeper information on the numbered stops. The trail is 1.25 miles long, and has a 60 foot elevation change.

images.altText: Path, Trail, Stone, Walls, Blue Sky, Wood, Mountains
images.caption: The walls of the South Pueblo along the Ancestral Site Trail
images.title: The Ancestral Site Trail.

stops.significance: The E.E. Fogelson Visitor Center welcomes visitors to the park, allowing them to learn information and prepare to head out on the trail. The Visitor Center also includes an introductory film, a museum, and a bookstore.
Pecos Pueblo was a regional trading center that drew items from the Gulf of Mexico to the Pacific, and down into what is now Mexico.

The 1717 Mission Church and Convento remain from the Franciscan attempts to convert the Pecos people to Christianity. This site is built on the site of an earlier mission that was destroyed during the Pueblo Revolt of 1680.

data.title: The Ancestral Sites Trail
