data.description: Learn the many species of birds who call South Marble Island home! This rocky island is not only home to endangered Steller Sea Lions, but also many birds who feast in the productive waters surrounding the island. Keep a look out for humpback whales who also frequent this area.

images.altText: aerial view of south marble island, a rocky outcropping. Trees and green cover the higher parts.
images.caption: Bird's eye view of South Marble Island
images.title: South Marble Island bird's eye view

stops.significance: A highlight of any trip into the bay is the variety birds readily seen. A slow cruise past South Marble Island offers the opportunity to see many species of birds at once. The island provides nesting habitat for some, while also providing space for birds to rest between feeding excursions. Here are a few of the birds to look out for at South Marble Island and elsewhere in the bay.
stops.assetName: South Marble Island - Bird Tour Introduction

stops.significance: The glaucous-winged gull is not the heaviest bird that lives on South Marble Island, but it does have the largest wingspan at around 58 inches. Click explore to learn more.
stops.assetName: Birds of South Marble: Glaucous-winged Gull

stops.significance: This bird's name comes from their call, a repeated, "Kitti-wake, kitti-wake, kitti-wake!". Click explore to learn more.
stops.assetName: Birds of South Marble: Black-legged Kittiwake

stops.significance: How do these birds use their beautiful orange bill? Not only is it used to scoop up numerous fish to eat, these birds nest in burrows dug into the earthen hills of South Marble Island, and they use their large bills to dig with.
stops.assetName: Birds of South Marble: Tufted Puffin

stops.significance: Puffin bills function like pipe wrenches, opening wide to allow them to carry many fish at one time. And while puffins do fly, they are adapted to be excellent swimmers, diving deep and able to catch several fish at once in their spectacular bills.
stops.assetName: Birds of South Marble: Horned Puffin

stops.significance: The pigeon guillemot's wings are rounded to help it 'fly' underwater. Like other birds at South Marble, it is an even more capable swimmer than flier.
stops.assetName: Birds of South Marble: Pigeon Guillemot

stops.significance: An all-black bird with a vivid orange beak, the black oystercatcher is a striking bird that nests just above the high tide line on Glacier Bay's beaches. Click explore to learn more.
stops.assetName: Birds of South Marble: Black Oystercatcher

stops.significance: The pelagic cormorant is a striking bird. It's long neck and large wingspan allow it to fly with grace above the water's surface, and you are probably noticing a trend here, allows it to swim and fish with power and expert ability.
stops.assetName: Birds of South Marble: Pelagic Cormorant

stops.significance: The Common Murre is an understated bird, but remarkable nonetheless. They nest on rocky leges around South Marble Island, and their eggs have a unique characteristic: They are rounded at one end, which lets them roll in a circle, rather than off the side of the cliffs upon which they nest.
stops.assetName: Birds of South Marble: Common Murre

stops.significance: The marbeled murrelet is a brown bird during their breeding season in Glacier Bay, their round bodies and low flight with rapid wing beats has earned them the nickname of "flying baked potatoes." Click explore to learn more and see anatomical statistics.
stops.assetName: Birds of South Marble: Marbled Murrelet

stops.significance: The final stop of your tour ends with the Kittlitz's Murrelet. A large portion of this bird's worldwide population is thought to live in Glacier Bay. Scientists continue to study these unassuming birds as glaciers melt and the habitat they rely on shrinks with the melting ice.
stops.assetName: Birds of South Marble: Kittlitz's Murrelet

data.title: The Birds of South Marble Island

data.description: The Black Heritage Trail® showcases residences and community buildings associated with a Black community that thrived on, and near, the north slope of Beacon Hill before, during, and after the American Civil War. Throughout that time, this community struggled and organized for equal rights and access to equal education. Community members championed the movement to abolish slavery and even housed freedom seekers on their journey along the Underground Railroad.

images.altText: Smith Court with brick buildings surrounding the court.
images.caption: Smith Court is home to three stops on The Black Heritage Trail®.
images.title: The Black Heritage Trail®

stops.significance: The Robert Gould Shaw and Massachusetts 54th Regiment Memorial commemorates one of the first African American regiments of the Civil War. Following his Emancipation Proclamation in 1863, President Lincoln called for the raising of Black regiments. Massachusetts Governor John Andrew soon created the Massachusetts 54th Volunteer Infantry and chose Robert Gould Shaw, the son of prominent abolitionists, to serve as its colonel. Through their heroic, yet tragic, assault on Fort Wagner, South Carolina on July 18, 1863, in which Shaw and many of his men died, the 54th helped erode Northern public opposition to the use of Black soldiers and inspired the enlistment of more than 180,000 Black men into the U.S. forces. To commemorate this brave Black regiment, Bostonians chose Augustus St. Gaudens to create this high relief bronze monument, which sits prominently on Beacon St. across from the Massachusetts State House. Unveiled in 1897, this monument depicts the 54th as they marched down Beacon St. off to war in 1863.
stops.assetName: Robert Gould Shaw and Massachusetts 54th Regiment Memorial

stops.significance:
George Middleton and Louis Glapion began constructing this two-family residence at 5 Pinckney Street in 1786. Finished a year later, this building is believed to be the oldest standing home on Beacon Hill. 
Louis Glapion worked as a hairdresser and may have been from the French West Indies. During the Revolution, George Middleton led a Black militia company called the Bucks of America. While little evidence of this group has survived, they likely guarded the property of Boston merchants during the Revolution. A horse breaker and livery man by profession, Middleton also served in several Black community organizations. He became the third Grand Master of the African Lodge, later known as the Prince Hall Masons. Middleton and others also organized the African Society, a charitable organization dedicated to community service, uplift, and education. As a community leader, George Middleton helped build some of the early institutions and organizations in the long history of Black activism on Beacon Hill.

Built in 1824, this building originally served as the Boston English High School. It became the Phillips Grammar School in 1844, named after Boston’s first mayor, John Phillips. Until 1855, the Phillips School, like most public schools in the city, only educated White students. Black students attended segregated schools nearby, including one in the basement of the African Meeting House and then later at the Abiel Smith School. Equal School Rights activists such as William Cooper Nell, Lewis Hayden, Benjamin Roberts, and others led protests and petition drives that ultimately compelled the state legislature outlaw segregated schools in Massachusetts in 1855. Following this landmark victory, the Phillips School become one of the first public schools in Boston with an interracial student body.

John J. Smith, a barber, community activist, and state legislator, lived in this home from 1878 to 1893. Born free in Richmond, Virginia, Smith moved to Boston in the 1840s. He became a leading community activist and ran a barbershop that became a center for abolitionist activity. Smith played a crucial role in helping Shadrach Minkins, a freedom seeker arrested in Boston under the provisions of the 1850 Fugitive Slave Law. In a daring rescue, Black Bostonians freed Minkins from the courthouse where the slave catchers held him and helped him make his way to freedom in Canada. Smith and his wife, Georgiana, also participated in the equal school rights movements of the 1850s. Their daughter, Elizabeth, became the first person of African descent to teach in an integrated public school in Boston. During the Civil War, Smith recruited for the Black Massachusetts regiments and the 5th Calvary. He later served in the Massachusetts House of Representatives for three terms, as well as on the Boston Common Council.

Built in 1807, this building originally housed the Third Baptist Church. In April 1836, member Timothy Gilbert tested the church’s racial segregation policy by inviting several African Americans to join him in his pew. The church immediately expelled Gilbert for this violation. He soon set out with several other members to form the First Free Baptist Church, which became officially recognized in 1839. In 1876, the First African Methodist Episcopal congregation purchased the Charles Street Meeting House. This prompted one historian to note while African Americans once sat in one section of the church, "now they own the building." The Meeting House also served as a forum and gathering place for activists. For example, in 1895 Josephine St. Pierre Ruffin and other Black clubwomen formed the National Federation of Afro-American women, a precursor to the National Association of Colored Women. The AME congregation held services in this location until 1939, becoming the last Black institution to leave Beacon Hill.

The Lewis and Harriet Hayden House served as the preeminent Underground Railroad safe house in Boston during the 1850s. In the 1840s, the Haydens escaped slavery in Kentucky and eventually settled here. They lived in this house by 1850, operated it as a boardinghouse, and turned it into one of the most documented safe houses in the area. The Haydens notably assisted in high-profile Fugitive Slave Law cases, helping William and Ellen Craft as well as Shadrach Minkins on their journeys to freedom. In addition to their Underground Railroad work, Lewis and Harriet played other prominent roles in the community. Lewis served as Grand Master of the Prince Hall Masons, presided over numerous community meetings, and participated in the Equal Schools movement. During the Civil War, he recruited Black soldiers for the Massachusetts regiments. Following the War, Lewis Hayden served as one of the first Black members of the state legislature and, along with Harriet, lent his support in the fight for women’s suffrage.

Clothes dealer and community activist John P. Coburn and his family lived at this home beginning in 1844. In addition to his clothing shop, limited evidence suggests that Coburn may have ran a gaming house for wealthy Bostonians in his house. Coburn served as the treasurer of the New England Freedom Association, an organization dedicated to assisting freedom seekers who escaped slavery and came to Boston on the Underground Railroad. In 1851, authorities arrested, though later acquitted, Coburn for his alleged role in aiding in the courthouse rescue of Shadrach Minkins. Along with other community leaders in the 1850s, Coburn founded the Massasoit Guards, an unsanctioned Black militia. Militia groups such the Massasoit Guards can be considered precursors to the Black Civil War regiments, including the famous 54th Massachusetts. Coburn died in 1873 and his home passed to his son Wendell, whose widow, Mary, lived in the house until the turn of the twentieth century.

As home to the African Meeting House and the Abiel Smith School, Smith Court served as a vital center of African American life and culture for much of the nineteenth and earlier twentieth century in Boston. The residences along Smith Court also provide a valuable window into the lives of the African Americans who called this neighborhood home. Residents of 3 Smith Court, James Scott and William Cooper Nell, both sheltered freedom seekers in the 1850s. In 1849, George Washington purchased 5 Smith Court. He served as deacon of the First Independent Baptist Church at the African Meeting House. Built in 1799, 7A Smith Court is the only surviving example of the early homes that lined Holmes Alley. African American chimneysweep and clothing dealer Joseph Scarlett owned 7 Smith Court, 7A Smith Court, and 2 Smith Court. Living in 2 Smith Court, Scarlett rented out the other properties. By the time of his death in 1898, Scarlett owned 15 different properties in Boston, Cambridge, and Charlestown.

The Abiel Smith School opened in 1835 and served as the segregated public school for Black children in Boston for twenty years. Prior to this, Black students attended school at the African School on the ground floor of the African Meeting House. Overcrowded and underfunded, the Smith School became the focal point in the Black community’s ongoing struggle for Equal School Rights in the 1840s and 1850s. William Cooper Nell led the charge against the segregated Smith School, facing opposition from Whites and well as from some in his own community. Over the course of more than 15 years, through a series of local petitions, protests, court cases, and ultimately a state-wide petition, Nell and others successfully convinced the legislature to outlaw public school segregation in 1855. Today, the Smith School houses the Museum Store and exhibition galleries of the Museum of African American History.

Built in 1806, the Meeting House stands as the oldest surviving Black church structure in the nation. It first served as the home for the First African Baptist Church. It also housed the African School for a number of years before the Smith School opened next door, and it hosted numerous community lectures, celebrations, and adult education classes. The Meeting House also served as a gathering space for social activism. Maria Stewart, William Cooper Nell, Lewis Hayden, John Smith, John Coburn, and others used its platform to fight for equal school rights, the end of slavery, and for civil rights. During the Civil War, the Meeting House became a recruitment center for the MA 54th Regiment. A Black church and community center until the end of the 1800s, it became a synagogue in 1904. In 1972, the Meeting House was purchased by the Museum of African American History, who continues to own and operate it today.

data.title: The Black Heritage Trail®

data.description: Hear stories of the officers, soldiers, and civilians during the British Occupation of Philadelphia from September 1777 to June 1778. Which side would you choose?

images.altText: A 19th century painting showing wounded soldiers being treated at Independence Hall.
images.caption: After the Battle of Germantown, The British army housed wounded soldiers inside Independence Hall.
images.credit: Peter Frederick Rothermel, 1862, Pennsylvania Academy of the Fine Arts
images.title: The State House After the Battle

stops.significance: Benjamin Franklin constructed a large and elegant house in this quiet courtyard, outlined at present by a modern steel "ghost" structure. During the occupation, Franklin was in Paris negotiating an alliance with the French. While he was away, British General Charles Grey took up residence in Franklin’s large, three story home. It was one of the finest in the city, and contained a library and electrical equipment. The British stole many of Franklin’s musical instruments, books, and printing tools as well as his portrait. When told that General Howe had captured Philadelphia, Franklin replied, “It is Philadelphia that has captured Howe.” The city that had once so charmed Franklin seemed to have the same effect on the British officers.

Philadelphia’s population nearly doubled once the bulk of the British army arrived to occupy the city. Here at Carpenters’ Hall—where the First Continental Congress met in 1774—British soldiers were treated for their wounds. Local residents worked in the building’s basement, weaving blankets and stitching clothes. For six weeks, conditions were difficult. City residents and the British army lacked food, clothing, firewood and other necessities because supply ships could not reach the city. The American garrison at Ft. Mifflin on the Delaware River posed one obstacle for the ships. The Americans had also placed chevaux de frise, devices used to impale ships’ hulls, in the Delaware River.  Aiding the British was Philadelphian Abraham Carlisle, a member of the Carpenters’ Company.  He informed the British where these devices were hidden. When the American garrison fell, the British used the Carlisle's information to bring their supply ships into the city. Carlisle was later tried and hanged for treason.

In late September 1777, the British army sacked the city. Some of the soldiers made quarters in the Assembly Room of this building, where the Declaration the Independence had been adopted a year earlier. A large pit was dug nearby, where the British disposed of dead men, horses and garbage. The stench was so unbearable that the State House could not be used for a number of months after the American army returned in 1778. A large room spanning the second floor, called the Long Gallery, took on a new use. In happier times, it was a place where Pennsylvania officials hosted elaborate banquets and parties. During the occupation, it was the scene of illness and death. The British imprisoned wounded or ill American officers there.  The sick and dying were placed on litters. Some prisoners were able to survive. Others succumbed to their afflictions. Imagine—as a soldier—dying for your country in the very building were the country was founded.

On July 8th, 1776, the Declaration of Independence was publicly read here in the yard before a large, enthusiastic crowd. Little over a year later, Philadelphians witnessed red-coated British soldiers marching in precision in the same yard.  Across the street, where you see an insurance company building today, sat the Walnut Street jail. Here the British incarcerated American soldiers and ordinary citizens. These citizens had been accused of aiding the enemy cause. Philadelphia Loyalist Joseph Galloway implemented a network of over 80 spies. The spies were city residents who passed along information about their friends or neighbors to Galloway. Those imprisoned met a harsh fate. Hundreds died of mistreatment, beatings and starvation under the approval of Provost Marshal William Cunningham. Philadelphia resident Mrs. Eliza Farmar wrote that one day she sent broth and other food to the prisoners. Cunningham kicked the broth over onto the dirt and laughed as the starving prisoners tried to lap it up.

Formerly called Southeast Square, Washington Square was one of the five public squares laid out by William Penn’s surveyor, Thomas Holme. In the 18th century, it was a pasture as well as a potters’ field, or burial ground. During the British occupation in 1777 and 1778, American soldiers died while incarcerated in the nearby Walnut Street jail. Others succumbed to their wounds on the second floor of Independence Hall. The British buried some of those men in this Square. It is believed that several thousand British and American soldiers are buried here, in unmarked graves. Look for the Tomb of the Unknown Revolutionary War soldier. Today, an eternal flame burns in memoriam where the remains of an American soldier lie in silent repose.

In 1777-1778, British General William Howe made himself at home in this large house vacated by Pennsylvania proprietor Richard Penn.  Later occupants included American General Benedict Arnold and Presidents Washington and Adams.

During the British Occupation, General Howe hosted parties here.  He and the other British officers also attended lavish affairs all across the city.  They – along with Philadelphia’s Loyalist elite-socialized at everything from foot races to play performances.  

Although the home was demolished in 1832, the foundations are still embedded in the ground and form part of the outdoor exhibit. The exhibit examines the paradox between slavery and freedom, and includes a memorial wall recognizing those who toiled in bondage at this site. Located just steps from the Liberty Bell Center, the exhibit is open daily from 7am to 10pm. No tickets are required, and there is no admission fee.

Both patriots and loyalists worshipped at Christ Church. During the Revolutionary War, Rector Jacob Duche initially supported the American cause, serving as chaplain to the Second Continental Congress. But Duche remained in the city when the British invaded in 1777. During Sunday services at Christ Church, he said prayers on behalf of King George III, perhaps fearing retribution for his allegiance to the Congress. Despite this, the British arrested Duche.  After a night in the Walnut Street jail, Duche recanted his allegiance to the United States. He even sent a letter to General Washington urging him to surrender. Washington was furious, but later came to believe that Duche’s actions were motivated by fear. Duche left with the British army and sailed to England. After the war, he returned to Philadelphia. 
Take a moment to consider the impact of the occupation on all Philadelphians. If you were living in Philadelphia during the British occupation, which side would you choose?

data.title: The British Occupation of Philadelphia

data.description: The history of this coastal region includes stories of hard work, noble ideals and freedom. These narratives become less romantic and more difficult to understand when we include the story of slavery. On this walking tour, we’ll explore how enslaved labor in the West Indies fueled colonial New England’s economy and examine the story of a well-known Salem merchant, Richard Derby, to consider the opportunities slavery afforded white colonists.

images.altText: Black and white photo of large sailing vessel travelling through open water.
images.caption: The FRIENDSHIP was a trading vessel that traveled the world.
images.title: FRIENDSHIP OF SALEM

stops.significance: In Salem, fish would not only be a vital food source but the ticket to a global trade market.

Before American independence, the British Customs Service collected duties (taxes) on imported cargo. Later the U.S. Customs Service stored cargo in bonded warehouses like this one until merchants paid duties and storage fees. This system allowed merchants to maximize profit by waiting for trade goods to increase in value before paying duties and putting goods on the market.

Wealthy Salem merchants amassed enough wealth to own large houses, fishing stations, fishing and trading vessels, rum distilleries, farms, and wharves. Stories of colonial prosperity speak to hard work, innovation, and are early examples of the American dream fulfilled in the business of slavery.

This structure, built by Captain Henry Prince, was documented in Salem directories as a “West India Goods Store” from 1836 to 1851. Like other retail shops, this store sold items from all over the world, in addition to local produce and products. Items from the West Indies–sugar, molasses, coffee, indigo–were the products of forced labor camps, also known as slave plantations.

The original FRIENDSHIP was built in 1796 in a Salem shipbuilding yard. This trading vessel traveled across the Atlantic world, including one trip to Venezuela in 1799. It returned with products of enslaved labor–cocoa, indigo, and coffee.
With increasing fortune, Richard and Elias Hasket Derby began construction of Derby Wharf in 1762. The wharf became a center of maritime trade and later privateering during the Revolutionary War.
The business of slavery continued in New England following the Revolutionary War with the U.S. Customs Service collecting taxes on goods produced by forced labor.

data.title: The Business of Slavery

data.description: Are you wanting to follow the Lewis and Clark trail chronologically through their time at the mouth of the Columbia River? Do you just want to know the main Lewis and Clark sites in the Pacific Northwest to visit? This is the FULL Lewis and Clark experience tour for your stay here in the Pacific Northwest! Sites on this tour are in chronological order from when the expedition first arrived here but you can visit them in any order. This tour features both State and National Parks. Fees apply.

images.altText: A black and white sketch map of the mouth of the Columbia River with labels of different sites
images.caption: Captain Clark drew a detailed map of the mouth of the Columbia River, all sites you can visit today.
images.title: Clark's map of the Columbia River

park.fullName: Lewis and Clark National Historical Park
park.name: Lewis and Clark

stops.significance: Coming down the Columbia River this is one of the first major stops at the mouth of the river. However, it was not by their own choice, but instead the raging storms forced them to camp upon driftwood and rocks.

This site was used not only by the expedition for surveying and scouting after escaping Dismal Nitch but was also the central trade hub of the Chinook Nation with fur trading vessels. Later on in its life it would become a settler town and the McGowan church still stands to this day.

Cape Disappointment had already been named by the time the expedition arrived, but that didn't stop Lewis and a few others from traversing the area in search of where fur traders may come into the Columbia. Today there are many hiking trails and notably a large Lewis and Clark interpretive center here that speaks on the entire expedition and features some of Sergeant Patrick Gass's items. 

This site is a Washington State Park site and requires separate fees or passes where applicable.

Fort Clatsop is the winter headquarters site for the Lewis and Clark expedition. They arrived at this site on December 7th, 1805 and will stay until March 23rd, 1806. It is here that they survive for 106 days, with 94 of them being raining. 

From this location smaller parties of the Corps will explore the region, make their way to the ocean to make salt, and eventually even head around Tillamook Head in search of a whale.

A replica of Fort Clatsop can be found here as well as an interpretive center. 

Other audio self-guided tours are available for this site and are recommended for a full experience.
 
National Park fees apply here, with a national park pass getting the pass holder and three adults in for free.

The Lewis and Clark expedition paddled by this site frequently on their hunting trips and other exploration voyages from their headquarters site at Fort Clatsop. The local nations that lived here have used the river as a means of trade and travel for generations. 

More recently the site was a logging wet sort yard, but now has been turned into a picnic area with interpretive panels and signs to enjoy.
stops.assetName: Netul Landing & the Netul River Trail

stops.significance: Youngs River Falls is a scenic vista that has been featured in many notable films throughout the years. However not as many know that this site was originally documented by Sergeant Patrick Gass during a hunting expedition.

Salt was a very important part of the American diet, whether it was for flavoring or more importantly food preservation. With their salt supplies dwindling the expedition needed to restock for their return journey. 

To that end they had a crew down 15 miles from Fort Clatsop boiling the ocean water 24/7until February 20th 1806 where they completed making approximately 3.5 bushels, or 28 gallons, of "Excellent, fine, strong & white" salt.

There was an indigenous household nearby of whom the party befriended as well, trading and receiving aid from them.

The final stop on the Lewis and Clark journey has you visiting where the 105-foot blue whale washed ashore. Unfortunately, by the time they arrived the whale was stripped clean and they would end up going to nearby modern-day NeCus' Park to trade for blubber and oil.

data.title: The Complete Lewis and Clark Pacific Northwest Tour

data.description: This self-guided tour will explore some of the key points of the Confederate defensive position and their actions near Cheatham Hill during the Battle of Kennesaw Mountain.

images.altText: This is a color oil painting showing a chaotic Civil War battle
images.caption: Union soldiers attempt to break the Confederate line at Cheatham Hill
images.title: 'Dead Angle'

stops.significance: Monument honoring the Texas regiments present during the Battle of Kennesaw Mountain. Monument also stands at the location where most of the regiments were located during the battle.
This was the site of a notable truce during the battle of Kennesaw Mountain. Both sides ceased firing and worked together to drag wounded and burning men to safety.
Key artillery position utilized by the Confederate defense during the battle of Kennesaw Mountain.
Arguably the most violent and chaotic location during the Battle of Kennesaw Mountain and the site of the most casualties.
A grave honoring an unknown soldier of the Battle of Kennesaw Mountain. This is the only official burial in the park.
stops.assetName: The Grave of the Unknown Soldier

data.title: The Confederate Line of Cheatham Hill

data.description: How are the stories of the American Revolution remembered and re-told? Together, these six tour stops reveal how our society’s collective memory is constantly evolving. A walking tour developed by students in HIST 1776, Harvard College, Fall 2021. Special thanks to the Boston Camerata and their artistic director Anne Azema for permission to use music from their 2019 album Free America! Songs of Resistance and Rebellion released by Harmonia Mundi for this walking tour.

images.altText: watercolor of four men in different uniforms, a Black soldier, a militiaman, a rifleman, and officer
images.caption: Jean Baptiste Antoine de Verger depicted his fellow soldiers in his Revolutionary War journal.
images.credit: Anne S.K. Brown Military Collection at the Brown University Library
images.title: Soldiers in Uniform by Verger

park.fullName: Longfellow House Washington's Headquarters National Historic Site
park.name: Longfellow House Washington's Headquarters

stops.significance:
The house you stand in front of right now was the headquarters of General George Washington for nine months, from July 1775 until April 1776.  Here, Washington first grappled with slavery in New England and the presence of Black soldiers in the new Continental Army.

It seems that the stories of Washington’s encounter with Darby Vassall and his initial enlistment ban of Black soldiers clash with the American Revolution’s ideals of liberty and justice for all. How do you think you can reconcile these stories and ideals, if at all?

Music: "Chester" performed by members of the Boston Camerata under the direction of Anne Azema from their 2019 album released by Harmonia Mundi.

During the Revolutionary War, soldiers of the Continental Army used this area to practice military drills and set up camps. The various memorials and monuments you see here allude to the long history of this park. In particular, there are three notable monuments to the American Revolution: three cannons installed in 1875, a marker for the "Washington Elm," and a memorial to Prince Hall.

Which monument speaks to you the most? How do these three monuments differ in the ways they present memorializing the Revolutionary War period?

Music: "Free Americay!" performed by members of the Boston Camerata under the direction of Anne Azema from their 2019 album released by Harmonia Mundi.

Among the hundreds of burials, many unmarked, in this cemetery are at least nineteen soldiers from the Revolutionary War, including two Black soldiers named Cato Freeman and Neptune Frost.

What does the story of Cato Freeman reveal about the American Revolution and about New England as the so-called “cradle of liberty”?

Music: "Liberty Tree" performed by members of the Boston Camerata under the direction of Anne Azema from their 2019 album released by Harmonia Mundi.

When George Washington first arrived in Cambridge on July 2, 1775, he set up his initial headquarters here in the Harvard president’s residence, today called the Wadsworth House.

After about two weeks, Washington moved out of this Headquarters - possibly because of its proximity to the Continental Army's barracks, also in Harvard Yard.

Music: "The Cuba March" performed by members of the Boston Camerata under the direction of Anne Azema from their 2019 album released by Harmonia Mundi.

From 1775 to 1776, Massachusetts Hall, now an office building and student dormitory, served as the barracks for approximately 640 members of the Continental Army. Early in Washington's time in command he began to make clear distinctions in the rank and status of officers and enlisted men.

In some ways, Washington's emphasis on hierarchy clashes with the central role of equality in the language of the Revolution. Where does hierarchy show up in your life? Do you associate it with tension, or order?

Music: "Boston March" performed by members of the Boston Camerata under the direction of Anne Azema from their 2019 album released by Harmonia Mundi.

Fort Washington Park is the home of the only physical remnant left of the many fortifications built by Washington and his troops during the siege of Boston. Since historic preservation was not on the minds of many during the early years of the United States, all of the other fortifications built during the war were lost to farmers and developers.

Are there any historical landmarks in your town that you’re glad have been preserved? Is there anything you know of that you wish had been preserved?

Music: "The Appletree" performed by members of the Boston Camerata under the direction of Anne Azema from their 2019 album released by Harmonia Mundi.

data.title: The Continental Army in Cambridge

data.description: Step back in time to follow in the footsteps of the people who travelled through this area before it was a national park. The Crossing Trail follows one of the old roads used by American Indians and early settlers as well as Revolutionary War troops lead by George Washington and the Comte de Rochambeau as they crossed through this area on their way to Yorktown.

images.altText: Narrow dirt path winds through a green forest
images.caption: Hike the Crossing Trail
images.title: Crossing Trail

data.title: The Crossing Trail Hike

data.description: The Freedom Trail is a collection of public and private sites linked together throughout Boston which work to preserve the history of sites relevant to Boston's role in America's struggle for freedom. Boston National Historical Park, established in 1974, works with these sites in order to preserve and tell these stories. The trail itself stretches from Boston Common to Charlestown Navy Yard - two and a half miles for visitors from all over the world to come explore their past.

images.altText: Photo looking down at a red brick sidewalk. In center is a bronze circular medallion
images.caption: Freedom trail path and medallion
images.title: The Freedom Trail

stops.significance:
Welcome to Boston’s Freedom Trail. Originally designed in the 1950s, the Freedom Trail is an iconic symbol of Boston. Its red brick line snakes through some of the oldest parts of this City, leading visitors to notable historic sites in the Downtown, North End, and Charlestown neighborhoods of Boston. The trail introduces visitors to Boston's storied, complicated, and multi-faceted history. While many sites are primarily recognized for their role in the American Revolution, all the sites on the Freedom Trail have stood as the backdrop of subsequent social, political, and religious movements, controversies, and challenges. 

While the Freedom Trail can be picked up at any site, most visitors choose to start at the Boston Common. This is our first stop.

Considered the oldest public park in the United States, Boston Common remains the last piece of relatively undeveloped landscape in Downtown Boston. The land you stand on—called Shawmut by the Massachusett people—connects thousands of years of use. Here, the ancestors of the Massachusett lived, hunted, and fished. To this day, members of the Massachusett return every year to the Common to rebuild a fishing weir on the same ground. The Boston Common has served a combination of public, military, agricultural, and recreational purposes throughout its history. In the 1760s and 70s, colonists protested here against British policies. During the American War for Independence, British soldiers used the space for training and encampment. Following the war, it held celebrations for the nation’s independence. Bostonians have since gathered on the Common for various events, including women’s rights demonstrations, Anti-Vietnam War protests, Civil Rights rallies, and Boston Pride.

The Robert Gould Shaw and Massachusetts 54th Regiment Memorial commemorates one of the first African American regiments of the Civil War. Following his Emancipation Proclamation in 1863, President Lincoln called for the raising of Black regiments. Massachusetts Governor John Andrew soon created the Massachusetts 54th Volunteer Infantry and chose Robert Gould Shaw, the son of prominent abolitionists, to serve as its colonel. Through their heroic, yet tragic, assault on Fort Wagner, South Carolina on July 18, 1863, in which Shaw and many of his men died, the 54th helped erode Northern public opposition to the use of Black soldiers and inspired the enlistment of more than 180,000 Black men into the U.S. forces. To commemorate this brave Black regiment, Bostonians chose Augustus St. Gaudens to create this high relief bronze monument, which sits prominently on Beacon St. across from the Massachusetts State House. Unveiled in 1897, this monument depicts the 54th as they marched down Beacon St. off to war in 1863.
stops.assetName: Robert Gould Shaw and Massachusetts 54th Regiment Memorial

stops.significance: Completed in 1798, the Massachusetts State House sits at the western edge of the Boston Common. Designed by Charles Bullfinch, the building houses the State Senate, House of Representatives, and Governor’s Office. Since its completion, the Massachusetts State House has been a site of debate and discussion. Representatives and members of the public have grappled with the essential principles of justice, liberty, and representation. Those who first struggled to gain access to the building still found ways to ensure their voices would be heard within its walls. Black and White abolitionists petitioned for the end of slavery and against the 1850 Fugitive Slave Law. African Americans petitioned for equal access to education, leading to the State Legislatures’ ban on segregated education in 1855. Women petitioned for greater civil rights, most importantly, the right to vote. When open, the State House offers free tours where you can see murals, statues, and governors’ portraits that illustrate the state’s history.

Park Street Church has stood on the corner opposite Boston Common since 1809. The church’s spire and its bells, which sound twice daily from its steeple, have long been Boston landmarks. The church's first members operated in an evangelical fashion, which led to this intersection being nicknamed “Brimstone Corner.” The church’s evangelical mission also meant it organized and supported some of the earliest missionaries sent out of the United States. The most notable missionaries went to Hawaii starting in 1819. Many missionary descendants were involved in the overthrow of the Hawaiian monarchy and annexation of the islands by the U.S. in the 1890s. While founded after the Revolutionary war, it remained a space of discussion for the founding principles, serving as site for lectures, speeches, and performances. During the 1800s, abolitionist organizations held events here that made the argument to expand liberty to all. Today, the church maintains an active evangelical congregation with weekly services.

One of Boston’s earliest burying grounds, the Granary Burying Ground serves as the resting place of early victims to British tyranny as well as Revolutionary heroes. It was established in 1660 when Boston’s first burying ground, now known as the King’s Chapel Burying Ground, began to run out of burial space in the late 1650s. The Burying Ground acquired its name from a granary, a grain storage building, built next door in 1737. Examples of the iconic New England gravestone art, such as images of cherubs, scythes, willow trees, and Classical urns, can be found throughout the burying grounds. Some of colonial Boston’s most famous residents are buried in the Granary, including John Hancock, Paul Revere, Samuel Adams, and Crispus Attucks. Less famous figures, such as victims of fire and plague, and generations of common people, are also buried there. Granary Burying Ground remains a popular space where visitors can pay tribute to the named and unnamed revolutionaries of colonial Boston.

Founded in 1686 as Boston’s first Anglican church, King’s Chapel held services in temporary locations until 1688 when a wooden chapel was constructed on the corner of the town’s first burying ground, now known as the King’s Chapel Burying Ground. The current stone chapel was designed in 1749 and completed in 1754. Many in the congregation remained loyal to the crown leading up to the American Revolution. A third of the church’s members and its reverend fled during the British evacuation of Boston on March 17, 1776. During this time, Old South Church used King’s Chapel for services due to damage their building had sustained. The remaining congregation finally returned in 1782. In 1787, the congregation officially declared themselves Unitarian and independent, making it the first Unitarian church in the United States. The congregation still meets in the 1754 building and remains an active Christian Unitarian church. King’s Chapel is also open for general visitation.
The King’s Chapel Burying Ground is the oldest European burial space in the city of Boston, dating back to 1630 and the earliest days of the Massachusetts Bay Colony.

Founded in Boston on April 23, 1635, the Boston Latin School became the first school in what is now the United States. The first headmasters held classes in their homes until the completion of the school building at this site. The wooden structure remained for the next 100 years, and then it moved across the street to a new location. A mosaic in the sidewalk commemorates this original site of the school. In the 1700s, several of Boston's well-known revolutionary figures, such as Samuel Adams and John Hancock, studied here before attending Harvard. A statue of Benjamin Franklin remembers the school’s most famous dropout.

The Old Corner Bookstore gained prominence in the literary world under the ownership of William D. Ticknor and James T. Fields. From the 1830s to the 1860s, they helped shape Boston’s literary scene. The bookstore sold works written by both New England and British writers, including Ralph Waldo Emerson and Charles Dickens. While the site is known as a 19th century bookselling hub, its history goes back much further. In the 1630s, Anne Hutchinson used it to hold secret, unorthodox religious meetings. In 1960, the building was threatened to be demolished, but a group of citizens jumped to save it. This effort led to the establishment of Historic Boston Incorporated, which formed to save and restore the building. Today, the Old Corner Bookstore remains a commercial space in the heart of Downtown Boston.

In 1669, 50 men and women rejected Boston’s First Church and its narrow view of church membership and voting citizenship. These “Dissenting Brethren” formed a new church reflecting their more open vision of membership and citizenship. In 1729 they built their new Meetinghouse, now known as Old South Meeting House. It remains a brick and wood expression of their Puritan belief and worship. This site became an active place of debate in the years leading to the American Revolution. Speakers such as Dr. Joseph Warren commemorated the Boston Massacre and protested other unjust laws. In 1773, thousands packed Old South Meetinghouse to protest the arrival of East India Company Tea and the tax it was subject to. Their final meeting on December 16 resulted in the Boston Tea Party where Bostonians dumped 92,000 pounds of tea into the ocean, helping to precipitate war and independence. During the siege of Boston, British soldiers tore up pews and pulpit, spread dirt over the floor and turned it into a riding stable.

Starting in 1713, the colonial governing bodies met in three chambers on the second floor of the Old State House. These men waged policies that expanded their control and influence over New England and modern-day Canada. In doing so, they came into conflict with Indigenous peoples and French colonists. The Seven Years’ War with France and their Indigenous allies led to internal conflict as popular legislators rejected new laws and taxes proposed by British Parliament. This resistance turned into revolution. 

Following the Revolutionary War, the government of Massachusetts transformed into a government built upon the idea that all men are created equal. But this experiment also inherited and continued a legacy of land dispossession, enslavement, and exclusion. The Old State House represents both the painful legacies of colonial America and the promise that the people have the tools to confront injustice and shape a more just and equitable future. 

Revolutionary Spaces stewards the Old State House today.

After two years of occupation by the British Army, tensions in Boston reached an all time high in 1770. On March 5, a wigmaker’s apprentice got into a fight with a 29th Regiment soldier over a bill dispute. Confusion of the scene increased as calls of a fire brought people into the streets. A crowd of men gathered, some with buckets, others with makeshift weapons, such as snowballs and bricks. The soldier called for backup. The standoff escalated, and one soldier was struck and fell. As he stood, he lowered his musket and fired, as did others, though no order was given. The first bloodshed of the Revolution in Boston fell in front of the Old State House. In all, five men died. After a trial in October,  only two soldiers were convicted of manslaughter. Though the two sides settled into an uneasy compromise, the patriots did not forget the massacre on King Street. A “round, wheel-shaped” memorial consisting of 13 circles of cobblestones was installed at the foot of the Old State House in 1886.

The original Faneuil Hall finished construction in 1742 and served as a town meeting hall and marketplace. Bostonians named the building after its benefactor, Peter Faneuil, a Boston merchant who profited from the labor of enslaved persons in the Caribbean and from trafficking enslaved Africans around the Atlantic. His wealth, and likely the funds for the building, came from the profits of his Atlantic trading empire. While the building has gone through rehabilitation and expansion since 1742, Faneuil Hall has remained a site of meetings, protests, and debate. Its unofficial name, the “Cradle of Liberty,” was coined by James Otis in 1763. Though most known for its Revolutionary-era protests, Faneuil Hall has served as a gathering space for successive generations to discuss and debate the meaning and legacy of American liberty, including abolitionists, women’s suffragists, labor activists, and the LGBTQ+ community. Today, Bostonians continue to use Faneuil Hall for political, social, and cultural events.

Built around 1680, this house replaced the parsonage of the Second Church of Boston, which was destroyed in the Great Fire of 1676. Paul Revere bought the home in 1770 while working as a silversmith. He joined “the cause of liberty” as a political cartoon engraver, courier, and spy. Revere and others warned patriots that British soldiers left Boston to head towards Lexington and Concord on April 18, 1775. He continued to support the cause during the years of the Revolutionary War. After Revere sold the home around 1800, it became a sailors’ boarding house. Throughout the 19th century, the North End was home to Irish immigrants, Eastern European Jews, and Southern Italians. The home became a tenement with businesses. In 1902, Revere’s great-grandson purchased the house to prevent it from being demolished. The Paul Revere Memorial Association began restoring the house in 1905 and opened to the public in April 1908. The home remains open today. It is the only remaining 17th century home in Boston.

Built in 1723, the Old North Church, known officially as Christ Church, is the oldest standing church building in Boston today. Built in the style of London architect Christopher Wren, Old North stands as one of the earliest examples of Georgian architecture in North America. On the evening of April 18, 1775, British soldiers left Boston and headed towards Lexington and Concord. Paul Revere instructed that a lantern signal be sent from the tallest building in town, the church’s steeple, to indicate how the army had left. The lantern’s story was immortalized in Henry Wadsworth Longfellow’s 1861 poem 'Paul Revere’s Ride,' with the famous phrase, “One if by land, and two if by sea.” This alert gave the militias around Boston time to prepare. The skirmishes at Lexington and Concord the next day are considered the opening battles of the American Revolution. Old North maintains an active Episcopal congregation and welcomes visitors to the church and historic site.

Copp’s Hill Burying Ground was established in 1660 after the burying ground at King’s Chapel began to fill up. Located on a hill that partially belonged to shoemaker William Copp, it became the resting place of thousands of people who lived, worked, and died in the North End. Among those interred are merchant John Pulling Jr. and Old North Church caretaker Robert Newman, two men believed to have held the signal lanterns on April 18, 1775 to warn of the British advance on Lexington and Concord. Copp’s Hill also houses many of the graves of Boston’s early African population, including Black educator, leather dresser, and Masonic Grand Master Prince Hall. Though blocked by the nineteenth century houses that now fill the North End, Copp’s Hill still offers a beautiful view of the Charles River and Charlestown. Visitors can get a glimpse of the same vantage point British soldiers used during the Battle of Bunker Hill, setting up their cannons among the headstones and bombarding Breed’s Hill on June 17, 1775.

On the evening of June 16, 1775, colonial militia units marched here to Charlestown and fortified what’s known today as Breed’s Hill. By morning, British cannon opened fire as British forces assembled to land and attack the hill. As the British forces began their assault, units from Massachusetts, Connecticut, and New Hampshire hastily formed a line of defense. Among those on the battlefield were also over one hundred patriots of color, indigenous men and men of African descent. While the militias initially held back British soldiers, they were soon forced to retreat. This bloody battle lasted no longer than two hours and was devastating to both sides. While ultimately a loss for the New England forces, the Battle of Bunker Hill became symbolic of the spirit of those fighting for ideas of liberty.

At the Museum, visitors can explore exhibits and dioramas that share the stories of the Battle of Bunker Hill, the construction of the Monument, and the history of the Charlestown Neighborhood.

The Bunker Hill Monument was built to memorialize the location of the Battle of Bunker Hill and make the battle a unifying, shared story for Americans. It resembles an Egyptian obelisk, and has a 294-step granite staircase to the top. The people of Charlestown have embraced the battle and later the Monument with celebrations and parades every June 17. Activists and artists have since activated the Monument throughout the 20th and 21st centuries.  
Adjacent to the monument is the Bunker Hill Lodge, built in 1903; this Greek Revival granite building replaced an earlier wooden structure built to house the Doctor Joseph Warren statue. The Lodge also held artifacts and dioramic scenes from the battle. The National Park Service moved these items to the Bunker Hill Museum in 2008, which sits directly across from the Monument.

The area Charlestown Navy Yard occupies was once tidal flats that provided sustenance to local Indigenous communities. These flats acted as a landing area in the 1775 Battle of Bunker Hill. Established in 1800, the Charlestown Navy Yard served as a space of shipbuilding innovation for 174 years: Dry Dock 1 was the one of the first two dry docks constructed in the country; the Ropewalk produced all the rope for the entire U.S. Navy; and the Chain Forge developed and used a unique process called Die-Lock, which created incredibly strong links. Workers at the Charlestown Navy Yard built over 200 ships and repaired thousands more. Over half of these ships were constructed during World War II, the most productive years of the Charlestown Navy Yard. During this time, the Navy Yard increased its workforce from 17,000 civilian workers to over 50,000 workers, including women and workers of various ethnic and racial backgrounds. The Navy Yard joined Boston National Historical Park in 1974.

The USS CONSTITUTION and five other warships comprised the new Navy for the United States after the Revolutionary War. Built in Boston and launched in 1797, the CONSTITUTION is the oldest commissioned warship afloat in the world today. During the War of 1812 the ship gained fame and its name “Old Ironsides.” During its first big battle against the British warship HMS GUERRIERE, sailors observed how well the ship’s hardwood sides repelled the cannonballs. It also had 55 guns on board. The ship went on to defeat four other British warships during the war and evade capture. The ship served on squadrons around the world and seized its last ship in November 1853 while on patrol for slave traders headed to America from West Africa. It later became a training vessel. After a national cruise from 1931 – 1934, it returned to Boston, where it remains today. The CONSTITUTION now sits in the Charlestown Navy Yard as both a training and ceremonial ship for the Navy, as well as an educational experience for visitors.

The USS Constitution Museum opened in 1976 in the former pump house for Dry Dock 1 in the Charlestown Navy Yard. The Museum is a private, non-profit, and non-government funded complement to the USS CONSTITUTION. Museum staff collect, preserve, and interpret the artifacts and archival material related to the Ship and crew through interactive exhibitions, compelling programs, and engaging outreach initiatives. Through its innovative education programs, interactive exhibits, and groundbreaking research, the Museum presents a model for how stories of the past can become relevant, relatable, and, most of all, fun for all ages. Working with the National Parks of Boston, the Museum expanded into two adjacent buildings and built a connecting corridor in the mid-1990s. In 2001, the Museum completed renovations on a new storage facility and research library. Today, over 350,000 people visit the Museum each year to learn, explore, and research, making it one of Boston’s most visited museums.

Built in 1943 in San Pedro, California, USS CASSIN YOUNG is one of 175 Fletcher-class destroyers built during World War II. The ship’s namesake was Captain Cassin Young, a U.S. Navy service member who earned a Medal of Honor for heroics at Pearl Harbor and was killed in action at the Naval Battle at Guadalcanal. The ship was active in the Pacific Theater during WWII, serving in seven separate campaigns. It had a crew of 325 men. Commissioned in December 31, 1943, the ship engaged in combat in April 1944. Following the April 1, 1945 assault on Okinawa, CASSIN YOUNG took up the duties of radar picket ship, where it was struck by kamikazes twice. It was decommissioned in May 1946 but was recalled at the outbreak of the Korean Conflict in September 1951. The ship was decommissioned again on April 29, 1960 and moved to a reserve fleet in Norfolk Naval Shipyard, Virginia. It has been a part of the Boston National Historical Park since June 1981, opening to the public as a museum ship at the Charlestown Navy Yard.

data.title: The Freedom Trail®

data.description: El sendero de la libertad es una colección de lugares vinculados en toda la Ciudad de Boston que trabajan para preservar la historia de los sitios relacionados con el rol de Boston en la lucha de los EE. UU. por la libertad. El Parque Nacional Histórico de Boston trabaja con estos sitios para preservar y contar estas historias. El sendero en sí se extiende desde el Boston Common hasta el Astillero Naval de Charlestown; 2.5 millas para que los visitantes alrededor del mundo vengan a explorar su pasado.

images.altText: Freedom Trail medallion with brick lines extending in three directions
images.caption: Visita el sendero de la libertad, "The Freedom Trail," en Boston, Massachusetts.
images.title: The Freedom Trail - Español

stops.significance: Bienvenido al Sendero de la Libertad en Boston. Diseñado originalmente en la década de 1950, Freedom Trail es un símbolo icónico de Boston. Su línea de ladrillos rojos serpentea a través de algunas de las partes más antiguas de esta ciudad, llevando a los visitantes a sitios históricos notables en los vecindarios del centro de Boston, North End y Charlestown. El sendero presenta a los visitantes la rica, complicada y multifacética historia de Boston. Si bien muchos sitios son reconocidos principalmente por su papel en la Revolución Americana, todos los sitios en el Sendero de la Libertad han sido el telón de fondo de posteriores movimientos, controversias y desafíos sociales, políticos y religiosos. El Sendero de la Libertad se puede tomar en cualquier lugar, y la mayoría de los visitantes eligen comenzar en el parque público del Boston Common. Esta es nuestra primera parada.

Considerado el parque público más antiguo de los Estados Unidos, el Boston Common sigue siendo la última parte del paisaje relativamente subdesarrollado en el centro de Boston. La tierra en la que se encuentra, llamada Shawmut por la tribu de Massachusetts, conecta miles de años de uso. Aquí, los ancestros de los Massachusetts vivieron, cazaron y pescaron. Hasta el día de hoy, los miembros de la tribu Massachusetts regresan todos los años al Common para reconstruir una presa de pesca en el mismo terreno. El Boston Common ha tenido una combinación de propósitos públicos, militares, agrícolas y recreativos a lo largo de su historia. En las décadas de 1760 y 1770, los colonos protestaron aquí contra las políticas británicas y durante la Guerra de Independencia de los Estados Unidos, los soldados británicos utilizaron el espacio para entrenamiento y campamento. Después de la guerra, realizó celebraciones por la independencia de la nación. Desde entonces, los bostonianos se han reunido en Common para varios evento

El monumento conmemorativo del regimiento 54 de Massachusetts y Robert Gould Shaw conmemora uno de los primeros regimientos afroamericanos de la Guerra Civil. Después de su Proclamación de Emancipación en 1863, el presidente Lincoln pidió el reclutamiento de regimientos negros. El gobernador de Massachusetts, John Andrew, pronto creó la 54ª Infantería de Voluntarios de Massachusetts y eligió a Robert Gould Shaw, hijo de destacados abolicionistas, para que sirviera como su coronel. A través de su heroico pero trágico asalto a Fort Wagner, Carolina del Sur el 18 de julio de 1863, en el que Shaw y muchos de sus hombres murieron, el Regimiento #54 ayudó a levantar la oposición pública del norte al uso de soldados negros e inspiró el alistamiento de más de 180.000 hombres negros en las fuerzas estadounidenses. Para conmemorar a este valiente regimiento negro, los bostonianos eligieron a Augustus St. Gaudens para crear este monumento de bronce en alto relieve, que ocupa un lugar destacado en la Calle Beacon frente
stops.assetName: Robert Gould Shaw and Massachusetts 54th Regiment Memorial

stops.significance: Completada en 1798, la Casa del Estado de Massachusetts se encuentra en el borde occidental del Boston Common. Diseñado por Charles Bullfinch, el edificio alberga el Senado Estatal, la Cámara de Representantes y la Oficina del Gobernador. Desde su finalización, la Casa del Estado de Massachusetts ha sido un lugar de debate y discusión. Representantes y miembros del público han lidiado con los principios esenciales de justicia, libertad y representación. Aquellos que tuvieron problemas en el inicio para acceder al edificio aún encontraron formas de asegurarse de que sus voces se escucharan dentro de sus paredes. Los abolicionistas blancos y negros peticionaron a favor del fin de la esclavitud y en contra la Ley de Esclavos Fugitivos de 1850. Las mujeres peticionaron mayores derechos civiles, sobre todo, el derecho al voto. Cuando la Casa del Estado está abierta ofrece recorridos gratuitos donde se pueden ver murales, estatuas y retratos de gobernadores que ilustran la historia del estado.

La Iglesia de la Calle Park se encuentra en la esquina opuesta del Boston Common desde 1809. La aguja de la iglesia y sus campanas, que suenan dos veces al día desde su campanario, han sido durante mucho tiempo puntos de referencia de Boston. Los primeros miembros de la iglesia operaron de manera evangélica, lo que llevó a que esta intersección fuera apodada "Brimstone Corner" (La Esquina de Azufre). La misión evangélica de la iglesia también significó que organizó y apoyó a algunos de los primeros misioneros enviados fuera de los Estados Unidos. Muchos descendientes de misioneros participaron en el derrocamiento de la monarquía hawaiana y la anexión de las islas por parte de Estados Unidos en la década de 1890. Aunque fue fundada después de la Guerra Revolucionaria, siguió siendo un espacio de discusión de los principios fundacionales, sirviendo como sede de conferencias, discursos y actuaciones. Hoy en día, la iglesia mantiene una congregación evangélica activa con servicios semanales.

Uno de los primeros cementerios de Boston, el Cementerio del Granero, sirve como lugar de reposo  de las primeras víctimas de la tiranía británica y de los héroes revolucionarios. Se estableció en 1660 cuando el primer cementerio de Boston, ahora conocido como el Cementerio de la Capilla del Rey (King's Chapel Burying Ground), comenzó a quedarse sin espacio para sepulturas a fines de la década de 1650. El cementerio adquirió su nombre debido a un edificio de almacenamiento de granos, construido al lado del cementerio en 1737. Algunos de los residentes más famosos del Boston colonial están enterrados en el granero, incluidos John Hancock, Paul Revere, Samuel Adams y Crispus Attucks. Figuras menos famosas, como víctimas de incendios y plagas, y generaciones de personas comunes, también están enterradas allí.  El cementerio del Granero sigue siendo un espacio popular donde los visitantes pueden rendir homenaje a los revolucionarios con nombre y sin nombre del Boston colonial.

Fundada en 1686 como la primera iglesia anglicana de Boston, la Capilla del Rey celebró servicios en lugares temporeros hasta 1688, cuando se construyó una capilla de madera en la esquina del primer cementerio de la ciudad, ahora conocido como el Cementerio de la Capilla del Rey. La capilla actual de piedra fue diseñada en 1749 y terminada en 1754, ya que muchos en la congregación permanecieron leales a la corona antes de la Revolución Americana. Un tercio de los miembros de la iglesia y su reverendo huyeron durante la evacuación británica de Boston el 17 de marzo de 1776. La congregación restante finalmente regresó en 1782. En 1787, la congregación se declaró oficialmente unitaria e independiente, convirtiéndola en la primera iglesia de esta denominación en los Estados Unidos. La congregación todavía se reúne en el edificio de 1754 y sigue siendo una iglesia unitaria cristiana activa. La Capilla del Rey también está abierta para visitas generales.
El Cementerio de la Capilla del Rey es el espacio funerario europeo más antiguo de la ciudad de Boston, que data de 1630 y los primeros días en la Colonia de la Bahía de Massachusetts.

Fundada el 23 de abril de 1635 en Boston, la Boston Latin School o (Escuela Latina de Boston) se convirtió en la primera escuela en lo que hoy es Estados Unidos. Los primeros directores impartieron clases en sus casas hasta la finalización del edificio escolar en este lugar. La estructura de madera se mantuvo durante los siguientes 100 años y luego se trasladó al otro lado de la calle a una nueva ubicación. Un mosaico en la acera conmemora este sitio original de la escuela. En la década de los 1700, varias de las figuras revolucionarias más conocidas de Boston, como Samuel Adams y John Hancock, estudiaron aquí antes de asistir a Harvard. Una estatua de Benjamin Franklin recuerda al desertor escolar más famoso.

La librería de la Antigua Esquina ganó prominencia en el mundo literario bajo la propiedad de William D. Ticknor y James T. Fields, quienesdesde la década de 1830 hasta la de 1860, ayudaron a dar forma a la escena literaria de Boston. La librería vendía obras escritas por escritores británicos y de Nueva Inglaterra, incluidos Ralph Waldo Emerson y Charles Dickens. Si bien el sitio es conocido como un centro de venta de libros del siglo XIX, su historia se remonta mucho más atrás. En la década de 1630, Anne Hutchinson lo usó para celebrar reuniones religiosas secretas y poco ortodoxas. En 1960 se amenazó con demoler el edificio, pero un grupo de ciudadanos saltó para salvarlo. Este esfuerzo condujo al establecimiento de Historic Boston Incorporated, que se formó para salvar y restaurar el edificio. Hoy en día, la librería de la Antigua Esquina sigue siendo un espacio comercial en el corazón del centro de Boston.

En 1669, 50 hombres y mujeres rechazaron la Primera Iglesia de Boston y su visión estrecha de la membresía de la iglesia y la ciudadanía electoral. Estos “hermanos disidentes” formaron una nueva iglesia que reflejaba su visión más abierta de membresía y ciudadanía. En 1729 construyeron su nuevo Centro de Reuniones, ahora conocido como Old South Meeting House. Este sitio se convirtió en un lugar activo de debate en los años previos a la Revolución Americana. En 1773, miles llenaron Old South Meeting House para protestar por la llegada de la compañía  East India Company Tea y el impuesto al que estaba sujeto. Su reunión final el 16 de diciembre resultó en el Boston Tea Party o Fiesta del Té de Boston, donde los bostonianos arrojaron 92,000 libras de té al océano, lo que ayudó a precipitar la guerra y la independencia. Durante el sitio de Boston, los soldados británicos destrozaron los bancos y el púlpito, esparcieron tierra por el suelo y lo convirtieron en un establo.

A partir de 1713, funcionarios del gobierno colonial se reunieron en tres cámaras ubicadas en el segundo piso de la Antigua Casa de Estado. Estos hombres implementaron políticas que ampliaron su control e influencia sobre Nueva Inglaterra y el actual Canadá y al hacerlo, entraron en conflicto con los pueblos indígenas y los colonos franceses. La Guerra de los Siete Años con Francia y sus aliados indígenas desató un conflicto interno cuando legisladores populares rechazaron las nuevas leyes e impuestos propuestos por el Parlamento Británico. Esta resistencia se convirtió en una revolución. Posterior a la Guerra Revolucionaria, el gobierno de Massachusetts se transformó en un gobierno basado en la idea de que todos los hombres son creados iguales. Pero este experimento también heredó y continuó un legado de desposesión de tierras, esclavización y exclusión.

El 5 de marzo 1770, el aprendiz de un peluquero se peleó con un soldado del Regimiento 29 por una disputa sobre una factura. Se reunió una multitud de hombres, algunos con baldes, otros con armas improvisadas, como bolas de nieve y ladrillos. El soldado pidió refuerzos y el enfrentamiento se intensificó donde un soldado fue golpeado y cayó. Mientras se ponía de pie, bajó su mosquete y disparó, al igual que otros, aunque no se dio ninguna orden. El primer derramamiento de sangre de la Revolución en Boston cayó frente a la Antigua Casa de Estado. En total, cinco hombres murieron. Después de un juicio en octubre, solo dos soldados fueron declarados culpables de homicidio involuntario. Aunque las dos partes llegaron a un compromiso incómodo, los patriotas no olvidaron la masacre en King Street. En 1886, se instaló un monumento "redondo, en forma de rueda" que consta de 13 círculos de adoquines al pie de la Antigua Casa de Estado.

El edificio original de Faneuil Hall terminó de construirse en 1742 y sirvió como salón de reuniones y mercado. Los bostonianos nombraron el edificio en honor a su benefactor, Peter Faneuil, un comerciante de Boston quien se benefició del trabajo de las personas esclavizadas en el Caribe y del tráfico de esclavos africanos en el Atlántico. Si bien el edificio ha pasado por rehabilitación y expansión desde 1742, Faneuil Hall sigue siendo un lugar de reuniones, protestas y debates. Su nombre no-oficial es la "Cuna de la Libertad", fue acuñado por James Otis en 1763. Aunque más conocido por sus protestas de la era revolucionaria, Faneuil Hall ha servido como un espacio de reunión para que generaciones sucesivas discutan y debatan el significado y el legado de la libertad americana, incluidos los abolicionistas, las mujeres sufragistas, los activistas laborales y la comunidad LGBTQ+. Hoy en día, los bostonianos continúan usando el Faneuil Hall para eventos políticos, sociales y culturales.

Construida alrededor de 1680, esta casa reemplazó a la casa parroquial de la Segunda Iglesia de Boston, que fue destruida en el Gran Incendio de 1676. Paul Revere compró la casa en 1770 mientras trabajaba como platero. Revere y otros advirtieron a los patriotas que los soldados británicos abandonaron Boston para dirigirse a Lexington y Concord el 18 de abril de 1775. Continuó apoyando la causa durante los años de la Guerra Revolucionaria. Después de que Revere vendiera la casa alrededor de 1800, se convirtió en una pensión para marineros. A lo largo del siglo XIX, el North End fue el hogar de inmigrantes irlandeses, judíos de Europa del Este e italianos del sur. La casa se convirtió en una vivienda con negocios. En 1902, el bisnieto de Revere compró la casa para evitar que fuera demolida. La Asociación Conmemorativa de Paul Revere comenzó a restaurar la casa en 1905 y abrió al público en abril de 1908. La casa permanece abierta hoy. Es la única casa del siglo XVII que queda en Boston.

La iglesia del Old North Church fue construida en 1723, oficialmente conocida como la Iglesia de Cristo y es la iglesia más antigua de Boston en la actualidad. Construído al estilo del arquitecto londinense Christopher Wren, Old North se erige como uno de los primeros ejemplos de arquitectura georgiana en América del Norte. En la tarde del 18 de abril de 1775, los soldados británicos abandonaron Boston y se dirigieron hacia Lexington y Concord. Paul Revere ordenó que se enviara una señal de linterna desde el edificio más alto de la ciudad, el campanario de la iglesia, para indicar cómo se había ido el ejército.  Esta alerta le dio tiempo a la milicia de Boston para prepararse. Las escaramuzas en Lexington y Concord al día siguiente se consideran las batallas iniciales de la Revolución Americana. Old North Church mantiene una congregación episcopal activa y da la bienvenida a los visitantes a la iglesia y al sitio histórico.

El cementerio de Copp's Hill se estableció en 1660 después de que el Cementerio de la Capilla del Rey comenzara a llenarse. Ubicada en una colina propiedad en parte del zapatero William Copp, se convirtió en el lugar de descanso de miles de personas que vivieron, trabajaron y murieron en el North End. Entre los enterrados se encuentran el comerciante John Pulling Jr. y el cuidador de Old North Church, Robert Newman, dos hombres que se cree que sostuvieron linternas de señales el 18 de abril de 1775 para avisar sobre el avance británico en Lexington y Concord. Copp's Hill también alberga muchas de las tumbas de la población africana temprana de Boston, incluido el Educador negro, el vestidor de cuero y el Gran maestro masónico Prince Hall. Aunque bloqueado por las casas del siglo XIX que ahora llenan el North End, Copp's Hill todavía ofrece una hermosa vista del río Charles y Charlestown.

En la tarde del 16 de junio de 1775, las unidades de la milicia colonial marcharon hacia Charlestown y fortificaron lo que hoy se conoce como “Breed's Hill". Por la mañana, los cañones británicos abrieron fuego cuando las fuerzas británicas se reunieron para aterrizar y atacar la colina. Cuando las fuerzas británicas comenzaron su asalto, las unidades de Massachusetts, Connecticut y New Hampshire rápidamente formaron una línea de defensa. En el campo de batalla había más de cien patriotas de color, indígenas y afrodescendientes. Si bien las milicias inicialmente retuvieron a los soldados británicos, pronto se vieron obligados a retirarse. Si bien en última instancia fue una pérdida para las fuerzas de Nueva Inglaterra, la Batalla de Bunker Hill se convirtió en un símbolo del espíritu de quienes luchan por las ideas de libertad. En el Museo, los visitantes pueden explorar exhibiciones y dioramas que comparten las historias de la Batalla, la construcción del Monumento y la historia del vecindario de Charlestown

El Monumento de Bunker Hill se construyó para conmemorar la ubicación de la Batalla de Bunker Hill y hacer de la batalla una historia compartida y unificadora para los estadounidenses. Se parece a un obelisco egipcio y tiene una escalera de granito de 294 escalones hasta la cima. La gente de Charlestown ha abrazado la batalla y más tarde el Monumento con celebraciones y desfiles cada 17 de junio. Desde entonces, activistas y artistas han activado el Monumento a lo largo de los siglos XX y XXI. Junto al monumento se encuentra el Bunker Hill Lodge, construido en 1903; este edificio de granito del Renacimiento griego reemplazó una estructura de madera anterior construida para albergar la estatua del Doctor Joseph Warren. El Lodge también tenía artefactos y escenas diorámicas de la batalla. El Servicio de Parques Nacionales trasladó estos artículos al Museo Bunker Hill en 2008, que se encuentra justo enfrente del Monumento.

El área que ocupa el Astillero Naval fue una vez planicies de marea que proporcionaron sustento a las comunidades indígenas locales. Estos pisos sirvieron como área de aterrizaje en la Batalla de Bunker Hill de 1775. Establecido en 1800, Charlestown Navy Yard (CNY) sirvió como un espacio de innovación en la construcción naval durante 174 años: El Muelle Seco 1 fue uno de los dos primeros diques secos construidos en el país; el Ropewalk produjo toda la cuerda para toda la Marina de los EE. UU.; y Chain Forge desarrollaron y utilizaron un proceso único llamado Die-Lock, que creó vínculos increíblemente fuertes. Los trabajadores del CNY construyeron más de 200 barcos y repararon miles más. Más de la mitad de estos barcos se construyeron durante la Segunda Guerra Mundial, que fueron los años más productivos del CNY. Durante este tiempo, el Navy Yard aumentó su fuerza laboral de 17 000 trabajadores civiles a más de 50 000 trabajadores, incluidas mujeres y trabajadores de diversos orígenes étnicos y raciales.

Construído en Boston y lanzado en 1797, el CONSTITUTION es el buque de guerra comisionado a flote más antiguo del mundo en la actualidad. Durante la Guerra de 1812, el barco ganó fama y su nombre de su "Old Ironsides". Durante su primera gran batalla contra el buque de guerra británico HMS GUERRIERE, los marineros observaron lo bien que los costados de madera del barco repelían las balas de cañón. El barco sirvió en escuadrones de todo el mundo y le arrebató su último barco en noviembre de 1853 mientras patrullaba en busca de  traficantes de esclavos que se dirigían a América desde África occidental. Más tarde se convirtió en un buque escuela. Después de un crucero nacional de 1931 a 1934, lo devolvió a Boston, donde permanece hoy. El CONSTITUTION ahora se encuentra en el Astillero Naval de Charlestown como un barco ceremonial y de entrenamiento para la Marina, así como una experiencia educativa para los visitantes.

El Museo del USS Constitución abrió sus puertas en 1976 en la antigua casa de bombas de Muelle Seco 1 en Charlestown Navy Yard. El Museo es un complemento privado del USS CONSTITUTION, sin fines de lucro y no financiado por el gobierno. El personal del museo recolecta, preserva e interpreta los artefactos y el material de archivo relacionado con el Barco y la tripulación a través de exhibiciones interactivas, programas atractivos e iniciativas de divulgación atractivas. En colaboración con los Parques Nacionales de Boston, el Museo se expandió a dos edificios adyacentes y construyó un corredor de conexión a mediados de la década de 1990. En la actualidad cada año más de 350 000 personas visitan el Museo cada para aprender, explorar e investigar, lo que lo convierte en uno de los museos más visitados de Boston.

Construido en 1943 en San Pedro, California, el USS CASSIN YOUNG es uno de los 175 destructores de clase Fletcher construidos durante la Segunda Guerra Mundial. El homónimo del barco era el Capitán Cassin Young, un miembro del servicio de la Marina de los EE. UU. que ganó una Medalla de Honor por sus actos heróicos en Pearl Harbor y murió en acción en la Batalla Naval de Guadalcanal. El barco estuvo activo en el Pacifico durante la Segunda Guerra Mundial, sirviendo en siete campañas separadas con una tripulación de 325 hombres. Lanzado el 31 de diciembre de 1943, el barco entró en combate en abril de 1944. Después del asalto a Okinawa el 1 de abril de 1945, CASSIN YOUNG asumió las funciones de barco de piquete de radar, donde fue atacado dos veces por kamikazes. Fue dado de baja en mayo de 1946, pero fue reactivado  al estallar el conflicto de Corea en septiembre de 1951. El barco fue dado de baja nuevamente el 29 de abril de 1960. Ha sido parte del Parque Histórico Nacional de Boston desde junio de 1981.
