data.description: Walk through the pathway of presidents, first ladies, and diplomats and discover their stunning garden. By the end of this tour you'll understand why John Adams wrote of the "constant Peace and Tranquility" he felt while living here.

images.altText: A sepia toned watercolor of Old House with a horse drawn carriage in front
images.caption: Watercolor of the Old House by E. Malcolm
images.title: Watercolor of the Old House

stops.significance: The first stop is outside Old House at Peace field.  John and Abigail Adams purchased the property in 1788 with the idea that John would retire from public life.  The nation had other plans as John was elected Vice President in 1788 and President in 1796.  The room on the second floor all the way to the right is where John Adams died on July 4, 1826.  John Quincy and Louisa Catherine Adams also called this house home.  The home remained in the hands of the Adams Family until 1946 when it was donated to the National Park Service.
The boxwood hedges were planted by Leonard Vassell in 1731 when the house was originally built.  The boxwoods use the original root system, and predate the Adams Family's presence on the property.

The wisteria was planted by Charles Francis and Abigail Brooks Adams, the third generation of the Adams Family to call Peace field home.  By the third generation the garden was being transformed into a gentleman's estate.

This yellowwood tree was planted by John Quincy and Louisa Catherine Adams circa 1830.  The seedling was probably acquired in Washington D.C., as yellowwoods are not native to Massachusetts.  This is one of the oldest trees that remains on the property.
Abigail Adams brought these White Roses of York from Great Britain to this home in 1788.  The roses continue to bloom every June using the same root system.

The Stone Library houses the collection of three generations of Adams Family books, from John Quincy Adams through his grandsons Henry and Brooks Adams.  The property is built separately from the house to protect the books from fire.
The post holes for the Dry Yard date back to the time of John and Abigail Adams (1788 - 1826).
The water pump is a reproduction of the original which was installed in the early 1700s.  This pump served as the water source for the house until the 1850s.

The Carriage House was built by Charles Francis Adams in 1873.  The building not only housed the family's carriage and horses, but also the coachman.  Today it serves as office space for National Park staff.  The barn is used for education programming.

data.title: The Garden of Old House at Peace field

data.description: In Lowell, where the motto on the city seal is "art is the handmaid of human good," it seems only fitting that contemporary works of art stand alongside historical sites. Created by international artists, these works specifically address the themes of the Lowell National Historical Park: the Industrial City, Labor, Machines, Power, and Capital. Each artist selected the site for their original work, and we encourage you to explore the art, history, and culture along this walking tour.

images.altText: A metal sculpture of five women, together in a group looking into the distance.
images.caption: "Homeage to Women" Sculpture
images.title: Homage to Women

stops.significance:
This life-size bronze sculpture of an Irish canal digger stands as a tribute to those nineteenth-century laborers who by hand dug Lowell's 5.6 miles of canals. The water in these canals powered the city's textile mills. The granite blocks stacked in the middle of the fountain resemble those used to construct the canal walls. The realistic figure symbolizes the lives and struggles of all workers who have contributed to our industrial society. Labor and power are two of five interpretive themes of the Lowell National Historical Park and the Lowell Heritage State Park. Through various public history and educational programs, the Parks celebrate the heritage of Lowell's working people and the city's water power system.

Realistic figures created by artists Ivan and Elliot Schwartz have been displayed in many museum exhibits and theater productions. Their work has also been featured at the National Air and Space Museum of the Smithsonian in Washington, D.C.

This larger-than-life sculpture of five intertwined figures is a tribute to Lowell's nineteenth century "mill girls," yet it also celebrates the contributions made by women throughout time. The statue suggests the struggles and aspirations of working women everywhere. The figures are intended to represent women of different races. "Women all over the world have one trait in common," the artist explains. "They work, they work hard, and their work is unheralded."

Mico Kaufman, of Tewksbury, Massachusetts, is considered one of the premiere medal artists of his time. He studied at the Academy of Fine Arts in Rome and Florence. He designed the official inaugural medals for presidents Ford and Reagan, and was named Sculptor of the Year in 1978 by the American Numismatic Association. Among his other works of public art in the area are a tribute to Claude Debussy at UMass Lowell, the Rouse Monument at J.F.K. Plaza near Lowell City Hall, and the statue of Helen Keller and Annie Sullivan in Tewksbury.

This twenty-foot-high kinetic sculpture captures the essence of flowing water with sunlight and sound. This piece, which illustrates the theme of "the power of water," won a nationwide design competition. Ihara designed his piece so that originally the fountain's flow would move the 40 copper-colored steel cubes, which are arranged in a pyramid pattern. Today wind spins the cubes and simulates the sparkling quality of water as it is moved by wind and light plays upon it. Pawtucket is a Native American word for "falling water."

A graduate of Tokyo University, Micho Ihara is a former fellow of the Center for Advanced Visual Studies of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. A number of his works are kinetically engineered to move in the wind. "Composing music must be very close to the process of orchestrating the structure of my sculpture," the artist says. Although he works with metal, usually stainless steel, his sculptures are much more about air and light.

This black patina bronze sculpture was commissioned by former U.S. Senator Paul E. Tsongas and Nicola Sauvage Tsongas in memory of their families. The sculpture's bold form and three distinct, yet related, elements suggest the embracing strength of a family group. Its title means "love and honor" in Greek, and the piece symbolizes a universal tribute to the family, particularly those Lowell families of immigrant heritage.

Born in New York City, Dimitri Hadzi moved to Europe following service in the Second World War. In 1956 he represented the United States at the Venice Biennale, a major international art exhibition. His sculptures are presently on view in museums and public spaces all over the world. Although the artist considered himself a "traditional sculptor," most of his work is abstract in style. He reduces ideas and complex visual information into simpler forms. His shapes are often based on natural forms and have an organic energy.

This work of public art is a tribute to Jack Kerouac (1922-1969), the Lowell native whose most famous book, On The Road, challenged the conformism of the 1950s and remains a pivotal "coming of age" novel. Five of his novels are set in Lowell and his writings are part of the city's cultural heritage.

Excepts from 10 of Kerouac's 20 books appear on eight triangular, polished, reddish-brown granite columns, creating a literary giant's memorial in language. The granite was quarried in South Dakota, and cut in Minnesota. West Virginia graphic designers worked on the text. The paved path, shaped as a cross and series of circles, refers to Kerouac's Roman Catholic and Buddhist beliefs, and evokes his lifelong spiritual quest. The design is reminiscent of a mandala, a pattern symbolizing the universe.

The artist, Ben Woitena, of Houston, Texas, knows Kerouac's work well. His design was selected in a national competition. His preferred medium is welded and and painted steel.

These three pieces are derived from Lowell's industrial symbols. They are intended to be objects for seating and climbing, functioning as a kind of furniture as well as visual art.

Sculpture One is a six-ton silhouette of Francis Cabot Lowell (1774-1817), the early textile manufacturer for whom the city is named. Sculpture Two is a tipped, mammoth, granite thread spool mounted on a granite base, which can also be seen as a spindle or beehive, symbolizing hard work and industry. Sculpture Three is a saw-toothed horizontal piece that might be the roofline of a boardinghouse or factory, or, perhaps, gears belonging to textile machinery. The ten-foot high spindle or smokestack is located near the entrance to the Boott Cotton Mills and emulates its red-brick chimney. The Lowell Sculptures was the winner of a nationwide design competition.

Connecticut artist Robert Cumming is a painter, photographer, and printmaker, as well as a sculptor.
stops.assetName: "The Lowell Sculptures: One, Two, and Three" Sculptures

data.title: The Lowell Public Art Collection

data.description: This tour traces the planning and development of the park and how the reconstructed Fort Stanwix came into being.

images.altText: From above a 4-pointed star-shaped wooden fort.
images.caption: Aerial view of Fort Stanwix National Monument.
images.title: Overhead Fort Stanwix

stops.significance: The location you are standing at is known locally as the "American Corners." It is the intersection of modern roads today. But during the time of the American Revolution it was the center of the Oneida Carry, and during the early years of the nation's history, it became the starting point of the the Erie Canal build. The canal eventually ran straight through this location, replacing the portage that came before it.
During the Siege of 1777, an American flag flew over this wall of the fort in defiance of British orders to surrender.

Within the bounds of this park are monuments dedicated to the fort's commander, Peter Gansevoort, the Erie Canal, and Siege of 1777. Bordering it is the Rome Historical Society - Friends of the Fort and the National Park Service administration building.
This memorial was completed in 1976 in honor of those who fought and died at Fort Stanwix/Schuyler during the American Revolution.

data.description: Take a stroll through 100 years of Anniston history and learn about some of the people, places, and changes that have shaped the "Model City" from its founding in the 1870s through the integration efforts of the Bi-Racial Human Relations Council in the 1960s. The "Model City" Walking Tour route is about two miles long and includes seven stops throughout downtown Anniston. For the full experience, listen to the tour's interpretive audio, or follow along with the accompanying transcript.

images.altText: a red-brick wall facing an empty alleyway featuring a large silver painting of a bus and panels.
images.caption: The Greyhound mural, titled "Could You Get on the Bus?" at the Anniston Greyhound Bus Depot.
images.title: Greyhound Mural

stops.significance: The Anniston Greyhound Bus Depot witnessed the early stages of an attack on a small group of nonviolent civil rights activists in Anniston in May of 1961.
Zinn Park is an inviting downtown park, located a few blocks off Noble Street in downtown Anniston.
A "city within a city," the West 15th Historic District was the epicenter for African American commercial and social life in Anniston between 1898 and 1950.

Located in the heart of the Downtown Anniston Historic District, this street corner provides a welcome resting place during an afternoon of exploration in downtown Anniston. 

From this point, visitors can few several notable historic buildings in downtown Anniston, including the Kress building (1108 Noble Street), site of some of Anniston's earliest integration efforts, the Calhoun County Courthouse (25 W. 11th Street), site of the trial of Willie Brewster, and many other historic commercial buildings built during the 20th century.

The Trailways Station in downtown Anniston was the site of violence and intimidation of Freedom Riders in route to Birmingham on May 14, 1961.
The Public Library of Anniston-Calhoun County was the site of integration efforts by African American faith leaders in 1963.

data.description: You are standing on Tory Row, famous for the wealthy people who lived here before the American Revolution. What convinced them to stay loyal to the Crown and did their neighbors agree? What did it mean to be a loyal in 1774? Come find out! This walking tour takes about 1 hour to complete and covers 0.7 miles from 105 Brattle Street to the Cambridge Common. The path stays on sidewalks and paved trails, but can be uneven. The tour can be paired with the park’s “The Road to Revolution” Junior Ranger book.

images.altText: Historic map of Boston and Cambridge
images.caption: See what led this Brattle Street neighborhood down the road to revolution.
images.title: The Road to Revolution Walking Tour

park.fullName: Longfellow House Washington's Headquarters National Historic Site
park.name: Longfellow House Washington's Headquarters

stops.significance:
John Vassall built this colonial mansion in 1759 with the money he received from the sugar industry. Vassall inherited a plantation in Jamaica and enslaved people who worked on the plantation and in this home. Vassall benefitted from his family’s status. He attended Harvard, served as a justice of the peace and was a militia officer. He was a typical British country gentleman and well respected. Until the 1770s, that is.  

 In March of 1770, the Boston Massacre occurred between colonists and British soldiers occupying the city. Five people were killed by the soldiers and became martyrs for a budding anti-British cause. In December 1773, during the Boston Tea Party, colonists took to the streets in protest, throwing 342 chests of tea into the harbor. Additionally, Boston colonists destroyed the governor's home, marched with effigies of government officials, and deployed intimidation tactics against merchants selling British goods. John Vassall would have heard of these unsettling events.

This is the home of Penelope and Henry Vassall, aunt and uncle of John Vassall. By September 1774, Penelope was a widow and would have looked out these windows as the turmoil reached her neighborhood.

Colonists had discovered that the governor had retrieved a nearby stockpile of gunpowder and brought it back to Boston. The man who gave the governor the key to the powder house was none other than William Brattle, who lived down the road. In protest, 4,000 colonists descended on Cambridge. After chasing Brattle out of town, they turned and marched down this street, passing in front of Penelope’s home. The colonist surrounded homes further down the street, demanding that the men inside resign from their government positions.

To avoid potential property damage and bloodshed, the men agreed to resign and their families fled. Penelope left for the safety of her Caribbean plantation. Both sides felt that they were the loyal British subjects upholding English liberties. So, what does it mean to be a loyal citizen?

The Read family stayed in Cambridge after the Powder Alarm. Eight months later on April 19th, 1775 two Reads marched to Lexington and Concord. This community had begun to take sides – “Loyalist” or “Patriot”- with shrinking room for the neutral.

These events did much to change the minds of the uncertain. Parliament had decided that Boston must pay for its actions and passed the Coercive Acts to compel them to cooperate.  The acts closed the port of Boston to trade, its main lifeline and limited colonists’ right to self-govern, ultimately replacing their governor with British General Gage. Instead of subduing colonists, it provoked outrage. Local Patriots saw the Powder Alarm as another tyrannical grab for power. When the midnight rider, William Dawes, came through town in April, people like the Reads were ready to arm themselves.

After the official start of the American Revolution, soldiers from all over New England gathered in Cambridge. The conviction of these soldiers would soon be tried again.

Christ Church, the oldest surviving church in Cambridge, was built in 1760 by the wealthy inhabitants of the town, including John Vassall. By 1775, with its Anglican parishioners gone, the church sat empty.  

The New England army quickly moved in and used the church as barracks for its soldiers. This was the fate of many of the abandoned properties in Cambridge. Penelope Vassall’s house was used as a hospital and John Vassall’s, where the tour began, housed a regiment of soldiers from Marblehead, Massachusetts. This was no longer Loyalist country, but an encampment for the fledgling New England Army.

After Lexington and Concord, British troops retreated to the safety of Boston. The city sat on a peninsula and was heavily guarded by land and sea. However, the British generals knew that they needed to claim the high ground to protect themselves. They set their eyes on Charlestown.

The New England Army in Cambridge got wind of the plan. Colonists marched to Charlestown and dug an entrenchment on Breed's hill. The next morning, the British were surprised to see the land they intended to claim had been taken. Throughout June 16th, British forces attacked the New England army and bombarded Charlestown with cannon fire. Eventually, British soldiers overtook the hill, forcing colonists to retreat. Though they won the battle, it was at a high cost of life.

Follow the northern path, just to the left of the cemetery entrance, along Garden Street. After the large oak tree in the corner, there are two monuments to fallen soldiers from Lexington and Concord and the Battle of Bunker Hill.

After the Battle of Bunker Hill a new leader would ask for the New England soldiers' loyalty.

General George Washington arrived on July 2nd. He was sent to Cambridge by the Continental Congress to develop a professional army and get the British to leave Boston. Though a myth, the monument here says he took command at this spot. Washington’s first headquarters, ironically, was the home of a Loyalist we already met – John Vassall.

Earning the loyalty of New England soldiers would not be easy. As a Virginian, and an outsider, he harbored negative views of the soldiers and was challenged by the fact that the army was racially integrated. He eventually earned their respect, though, by forcing the British to evacuated Boston on March 17th, 1776. Washington knew that his success depended on the loyalty of his soldiers, and he made a bid for that loyalty in his first General Orders on July 14th, 1775. That text is immortalized on the back of this monument.

What does loyalty mean to you?

data.title: The Road to Revolution

data.description: Explore the events that led up to the American Revolution, and see exactly where they happened.

images.altText: A black and white period engraving showing men in 18th century garb sitting and standing in a room.
images.caption: Explore the events that led to the Declaration of Independence, and see where exactly they happened.
images.title: Congress voting the Declaration

stops.significance: British Parliament insisted it was their right to tax the Colonies, but many colonists felt that “taxation without representation” violated English rights. Protests to Parliamentary action at times boiled over, as witnessed here in Franklin Court in October of 1765. Benjamin Franklin chose this courtyard to build a home, but left during construction to act as a colonial spokesman in London in 1763. Two years later Parliament passed the Stamp Act, a direct tax on paper used in the colonies to help pay for stationing British soldiers in North America. Believing that Benjamin Franklin had endorsed the Stamp Act, some Philadelphians declared that Franklin’s home should be destroyed. Franklin’s family fled, except for his wife Deborah, who with the help of friends stayed to defend the home. They prevailed, and the mob was convinced to leave. Though Franklin helped to convince Parliament to repeal the Stamp Act, Parliament insisted it was their right to legislate over the colonies. The road to revolution had begun.

The printing press played a vital role in paving the way to revolution. Philadelphia had as many as six printing offices in the 1770s. Philadelphia’s newspapers kept its people informed on the actions of Parliament and reported what was going on in other Colonies, as when the Intolerable Acts, closed the Port of Boston and in effect declared martial law on the Colony of Massachusetts. The many pamphlets and handbills that came from the presses during this time argued for and against revolution. In early 1776 thousands thrilled to read Thomas Paine’s radical pamphlet Common Sense where he proclaimed, “We have it in our power to begin the world over again.” The most famous printed document to come from the press during the Revolution was the Declaration of Independence printed at the office of John Dunlap near 2nd and Market Streets. These printed Declarations were distributed to the brand new States, the armies in the field, as well as to the King and Parliament.

Delegates from 12 British Colonies met in Philadelphia in the autumn of 1774 for the first Continental Congress. They discussed a response to Parliament’s “Intolerable Acts,” which brought martial law to the Port of Boston. It was the feeling of many, that the cause of Massachusetts was that of all the Colonies. Soon after the delegates arrived in Philadelphia, they chose to meet here in Carpenters’ Hall.  The newly completed building was home to the Carpenters’ Company, a local builders’ trade guild, whose many members supported the radical cause. This was not so for many of the delegates attending the Congress. Far from declaring independence, actions included agreements to establish a Colonial-wide boycott of British goods, sending a petition sent to King George III begging his assistance with their grievances, and agreeing to meet again in Philadelphia for a second Congress the following year. To the disappointment of the radicals in New England and Virginia, the road to revolution would be a slow one.

Upon their return to Philadelphia in May of 1775, the second Continental Congress met here inside the Pennsylvania State House. Moderation initially ruled the day – in spite of blood being spilt on the battlefields of Lexington and Concord. In July of 1775 delegates meeting in the Assembly Room signed the Olive Branch Petition, praising the King and again asking for his assistance. Within months however, word was received that the King had rejected their second petition, had proclaimed the Colonies to be in “open and avowed rebellion,” and that he intended to suppress it by force of arms. Members of Congress and many Americans realized that the only way they were going to be able to protect their rights as British people, was to no longer be a part of the British Empire. This was made official in Independence Hall, when delegates from 13 Colonies signed a Declaration of Independence, pledging their “lives, fortunes, and sacred honor” to the cause of Independence. America had set out on the road to revolution.

Bells rang throughout the city as throngs of people gathered here in the State House Yard on the hot afternoon of July 8th, 1776 to hear Col. John Nixon read in public for the very first time the stirring words of the Declaration of Independence. Passions ran high as loyalists jeered and cried treason. Patriots cheered and ripped the King’s Coat of Arms off of the wall inside the Pennsylvania State House, and later burned it in a large bonfire in the center of town.

The West Wing houses the Great Essentials Exhibit which includes three original printed documents key to the founding of the United States, The Declaration of Independence, the Articles of Confederation and the Constitution of the United States. You will notice that the copy of the Declaration of Independence has no signatures. In fact the Declaration was not initially created to be signed, but rather to be mass produced on a printing press and widely distributed. This is the original printed copy of the Declaration of Independence used by Col. John Nixon for the very first public reading of that famous document on July 8, 1776, one of 25 original copies known to exist. One of its brothers, a copy sent to the British government, still resides in the Hall of Records in London.

data.title: The Road to Revolution, 1763-1776

data.description: The Selma to Montgomery March was a multi-day event, traveling 54 miles from Brown Chapel African Methodist Episcopal (AME) Church on March 21, 1965, in Selma to the steps of the Alabama State Capitol in Montgomery on March 25, 1965. This driving tour will follow the steps of the March, with several stops along the way that can be explored on foot or driven past. To follow the tour with a vehicle, please plan for about 70 miles of travel and 90 minutes of time.

data.description: The Kelly and Ashton mill villages lie on opposite banks of the Blackstone River, in Lincoln and Cumberland, RI. Learn about the growth of industrialization and the changes in transportation that transformed this former farmland into a busy community.

images.altText: Overlooking the Blackstone River at Ashton Village and the Blackstone River State Park
images.caption: Overlooking the Blackstone River at Ashton Village and the Blackstone River State Park
images.title: Overlooking the Blackstone River

park.fullName: Blackstone River Valley National Historical Park
park.name: Blackstone River Valley

stops.significance: This site demonstrates the dramatic story of the transportation revolution.
This natural crossing point of the river has been used by people for well over 1,000 years.
This was the former site of Kelly Mill. This mill reaped the benefits of the Blackstone Canal, and it was an important part of the growing Lonsdale Company.
Blackstone Canal was one of many progressive steps made in transportation in the Blackstone Valley.

The Providence and Worcester Railroad opened in 1847. This led to closing of the Blackstone Canal the following year. At a meeting of prominent industrialists in Worcester, one man proclaimed:  “The two Unions between Worcester and Providence - The first was weak as water, the last is strong as iron.” The railroad increased transportation speeds while decreasing costs. By the 1860s, the trip between Worcester to Providence was down to about an hour (the same speed that you could travel between the two locations, if going by car, today!)
New developments in transportation brought even more demand for local industry. When the Lonsdale Company decided to expand their operations here at Ashton, they built their new brick mill on this side of the river, taking  advantage of the quicker and cheaper transportation afforded by the railroad. The Ashton Mill was 12 times larger than the Kelly Mill and produced fine muslin cloth. Workers lived nearby in a mill village. By 1869, there were lines of handsome brick homes,

Living close to your workplace was not just convenient in the 1800s; often, it was a necessity. In the early  twentieth century, transportation technology soared to new heights. 
With the invention of the automobile, people could live further and further away from where they worked. Many of these commuters also pushed for new road systems, which further changed landscapes such as this one. In the 1940s, the Ashton Viaduct (the large cement bridge in front of you) was completed. This viaduct, which offers a new means of crossing of the river, towers over  the centuries old crossing point. As railroads became a less significant mode of overland transportation, the modern Interstate System was established in the 1950s. The bridge you can see way off in the distance is for Interstate 295. 
Conclusion 
Imagine a small airplane flying under the Ashton Viaduct. After major shifts in travel by land and by sea, people sought to conquer the air.  Try and picture the small airport that once stood several hundred yards d

data.title: The Story of Blackstone River State Park: Canal Barges, Trains, and Planes

Cattail is an iconic wetland grass with a variety of uses.
The Sunken Forest is one of just two maritime holly forests on planet earth. Stop here to learn a bit more about American Holly trees.

data.description: This audio tour introduces you to the Tukudika Indians, a band or related bands of Mountain Shoshone whose teviwa (Shoshone for homeland) included the area that is now Yellowstone National Park. During the tour, you will learn about Tukudika lifeways. As you listen, imagine what Yellowstone might have been like before it became the world’s first national park. Reflect upon what the concepts of home and lifeways mean to you.

images.altText: A group of people sitting inside a teepee structure.
images.caption: Tukudika (Sheepeater) men, women, and children
images.title: Tukudika

data.title: The Tukudika

data.description: Over the next twelve stops we will hear powerful stories of people who seized their freedom on the Underground Railroad and came to Boston. We will also learn about the activists and allies in this city who helped these freedom seekers* along their way. This tour weaves through Beacon Hill followed by a few stops in Downtown Boston. The tour concludes at Long Wharf. *"Freedom seeker" refers to an enslaved person who took action to obtain their freedom from slavery (NPS Network to Freedom).

images.title: Underground Railroad in Boston

park.fullName: Boston African American National Historic Site
park.name: Boston African American

stops.significance:
Welcome to the National Parks of Boston’s Underground Railroad walking tour. Over the next 12 stops we will hear powerful stories of people who seized their freedom on the Underground Railroad and came to Boston. We will also learn about the activists and allies in this city who helped these freedom seekers.
Our tour begins here on Smith Court, a center of Black life and activism in 1800s Boston. The African Meeting House served as a church, schoolroom, and gathering space for the community. Here, Underground Railroad activists planned how they were going to help those escaping slavery.
Black Bostonians also gathered here in response to the 1850 Fugitive Slave Law, which allowed slave catchers to roam free states in search of runaways and mandated the assistance of state and local authorities, as well as the public, in returning freedom seekers to slavery.
Those who lived in this court helped shelter freedom seekers, and in one case, saved a freedom seeker from an attempted capture by a slave catcher.

While much of the Underground Railroad activity in Beacon Hill occurred among the Black residents of the community, there are also instances of White allies providing refuge to freedom seekers. Two of these allies, George and Susan Hillard, used their status and privilege to shelter several freedom seekers at their home.
Susan Hillard was a staunch abolitionist and used her husband's political cover as a conservative politician to hide freedom seekers in their home throughout the 1850s. While it is unclear how much George knew of Susan’s ongoing Underground Railroad activities, he likely had some awareness and either did not interfere, or quietly supported her efforts.
The Hillards most notably sheltered freedom seeker Ellen Craft in October 1850 when slave catchers tracked her and her husband William to Boston. With the help of both the Hillards, Ellen and William Craft averted the slave catchers.
When the home underwent repairs years later, a secret attic was found, as well as two plates and two spoons.
stops.assetName: George S. and Susan Hillard House

stops.significance:
You are now in the Lower Southac neighborhood, so named because Phillips Street once was called Southac Street. This neighborhood teemed with Underground Railroad activity.
Lewis and Harriet Hayden lived at number 66. The Haydens, who fled slavery themselves, sheltered scores of freedom seekers, including William and Ellen Craft.
A couple doors down, 70 Phillips Street, was the home of Elizabeth Riley. Riley sheltered freedom seeker Shadrach Minkins in her attic after he was rescued from the courthouse.
The Riley home also included 1 Southac Court, where famed freedom seeker Jane Johnson and her sons lived. Johnson took in other freedoms seekers at her home here on Southac Court and at her later Beacon Hill residences.
Across the street stands 81-83 Phillips Street. Black lawyer, doctor, dentist, and activist, John Sweat Rock, lived here and provided medical care to freedom seekers. Two boardinghouses that housed freedom seekers once stood here as well, operated by John R. Taylor and William Manix.
stops.assetName: Site of William and Elizabeth Riley's House

stops.significance:
Twelfth Baptist Church, known as the "Fugitive Slave’s Church," once stood at this approximate site. With many freedom seekers worshipping here, Twelfth Baptist Church served as a sacred space for its congregants as well as a center for Underground Railroad assistance.
Reverend Leonard Grimes led this church for 25 years. After growing up free in Virginia, Grimes dedicated his life to supporting freedom seekers, using his position in the Beacon Hill community to do so.
After the passage of the 1850 Fugitive Slave Law, more than 40 congregants of Twelfth Baptist fled north out of fear of capture. Grimes raised money to pay for many of these individuals’ freedoms and supported many more freedom seekers on their journey.
Grimes played a role in almost every major fugitive slave case in Boston in the 1850s, as some of these freedom seekers, including Shadrach Minkins and Anthony Burns, worshipped at Twelfth Baptist.
Today, there is a plaque at the site of Leonard Grimes’ 28 Grove St. home.

Here at 5 Phillips Street once stood the home of Henry Thacker, a prominent Black caterer and activist. In 1847, Thacker aided George and Lizzie Lewis, a father and daughter who escaped from slavery. Forced to separate on their journey north, Lizzie came to Boston and stayed at Thacker’s home. George, on the other hand, went to Albany, New York. While there, George learned his daughter was in Boston. Reverend Grimes visited George and assured George his daughter was safe with the Thackers. Soon after, Captain Austin Bearse, brought George to the city.
Outside this home is where father and daughter finally reunited.
Across the street lived Joshua Bowen Smith, known as the “Prince of Caterers.” In this high-profile position, Smith was able to keep a careful watch out for slave catchers. He also employed and assisted numerous freedom seekers. Smith lived with fellow activist John Coburn, who assisted with the rescue of freedom seeker Shadrach Minkins from the Boston courthouse in 1851.
stops.assetName: Site of Henry L. W. Thacker House

stops.significance:
Today’s bustling Cambridge Street looks different than the Cambridge Street of the mid-1800s, which was narrower and still somewhat residential. Black porter Burrill Smith, who sheltered freedom seekers and hosted the famed Underground Railroad conductor Harriet Tubman, lived at 168 Cambridge Street.
Black-owned businesses, including Lewis Hayden’s clothing shop, were also located on Cambridge Street. Many of these businesses, including Hayden’s, became informal community centers for activists. Sometimes, these shops also served as safe houses or rendezvous points for freedom seekers.
Freedom seeker William Craft established his cabinet making shop at 51 Cambridge Street.  When slave catchers came looking for William and his wife Ellen in October 1850, William barricaded himself in his shop. Abolitionists, “armed to the teeth,” guarded the Crafts and forced the slave catchers to abandon their plans and leave the city. The Crafts fled to England, returning to the U.S. following the Civil War.

The Revere House Hotel, which used to stand here at Bowdoin Square, has unique ties to the Underground Railroad history of Boston.
In April 1850, Massachusetts Senator Daniel Webster delivered a speech at the Revere House Hotel in support of the Compromise of 1850. This package of legislation included the new Fugitive Slave Law, which allowed slave catchers to apprehend freedom seekers without due process throughout the country and mandated local and state authorities, as well as the public, to comply with it. Responding to fierce backlash, Webster called upon Massachusetts residents to enforce this law as their Constitutional duty, despite whatever misguided convictions they had.
Once in effect, the Fugitive Slave Law drew slave catchers to Boston in search of freedom seekers believed to be in the area. With its proximity to Beacon Hill's Black community, the Revere House Hotel provided enslavers and their agents a place to lodge while they pursued freedom seekers living and working in the city.
stops.assetName: Site of the Revere House Hotel

stops.significance:
Writers for "The Liberator," a major printed voice of the anti-slavery movement, never shied away from confronting those who supported slavery and the Fugitive Slave Law. Instead, they advocated for open defiance of the Fugitive Slave Law and called upon people to directly assist freedom seekers.
For almost three decades, "The Liberator’s" office stood on Cornhill Street, which was located roughly in this area of City Hall Plaza. 
Working alongside Black writers such as William Cooper Nell, editor William Lloyd Garrison used "The Liberator" to call for immediate emancipation and equal rights for Black Americans. This paper documented anti-slavery meetings and shared the stories of freedom seekers, including William and Ellen Craft, Shadrach Minkins, Anthony Burns, and others.
When freedom seekers arrived in Boston, they knew they could find support and aid at "The Liberator" office. This office stood as a central hub of Underground Railroad activity where allies directly provided support for freedom seekers.

Faneuil Hall gained its reputation as the "Cradle of Liberty" from the meetings that helped inspire the American Revolution. It lived up to that nickname with its abolitionist and Underground Railroad connections.
By the late 1830s, Boston abolitionists began using Faneuil Hall to host meetings and rallies. Oftentimes, they called these meetings to protest high profile fugitive slave cases.
For example, in 1842, authorities arrested freedom seeker George Latimer, which prompted abolitionists to gather in Faneuil Hall to call for action against Latimer’s arrest. His case led to a petition drive that spurred the 1843 Personal Liberty Act, which prevented state officials and facilities from supporting the capture of freedom seekers.
Following the passage of the 1850 Fugitive Slave Law, Bostonians held a meeting here to establish the Boston Vigilance Committee. This organization provided valuable assistance to freedom seekers: shelter, clothing, money, legal aid, medical attention, and passage further north.

Though no longer standing, the Boston Court House played a crucial role in several Fugitive Slave Law cases. In February 1851, authorities arrested freedom seeker Shadrach Minkins and brought him to this courthouse. Lewis Hayden and other militant abolitionists stormed the building, overwhelmed the guards, and carried Minkins to safety.
The federal government responded by arresting freedom seeker Thomas Sims a couple months later. This time, the courthouse was draped in chains and guards were stationed outside. Abolitionists could not free the heavily guarded Sims. On April 12, 1851, authorities marched Sims to Long Wharf and sent him back into slavery.
In 1854, slave catchers arrested freedom seeker Anthony Burns and brought him to this courthouse. Militant abolitionists led a failed assault on the courthouse to free Burns. In the aftermath of the assault, federal troops were brought in to guard the courthouse while Burns awaited his return into slavery.

Standing in front of the Old State House, you will see a circular cobblestone marker commemorating the Boston Massacre, the 1770 incident in which British soldiers shot and killed five protesting Bostonians, including Crispus Attucks, likely a freedom seeker of mixed African and Native ancestry.
On the morning of June 2, 1854, federal troops marched Anthony Burns over this spot as they made their way to the waterfront where a ship awaited to bring Burns back to slavery. While hundreds of federal soldiers guarded and escorted Burns, an estimated 50,000 people lined State Street in protest.
The sad irony of federal marshals marching Anthony Burns back to slavery over this very spot where Attucks fell was not lost on the abolitionists in the crowd, who called it the "death of liberty."  
Nine months following Burns' return to slavery, Bostonians, under the leadership of Reverend Leonard Grimes, raised money and secured Anthony Burns’ freedom. He later attended Oberlin College and became a minister.

Long Wharf, the port, and the surrounding harbor strongly tie to the history of slavery in Boston, from the years of the slave trade to those of the Underground Railroad and emancipation.
During the colonial period, local merchants created vast amounts of wealth by trafficking enslaved individuals and trading goods consumed and produced by enslaved labor. Long Wharf served as one of the primary entry points for enslaved individuals into the colony. During the Underground Railroad years, Boston’s wharves became both an entry and departure point for freedom seekers. While those such as Thomas Sims and Anthony Burns were forcibly transported back into slavery through the Harbor, the wharves also welcomed freedom seekers, such as Elizabeth Blakeley, as they took their first steps into a free state.
Freedom seekers and their supporters created a legacy of resilience, bravery, and sacrifice that continues to inspire us today and encourages us to consider how we too can ensure a more just and freer world.

data.title: The Underground Railroad in Boston

data.description: This self-guided tour details key points of the Union army's assault at Cheatham Hill during the Battle of Kennesaw Mountain.

images.altText: Painting showing the chaotic battle scene at the 'Dead Angle' during the battle of Kennesaw Mountain
images.caption: Hell broke loose in Georgia sure enough
images.title: Assault on Cheatham Hill

stops.significance: Headquarters of Maj. General George H. Thomas during the battle of Kennesaw Mountain.
Trenches like the one before you provided some final protection for some of the Union soldiers who would later engage on a fateful assault on the Confederate defenses.

Col. Dan McCook would rally his men from this spot prior to the assault. After a famous speech, and then leading from the front, McCook's brigade would go up the center and attack the sailent known as 'The Dead Angle'.
This is where the bulk of the Union attack was concentrated. McCook's brigade would charge up the center of the field, Mitchell would take the left, Harker the far left.
At or very near this site, Col. Dan McCook would mount the Confederate earthworks and receive a mortal wound while stirring his men on.
Sgt. C.H. Coffey was killed and temporarily buried in this spot during the battle of Kennesaw Mountain.
This is the site of the far left Union assault on the Confederate line, and approximately where Gen. Charles Harker was mortally wounded. Harker would die later that afternoon from his wounds.
Monument dedicated to the Union soldiers that fell in this location during the Battle of Kennesaw Mountain.
This is the grave of an unknown soldier found well after the war and given full Union and Confederate honors.
stops.assetName: The Grave of the Unknown Soldier

data.title: The Union Assault at Cheatham Hill

data.description: The Village Trail is 1.3 miles round trip. The gravel trail is flat and wheelchair accessible. There are benches along the way. Leashed dogs are allowed. You will need water and bug spray. This tour starts in front of the earthlodge at the garden interpretive sign on the left.

data.description: Thurmond was the heart of the New River Gorge, carrying shipments of coal from surrounding coal fields to industrial areas nationwide. Visit the historic downtown (open year round) and depot (open seasonally) to learn more about what life was like in and around this railroad town. Service is spotty in Thurmond, we recommend downloading park content for offline use to ensure access to this tour. *NOTE* The railroad tracks are ACTIVE! Please only cross the railroad tracks at the crossing, near the Depot.

images.altText: A yellow long building next to railroad tracks with a blue and yellow train on them
images.caption: A train approaches the Thurmond Depot
images.title: Thurmond, West Virginia

park.name: New River Gorge

data.description: Wayside exhibits highlighting Yosemite's geology, ecosystems, natural and cultural history, etc., found along Tioga Road, from near Crane Flat to Tioga Pass, are grouped together in this tour. Each wayside exhibit is audio described. A few wayside exhibits are not on accessible paths.

data.description: Visit Tomales Point to learn about the history of a dairy ranch that was established in the 1850s, to view tule elk, to relax at an isolated and beautiful beach, and/or to take a hike through the Phillip Burton Wilderness to the northern end of Point Reyes National Seashore.

images.title: Tomales Point. June 7, 2020.

data.description: When you are the President of the United States, there is no vacation from the immeasurable responsibility of the office. But the trail you are about to climb leads to a place that, for Franklin Delano Roosevelt, came as close to a retreat as possible.

images.altText: FDR in an automobile surrounded by the architect and others at Top Cottage.
images.caption: FDR at Top Cottage just before completion of construction in 1939.
images.title: FDR at Top Cottage

data.title: Top Cottage Trail

data.description: The name Brown has been a symbol with different meanings throughout Topeka's history. To some, it meant assistance on their path to freedom For others it represents the legal brawl that led to racial integration. This tour will visit several historic sites, each with a slice of Topeka's civil rights story from abolitionist John Brown to Rev. Oliver Brown, lead plaintiff of the 1954 landmark Brown v. Board decision.

images.altText: Blurred stylized graphic of topeka statehouse. One half in color, one half black and white.
images.caption: Topeka has a storied past in regards to civil rights.
images.credit: NPS Photo Illustration by Preston Webb
images.title: Topeka's Civil Rights History

data.description: Since time immemorial, people have called this place home. While some cultural groups left little evidence of their presence, others made lasting marks on the landscape. Petroglyphs (etchings) and pictographs (paintings) created on the rocks centuries ago offer an intriguing connection to the people and cultures of the past. This self-guided tour will traverse the landscape once traveled by the ancestral indigenous people of the region well over 1,000 years ago.

images.altText: A dark orange, brown rock with human shaped carvings left by ancestral Native American peoples.
images.caption: The McKee Springs Petroglyphs are an excellent example of the Classic Vernal style.
images.title: McKee Springs Petroglyphs

stops.significance:
Since time immemorial, people have called this place home. While some cultural groups left little evidence of their presence, others made lasting marks on the landscape. Petroglyphs (etchings) and pictographs (paintings) created on the rocks centuries ago offer an intriguing connection to the people and cultures of the past. 

The Quarry Visitor Center on the Utah side of the monument makes an excellent staging point for any tour. Check with a ranger at the front desk for a park map, road and weather conditions. This self-guided tour will traverse the landscape once traveled by the ancestral indigenous people of the region well over 1,000 years ago.

A very short and mostly level trail leads to a small alcove where both types of rock art are located. Based on archaeological evidence, this shelter was used, but not extensively occupied, between 700 and 1,300 years ago by the ancestral indigenous people of the region. They may have reserved this shelter for special purposes and activities. 
Swelter Shelter has been occupied by older cultures dating to as far back as 9000 years ago. The rock art alcove faces directly south, catching the sun from the early morning until late afternoon. The sandstone "shelter" traps and reflects heat, producing the sweltering conditions that inspired its name by archaeologists in 1965.

Just off pullout #13 along the road, you will find the first of the Cub Creek Petroglyph panels. Walk up a short flight of stairs leads up to a variety of petroglyphs including human figures, called anthropomorphs, shape patterns called geomorphs as well as other designs. The intricacy of the artwork left by these ancestral people over a period of several hundred years, shows a people who were not struggling for survival but thriving.

A quarter mile hike up from Cub Creek Road leads to a variety of panels along a sandstone cliff. Over 1,000 years ago, the ancestral indigenous people of the region came here to carve and create elaborate designs including the 5-foot long lizard petroglyphs. 

As you walk along the trail, many different designs will stand out on the rock face. Some designs appear more intricate than others which reflect the individual skills and styles of the artists. Higher panels would have been more accessible in years past prior to the cliff eroding away, or scaffolding would have been constructed to reach higher places.

Mckee Springs, near Rainbow Park displays some of the finest large human-like designs in Dinosaur, and many other figures. Some petroglyphs show traces of pigment, possibly indicating that many designs originally included painted areas. A large human figure holding a shield displays many diagnostic features of the classic Vernal style of rock art found in the region.

Why did these ancestral native peoples choose to create these specific designs and figures? We can speak with modern Native American groups - including the Ute and other descendants - about what they might mean. People rarely "disappear." Culture is a living part of how we relate to each other and our environment. As people adapt to changes in their environment, their culture changes. 700 years ago, these ancestral peoples adapted and became something new.

data.title: Tour of the Indigenous Past: Petroglyphs and Pictographs

data.description: The Tour of the Tilted Rocks is a 10-mile (20 mile round-trip) scenic auto tour that takes visitors along the Cub Creek Road. During the tour, multiple points of interest will be easily accessible from the roadside including petroglyphs sites, scenic overlooks and vistas, trailheads, and the Josie Morris Homestead Cabin.

images.altText: Orange colored sandstone bluffs rising above desert shrubs under a partly cloudy blue sky.
images.caption: Cub Creek Road winds along for 10 miles through beautiful desert scenery.
images.title: Cub Creek Road Scenery

stops.significance:
While Dinosaur National Monument is known for its impressive display of dinosaur bones, there is much more to discover here. The monument was originally established in 1915 to preserve the quarry and the surrounding 80 acres. Many visitors to the area found beauty in the nearby river canyons and wanted to see them preserved. In 1938, President Franklin D. Roosevelt increased the monument’s size by over 210,000 acres. This protected not only the deep, colorful canyons of the Green and Yampa Rivers, but also the many cultural features left by the native peoples and settlers of the area. The Green and Yampa rivers are largely responsible for the size and shape of the monument. Besides creating dramatic scenery, the 
 rivers support a greater variety of life than could otherwise exist in this high desert. Allow at least an hour for this 24-mile round-trip drive. Watch for wildlife on the road and stop only in parking areas or where there is ample space on the shoulder.

After you pull off on the shoulder, look for a sheltered area at the base of the rocky cliff. It is one of the monument’s oldest known sites of human occupation. Stone tools found at ‘Swelter Shelter’ are up to 10,000 years old. These artifacts belong to a time-period known as the Desert Archaic era. The pictographs (paintings) and petroglyphs (etchings) on the shelter’s walls are not quite as old. They were made about 1,000 years ago by people of the archeologically defined Fremont Culture, whose rock imagery appears on many cliffs and canyon walls, including sites further along this road. Petroglyphs and pictographs are fragile, irreplaceable records of the past that many still hold sacred. Touching them can leave skin oils behind and tracings or rubbings can ruin the designs. Federal law protects all artifacts, including these sites. Do your part to respect and protect the past and report any vandalism immediately.

The Sound of Silence hiking trail begins at this pullout, promising adventure, and plenty of inspiration. This is a moderate-to-difficult, three-mile route that will take you into an arid landscape of towering stone walls, dark red paths, and quiet solitude. This hike is best enjoyed in the morning or early evening – after the sun has started to set – when temperatures are cooler. Remember, during the Summer it is hottest around 5pm. Do not start this hike without good hiking boots. This trail is easy at first but gets more difficult the further you walk. Take at least a half-gallon, or two liters, of water per person, a hat, and sunblock on this hike.

Look out over this vast landscape. What do you notice most prominently in this location? It is difficult to miss the rocky ridges jutting out from amongst the Utah Juniper trees that cover this expanse. Juniper trees, and the habitat they create, make up a significant portion of the monument’s scenery. The Utah Juniper is a hardy tree that thrives in environments where other plants would find it difficult to take root. Able to withstand intense heat, fierce cold, overbearing sunlight, extreme lack of water, and blasting winds, the juniper provides an important source of food and shelter for desert dwellers. Small birds, including the downy woodpecker, will often nest in the juniper. If you look closely, you might see a jackrabbit or desert cottontail finding shade and refuge beneath the low, narrow canopy.
stops.assetName: Tour of the Tilted Rocks Stop #3

stops.significance:
The tilt and colors of the rocks are the most noticeable features of the landscape. Each rock layer was formed in a certain environment at a specific time. Geologists call those discrete layers formations. The formation on either side of the road here formed in streams and rivers during the late Triassic Period, resulting in a coarse-grained, gritty yellow and tan sandstone. Utah is famous for red rocks which contain oxidized iron minerals that were exposed to air. Often nearby 
there are green rocks that are reduced iron minerals which altered in water. The yellow colors in the sandstone right here are also result from a mixture of materials, including iron oxides, sulfides, and silicates, called limonite.
stops.assetName: Tour of the Tilted Rocks Stop #4

stops.significance:
The view before you is dynamic, constantly changing. Down below, the Green River carves its way out of Split Mountain. Throughout the year its flow will fluctuate due to a variety of factors from snowmelt, precipitation runoff, and dam releases from the Flaming Gorge Reservoir. The sediment that flows downstream is crucial for life in and along the river and also influences the water’s variable colors.
During the springtime, the Green River surges with snowmelt raising the water levels as well as the sediment load being carried. As the waters pass along the banks they deposit silt, sand, and other debris which creates habitat for flora and fauna. During flooding events, fish such as the endangered Razorback Sucker will navigate through the newly formed off-channels and wetlands where the larvae can grow in sheltered nursery habitat before returning to the main channel. Along the banks of the river, sediment and groundwater create riparian areas.

This overlook provides a panoramic view of the Cub Creek Valley, which lies between Split Mountain on the left and Blue Mountain on the right. The influence of water in this dry environment is easy to see. The native cottonwood trees shading the campground below depend on the Green River, as do the irrigated crops in the field outside the monument across the river. Just a short distance away from the river’s life-giving waters, sparse grasses, shrubs such as sagebrush and greasewood, and a few small juniper trees reveal the true desert nature of this land. At an elevation of 5,000 feet, rain and snow provide less than 10 inches of water a year. Plants must conserve water or perish. Few cactus species can tolerate subzero winter temperatures but prickly pear cacti are found here, though they are small and scarce.

Ahead and to the right are hills banded with shades of gray, red, purple, and brown. The distinctively colorful layers help to identify the Morrison Formation, a group of rock layers that occur throughout this region. Paleontologists find this rock attractive for more than its colors; a few of its outcrops contain 150 million year old dinosaur fossils like those found at the Dinosaur Quarry. The formation originated as muds and sands laid down by a network of ancient rivers whose water nourished an abundance of plants, dinosaurs, and other animals. It is thought that during times of drought the river would dry up and there would be massive die-offs. Dinosaur carcasses collected in the river bed. When the rains returned, the river flowed again and transported bones and carcasses then buried them in sand and mud where they were preserved.
stops.assetName: Tour of the Tilted Rocks Stop #7

stops.significance: A short side road leads to a bend in the Green River called Placer Point. The name refers to an effort in the 1930s to dredge and sluice gold from the river bottom. The gold particles were too fine to extract profitably and the operation eventually folded. Although gold did not play a leading role in this area’s history, the Green River did. Today you can observe the river through the senses as it wanders through the monument. As you approach the river itself, you may hear the babble of water flowing across the rocky bottom of the riverbed. The rush of water here is a far echo of the roaring rapids that can be found further upstream through the canyons. Other sounds may also heard across the landscape. Across the river high on the cliff tops, Perigrine Falcons make their nests. Falcons will make a call sounding like “kak-kak-kak-kak-kak,” which at full volume can be as loud as a motorcycle.

The road to the right will take you outside of Dinosaur National Monument, crossing private property. You will pass through two gates. The road will lead you to a fenced petroglyph site protected by the Bureau of Land Management. This site is of a similar time and style to petroglyphs found throughout the monument. When driving to and from the petroglyph site, remember to leave all gates as you found them. If you open a gate, close it behind you.
stops.assetName: Tour of the Tilted Rocks Stop #9

stops.significance: From long-time settlers to brief passers-by, many of us like to name what we see around us. The rock on the left has gone by many names depending on who was looking at it and how far they let their imagination go. ‘Turtle Rock’ is the name most often suggested for this rock. The many holes result from more rapid weathering of weaker parts of the rock. This is Entrada Sandstone, the same type of rock which forms arches in Arches National Park.

The tour continues to the left here. The Blue Mountain road on the right leaves the monument. It is steep, rough, and suitable only for 4-wheel drive vehicles with off-road tires. It climbs about 3000 feet to the top of Blue Mountain. This mountain offers dramatic views of the area. The summit also harbors a relict woodland called Point of the Pines. Some mountaintops in this area contain small groves of conifers like ponderosa pine only on the very top. During the last ice age these trees were much more widespread in the region. With a warmer and drier climate during the last 10,000 years, these trees are now restricted to mountaintops where they find just enough moisture to survive. Follow the left fork across Cub Creek, a spring-fed stream that flows all year. Its channel may seem deep for such a small volume of water, but the creek is not always small.

Across the creek is Elephant Toes Butte, eroded from Nugget Sandstone. Though the sandstone dates back to the time of the dinosaurs, it records a far different environment from that of the dinosaur quarry. The parallel layers in Elephant Toes Butte shows that it originated as tall sand dunes in a desert 200 million years ago. The dunes were later compressed into sandstone.

Please remember not to touch rock imagery. For your own safety, watch your step if you approach for a closer look. Please do not proceed beyond the End Of Trail sign. Stop 14 has a trail that will allow you to access many more petroglyphs along the upper portion of the cliff face. Like those at Swelter Shelter, these petroglyphs are about 1,000 years in age. Using sharp tools, the dark natural stain on the rock surface, called desert varnish, was pecked away to reveal the light colored sandstone beneath. Some of the designs, such as bighorn sheep and other animals, are easily recognizable, but their meaning is not. The images may have been related to hunting, clan identification, territorial marking, ceremonial or religious purposes, maps or way finding, record keeping, or purely for leisure and artistic expression. While we may not know their exact intent, we can speak with modern Native Americans – such as the Ute and other groups with cultural ties to this area – for further insight and understanding.

On the rock ledge high above the road is a large concentration of petroglyphs. You can look for petroglyphs from the parking lot if you have binoculars, or hike the short, steep trail to see them up close. If you have a good eye, you may see the giant lizard from the road without binoculars. Though we do not know what the petroglyphs mean, one thing that they tell us is that their makers were living a comfortable lifestyle here in the high desert. They could take the time needed to create artwork that has endured. Petroglyphs such as the large lizard likely took months to complete. The people who made this art certainly must have felt it was worth their time and effort.

Josephine Bassett Morris is a local legend. Independent in both action and thought, she lived life on her own terms. It is here that she chose to settle in 1914. Josie built several cabins on her homestead, the last being the one you see today, constructed in 1935. Josie provided for herself. She raised and butchered cattle, pigs, chickens, and geese. She canned the harvest from her large vegetable garden. Josie’s source of heat came from wood burning in the fireplace. Her water came from the spring. There was no electricity; her light came from an oil lamp. Josie lived a 19th century lifestyle well into the 20th century. For Josie Bassett Morris, the benefits of the isolation she experienced living here were solitude and beauty.
Josie was accused (though not convicted) of cattle rustling twice and was an alleged associate of the outlaw Butch Cassidy. Married five times, she ultimately chose a single life. In 1964, while feeding her horse, it nudged her and she slipped on some ice. She suffered a broken hip.

Split Mountain forms a backdrop to Josie’s cabin. Made of Weber Sandstone, it is another ancient desert sand dune formation that is even older than the dinosaurs. Two of its features provided
resources for Josie. Erosion created deep narrow canyons with nearly vertical walls. They are called box canyons. Josie used two of these as corrals. She simply fenced the narrow open ends and let the canyon walls confine her livestock. Josie also needed water for her livestock. The porous Weber sandstone absorbs rain and snowmelt. The water eventually emerges as springs in the canyons. While a blessing, the springs from Box and Hog canyons also gave Josie some headaches because of water use laws. The law stated that any spring that fed a larger stream, like Cub Creek, which
another person had rights to, allowed that user to take all the water. Another local rancher owned the rights to Cub Creek. This prevented Josie from using the spring water on her own land. What did Josie do?

data.title: Tour of the Tilted Rocks: Cub Creek Road

data.description: Follow the route of the April 19, 1775 Battle Road where the British soldiers were continuously attacked by Colonial minute men and militia. See battle sites, grave sties and "witness houses" in Concord, Lincoln and Lexington. It is 5.5 miles from end to end. We recommend you place a vehicle at each end or consider only doing part of this tour. You can also drive to different locations and walk a short distance to the trail or sites.

images.altText: Two story wooden colonial house on a grassy hill.
images.caption: Explore the Battle Road Trail!
images.title: Captain William Smith House

stops.significance: Meriam's Corner is where colonial militiamen and minute men first attacked the British column during their return march to Boston on April 19, 1775.
The Nathan Meriam House, built in 1705, is located at the junction of the Lexington and Bedford Roads. A witness to history, the fighting on the Battle Road erupted in the front yard of the house.

This gravestone marks the burial of British soldiers killed at Meriam's corner by Colonial militia on April 19, 1775. These British soldiers were the first to fall during an eight hour running battle from Concord to Boston that afternoon.

Samuel Brooks (1739-1811) was living with his widowed mother on land first settled in 1692 by his grandfather Daniel, on the Bay Road in Concord. His house was located on the border of the town of Lincoln in an area that had been owned by members of his family since the mid-17th century. Samuel Brooks was a veteran of the battle on April 19, 1775 the British Army passed by here on their way to Concord and later back again during their fighting retreat to Boston.

The Job Brooks House sits on the Bay Road. On April 19, 1775 the British regulars marched past here on their way to Concord, then back again during their fighting retreat to Boston. An intense skirmish took place just yards from this house at Elm Brook Hill.

Elm Brook Hill is where militiamen from Woburn, Reading and other towns set up a violent attack against the embattled British column, and where the British column suffered the heaviest concentration of casualties between Concord and Arlington.

At this sharp curve in the Bay Road there is a stone grave marker for British soldiers killed on April 19, 1775. In the years following the famed battle, local historians dubbed this segment of road, "The Bloody Angle." Today, more closely following historical sources, it is known as Elm Brook Hill. There may have been as many as eight British soldiers killed in this area. This grave marker at the northern curve memorializes those British soldiers buried along the roadside after the fight.

Hartwell Tavern was a well-known stop for travelers on the Bay Road in Lincoln. On April 19, 1775 the British column passed by here on their way to Concord and again during their fighting retreat to Boston in the afternoon. Three of the Hartwell sons, including John and Isaac who lived here, fought as minute men.

This was the home of Samuel Hartwell, his wife Mary, and their three small children. Samuel Hartwell served as a sergeant in the Lincoln Minute Men and participated in the fighting on April 19, 1775. Decades later Mary Hartwell provided a vivid account of her experiences that day.  The house burned down in 1968 leaving only the chimney and cellar.

The Captain William Smith House sits on the Bay Road in Lincoln. It was home to William, wife Catherine, three young children and an enslaved man named Cato. On April 19, 1775 the British column passed by here on their way to Concord and again during their fighting retreat to Boston in the afternoon. A wounded British soldier was left behind and treated at the house. He died and is buried near by.

stops.assetName: Grave of British soldier near Folly Pond

stops.significance: This monument marks the location where Paul Revere was captured by a patrol of British officers while spreading the alarm through the countryside, thus ending his famous "midnight ride."
British soldiers killed on April 19, 1775 are buried atop this small knoll near the Josiah Nelson farm ruins. The knoll is known locally as "The Soldiers' Graves."
stops.assetName: The Soldiers' Grave Near The Josiah Nelson Farm.

stops.significance: Minute Man Visitor Center features historical exhibits, a multimedia theater presentation about the events of April 19, 1775, restrooms, visitor information and a park store.

Parker's Revenge is the name given to the second engagement between the British regulars and the Lexington militia company under Captain John Parker. Despite the significance of the battle the location was a mystery. Between 2012 and 2016 Minute Man NHP, in partnership with the Friends of Minute Man National Park, NPS Northeast Region Archaeology Division, and community partners and volunteers, conducted a historical and archaeological investigation to find it.

The Jacob Whittemore House is the only April 19th witness house in the park that is in the town of Lexington. Paul Revere passed by here on his midnight ride. Later the British column passed by here on their way to Concord, and back again in the afternoon during their fighting retreat back to Boston.

The Bluff is a sharp outcrop of rocks created by dramatic geological forces millions of years ago. On April 19, 1775 British soldiers fought a short rearguard action from this high, wooded overlook during their retreat to Boston. Today the bluff is a prominent geological and historical feature in Minute Man National Historical Park.

At a sharp outcropping of rocky hillside known as “The Bluff,” British regulars fought a rearguard action during their retreat to Boston on April 19, 1775. This gravestone marks the burial of two British soldiers killed in action near this place.
stops.assetName: Grave of British Soldiers at The Bluff

stops.significance: Home to the Fiske family since 1647, this hill saw intense fighting during the opening battle of the American Revolution. On April 19, 1775 fighting between Colonial Militia and British Regulars spilled over the crest of Fiske Hill including through the Fiske farm. When the fighting ended the dead and dying lay strew across the landscape and local resident Rebecca Fiske remember coming home to find a dead British Soldier near her doorstep and three wounded men laying within her home. Today Fiske Hill remains a popular hiking location within Minute Man NHP

On April 19, 1775 fighting between Colonial Militia and British Regulars spilled over the crest of Fiske Hill. When the fighting ended the dead and dying lay strew across the landscape. Local resident Rebecca Fiske remember coming home to find a dead British Soldier near her doorstep and three wounded men laying within her home. The next day, Rebecca's husband carried two deceased British soldiers to a meadow a short distance from their house for burial.

Home to the Fiske family since 1647, this hill saw intense fighting during the opening battle of the American Revolution. On April 19, 1775 fighting between Colonial Militia and British Regulars spilled over the crest of Fiske Hill including through the Fiske farm. When the fighting ended the dead and dying lay strew across the landscape and local resident Rebecca Fiske remember coming home to find a dead British Soldier near her doorstep and three wounded men laying within her home. Today Fiske Hill remains a popular hiking location within Minute Man NHP

data.description: See all the points of interest at the Dwight D. Eisenhower Memorial. Enter the memorial at the nearest intersection on 6th and Independence Ave SW to begin the tour.

images.altText: An open air park with tress, grass, statues, columns and buildings.
images.caption: Dwight D. Eisenhower Memorial
images.title: Dwight D. Eisenhower Memorial

stops.significance: On a pedestal at the northwest plaza entrance, a life-size sculpture of Eisenhower as a young man depicts the trajectory of his life as the quintessential American story. Inscribed in stone nearby is an excerpt from Eisenhower's Abilene Homecoming Speech on June 22, 1945.
stops.assetName: Dwight D. Eisenhower Memorial: The Young Man

stops.significance: Dwight Eisenhower returned to Abilene on June 22, 1945 to a parade welcoming him home and honoring his leadership in Europe during World War II. After watching the celebration, his grateful acceptance of the recognition began with the above quote. He went on to say that this parade was not just for him; he was only a "symbol" of the soldiers, sailors and airmen who helped bring Allied victory.
stops.assetName: Dwight D. Eisenhower Memorial: Homecoming Speech

stops.significance:
On the right side of the memorial core, Eisenhower as the Supreme Commander of the Allied Expeditionary Force during World War II is commemorated by a bronze heroic-sized statue with sculptures of his soldiers inspired by the famous photograph with the 101st Airborne Division before their jump into France. Behind the sculptures is a bas relief depicting the Normandy landings on D-Day, June 6, 1944.

On the back side of the stone you will see an inscription of Eisenhower's Guildhall acceptance speech given after receiving the “Freedom of the City” at London’s Guildhall, a symbolic act making him a citizen of the city.
stops.assetName: Dwight D. Eisenhower Memorial: Honoring the General

stops.significance:
On the left side of the memorial core, the bronze heroic-sized statue of Eisenhower as 34th President of the United States places him at the center of the White House Oval Office flanked by sculptures of civilian and military advisors, symbolizing the balance Eisenhower struck between conflicting demands of national security and peaceful progress. The bas-relief global background depicts a map of the world symbolizing Eisenhower's role as a world statesman and preeminent internationalist pursuing universal peace.

On the back side of the stone you will see an inscription of President Eisenhower's First Inaugural and Farewell Address to the country.
stops.assetName: Dwight D. Eisenhower Memorial: Honoring the President

stops.significance: Under the design direction of architect Frank Gehry, artist Tomas Osinski has created a stainless-steel tapestry for the Dwight D. Eisenhower Memorial. The tapestry depicts the Pointe du Hoc promontory of France’s Normandy coastline during peacetime and serves as a symbol of the peace Eisenhower sought and won as Supreme Allied Commander during World War II and then maintained and nurtured as 34th president. Although the artistic feature draws inspiration from historic tapestries, the process and materials implemented in the Eisenhower Memorial introduce a new innovative perspective on the conventional practice of tapestry weaving.

data.title: Tour the Dwight D. Eisenhower Memorial

data.description: Visitors walking the grounds can gain additional perspectives with two cell phone tours. Stops #1 - #10 provide a general overview of the 8 acre property with references to the historic 1880 farm that once occupied nearly 160 acres; stops #11-#20 focus on the 1880 presidential campaign that was conducted from the front porch of the Garfield Home. Wayfinding signs with the phone number and QR code are located around the site. A map with stops is also available inside the Visitor Center and brochure box.

park.fullName: James A Garfield National Historic Site
park.name: James A Garfield

data.title: Tour the grounds with 2 cell phone apps.

data.description: This trail reveals a story of struggle and survival for some of rarest plants and animals of Hawaiʻi. Plant picking is prohibited in this Special Ecological Area (SEA). Dogs, horses, and bicycles are prohibited on this trail.

images.altText: Old growth mesic forest with dirt trail.
images.caption: Kīpukapuaulu is a hot spot of biological diversity and a fertile oasis of flourishing plants.
images.title: Kīpukapuaulu

data.title: Trail Guide: Kīpukapuaulu

data.description: Venture through a landscape formed in a five-year eruption that re-created this land. This trail tells the story of one of the longest known rift zone eruptions of Kīlauea. The well-marked trail crosses massive lava fields, skirts gaping fissures, and takes you to spectacular features formed by rapidly cooling lava flows.

images.altText: Barren volcano sits in a distance. Red and green fern grows in one of its cracks.
images.caption: The powerful forces that created this landscape will reshape it in the future.
images.title: Maunaulu Eruption Guide

stops.assetName: Other Lava Shields Along the East Rift Zone

data.title: Trail Guide: Maunaulu

data.description: Walk in the footsteps of the kūpuna (elders) to Puʻuloa (hill of long life). It is a sacred and awe-inspiring gallery of kiʻi pōhaku (images carved in stone). These simple etchings document the life and culture of the native Hawaiian people. The petroglyphs are very fragile. Stay on the boardwalk. Walking on the lava surface will fragment the delicate petroglyphs.

images.altText: A volcanic dome in a distance surrounded by lava rock.
images.caption: Learn more about the meaning and history of Puʻuloa.
images.title: Puʻuloa Petroglyphs Title

stops.significance: Storied place of Hawaiʻi.

data.title: Trail Guide: Puʻuloa Petroglyphs

data.description: The Trail of the Shadows is an easy, 0.7 mile-loop trail that weaves around the Longmire Meadow. Created by volcanic mineral springs, this unique low elevation meadow is home to a rich ecosystem of plants and animals and has a long history of human use. This tour follows a set of exhibit panels located along the trail travelling counterclockwise from the main trailhead, which is located across the street from the National Park Inn in Longmire.

images.altText: A glaciated mountain peak above a forested ridge with steep cliffs.

images.title: Longmire Meadow Views
